HEADLINE: Whitman Backs Clinton Rules Designed to Cut Diesel Pollution 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
The Bush administration has decided to let stand regulations imposed by President Bill Clinton that are intended to reduce substantially the pollution caused by diesel fuel and engines, officials said today.
 In a victory for environmentalists, Christie Whitman, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said she would support the regulations, which were drafted by Clinton officials in a last-minute flurry of new rules and then put on hold when President Bush took office in January. 
 Mrs. Whitman said the new standards would eventually cut pollution from heavy-duty trucks and buses by 95 percent and reduce the sulfur content of highway diesel fuel by 97 percent. The move, she said, would prevent an estimated 8,300 premature deaths and tens of thousands of cases of bronchitis each year. 
"The Bush administration determined that this action not be delayed in order to protect public health and the environment," Mrs. Whitman said. "I look forward to working with state and local governments to meet their air quality goals as well as with citizens and businesses to ensure that diesel trucks and buses remain a viable and important part of the nation's economy."
Under the new regulations, diesel producers will be required to virtually eliminate sulfur from the fuel. Sulfur produces soot and clogs up a vehicle's catalytic converter, the device that removes other pollutants. With the removal of sulfur, manufacturers of diesel engines will be required to incorporate the sophisticated pollution-control devices that are standard equipment in cars.
The changes will be phased in. About 80 percent of all diesel fuel must be virtually sulfur-free by 2006, the rest by 2010. Engine manufacturers will have until 2010 to complete their modifications.
Environmentalists and public health advocates praised Mrs. Whitman's decision. 
Carl Pope, the executive director of the Sierra Club, said the move would significantly ease respiratory problems for children and adults.
"Because of this decision, children with asthma will be able to spend more time outdoors," Mr. Pope said in a statement. "The elderly and people with respiratory problems will be able to breathe easier."
Frank O'Donnell, the executive director of the nonprofit Clean Air Trust, said the rules affecting everything from delivery vans to 18-wheel tractor-trailers would result in the equivalent of removing 13 million trucks from the road.
But diesel producers, truckers and other industries that depend on that fuel voiced concerns that the regulations would require expensive capital improvements and possibly force small refiners out of business.
"Diesel is the lifeblood of commerce in this nation," said Jay McKeeman, the executive vice president of the California Independent Oil Marketers Association. 
Mr. McKeeman warned that the increased costs would be felt throughout the economy.
"When you start tinkering with diesel and its costs," Mr. McKeeman said, "you are going to have an automatic ripple effect in all segments of the economy. The use of diesel is pervasive."
Mrs. Whitman said the phase-in period gave companies sufficient time to upgrade their equipment. The plan will have special provisions offering greater flexibility for small manufacturers, officials said.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Sees Bumpier Road For Economy 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
Two weeks after suggesting that the economic downturn was likely to be relatively brief, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave Congress a somewhat more pessimistic assessment today, saying the slowdown "has yet to run its full course."
 He left little doubt that further interest rate reductions were coming to follow up on the two half-point cuts made by the Fed in January. But Mr. Greenspan dashed the hopes of investors, who have increasingly looked to the Fed to rescue the stock market from its swoon, that he would signal a rate cut before the Fed's next scheduled meeting on March 20. 
 The result was a broad sell-off again on Wall Street. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 141.60 points, to close at 10,495.28. The Nasdaq composite index fell 55.99 points, finishing the day at 2,151.83.
"Our take on his appearance was that the Fed is on track to reduce rates, but won't act until March 20 unless something unforeseen happens before then," said David Orr, chief economist at First Union Capital Markets.
Mr. Greenspan's appearance before the House Financial Services Committee came just after the Commerce Department reported that economic growth the last three months of 2000 fell to 1.1 percent, its slowest annual pace in more than five years.
Mr. Greenspan's testimony largely tracked what he said in an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee on Feb. 13. He reiterated that in his view the long-term outlook remained bright and that the business cycle appeared to have accelerated in recent years, both on the way down and on the way back up.
The main reason, he said, is that businesses have invested heavily in technology that allows them to identify quickly and respond to what is happening in the marketplace -- and to improve their productivity, or output per hour.
But he altered his presentation in a few instances, striking a somewhat less optimistic tone that reflected continued deterioration of consumer confidence in recent weeks as well as other new data suggesting that the economy may not have bottomed out yet.
The economy, he said, "appears to be on a track well below the productivity-enhanced rate of growth of its potential and, even after the policy actions we took in January, the risks continue skewed toward the economy's remaining on a path inconsistent with satisfactory economic performance."
When he appeared before the Senate two weeks ago, Mr. Greenspan said the nation had not slid into recession and that consumer confidence was at a level "that in the past was consistent with economic growth."
Today, he suggested that consumer confidence had declined to potentially more worrisome levels. 
Gauges of confidence "will require close scrutiny in the period ahead, especially after the steep falloff of recent months," he said. "But for now, at least, the weakness in sales of motor vehicles and homes has been modest, suggesting that consumers have retained enough confidence to make longer-term commitments."
In response to a question, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed preferred to raise or lower interest rates at its regularly scheduled meetings, although he added that it would act between meetings if necessary, as it did in early January.
And while he suggested that ups and downs on Wall Street had some effect both on the economy and on consumer confidence, he gave no indication that the Fed would cut rates just to prop up tumbling stock prices.
That was not a welcome message to investors, who had speculated the last few days that the Fed would cut rates by another half percentage point or even more this week in an effort to keep the stock market from cracking.
"Investors are forewarned," said Richard Yamarone, an economist at Argus Research. "The Federal Reserve is in the business of managing the economy, not the financial markets -- especially not the Nasdaq."
But Mr. Greenspan made a point of noting that because the economy can shift gears with greater speed nowadays, the Fed will, too. 
Pressures on the economy that first began appearing in 1999 "have engendered a retrenchment that has yet to run its full course," Mr. Greenspan said. "This retrenchment has been prompt, in part because new technologies have enabled businesses to respond more rapidly to emerging excesses. Accordingly, to foster financial conditions conducive to the economy's realizing its long-term strengths, the Federal Reserve has quickened the pace of adjustment of its policy."
Mr. Greenspan did not signal any concern about recent inflation reports suggesting that price increases were picking up even as the economy is slowing down. Some analysts have said that any lasting pickup in inflation could inhibit the Fed from cutting rates as aggressively as it would otherwise in coming months.
Economists at Credit Suisse First Boston said in a report today that Mr. Greenspan's "depiction of current conditions was more cautious than in his Senate testimony two weeks ago."
But some economists said the downturn was even more pronounced than Mr. Greenspan was letting on. Ian Shepherdson, an economist at High Frequency Economics, said Mr. Greenspan might be reluctant to make the situation worse by signaling the economy is falling apart. 
Moreover, Mr. Shepherdson said, Mr. Greenspan might want to avoid encouraging Republicans in Congress to bid up the size of President Bush's proposed $1.6 trillion tax cuts on the ground that a declining economy needs additional fiscal stimulus.

HEADLINE: Memo Feeds Concern That Exports to U.S. Help Burmese Junta 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Myanmar, which has been governed by a military junta for more than a dozen years, is rapidly increasing apparel exports to the United States despite American economic sanctions.
 A newly declassified State Department cable describes how factories in Myanmar, formerly Burma, have produced garments for leading American designers and retailers, including Kenneth Cole, Nautica, Jordache, Kmart and Wal-Mart. 
 The cable, written by the American Embassy in Myanmar's capital, Yangon, to the secretary of state voices concern that Myanmar's military leaders are benefiting financially from these shipments because most of the factories are joint ventures partly owned by the military government. 
"The Burmese garment industry is booming -- growing 45 percent in the last year," said the cable dated last July.
In 1999, the cable said, Myanmar exported $168 million worth of garments to the United States, but those shipments more than doubled last year, soaring to $403.7 million. That places Burma's apparel exports to the United States well above France's, at about the same level as Israel's exports to the United States.
Four years ago, President Bill Clinton banned new American investments in Myanmar, but the government has not banned all trade, although it has encouraged companies not to do business there. Mr. Clinton took those actions because of the military junta's repression of the democratic opposition and its leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a winner of the Nobel Peace Prize.
The cable was obtained from Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat who along with Senator Jesse Helms, a North Carolina Republican, and Senator Mitch McConnell, a Kentucky Republican, has called for the ban on apparel imports from Myanmar. "Here we have perhaps the most brutally repressive military regime in the world," Senator Harkin said. "And by importing all this apparel from there, we're putting close to half a billion dollars into their coffers every year."
Most of Myanmar's garment factories, the cable states, have been financed by Korean, Taiwanese and Hong Kong manufacturers that have turned to Myanmar because they are bumping up against quotas imposed by the United States limiting imports from their countries.
Jessica Moser, a Wal-Mart spokeswoman, said the company's American stores stopped importing apparel from Myanmar three years ago. She added that Wal-Mart stores in other countries only stopped such imports about a year ago.
Michele Jasukaitis, of Kmart, said, "We do not import directly from Burma, and we double-check our distribution centers for any indirect imports from Burma."
Kenneth Cole officials acknowledged that one of the designer's subcontractors had been importing sweaters from Burma, but the company said it terminated such imports from Myanmar as soon as it learned about them several months ago.
Nautica and Jordache officials did not return telephone calls.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE PROMOTIONAL CAMPAIGN; 
Bush Takes His Tax Proposal on Tour

BYLINE:  By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: OMAHA, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
President Bush took his proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut and hit the road today, traveling to the heartland in the hope of building enough support to propel the measure through Congress untrimmed and untrammeled.
 He also talked about the rest of his presidential to-do list: more money for education, the revamping of Medicare and Social Security, military pay raises and an effort to eliminate nearly two-thirds of the $3.4 trillion federal debt over the next decade. 
 But he presented this slate of initiatives as what remained possible and affordable even if taxes were reduced by the figure he had specified over a 10-year period. Mr. Bush said he could do and pay for it all, and he suggested that some of the people who had insisted otherwise were gluttons for big government. 
"So we've set priorities," Mr. Bush told a crowd of several hundred supporters at a convention center here, referring to the budget outline that the White House released today and that the president foreshadowed in a State of the Union-style address to Congress on Tuesday night.
"We've paid down $2 trillion of debt," Mr. Bush continued. "We've got a trillion dollars of contingency set aside over the next 10 years. And there's still money left over."
"There's still money left over," the president repeated. And that, he added, was one reason he was so adamant about a tax cut. He appealed directly to his audience -- and to any American his words reached -- to help him make it happen.
"I'm here to ask you to join me in making the case to any federal official you can find," Mr. Bush said.
Hours earlier, in Beaver, Pa., near Pittsburgh, Mr. Bush said, "I might as well be just very upfront," explaining that he was traveling the country as part of "ginning up support for this plan."
That was Mr. Bush's first stop on a two-day, five-state tour intended to promote his legislative agenda, the centerpiece of which is a tax cut that is by no means guaranteed to pass the Senate, where the Republican-Democratic split is 50-50 and two Republicans have indicated reservations about the plan. One Democrat, Zell Miller of Georgia, has said he will support Mr. Bush's plan.
Mr. Bush's awareness of the challenge he faces was reflected in his itinerary, which was taking him to states with important Democrats he needs to woo or Republicans he needs fighting hard at his side.
Here in Nebraska, Senator Ben Nelson, a freshman Democrat, has not announced his position on Mr. Bush's proposed tax cut, but he has sent a few smiles in Mr. Bush's direction.
He did so again today, riding on Air Force One with the president and appearing with him at the rally-style event here.
Mr. Nelson told reporters he had serious qualms about the country committing to a tax cut without knowing for certain that federal surpluses would be as large as projected.
But he also said that he had been heartened by Mr. Bush's comments over recent days about paying down the federal debt.
"He understands I haven't signed on yet," said Mr. Nelson, who squeaked to victory in November while Mr. Bush trounced former Vice President Al Gore in Nebraska. "I'm looking for reasons to be there."
Another Senate Democrat whose vote White House officials hope to get is Max Cleland of Georgia, a state Mr. Bush just happens to be visiting on Thursday. His trip also includes Iowa and Arkansas.
Many Democrats are pushing a smaller tax cut, saying that they would like to devote more money to debt repayment and that Mr. Bush's proposal was too generous to the most affluent people in the country, whose tax rate would drop to 33 percent from 39.6 percent.
Those concerns are shared by enough Americans that even a few Bush supporters in Omaha acknowledged misgivings about the tax plan.
"I still think it's going to be a tax cut for the wealthy," said Karen Mohvic, 38, a paramedic here.
Even so, Ms. Mohvic said, she supported it, because her own calculations showed that she would save about $2,000 a year.
Others in the convention center expressed a less qualified enthusiasm. "If I order something from a catalog and I overpay, I expect to get money back," said Bill Boyd, 46, a hospital worker. Mr. Boyd said the same thinking should apply to taxes and surpluses, meaning he expected a refund from the government.
Mr. Bush promised one, saying that low- and middle-income people, not the rich, would get the largest tax reductions in terms of percentages. And he portrayed cutting taxes as a way to control the size of government, which he said would in turn help the economy.
Mr. Bush told workers at Control Concepts, a small business in Beaver, that "a sure way to make sure this economy gets drug down is to overspend."
In talking about a $1 trillion contingency fund, Mr. Bush was painting an incomplete picture. The additional spending he has advocated above and beyond the growth of current services would take a significant bite out of that amount.
But Mr. Bush mostly told the people at his events today what they wanted to hear, even digressing during his remarks in the Midwest to reiterate his support for federal subsidies for ethanol. It was if he had traveled back in time to his presidential campaign, and he frequently used lines and phrases from the speeches he gave then.
There did not seem to be many skeptics at today's events, which were carefully assembled. Control Concepts, which makes electrical switches for industrial machines, files taxes in a manner that would enable it to see a reduction under Mr. Bush's plan.
The president's audiences showered him with applause and his mood was correspondingly buoyant, though he was also basking in the satisfaction he and aides expressed about his performance in his address to Congress.
One aide said Mr. Bush was so energized after the speech that he talked with a friend in the White House until about midnight, two hours past his usual bedtime.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE CONTEXT; 
Surplus Feast: Will Tax-Cut Appetizer Leave Room for Debt-Slice Dessert?

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
During his run for the presidency, George W. Bush declared daily that Washington's budget surpluses should be returned to the people whose taxes created them. On Tuesday night, for the first time, Mr. Bush began discussing in detail the national debt that has to be repaid by the people who are saddled with it.
 Both sound like conservative principles: tax cuts to reduce the size of government and its burden on the national economy, debt repayment to run the government the way Americans are supposed to run their households. And, in fact, the budget Mr. Bush published today is a conservative's dream: it slows the pace of spending, cuts a few of the programs championed by the previous administration and returns $1.6 trillion to taxpayers over the next decade. 
 But very little in Washington is exactly what it seems, and this is no exception. Paying down the debt and "saving Social Security first" became, in the Clinton years, Democratic ideas, which Mr. Bush is now paying homage to in an effort to win over Democrats and secure quick passage of his tax cut.
The details released today, however, suggest something a bit more subtle.
Mr. Bush has now redefined the national debt, so that it looks more manageable. And Mr. Bush's aides are arguing that it does not need to be paid off so fast -- which, conveniently, leaves them a bit more room for their own favorite programs, like a national missile defense, new spending on education and creating private Social Security accounts.
All of this raises two questions: Which party is pursuing the more conservative course? And what does it say about the ideology of George W. Bush, whose "compassionate conservatism" seemed at times an effort to dress up the philosophy of Ronald Reagan in the moderate poll-tested oratory of Bill Clinton?
In fact, the battle now breaking out in Washington may turn the traditional definition of conservatism on its head. While Republicans have long been the party of tax cuts, Mr. Clinton tried to transform the Democrats into the party of "fiscal discipline," the one that would cut the debt first and then see what was left for tax cuts.
Mr. Bush's approach appears to be exactly the reverse -- cutting taxes first and then using what is left for debt reduction -- but the current political climate prevents him from saying so.
"There is a risk, when you add up all the initiatives in Bush's speech, that it will leave us at zero -- that there will actually be no paydown of debt," said Allen Sinai, the chief economist at Primark Decision Economics.
"Bush can't say that because the overwhelming conventional wisdom is that paying down the debt is good," said Mr. Sinai, who himself believes that paying off the debt entirely is not the best way to make use of the surplus.
"So Bush sets debt paydown as a goal," Mr. Sinai added, but effectively leaves it for last.
The reason is clear. For Mr. Bush and his team, the essence of post-Clinton conservatism is shrinking taxes first, building a national missile defense and giving individuals more control over how their Social Security contributions are invested. It is what one of Mr. Bush's aides calls "the modern Reagan legacy." Paying down debt is fine -- as long as it does not get in the way of Mr. Bush's other priorities.
For the first few weeks after his inauguration, almost everything broke Mr. Bush's way in this debate. The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, rode to his rescue, endorsing a tax cut, though he would not go so far as to approve the one Mr. Bush proposed, and suggesting that debt paydown could go too far. Mr. Bush seized on the economic slowdown to create a rationale for acting fast, arguing that lower interest rates alone could not revive the American economy. 
Today the Treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill, told the Senate Finance Committee that this might be the best moment in recent American history for a tax cut. "These circumstances are really unique," Mr. O'Neill said.
"The structural tax system is going to throw off so much money," he went on, that "we have to do something with it." 
And the new director of the Office of Management and Budget, Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., seizing on projections of a budget surplus that would continue to rise despite the economic slowdown, argued today that "there is vastly more than enough room" to repay the national debt at "historic levels" while still financing government initiatives "at moderate growth rates."
Mr. Daniels is right, if everything goes the way the administration wants it to go, which rarely happens here.
He has to assume that Congress will go along with all the cuts the Bush administration has proposed in 10 agencies. But many of those cuts will face intense opposition -- from the Commerce Department's Advanced Technology Program for research and development to more than 300 agriculture programs that Congress has allocated for farmers. Members of Congress of both parties cannot bear to see their constituents cut out of an expanding pie.
Then, of course, the surpluses have to materialize. And finally, Mr. Bush has to find a way to pay for missile defenses and military reform and those new private Social Security accounts. "Each of those is hundreds of billions of dollars," said Robert L. Bixby, executive director of the Concord Coalition, a bipartisan group that spent the 90's advocating deficit reduction and now presses for big paydowns of the debt. "While there is a lot of money around, there is not enough for all of those."

 INTERNATIONAL A3-11

Prosecutor in Belgrade Moves Against Milosevic
A Belgrade prosecutor announced the first formal investigation of Slobodan Milosevic, the former president of Yugoslavia, who is widely blamed for a decade of wars and for extensive corruption. A top official said Mr. Milosevic could be behind bars within two weeks. A8

Deadly British Rail Crash
Thirteen people were killed and 70 were injured when a high-speed passenger train hit an empty Land Rover stuck across a track in North Yorkshire and then collided with a freight train. A8

Troop Pullbacks in Congo
Rwanda and Uganda, two of the six outside nations fighting in the sprawling Congo conflict, took a step toward peace, pulling back soldiers from front-line positions in the expectation that other combatants would do the same. A3

Aid for French Farmers
France offered a $200 million emergency package to help French cattle farmers hurt by the mad-cow disease crisis. The offer won applause from farm union officials but raised questions about whether the European Union could keep a common agricultural policy in place. A7

Troubles for Argentine Leader
A Senate subcommittee in Washington found that several Argentine financial institutions had laundered money from drug dealing and bribery. It was a blow to President Fernando de la Rua, already hit with a series of political setbacks. A5

China Backs Rights Accord
Beijing has ratified an important United Nations human rights treaty, even as its own record comes under increasing international scrutiny. A11

Vatican Rebuke of Theologian
The Vatican formally rebuked a Belgian Jesuit, the Rev. Jacques Dupuis, after a two-year investigation of his writings. Obedient but unbowed, Father Dupuis said he could "in good conscience" continue his work. A9

Bush Presents Details Of Budget and Tax Cut

HEADLINE: In America; 
Voodoo Redux

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
It was a good speech, well written and well delivered. The president was relaxed, gracious, funny at times, even eloquent.
 He seemed so reasonable that it was difficult to tell from Tuesday night's speech that -- under the comforting cloak of his nice-guy conservatism -- George W. Bush plans to take the country on yet another wild and reckless economic ride. 
 Mr. Bush has gotten very good at masking the problematic aspects of his party's agenda. Ronald Reagan may have been more polished, but Mr. Bush is at least as good -- maybe better -- at hiding disturbing truths. 
The Bush tax cuts are too big and too skewed to the rich. But the president, with his smiling, aw-shucks demeanor, tells us not only that the size of the tax plan is "just right," but also that it's the best thing in the world for lower-income people. Listen:
"People with the smallest incomes will get the highest percentage of reductions. And millions of additional American families will be removed from the income tax rolls entirely." 
Now that seems pretty good. 
But Robert Greenstein, director of the respected Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, made the following very sobering comments about the Bush tax plan in testimony before the House Ways and Means Committee two weeks ago:
"Over all, 12 million families with 24 million children -- one of every three children in the United States -- would receive no tax reduction. Some 75 percent of these are working families. Some 55 percent of African-American children and 56 percent of Hispanic children live in families that would receive nothing from the proposed tax cut."
Mr. Bush did not bring that up during his speech. Nor did he mention that the wealthiest 1 percent of American families would devour nearly 40 percent of his tax cuts.
And if this tax cut passes and goes into effect, you can say good night to the entire projected non-Social-Security surplus over the next 10 years. Trust me, it will be gone.
There is, of course, a particularly bizarre deja vu quality to all of this. Ronald Reagan argued that massive tax cuts would prove an elixir for a troubled economy. Before hopping on the bandwagon as Mr. Reagan's vice president, George Herbert Walker Bush -- the current president's father -- famously derided Mr. Reagan's supply-side tax-cutting philosophy as "voodoo economics."
In his celebrated biography of Mr. Reagan, Lou Cannon wrote that James Baker, the elder Bush's close friend and longtime ally who served as Treasury secretary in the Reagan administration, would come to regret the fact that the budget deficits had "gotten away" from the administration. Mr. Baker wished, wrote Mr. Cannon, that "he had paid more attention to the consequences of the tax cuts."
Now we have another chance to pay attention to the potential consequences of a massive tax cut, a chance to look beyond George W. Bush's pretty words and affable demeanor to the debilitating reality of a government starved for cash for years to come.
The Democratic response to Mr. Bush's speech was not particularly well received. But the Congressional leaders Tom Daschle and Richard Gephardt, however ill at ease they may have seemed Tuesday night, have learned valuable lessons about the dangers of excessive tax cuts.
"In 1981," said Mr. Daschle, "Dick and I sat in the House Chamber when another new president talked to the American people about stimulating our economy. The words spoken that evening were strikingly similar to the message we heard tonight. We were promised that if we gave huge tax cuts to the wealthiest Americans, the benefits would trickle down, deficits would disappear and the economy would flourish.
"Congress supported that experiment. It was a huge mistake. As President Bush's own treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, said recently, it put America 'in a ditch that was horrendous.' "
It took 18 years of hard work and struggle, Mr. Daschle said, "to get out of that ditch."
President Bush quoted Yogi Berra on Tuesday night, but he could have pulled a better selection from the library of Yogi-isms. After all, it was Yogi who coined the wonderful phrase "It's deja vu all over again."

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE PROPOSAL; 
PRESIDENT UNVEILS $1.96 TRILLION PLAN THAT TRIMS TAXES

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
President Bush today proposed a $1.96 trillion federal budget for next year that would cut taxes, increase spending on education, medical research and the military but scale back corporate subsidies, health care grants for poor areas, agricultural research and a host of other programs.
 Mr. Bush's tax and spending framework, his first detailed statement of priorities, immediately drew attacks from Democrats. They said the president's budget would provide a tax-cut windfall to the wealthy while raiding money needed to keep Medicare healthy and requiring cuts in the Departments of Agriculture, Commerce, Energy, Interior, Justice, Labor and Transportation. 
 But Mr. Bush said his plan would prudently restrain the growth of government spending and provide the money needed to address issues he considered priorities. 
At the same time, he repeated his case that the projected federal surplus of $5.6 trillion over the next decade made his $1.6 trillion tax cut in the same period affordable, even after going a long way toward eliminating the national debt and setting aside money to create private investment accounts in Social Security.
Under his plan, Mr. Bush would begin phasing in reductions in the income tax rate and other provisions of his plan next year. But he has signaled that he would support efforts in Congress to begin phasing in the tax cut this year.
"The surplus is not the government's money," Mr. Bush said in Omaha today in the first day of a two-day trip to sell his tax cut and budget plan. "The surplus is the people's money. And I'm here to ask you to join me in making that case to any federal official you can find."
After six years in which President Bill Clinton's budgets were declared dead on arrival by the Republican majority on Capitol Hill, Republicans said Congress would take Mr. Bush's proposal seriously as it began drawing up its own spending plans.
Republican leaders acted quickly to give Mr. Bush's tax plan some political momentum, saying the House Ways and Means Committee would take up his proposal to reduce income tax rates on Thursday.
But even some Republicans acknowledged that Congress would find it difficult to cut programs, especially at a time of growing surpluses. And Democrats sought to reshape the budget by arguing that Mr. Bush's plan relied on money that was supposed to be off limits: $526 billion over the next 10 years in temporary surpluses from one division of the Medicare system. 
Most members of both parties in Congress have agreed that the Medicare surplus should be off limits for new spending or tax cuts, a restriction rejected by the administration. 
"His budget framework begins to tell the story that in order to enact his tax cut, something is going to have to give," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader in the House. "And in this case, that something is the soundness of our economic future and the immediate needs demanded by the budget."
In presenting his budget, Mr. Bush cast himself not as an ideological warrior in the mold of Newt Gingrich, who as speaker of the House in the mid-1990's led an effort to slash the size and influence of government, but as a pragmatic manager of the nation's resources.
He proposed an increase of 4 percent, or $25.7 billion, in spending on general government programs outside of Social Security and Medicare, to $660.7 billion for the fiscal year starting Oct. 1 from $635 billion in the current fiscal year. 
That increase would be slightly above what it would cost for the government to keep up with rising costs, but below the rate of increase in the past several years, including last year's increase of 8.6 percent.
And although Mr. Bush would seek to slow the growth in spending on Medicare, long a target of conservatives, he also proposed spending $156 billion over the next decade to add a program that would help retirees pay for prescription medicine.
The broad numbers obscured the ways in which increases in some areas were offset by cuts in others.
The Pentagon's budget would increase by $14.2 billion, to $310.5 billion. Education would get an additional $4.6 billion, bringing the total to $44.5 billion. The State Department's budget would increase $1.2 billion, to $23.1 billion. Despite having its overall budget cut, the Energy Department would get an additional $120 million next year for a program to help low-income homeowners insulate their houses.
But the increases in those areas and others would be largely offset by cutbacks elsewhere.
Eight of the 15 big cabinet-level departments would see their budgets decline in dollar terms, and some of the smaller agencies, like NASA, would barely keep pace with inflation. Even within some departments that would get an overall increase, some programs were slated for cutbacks or elimination.
Mr. Bush's 207-page budget document did not specify where all of the cuts would be made, but it provided some examples.
The Agriculture Department would lose $44 million for construction of research laboratories. The Commerce Department would suspend, pending a review, one of Mr. Clinton's initiatives, the Advanced Technology Program, which subsidizes research by corporations.
The Department of Health and Human Services would kill a $125 million program that sought to provide health care to the uninsured because other programs offered the same service. A drug-abuse prevention program run by the Department of Housing and Urban Development would be ended because the administration concluded that it had been ineffective.
Mr. Bush is also proposing to eliminate what budget analysts call earmarks and what most voters would call pork-barrel projects, programs proposed by members of Congress to benefit their districts or particular constituents. Mr. Bush's budget relies on eliminating $4.3 billion of them next year.
He has also targeted another $4.1 billion in one-time financing, which usually goes to emergencies like fighting forest fires but sometimes gets built in year after year.
Critics said the budget appeared to be deliberately vague about where the cuts would be made. And they said the scale of the cuts was understated because Mr. Bush did not include other initiatives that will come up in the next few years. Among them are development of a national missile defense, acquisition of a new generation of weaponry for the military and tax cuts with bipartisan support other than those included in the president's $1.6 trillion plan.
"This is a budget that conveniently omits the necessary costs of various ongoing items and the costs of administration priorities like missile defense, in part to avoid allowing policy makers and the public the tradeoffs that the tax cut entails," said Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group. "It's kind of a game of hide the ball."
In addition to setting out his spending plans, Mr. Bush's budget fleshed out his long-term proposals. 
The administration estimated that the surplus would be $5.644 trillion over the next 10 years. Of the total surplus, $2.591 trillion would come from Social Security, the administration said, and would be used only to reduce the national debt or to help create private investment accounts within the retirement system.
Mr. Bush said that he would allocate $1.62 trillion to his tax cut, $153 billion to adding prescription drug coverage to Medicare, $20 billion for general spending and $417 billion to the additional interest costs from using the surplus for purposes other than debt reduction.
That would leave $842 billion over 10 years for what Mr. Bush termed a contingency fund, which would pay for initiatives that his budget does not provide for specifically. 
But Democrats said that fund would quickly be exhausted. Once realistic estimates of other needs are taken into account, from aid to farmers to additional tax provisions to the administration's own proposals for increased military spending, the budget could slide back into deficit, Democrats said.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE REACTION; 
Republicans In the House Advance Plan For Tax Cuts

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
Acting swiftly to capitalize on President Bush's address to Congress, House Republicans put forward a $958 billion, across-the-board reduction in income tax rates today and said they would pass it through the House next week as the first stage of the tax cut.
 The introduction of the measure by Representative Bill Thomas of California, the Republican who heads the House Ways and Means Committee, opened the political battle over tax cuts that will be the defining first act of the Bush presidency. And putting maximum pressure on Democrats, Mr. Thomas sweetened Mr. Bush's proposals. 
 His bill would accelerate the president's plan to drop the lowest income tax rate to 10 percent from 15 percent and make that reduction retroactive. The rate would drop to 12 percent on the first $12,000 of taxable income for couples beginning Jan. 1 of this year. It would fall to 10 percent by 2006 when all the rates reductions will be fully phased in.
Republicans put the tax bill on a quick timetable in the House, a move that allows Mr. Bush to step up pressure on Democrats and on the Senate, where the tax cut is a harder sell. Republicans said the cost of the bill would be about $65 billion more than Mr. Bush's own proposal across 10 years. But Mr. Thomas said that there would still be "ample room" to enact the remaining features of Mr. Bush's $1.6 trillion, 10-year tax cut. And he flatly predicted passage both in committee and in the House.
"The Ways and Means Committee will present and pass tomorrow a permanent rate-reduction bill," he said. "The House of Representatives will have done its part by the first week in March. The question then is, When will the Senate respond in kind?" 
But the tax cut still faced trouble in the Senate, which is split 50-50. "We still, as of today, have to be saying we don't have the votes yet," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the budget committee. "But I hope you will say 'yet' because we're working on it." 
And at a hearing of the Senate Finance Committee, Senator John B. Breaux, a conservative Democrat from Louisiana and a crucial vote for the president, told Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill that Congress was bound to make substantial changes in the president's $1.6 trillion proposal.
"This is what Congress does," Mr. Breaux said. "There will be a time that will come that people who want to get something done are going to have to negotiate."
With Democrats calling for the tax cut to be slowed down and tied to the broader debate over budget priorities, the Republicans framed the tax cut as a stimulus to the shaky economy on a day when the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, said the slowdown had yet to run its course.
Republicans accused Democrats in unusually pointed language of seeking bad times. "There are some people who would have it politically convenient to have a recession because that means they would have a political advantage," said Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois. "We are not going to let that happen."
And Mr. Thomas said of Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, "I think the minority leader would be willing to discuss this all summer as the economy goes into the tank." 
Mr. Bush, who was stumping for his tax cut on the road, also spoke of the economy and Mr. Greenspan's warnings. "All the more reasons to accelerate the tax cut," he said. "and I think our nation needs to be wary of the economic times, and Congress needs to know that. Congress needs to work with me to accelerate a meaningful tax reduction package as quickly as possible."
The Democrats, bolstered by the release of an austere budget for 2002 that made outright cuts in 10 federal agencies in a time of surplus, said the nation could not afford a tax cut that would limit money for other needs. They accused the Republicans of trying to obscure the tradeoffs by moving fast. 
"We are spending money we don't have, and Democrats will not be a party to it," Mr. Gephardt said. He called the last years of prosperity a "golden period" and said that was why he was fighting so hard against the change in fiscal policy. "We are going to fight this thing because it has enormous consequences for the American people," he said.
Sounding the same themes, Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, the minority leader, said, "This budget has a single-minded focus on oversized tax cuts, to the exclusion of almost everything else Americans care about."
The Republicans' speed left the Democrats scrambling to complete a Democratic alternative and to assess the firmness of their own members. Representative David Bonior of Michigan, the House minority whip, said he thought about 90 percent of House Democrats would oppose the Republican tax cut as too expensive when it came to the floor next week.
"I think people see the fact that a size-10 foot will not fit into a size 7 shoe," Mr. Bonior said. 
Mr. Gephardt said the Democrats' rate-cut package would be worth about $500 billion. Democratic aides said the party was looking to direct its tax reduction to lower and middle-income people by reducing the lowest 15 percent tax rate and expanding the earned-income tax credit, which would reduce the payroll tax liability of many families who are harder hit by the Social Security payroll tax than income taxes.
At a sometimes testy briefing, Mr. Bush's top three economics advisers defended his tax cut from accusations by Democrats that 43 percent of the tax reductions would go to the richest 1 percent of taxpayers.
"It's a nonsense set of statistics," said Mr. O'Neill, the treasury secretary. But the three administration officials separately refused to specify the benefit that they believed would flow to the top 1 percent of taxpayers.

HEADLINE: THE PRESIDENT'S BUDGET: THE CUTS; 
Civil Works and Loans Targeted in Bush Plan

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
President Bush's budget includes proposals to cut hundreds of millions of dollars for rural development, loan guarantees for small businesses, research on advanced technology, public housing and construction of the international space station.
 The cuts would affect programs at the Departments of Commerce, Agriculture, Energy and Transportation, as well as the Small Business Administration. 
 In addition, Mr. Bush's budget shows that he wants to slow the growth of Medicare, slicing about 5 percent from the amounts that would be spent under current law in the coming decade. He did not say how he would achieve those savings, other than to promise that he would "modernize and reform Medicare," the health insurance program for 39 million people who are elderly or disabled. 
While Mr. Bush did propose a substantial increase in spending for the Education Department, Democrats said it was a much smaller increase than Congress approved for the current year. By the administration's reckoning, the department's budget would rise 11.5 percent, to $44.5 billion in 2002, compared with an increase of 35.7 percent this year.
Mr. Bush's plans for cuts are often couched in dry, bureaucratic words, in contrast to the fiery language that Ronald Reagan used to attack federal spending in the early 1980's.
For example, President Bush said he wanted to terminate a program that combats drug-related crime in public housing because the program "was found to have limited impact." The money pays for security guards and police protection at housing projects. Mr. Bush said local housing authorities could achieve the same goal by simply evicting tenants who traffic in illicit drugs.
Mr. Bush would reduce the civil works budget of the United States Army Corps of Engineers by 13 percent, to $3.9 billion. The cuts may affect projects popular on Capitol Hill to dredge harbors, protect the environment and build sewage treatment plants.
One program that escaped cuts was the rail service of Amtrak. Mr. Bush requested $521 million for 2002, the same amount that Congress provided in December. But under his proposal, the money would be made available more rapidly next year, so Amtrak could buy and repair rail cars and improve its track.
William H. Schulz, a vice president of Amtrak, said, "Under the budget proposal, Amtrak would be able to meet more of its capital needs, reducing trip times and providing better service to passengers." Amtrak serves 45 states, but half of its riders are in the Northeast Corridor, from Washington to New England.
The president would freeze the Justice Department's budget, but cut its assistance to state and local law enforcement agencies. 
Several themes run through Mr. Bush's proposals. He asks Congress to reduce what he calls "corporate subsidies." He would temporarily halt spending on a Commerce Department program that provides money to private companies for research on advanced technology. He would curtail loan guarantees and subsidies for shipyards and the ship-building industry.
Mr. Bush would cut assistance to exporters provided by the Export-Import Bank and the Overseas Private Investment Corporation.
He said his purpose was to "reduce subsidies that primarily benefit corporations rather than individuals." Presidents and members of Congress of both parties have often railed against corporate welfare, with mixed success. 
Senator Christopher S. Bond, the Missouri Republican who is chairman of the Senate Committee on Small Business, said he was "very concerned" about Mr. Bush's proposal to eliminate a program of loan guarantees for small businesses, which he said, "would not otherwise be able to obtain loans to support business expansion and new jobs."
Representative Nydia M. Velazquez of New York, the senior Democrat on the House Small Business Committee, said, "The new administration appears to be missing the point that small business is big business in America and is largely driving our economy."
President Bush said he wanted to reduce or eliminate a $45 million venture capital fund created last year to stimulate investment in economically depressed areas. President Bill Clinton and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert embraced the legislation, signed on Dec. 21, as a way to open new markets to American investors.
Experience suggests that Congress will reject some of these proposals, particularly those affecting small businesses. 
Another theme running through Mr. Bush's plan is a desire to remove funds for specific public works, highway projects and grants to colleges and hospitals that are already written into law. In recent years, Congress has become bolder in directing money to specific projects by name.
Mr. Bush said the government could save $4.3 billion next year by eliminating such earmarked items. Most of those projects were championed by lawmakers who are in Congress, many of whom sit on the powerful Appropriations Committees.

HEADLINE: Developer Is Picked for Queens Residential Project Across From U.N. 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
A large riverfront site where Pepsi-Cola was bottled and canned until two years ago would be transformed into a residential enclave with more than 3,000 apartments in seven buildings, small parks and an esplanade, under a proposal chosen yesterday as part of the Queens West development project.
 But the $1 billion undertaking at the north end of Queens West will not spell an end to the giant red Pepsi-Cola sign that has blazed over the East River since 1936. 
 Under its deal to acquire the 21-acre parcel from PepsiCo, the Rockrose Development Corporation will re-erect the 60-by-100-foot sign on a new parking garage, facing the United Nations headquarters across the river as it does now. 
"We look at it as pop art," said Jon McMillan, director of planning for Rockrose. "If you could have asked Andy Warhol to design a piece of sculpture for a park, that's what he would have come up with." 
And that is not the only unusual aspect of the Rockrose proposal. To design the project, the company has commissioned Arquitectonica, best known for high-rise condominiums in Miami with sleek skins, swooping lines and bold geometric patterns. The firm also designed the hotel now being built at Eighth Avenue and 43rd Street, the Westin New York at Times Square. 
Rockrose was designated yesterday as developer of the Pepsi site by the Queens West Development Corporation, a subsidiary of the Empire State Development Corporation. The Queens West board includes representatives of the state, the city, the Queens borough president and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. A final deal is to be reached within 90 days.
While Pepsi owns more than a quarter of the 74-acre Queens West site, the state controls the development rights that permit large-scale construction in what is a low-rise manufacturing zone. So any prospective developer had to win over both sides simultaneously.
Since 1997, the only sign of Queens West on the skyline has been the 42-story Citylights co-op, built by M. O. Associates. But in December, AvalonBay Communities broke ground for the first of three new apartment buildings. A month later, LCOR was chosen as the developer of 2 million square feet of commercial space at the south end of Queens West.
"The project is moving very, very quickly," Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the state development corporation, said yesterday. "It wasn't too long ago that there were many large developers who said, 'We admire Gargano's enthusiasm, but we don't think Queens West is a project that's going to be built.' Right now, it's one of the most exciting development projects in New York City."
Rockrose competed for the Pepsi site with Time Equities and the Related Companies and was selected, Mr. Gargano said, because it offered a "superior financial deal."
K. Thomas Elghanayan, the president of Rockrose, said his company was acquainted with government-sponsored planned communities, having developed four buildings at Battery Park City. And, he said, it is prepared to weather the economic downturn that is virtually inevitable over the seven or eight years it will take to complete the project.
"We have the sitzfleisch for this kind of development," Mr. Elghanayan said yesterday. "We can sit there for a long time."
The Queens West project will seek to draw Manhattanites with river views at rents markedly less than they might expect to pay on the other side of the river -- say, $2,100 a month for an 800-square-foot apartment that would command $3,300 in Manhattan, Mr. Elghanayan said, 
It will be at least three years, however, before the first building opens, with 500 apartments. Rockrose plans to expand northward in phases, with 940 units in three buildings, followed by 725 units in two buildings and then 975 units in the last and largest building. 
None of the towers will be higher than Citylights, Mr. McMillan said.
While neighborhood opponents have long been concerned about the scale of Queens West, Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey, who represents the district, said yesterday that "the manner in which it is laid out can be done so that it's not something that becomes an oppressive mass."
The buildings will be arrayed along Center Boulevard, a gently curving street, with small parks on either side. An intermediate school will be included as part of the third phase of the project.
Under the deal, Rockrose is to buy the parcel from Pepsi for a price that Mr. Gargano put at $50 million. It will then give the land to the Queens West Development Corporation and lease it back for a nominal amount. Rockrose will also build the infrastructure: streets, utilities, parks and bulkhead. "We think we can do it faster and more efficiently," Mr. Elghanayan said, "and ultimately, it will cost less."
The most distinctive bit of infrastructure will surely be the Pepsi sign. The Pepsi-Cola Bottling Company of New York moved to Brooklyn and another site in Queens, but PepsiCo insisted that the sign had to stay if there was to be a deal.
"People who visit New York from all over the world have memories associated with that sign," said Larry Jabbonsky, a spokesman for Pepsi. "It was pivotal to our negotiations."

HEADLINE: International Partners Forming Firm to Invest in Europe 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN 

 BODY:
The private holding company of Bernard Arnault, the chairman and chief executive of LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, is planning to announce today that it has formed a joint venture with TH Lee, Putnam Capital to create a European leveraged buyout firm that would also make other private investments.
 TH Lee, Putnam Capital is itself a joint venture between Thomas H. Lee Partners L.P. and Putnam Investments. The partnership is run by Thomas H. Lee, who is best known for buying the Snapple beverage business for $135 million in 1992 and selling it to the Quaker Oats Company for $1.7 billion two years later. Mr. Lee has just raised a $6.1 billion private equity fund, the largest ever. 
 The new venture is the latest involving leveraged buyout firms in the United States to set up outposts overseas. Many firms now say that Europe offers more opportunities than the United States. Private American equity firms bought 26 European companies in 2000, up from 7 in 1997, according to Thomson Financial Securities Data.
Mr. Arnault's holding company, Groupe Arnault, and TH Lee, Putnam Capital will begin assembling a team of about a dozen investment professionals for the joint venture, to be called TH Lee Groupe Arnault Partners. The venture will have offices in London, Paris and perhaps other sites and hopes to be making investments in European companies as early as this summer. The firm plans to focus on the financial sector, business and information services, telecommunications, media, and consumer products.
"Europe is an attractive market for private equity investing, as the integration of economies, markets and consumer preferences there continues at a rapid rate," Mr. Lee said in a statement, He added that the new venture would allow his American fund to "have a strategic and financial partner in Europe to broaden access to European companies." 
For Mr. Arnault, this is just his latest investment venture. Besides having, through Groupe Arnault, a controlling stake in Christian Dior S.A, which in turn controls LVMH- Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, he has invested $500 million in Europ@Web, an Internet investment firm and incubator. The results of his Internet investments have been mixed. He also has investments in telecommunications, media, technology and financial services, both in Europe and the United States.
"We have seen from firsthand experience the compelling investment opportunities available in Europe," Mr. Arnault said in the statement. He sought out Mr. Lee and TH Lee, Putnam Capital several months ago "in view of their outstanding record of identifying companies with exceptional growth potential, together with their demonstrated ability to help create value by strengthening management, increasing access to expansion capital and crafting appropriate and timely exit strategies."

HEADLINE: Senate Panel Approves Bill for Overhauling Bankruptcy Laws 

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
A bill that would overhaul the nation's bankruptcy system and make it far more difficult for people to wipe out their debts passed an important hurdle today when it was approved by the Senate Judiciary Committee and sent to the full Senate.
 Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. of Delaware was the only Democrat to join Republicans in supporting the measure, which was adopted in the committee on a vote of 10 to 8. 
 A similar bill is expected to be adopted by the full House as early as Thursday, and President Bush has signaled that he will sign the bill if it reaches his desk. President Clinton vetoed similar legislation in his final weeks in office, saying it was too harsh on debtors. 
With Mr. Clinton's departure, consumer groups and others opposed to the overhaul said their best hope for stopping or altering the bill rested with Senate Democrats. 
In an early test of their influence in a Senate split 50-50, Democrats are expected to try to amend the bill substantially during the floor debate, which is expected to begin this week.
"It's a very harsh, very one-sided bill that spells big trouble for consumers," said Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat who is a leading opponent of the bill and is expected to direct the floor fight.
Consumer groups and other opponents of the bill, which is being heavily promoted by lobbyists for the banking and credit card industries, have described it as potentially disastrous for workers who may be thrown out of their jobs if the economy continues to slow. 
They say it would also do nothing to stem the practices of banks and credit card companies that flood the mail with solicitations for easy, high-interest credit.
The bill's supporters say that it would end abuses of the bankruptcy system by debtors who can repay some of their loans. The legislation would disqualify many debtors from filing for Chapter 7 bankruptcy, which allows them to wipe out credit card debts and other unsecured loans, and force them into Chapter 13, which requires some repayment.
"Our current bankruptcy system is broken," said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, the Utah Republican who is chairman of the Judiciary Committee. "Under the current system, people with high incomes can run up massive debts and then use bankruptcy to get out of honoring them."
The number of personal bankruptcies reached a peak of 1.4 million in 1998, up from 718,000 at the beginning of the decade, but the number has dropped in each of the last two years. Last year, there were about 1.26 million bankruptcies.
Consumer groups have blamed banks and credit card companies for pushing many people into bankruptcy through aggressive marketing campaigns for high-interest loans.
A study released this week by the Consumer Federation of America showed that credit card companies mailed 2.5 billion solicitations for credit cards in the first three quarters of last year, which projected to 3.3 billion for the full year. That would reflect a 14 percent increase over the number mailed in 1999.
"Credit card issuers are brazenly lobbying for new bankruptcy restrictions at the same time their aggressive marketing and lending practices are pushing many families closer to the financial brink," said Travis Plunkett, the association's legislative director.
The bill passed the Judiciary Committee after the panel approved, on a voice vote, an amendment that would forbid companies entering bankruptcy from selling their customer lists in an effort to reimburse creditors.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Bush Proposes Framework For Tax Cut and Spending
President Bush proposed a $1.96 trillion federal budget for next year that would cut taxes and make room for his promised increases in spending on education, medical research and the military by scaling back corporate subsidies, health-care grants for poor communities and a host of other programs.
 Mr. Bush's tax and spending framework drew immediate attacks from Democrats. They said the budget would provide a tax-cut windfall to the wealthy while raiding money needed to keep Medicare healthy and requiring cuts elsewhere. Page A1. 

WorldCom Plans to Cut 6,000 Jobs
WorldCom plans to cut almost 7 percent of its workers, or 6,000 people, as it tries to streamline its operations before a planned revamping this spring, an executive said. C11.

G.D.P. Rose 1.1% in 4th Quarter
Gross domestic product grew at a revised annual rate of 1.1 percent in the fourth quarter, the slowest pace in five and a half years, the Commerce Department said. The rate had initially been estimated at 1.4 percent. The revised figure was half of the 2.2 percent recorded in the third quarter and was the slowest quarterly pace since a 0.8 percent gain in the second quarter of 1995. C11.

Federal Tax Agents Conduct Raids
Federal tax agents raided offices and arrested four leaders of what the Justice Department described as a money-laundering and tax-evasion operation whose clients ranged from small-business owners to drug dealers. C11.

T.W.A. Union Objects to Sale
Complaining that American Airlines was not bargaining in good faith, the machinists union at Trans World Airlines objected to American's plan to buy most of T.W.A.'s assets. C4.

Arnault to Form a Joint Venture
The private holding company of Bernard Arnault, the chairman and chief executive of LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, is planning to announce that it has formed a joint venture with TH Lee, Putnam Capital. C4.

Gateway Cuts Its Profit Outlook
Gateway, one of the manufacturers hit hardest by the recent downturn in consumer computer sales, told industry analysts that it did not expect to be profitable or expand sales until the second half of this year. Theodore W. Waitt, Gateway's chief executive, said the company would concentrate on cutting costs, improving customer satisfaction and restoring profitability to its traditional products. C10.

Unimog Focused on Truck Market
After considerable preparations to sell the four-wheel-drive Unimog to individuals, Freightliner is becoming much more cautious after public criticism and is promoting the vehicle strictly as a commercial truck. C4.

Mall REIT's Outpace Others So Far
While shopping mall real estate investment trusts face some problems, like the closing of some anchor tenants and too many movie theaters, they are outpacing some other REIT's this year. Market Place. C11.

A Genetic-Level Change for Society
While Wall Street frets over whether the discovery that the human genome consists of only 30,000 genes will limit the value of genomics companies, the potential effect of genomics on the economy and society runs much deeper. Alan B. Krueger: Economic Scene. C2.
