SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 40

LENGTH: 4693 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "ABCD: A COLLECTION OF ART BRUT," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 66th Street, Manhattan, (212) 977-7170 (through mid-July). Memorably vivid and widely abused, the phrase Art Brut (meaning raw or rough art) was coined in the 1940's by the French artist Jean Dubuffet. This exhibition, drawn from the holdings of a Paris-based foundation, attempts to reinstate his original meaning, revisiting the amazing pantheon of artists who inspired it and proposing some additions. Its many highlights include works by acknowledged greats like Adolf Wolfli, Aloise Corbaz, Henry Darger and Augustin Lesage, but the show also introduces many equally riveting artists unfamiliar to American audiences. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Roberta Smith).

* "AFRICAN FORMS," Museum for African Art, 593 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1313 (through Aug. 8). This show forgoes the figurative sculptures and masks that made African art a foundation of Western modernism to concentrate on supposedly humbler stuff, objects of physical adornment and daily use. With some 400 objects created by 156 ethnic groups, it proceeds in clusters of related carved wood neck rests, stools and boxes; ivory hairpins and snuff bottles; all kinds of jewelry; baskets and ceramic vessels; as well as spoons, weapons and musical instruments. The show is pervaded with elegance, economy of form and a sensitivity to materials that is both intensely spiritual and protomodern. Figurative sculpture and masks may be the "high art" of Africa, but there is no low. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50, students and 65+ (Smith).

* "COMMITTED TO THE IMAGE: CONTEMPORARY BLACK PHOTOGRAPHERS," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through April 29). This sharply installed survey of 94 artists covers several decades of work, much of it by a generation of photographers who came of age in the 1960's and 70's. The pictures are sorted by broad themes (people, beauty, family, religion, etc.), and formal polish tends to predominate over conceptual grit. The terrain is, over all, unsensational ordinary life, with the heat now and then turned up high. Images of urban churchgoers, Louisiana sugar cane cutters, the magnetic Billie Holiday and children in African refugee camps sit side by side. The eclectic array has its share of bland entries, but there are dozens of wonderful artists here, and their collective spirit is persuasive. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 am. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m (to 11 p.m. first Saturday of each month). Admission: $4; $2, students and 62+ (Holland Cotter).

* "CORREGGIO AND PARMIGIANINO: MASTER DRAFTSMEN OF THE RENAISSANCE," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through May 6). This copious and beautiful exhibition has nearly 130 drawings by two artists who were aligned in time, geography and, briefly, style in the third decade of the 16th century. Correggio, who blew the roof off Renaissance illusionism with the ecstatic ceiling paintings that he made in Parma in the 1520's, is represented by a room of exquisite mostly red-chalk studies that reflect a penchant for brazen foreshortening, glowing light and atmospheric sfumato; they also attest to a sensuousness that can seem more proto-Rococo than proto-Baroque. The two galleries of Parmigianino's drawings seem true to his Mannerist sensibility. A searching restlessness is evident in the constant shifts in medium, style and subject, the considerations of other artists' work (including Correggio's), the pensive self-portraits and portraits and, most of all, in several drawings that layer together unrelated motifs. So is a relatively new notion for his time: drawing for the sake of drawing. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Smith).

"THE GLOBAL GUGGENHEIM: SELECTIONS FROM THE EXTENDED COLLECTION," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through April 22). Of the big permanent collection shows that have been taking up so much space, the Guggenheim's is the last. It's also the coolest, the prettiest, the least programmatic and the most conservative. Despite the "global" spin of the title, this is strictly a Euro-American affair. And thanks to the eye of the curator, Carmen Gimenez, it is a very beautiful one. The great Wright spiral feels freshly swept out; the bays are sparingly hung; and dozens of top-notch works, including a few from the Hermitage in St. Petersburg and Guggenheim branches abroad, have been paired and grouped to ignite free-associational sparks. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 am. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"MAJOR INTERSECTIONS," Yeshiva University Museum, 15 West 16th Street, Chelsea, (212) 294-8330 (through April 1). The museum has a new downtown home in the Center for Jewish History, which it shares with four partners: the American Jewish Historical Society, the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, the American Sephardi Federation and the Leo Baeck Institute. This show is drawn from the permanent collections of four of the five, and through paintings, books, manuscripts and ephemera evokes fascinating lives and overwhelming sweeps of history. A highlight is an 11th-century wooden Torah ark door from Egypt; it is believed to have come from the Ben Ezra synagogue in Cairo, where Maimonides once worshipped. Hours: Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $4, students and 60+ (Cotter).

* PAUL McCARTHY, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through May 13). From his far-out position where the psychic security of Hollywood's packaging of sex and violence doesn't exist, Mr. McCarthy taps veins deep in the collective subconscious, way beyond where most shock artists have the audacity or intelligence to operate. A cultish presence on the Los Angeles art scene for years, his moment has finally come in New York with this retrospective and shows at Luhring, Augustine in Chelsea, Deitch Projects in SoHo and, in collaboration with the Public Art Fund, at the public atrium at 56th Street and Madison Avenue. We see an artist of wild highs and lows, of black comedy, cheap jokes, unspeakable actions, dry formalism and some real fiascos, the mark of an artist risking failure, a good sign. There is something beyond mere Pop parody or social provocation in the work, something to do with deep private needs and desires, which we perceive secondhand as comic pathos. It is art as tough therapy, disturbingly honest. Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* "NINETEENTH- AND 20TH-CENTURY CHINESE PAINTINGS FROM THE ROBERT H. ELLSWORTH COLLECTION, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 879-5500 (through Aug. 19). The 19th and 20th centuries were shattering times for China, bringing wars, civil violence and the fall of an empire. In art, old forms survived and flourished but also changed. This exhibition surveys how elite painting traditions developed for a new audience and under Western influences between 1850 and 1980. Among the highlights is a group of paintings by Qi Baishi (1864-1957), deservedly one of the most popular of all Chinese artists. The big news is that a major museum has quietly taken a firm stand on modern art in Asia, seeing it not as a postscript to a great tradition but as an integral, living part of the continuum. Hours and admission: See above (Cotter).

"THE OPULENT EYE OF ALEXANDER GIRARD," Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum, 2 East 91st Street, (212) 849-8400 (through March 18). The first comprehensive look at the multifaceted work of the architect and designer. Girard's contribution to contemporary design was a free approach that incorporated all sorts of visual stimuli, from Italian stage sets to Mexican folk art to motifs from modern technology, making exuberant use of color, pattern, texture and ornament. In photographs, models and objects, the exhibition displays his fabrics, graphics, interiors, furniture, tableware, radio cabinets and much else. A whole room is devoted to the more than 300 fabric and wallpaper designs he created for the Herman Miller Furniture Company from the 1950's to the early 1970's with fresh patterns and colors that pushed the limits of middle-class taste. While Girard may not have been a heavyweight in American design, he was one of its liveliest figures. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Tuesdays until 9 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $3, students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

* "PERFECTING MANKIND: EUGENICS AND PHOTOGRAPHY," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through March 18). A timely exercise wildly disproportionate in significance to its size, this one-room show tackles the complicated story of photography's supporting role in eugenics, the pseudo-science of human breeding. Via 19th-century composite portraits of Jews, snapshots of "Fitter Family" and "Perfect Baby" contest winners and early Nazi photographs of Aryans, we track the arc of eugenic popularity, an object lesson for our era of genetic engineering. And we see the dubious results of an unreflective faith in technological science, in this case the new technology of photography, which seemed at the time a reliable instrument of reason. Photographs, we are reminded by the exhibition, almost always say less than we think or want, and sometimes precious little except about our prejudices. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 62+ (Michael Kimmelman).

"JEAN POYET: ARTIST TO THE COURT OF RENAISSANCE FRANCE," Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through May 6). His reputation as one of the great manuscript illuminators of the Renaissance has declined over the centuries, with much of his work ascribed to others, but the French artist Jean Poyet (ca. 1445-1503) is re-established in this beautiful show as the true author of a number of well-known Books of Hours and other religious treasures. His use of perspective, color, light and shadow and his convincing representations of the human figure took his work well beyond the limitations of his Late Gothic predecessors, as seen in such powerful manuscripts as the "Missal of Guillaume Lallemant" and "The Hours of Henry VIII." The judicious use of lightbox transparencies, blown-up color photographs and a CD-ROM room where viewers can turn the pages of virtual manuscripts makes the show more accessible. It is one of the season's most impressive presentations. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 65+ (Glueck).

* CHARLOTTE SALOMON, Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through March 25). Put aside as much as possible the grim death that has boxed Salomon, like Anne Frank, into the eye-glazing, inviolate category of Holocaust artist, a disservice to her. "Life? Or Theater?," her quasi-fictional diary of text and nearly 800 pictures cued to musical themes, will make you feel you are in good company while flattering your intelligence. The allusions are varied, the tone at times surprisingly light. Film was a big inspiration to Salomon. Images vary among close-ups, flashbacks, long shots and montage. She had an illustrator's gift for distillation and paraphrase. The result is a complex meditation on the connection between love and art. It is a coming-of-age story about a woman squeezing a whole life into one great gesture. Ultimately the energy counts most, a civilizing energy. "Take good care of it," Salomon told the man to whom she entrusted the work before she was shipped to Auschwitz. "It is my whole life." So it was. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "VAN GOGH'S POSTMAN: THE PORTRAITS OF JOSEPH ROULIN," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9400 (through May 15). This revelatory micro-exhibition reunites five portraits of the postal worker Joseph Roulin, whom van Gogh met while living in Arles in the south of France. The show affords an excellent opportunity to study the painter's craft as he processes a single motif through a series of approaches from painterly naturalism to richly patterned symbolism. It is fascinating as well to see the portraits in light of the biographical background. Roulin cared for van Gogh after the famous ear-cutting incident, and he grew in the artist's imagination from an amusing local character to a figure of Christ-like benevolence. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; to 8:15 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Ken Johnson).

"ANDY WARHOL: PHOTOGRAPHY," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through March 18). When Warhol died in 1987, he left some 100,000 photographs in the form of prints, contact sheets and negatives. This exhibition is the first major examination of this material and focuses on its relationship to Warhol's photo-based paintings, early and late. Taken strictly as a display of photographs, the show feels a little thin, mostly because his output in the medium was almost willfully insubstantial. But as a fresh take on his hugely influential work and complex personality, the results are entertaining and sometimes revealing. Included is one of his "time capsules," cardboard boxes that he periodically filled with the material clutter of his life, then sealed, dated and stored away. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6, students and 62+ (Cotter).

Galleries: Uptown

RICHARD NONAS, "Sophia Maria and the Indians," Lawrence Markey, 42 East 76th Street, (212) 517-9892 (through March 10). Carefully placed in this gallery's square white room, the simple, rough-hewn wooden sculptures by a veteran Minimalist create a slowed-down, contemplative ambience. An inclined plane of heavy beams; a saw-tooth pattern cut into a thick plank; an X shape made of intersecting blocks: these Brancusian objects encourage a calming attention to elemental facts of light, space and structure (Johnson).

* "WOMEN DESIGNERS IN THE U.S.A., 1900-2000: DIVERSITY AND DIFFERENCE," Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, 18 West 86th Street, (212) 501-3000 (through April 8). At the turn of the 20th century, female designers were mostly white, middle-class and skilled in "female" pursuits; today their ethnicity is widely diversified, and they have made enormous progress in fields once open only to men. Architecture, landscaping, interiors, furniture, textiles, apparel, posters, tableware, wallpaper, ceramics, lighting, jewelry, floor coverings, silverware, doors for cars, costumes and industrial products are represented in this bountiful show, which shoehorns some 220 objects into three floors of tight gallery space. Work by American Indians and African-Americans is given special attention (Glueck).

Galleries: 57th Street

"A WINTER GROUP OF ARTIST COUPLES," Katharina Rich Perlow, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-7171 (through March 10). It is not a new idea, but it is always interesting to compare works by two artists who are (or were) a couple. This 22-artist show includes Abstract Expressionist paintings by James Brooks and Charlotte Parks; a squiggly drawing and a slashing painting by Willem de Kooning and Elaine de Kooning, respectively; and an elegant Constructivist-style drawing by Joel Shapiro with a delicately misty painting of a blue vase by Ellen Phelan (Johnson).

* OSKAR KOKOSCHKA, "Memorial Exhibition," Marlborough Gallery, 40 West 57th Street, (212) 541-4900 (through March 17). Throughout this show, we are reminded that in everything he did Kokoschka, who died in 1980 at age 93, gave his whole self, without evasion and without stint. It begins with his portraits of the composers Webern (1914) and Schoenberg (1925); continues with his big cityscapes, with their attention to telling detail; and makes a strong case for his late watercolors, in which the image is briskly defined and the color has an irresistible energy. This hand never shook (John Russell).

* "OUR BEAUTIFUL AND TORMENTED AUSTRIA: ART BRUT IN THE LAND OF FREUD," Galerie St. Etienne, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 245-6734 (through March 17). This extraordinary show introduces the recently discovered work of two self-taught Viennese artists: Emanuel Navratil (1875-1956), who made large color-pencil drawings that transform his native city into a magical kingdom of fantasy architecture, intricate pattern and bourgeois contentment; and Josef Karl Radler (1844-1917), a retired porcelain painter whose fusions of writing and painting infuse scenes of the hospital where he spent his final years with a power akin to illuminated manuscripts (Smith).

Galleries: SoHo

"HANDS ACROSS THE SEA," Phyllis Kind Gallery, 136 Greene Street, (212) 925-1200 (through March 15). Arranged in a series of telling, often surprising comparisons between American and European self-taught artists, this exhibition demonstrates that there is plenty of reason to stretch Jean Dubuffet's original definition of Art Brut beyond its original European perimeters (Smith).

ROBERT SCHMID, Sears-Peyton, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 966-7469 (through March 31). With sensitive, assiduous craft, Mr. Schmid paints small-scale copies of blurred, smeared, double-exposed or otherwise distorted snapshots of people, city streets and natural landscapes, which were taken with a defective camera. He organizes these images into gridded compositions that have a moody cinematic quality (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

BILL OWENS, Paul Morris, 465 West 23rd Street, (212) 727-2752 (through March 10). Mr. Owens published his famous and enthralling book "Suburbia" in 1973, but he continued his sharp-eyed documentation of suburban culture into the early 80's. This show presents large color prints from the series, including the images of a pretty young woman with big hair snorting coke in a restroom and a beautiful picture of a swimming pool titled "Hockney Painted This Pool" (Johnson).

"POETRY PLASTIQUE," Marianne Boesky Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9889 (through March 10). Art and poetry: made for each other. Poets write about art; artists turn to poetry for ideas. Sometimes the two disciplines meet in collaboration. Such meetings are the subject of this show, in which image and word are flexibly intertwined. Organized by the poet Charles Bernstein and Jay Sanders, it covers a stretch of recent historical ground, from word-peppered Blakean drawings by Robert Smithson from 1962 to work by Mira Schor, Richard Tuttle and Susan Bee from last year. When the gallery was host to a series of related panel discussions and readings, the buzz of voices and ideas made the art feel alive and interactive. Some of the pieces really need that charge; others do fine on their own. Certainly the cross-disciplinary concept behind the show is ripe for further exploration (Cotter).

"THEM!" Jay Grimm, 505 West 28th Street, (212) 564-7662 (through March 17). The most interesting items in this curiously didactic show about some of our least favorite animals are not artworks but actual exotic insects collected, mounted and framed by Bob Natalini. Otherwise, there are round photographic portraits of ants by Bill Scanga; nice washy watercolors of a praying mantis and a ladybug by Emilie Clark; and Shane Hope's strange, funky miniature assemblages with insectoid elements emerging from the gallery's electrical receptacles (Johnson).

Other Galleries

SARAH BEDFORD, JEANNE LORENZ AND AMY WILSON, Bellwether Gallery, 150 Franklin Street, Greenpoint, Brooklyn, (718) 389-3213 (through March 11). The unstated theme of this show is Americana gone decorously amok. Ms. Bedford's collagelike bad-dream visions of bugs, plants, geometric patterns and Currier and Ives sleigh rides are the most elaborate entries. Ms. Lorenz, in large grisaille watercolors, transforms winsome porcelain figurines from e-Bay auctions into bug-eyed mutants. Ms. Wilson also works in watercolor. In paintings the size of pages in children's books, she uses pleasing colors, draftsmanly finesse and wide-ranging research to chart the sinister inner workings of the military-industrial complex (Cotter).

Last Chance

"CONTEXT: MEXICO'S TALLER DE GRAFICA POPULAR AND ITS LEGACY," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, Morrisania, (718) 681-6000 (through Sunday). The Taller was established in Mexico City in 1937 to create a national art that would be accessible to the common man, and its utopian goals have inspired generations of Chicano and Puerto Rican artists. This small show, installed in the museum's permanent collection gallery, includes work by founding members of the Taller like Leopoldo Mendez and Pablo O'Higgins plus contemporary successors like Luis Jimenez, Rafael Tufino and Ester Hernandez. Hours: Wednesdays, noon to 9 p.m; Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $3; $2, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"LEONARDO DREW," Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, at 165th Street, Morrisania, (718) 681-6000 (through Sunday). The large-scale two-part wall here continues a theme for which Mr. Drew is noted: subtly gridded three-dimensional compositions made of distressed wood, stacked boxes and various other materials, then coated with rust to simulate the encroachments of time and nature. The walls and the castoff objects they contain have an aura of gritty poverty, evoking hard times and marginal lives. But they also make high-art connections: the allover and actively layered surfaces alluding to Abstract Expressionism, the grids evoking the rigorous formalism of geometric abstraction. In the nine years since his first New York solo show, Mr. Drew's voice has not lost its eloquence, although the work has lost the fresh rawness that gave it its initial impact. Hours and admission: See above. (Glueck).

JAYNE HOLSINGER, "American Stills," Margaret Thatcher, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 675-0222 (through tomorrow). This New York-based painter's small panel paintings -- based on family snapshots taken on a trip home to the Midwest -- are formally nondescript. But they are deftly made and convey a quietly touching affection for middle America, not an attitude frequently encountered in Chelsea galleries (Johnson).

"INTIMATE FRIENDS: THOMAS COLE, ASHER B. DURAND AND WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT," New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, (212) 873-3400 (through Sunday). The painters Cole (1801-1848) and Durand (1796-1886) and the poet Bryant (1794-1878) shared a close friendship, based in part on a vision of nature as a moral and spiritual force. Bryant sang its praises in poetry; Cole and Durand, founders of the Hudson River School, paid tribute in art. This show of paintings, drawings, manuscripts and periodicals from the society's own holdings celebrates the spiritual kinship of the trio, and lays out the notions about nature and civilization, Europe and America that involved them in long-term dialogue. Its centerpiece is Cole's five-part painting cycle, "The Course of Empire" (1836-38), an allegorical account of the rise and fall of an ancient classical civilization. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students 12+ and 65+ (Glueck).

PHILLIP KING, Garth Clark, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 246-2205 (through tomorrow). This English artist has a heavyweight title, president of the Royal Academy of Art in London, but his sculpture has always had a lighthearted way with form and metaphor. In the five large natural-color ceramic works on view here, Mr. King playfully abstracts traditional vessel forms, producing a witty, slightly surrealistic Neo-Classical Cubism (Johnson).

ROBERT LONGO, "The Freud Drawings," Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-7100 (through tomorrow). Mr. Longo's monumental charcoal drawings are based on photographs of Sigmund Freud's home in 1938, shortly before he fled to London. They are competently made with strong contrasts between velvety blacks and glaring whites; if they are compelling, however, it is because they trigger highly charged associations. Thus, through the spiritually cheap act of appropriation, the artist lays claim to an unearned moral profundity (Johnson).

* NINO MIGLIORI, "Neo-Realismo: Scenes of Life in Postwar Italy," Keith de Lellis Gallery, 47 East 68th Street, (212) 327-1482 (through tomorrow). Making you feel the camera wasn't there was one of the great attributes of the postwar Italian neo-Realist films like "Shoeshine" and "The Bicycle Thief." You tend to dismiss the artful camera, too, in Mr. Migliori's black-and-white stills, taken in the north and south of Italy from 1952 to 1959. Inspired by the great neo-Realist film directors, Mr. Migliori captured what might be called Italian quintessences in images that range from three pairs of women's white shoes clicking smartly along a sidewalk to a couple of monks playing volleyball, their long robes billowing about them (Glueck).

LARRY POONS, Salander-O'Reilly, 20 East 79th Street, (212) 879-6606 (through tomorrow). Painted in bright cotton-candy colors over surfaces enhanced by glued-on foam rubber, Mr. Poons's new paintings are swarming mindscapes populated by curious symbolic forms: spheres with Saturnine rings, pyramids, stars, ellipses and even mathematical notations. They have a kind of clumsy rawness of draftsmanship that suggests the work of a self-taught visionary. What they mean to the artist is hard to say, but they offer a fresh combination of terrestrial funk and cosmic exuberance (Johnson).

JOSHUA STERN, Parker's Box, 193 Grand Street, Williamsburg, Brooklyn, (718) 388-2882 (through Sunday). This is the first one-person show for a smart six-month-old gallery, and Mr. Stern's big photographs of sculptural heads are, in their bizarre way, suitably imposing fare for the occasion. They stare down from the walls like life-size family portraits, but who would would claim these cartoonish, pocked-skinned creatures as relatives? Actually, Mr. Stern has created something very grand from something very modest: the photographs are of tiny heads that the artist molded from chewed drinking straw wrappings; the sculptures themselves can be found on a little shelf in the back (Cotter).

BILLY SULLIVAN, "My World," Fischbach, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 759-2345 (through tomorrow). In Mr. Sullivan's luminous painted world it seems as though people are always on summer vacation, enjoying sunlit oceanside spaces indoors and out. In his best pictures, which look like watercolors even when painted with oils, he combines seemingly effortless snapshot-based draftsmanship and pastel colors to portray people at play or in states of enviable ease. Yet one cannot help wondering what darkness is hidden by such a determinedly hedonistic vision (Johnson).

HEADLINE: Stocks in Japan at 15-Year Low 

BYLINE:  By MIKI TANIKAWA 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 1 

 BODY:
Snubbing the Bank of Japan and the interest rate cut it announced yesterday, investors hammered Japanese stocks downward again today, with the benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index falling 1.57 percent, to 12,681.66, its lowest close in more than 15 years.
 The relentless decline in share prices in recent days is an embarrassing blow to the governor of the bank, Masaru Hayami, who declared in August that the Japanese economy was healthy enough to withstand higher interest rates. Over a storm of objections from political leaders, the Bank of Japan, the country's central bank, then raised its overnight call rate, the interest banks charge each other, to 0.25 percent from near zero. 
 Now, Mr. Hayami finds himself having to unwind the policy: yesterday's move lowered the call rate to 0.15 percent, after the largely symbolic discount rate, the interest the central bank charges for its loans to banks, was trimmed on Feb. 9.
Electronics stocks were among the hardest hit today, in part because of the continuing weakness in Nasdaq trading in the United States. Matsushita Electric Industrial fell 6.79 percent today; NEC fell 4.19 percent and Sony, 2.72 percent. Bond prices rose as investors sought a haven, pushing the yield on the benchmark 10-year government bond to its lowest level in more than two years, 1.210 percent.
Analysts said the bank's reversal of course on interest rates was insufficient to counteract dismal figures on industrial production in January that came out on the same day.
"The market felt something had to be done," said Yoshikazu Takao, managing director at Asahi Life Asset Management in Tokyo. "Without it, the market would have suffered even a greater decline."
Instead of "doling out policy in such a piecemeal fashion," in Mr. Takao's phrase, he and other analysts said the bank needed to regain the confidence of the markets by setting aside questions of pride and face-saving and wholeheartedly moving to ease monetary policy, by cutting the overnight call rate to zero and other measures.

HEADLINE: Factory Index and Spending Show a Bit of a Rebound 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1 

 BODY:
A gauge of manufacturing rose last month for the first time in a year, and consumer spending in January was the strongest in four months, two reports showed today, indicating that the economy may be turning around.
 The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index rose to 41.9 last month from 41.2 in January, breaking a string of 11 consecutive declines. Personal spending on goods and services rose 0.7 percent in January as consumers bought more automobiles, the Commerce Department said. 
 "The hemorrhaging may have stopped," said Richard Yamarone, senior economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York. Still, "it'll be slow going for the next four or five months."
A reading below 50 in the manufacturing index signals a contraction at factories, and the index has not been above that point since July of last year. That is why investors are betting the Federal Reserve will cut its benchmark interest rate a half percentage point at its March 20 meeting to keep the economic expansion going.
The Commerce Department showed an increase of 0.7 percent in January spending on goods and services. That was up from a 0.4 percent gain in December and the biggest rise since a 0.9 percent rise in September. The report also showed a 0.6 percent increase in January incomes after a 0.4 percent rise a month earlier.
Construction spending rose 1.5 percent in January, the biggest rise since a 1.7 percent jump in March 2000, led by more work on single-family homes, the Commerce Department reported.
The February new-orders component of the manufacturing index rose to 40.8 from 37.8 in January, signaling manufacturing may improve in coming months. It is "excellent news to see some bottoming in the new- orders component," said Steven Wieting, an economist at Salomon Smith Barney Inc. in New York. "This is one of the things that could stabilize the rest of the economy."
New orders carry the greatest weight and account for 30 percent of the overall index. The purchasing management association's production index rose to 39.7 from 37.9 in January. The report also showed inflation was less of a concern for manufacturers. An index of prices paid for raw materials fell to 58.1 in February from 65.7.
Fed policy makers say that manufacturing is mainly responsible for the economic slowdown as production cuts whittle away at excess inventory that accumulated amid slowing demand.
"I think the prospects that this is primarily an inventory correction centered in manufacturing is pretty high," J. Alfred Broaddus Jr., the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, Va., said last month.
The association's employment index, a gauge of hiring plans and labor market conditions accounting for 20 percent of the index, fell to 37.2 in February from 43 in January. The index has fallen for five consecutive months, the first time that has happened since April to August of 1973.
Separately, the Labor Department reported initial jobless claims rose by 39,000, to a level of 372,000 last week, the highest this year.

HEADLINE: Slightly Shaken, Briefly Shocked, Then Back to Mellow as Usual 

BYLINE:  By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 1 

 BODY:
Lori Brogan knows an earthquake when she feels one. A former Californian, she lived through serious quakes in Los Angeles in 1971 and 1994. So when the tall, two-story walls started wobbling back and forth in the Seattle Shirt Company on Wednesday morning, Ms. Brogan ran to stand under the doorjamb of the stockroom.
 "I was shocked," said Ms. Brogan, 33, who manages Seattle Shirt, a T-shirt emporium across the street from the Pike Place Market downtown. "I just stood there and thought, 'This is it.' " 
 So it was, and yet it was not. By this morning, Ms. Brogan's shop had already sold out of its first batch of celebratory "I Survived the Earthquake in Seattle" shirts in bold red and black letters, and the mood of this waterfront capital of coffee and mellow was settling into a kind of grateful astonishment that it had, in fact, endured the region's worst earthquake in a half-century with perhaps $2 billion in property damage but few serious injuries.
"Shaken, but OK," read the bold banner headline of The Seattle Times. The headline of the lead editorial was more pointed in a city sometimes stereotyped as smug: "Shaken From Complacency."
In fact, some locals said the earthquake seemed simply the culmination of a run of atypical bad news here, from the recent dot.com contraction to the violent protests at the World Trade Organization meeting in 1999 to a Mardi Gras celebration that turned violent and left 71 people injured and one dead after midnight Tuesday, just hours before the earthquake struck.
Even an unusually sunny spate of winter weather has left mountain snowpack and vital hydroelectric capacity below normal, and made Seattle feel more like Southern California. But this afternoon, a steady rain and soupy fog arrived as the sort of calming benediction that a rainbow might represent in clearer climes.
"It was a pretty startling experience, obviously, but I guess the shorthand on Seattle is that we're shaken but not stirred," said Walt Crowley, a local author and executive director of a Web site on Seattle history, historylink.org. "There's no panic in the streets, and in fact, the Fat Tuesday violence is probably a more disturbing event in its way." 
Mr. Crowley and his colleagues were updating their site when the quake struck and made fresh history. "Some bookshelves toppled over, but we stayed online," he said. 
Paul A. Toliver, the director of the King County Department of Transportation, was holding a staff meeting when the quake hit.
"We did quite well," Mr. Toliver said. "I actually moved here from San Francisco, but this was the worst I ever felt." 
Today, before heading to a meeting on quake damage with Joe Allbaugh, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Mr. Toliver took souvenir snapshots of the damage to the Fenix Underground tavern across the street from his office near Pioneer Square. 
The area, the scene of the Mardi Gras violence, is full of older, low-rise brick buildings, and was one of the places hardest hit. Today red and yellow police tape blocked off streets littered with bricks, crumbled mortar and broken glass.
Because the city emerged so relatively unscathed, merchants felt free to make fun. The Four Seasons Hotel featured upside-down cake, breakfast "panquakes" and seismic martinis (shaken, of course), while the Pike & Western Wine Shop downtown had a blackboard sign on the sidewalk that asked passersby, "What to drink after an earthquake?" and answered, "Anything."
And residents seemed disinclined to complain openly. "I am so sick of this city, it's just too much," a clerk in the wine shop was saying when a reporter entered this morning, but she quickly fell silent when he identified himself, and a co-worker, Peter Schmalzer, cheerily announced that the store had lost only about two dozen bottles, mostly tippy half-bottles of dessert wine, out of the thousands racked on its shelves.
"I got to tell you," Mr. Schmalzer added, "they were all shaking. I was just getting ready for them to go."
To be sure, glass objects fell, plenty of them, including expensive vases at the Vetri International Glass gallery, on First Avenue downtown, which together with its upstairs parent, the William Traver Gallery, is a leading dealer for Seattle's renowned studio glass industry. 
Mr. Traver estimated his losses at something like $300,000.
"It looks very clean now," Vetri's director, Heather Eslien, said this morning, as she rearranged a rainbow assortment of handblown goblets and glassware and gestured to a straw broom propped in the corner that had been busy for hours. "But it was really pretty messy yesterday. Everything just kind of swayed back and forth."
At the venerable Eliott Bay Book Company off Pioneer Square, perhaps 1,000 volumes, mostly current hardback fiction, fell off the shelves as the staff ran out in the street to escape the shaking, one clerk, David Hsieh, recalled today.
"I was downstairs in the cafe, and it suddenly sounded like a big train was going by on the street, which doesn't happen" Mr. Hsieh said. 
"It's incredible that more people weren't hurt."
Whatever the digital economy's troubles, it was ready for a digital-age earthquake, and by midafternoon today the online auction site eBay already featured 32 Seattle quake-related items, including an assortment of "debris, shaken earth and crushed vehicle remains" offered by Ian Maddox of Seattle, who usually sells computers and parts on the site.
"I found lots of bricks and whatnot demolished from a building downtown," said Mr. Maddox, who had drawn a top bid of $1.25 after two bidders, with 6 days remaining in the auction. "And I figured, Why not?"

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
New Rochelle Skyline Now Has a Skyscraper

BYLINE:  By NADINE BROZAN 

 BODY:
From almost any vantage point in New Rochelle, N.Y., the new apartment building almost complete at 255 Huguenot Street stands tall, its 25 stories slicing into the horizon, visible everywhere. 
 "Coming back from Montauk last summer," said New Rochelle's mayor, Timothy C. Idoni, "I got on the Cross Island Parkway just west of Glen Cove and noticed the impressive orange steel structure reaching into the sky. Suddenly I realized: that's New Rochelle." 
 The tallest structure in New Rochelle, the building is known as Avalon on the Sound. It marks the increasing concentration by AvalonBay Communities Inc., the development and management company, on the high-rise market. 
"This is a newer business for us," said Fred Harris, a vice president of development for the company in the New York metropolitan region. "Our existing portfolio is overwhelmingly garden apartment communities. But we are increasingly interested in urban infill locations with access to jobs, transportation and entertainment. Our market is renters by choice: people who rent because they want to, not because they can't afford to buy."
The company owns 136 complexes, or, as it prefers to call them, communities, containing 40,041 apartments in 12 states and the District of Columbia. In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut it has 29 communities, with a total of 10,102 apartments. Last winter it began construction of the first phase of Avalon Riverview, the three-building cluster it is putting up in the Queens West project in Long Island City. 
In New Rochelle, the first occupants of Avalon on the Sound are scheduled to move in next month.
The rental office had more than 1,000 inquiries even before it opened last week, said Robert Paley, senior development officer with AvalonBay Communities.
The original plan called for the construction of three buildings, one of them across Huguenot Street next to the New Rochelle Public Library. But the first building, which contains 412 apartments, has been so successful, he said, that Avalon scratched the third phase and expanded the second building to 600 units.
The first building cost $92 million, "about the same as it would have in Manhattan," Mr. Paley said. The City of New Rochelle, which owned the 2.4-acre site, gave AvalonBay Communities a 30-year tax deferral. In return, AvalonBay will pay the city a percentage of its annual operating income from the property, according to a spokesman for the company. Financing is being done through Fleet Bank. 
When complete, the building, in a rounded L-shape, will contain 41 studios (rent: $1,285 to $1,405), 144 one-bedroom apartments ($1,605 to $1,980), 185 two-bedrooms ($2,140 to $2,850) and 41 three-bedrooms ($2,815 to $3,435). They all bear the names of America's Cup boats, reflecting the location. 
Light and airy with views of the library and of the Sound -- which is actually about three-quarters of a mile away -- the units all have kitchens opening onto living-dining rooms, walk-in closets, and, with the exception of the studios, washers and dryers.
Communal amenities will include a 52-foot-long heated outdoor swimming pool that will be surrounded by decorative columns, with nearby barbecue grills and picnic tables.
Inside there is a club room with a fireplace, bar and kitchen that can be used by residents for parties. There is also a fitness center with exercise machines, a basketball court and a gym, a business center and a laundry room, all open 24 hours.
But what attracted Stanley and Mary Jane Lee, who now live on the Upper East Side and who have signed a leasefor a one-bedroom unit, more than anything else was the location. The Metro-North station is directly outside the rear door. (Insulation has been installed in the concrete block walls to shut out the sound of passing trains.) 
Stanley Lee, 32, is a dentist with a practice in New Haven and a commute that, he said, ranges from an hour and a half in the morning to three hours in the evening. His wife, 25, is a lawyer with an office in Midtown Manhattan. 
"We had been looking for a compromise, for about a year," Dr. Lee said. "In my drive I noticed the building, a big orange skeleton from I-95. I didn't even know how close to the train station and convenient to the highway it is."
To Mayor Idoni, Avalon on the Sound has become one more emblem of the renaissance of New Rochelle's downtown area after decades of retail and residential depression. 
Though its size is notable, there was never opposition to it as there was to the proposed Ikea superstore, plans for which were abandoned in February. 
"The residents of New Rochelle realized we had to do something dramatic to bring the business district back," Mr. Idoni said, and that meant a large residential development to bring dollars into the local economy. New Roc City, a $190 million complex with numerous athletic and entertainment facilities including two ice rinks, a bowling alley, a batting cage, video arcade and 18 movie screens, is two blocks away. 
The closest neighbor to Avalon on the Sound is Trinity-St. Paul's Episcopal Church, a 19th-century neo-Gothic structure that could not offer a more startling architectural contrast.
But, in the view of the Rev. Clair McPherson, the rector of the church, which was founded more than 300 years ago, the two structures complement one another rather than clash. "I think aesthetically it will be a better harmonization than many things I see in Manhattan," he said. "The two styles may be very different but they are compatible. There is something about a church spire that gives a feeling of tallness. "

HEADLINE: Debating the Bush Agenda, From Sea to Sea 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "The Return of Fuzzy Math" (editorial, March 1): 
 I agree with your suggestion that the Bush budget leaves no room for error and could end in deficit. But we should not be so determined to avoid risking a deficit that we cause a recession. Americans need that money more than their government does. 

DAVID E. PETERSON
Winter Park, Fla., March 1, 2001

HEADLINE: State Agency Sues to Claim Rights to Battery Park Site 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Battery Park City Authority and a major New York developer are wrestling over one of the last major development sites in Lower Manhattan.
 The authority, the state agency that controls the 92-acre Battery Park City, has sought for several years to sell the right to build a 1.8-million-square-foot skyscraper on a vacant parcel at the north end of the complex. But the developer, John E. Zuccotti, has told public officials and rival builders that his Brookfield Financial Properties has the exclusive right to develop the site on West Street, between Vesey and Murray Streets. 
 The long-simmering battle became public yesterday, after the authority filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court asking that Brookfield be barred from continuing to interfere with the authority's plans by invoking rights that "simply do not exist." These false claims, the agency said, could drive down the sale price, or scare off bidders who fear becoming entangled in a lawsuit by Brookfield.
At stake is a valuable chunk of real estate and a sale price that could exceed $100 million. But the value of the property could decline if there is a long delay and a recession.
"We consider this parcel an enormously valuable property," said James F. Gill, chairman of the authority. "We have a fiduciary duty to get the most we can for it. But people may not bid, or may bid less, because of the existence of this claim.
"Brookfield's playing a card that they think is a queen," he added. "I think they have a three or four."
Brookfield disagreed, saying it obtained control over commercial development at Battery Park City in the 1980's with the development of the World Financial Center, a complex of four large office towers that are home to American Express, Merrill Lynch and other companies.
Brookfield succeeded the original builder as manager of the World Financial Center and three of the four towers.
"We obtained certain rights affecting future commercial development at Battery Park City as a central part of the agreement to construct the World Financial Center," said Rick Matthews, a spokesman for the developer. "Brookfield continues to hold these rights and is confident that its position will be sustained through adjudication."
Battery Park City itself was built on landfill along the Hudson River 30 years ago. The complex includes more than 4,900 apartments, hotels, 30 acres of parks, an esplanade, schools and museums, as well as the eight-million-square-foot World Financial Center.
Only a few undeveloped parcels are left. The authority has wanted for some time to sell the development rights for the parcel now in dispute.
"There has been a question mark hanging over this site for years," said Stephen B. Siegel, chairman of Insignia/ESG, a real estate brokerage company. "Clearing it up will make it much easier to get a transaction done."
In 1998, Jerry I. Speyer, the developer, and Nasdaq, the electronic stock market, had considered building new Nasdaq headquarters on the site. Brookfield declared at the time that it was the only developer that could build on the site, much to the authority's chagrin.
The two sides appeared close to a resolution later that year, when Brookfield explored building new headquarters on that land for Chase Manhattan Bank, which was considering a merger with Merrill Lynch. But like the Nasdaq proposal, nothing came of it.
"There's no animosity here," Mr. Gill said. "I've got a good relationship with John Zuccotti. The court will decide whether he has a claim."

HEADLINE: Vehicle Sales Held Strong Last Month 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 1 

 BODY:
American consumers continued to flock to car dealerships in February despite the economic slowdown, producing another unexpectedly strong month for auto sales.
 Sales fell 6 percent last month from February 2000, but the year-earlier month had been one of the best in the industry's history because of lavish incentives. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales last month was 17.5 million vehicles, in an industry that considers anything above 16 million vehicles to be an excellent month. 
 "I don't think anyone was expecting it to be much above 16" million, said Haig Stoddard, the manager of industry analysis at Ward's Automotive, an auto industry data service in Southfield, Mich. "People I've talked to are at a loss -- if you look at how the economy is going, it's not making sense." 
The automakers' sales executives acknowledged that they, too, were somewhat mystified, but suggested three explanations for the market's remaining strong even as consumer confidence has plunged.
Rebates and other discounts became slightly more widespread last month than in January and were heavily advertised, especially by Chrysler. General Motors and especially Ford Motor increased somewhat their reliance on low-profit shipments to corporate and rental fleets. And vehicles remained fairly affordable last month, having barely risen in price over the last four years, excluding the addition of new options, even as incomes have climbed swiftly in recent years for the affluent families who buy most of the new cars and light trucks these days.
Brisk sales in February, combined with slower shipments from factories, helped car dealers clear lots that had become crammed with unsold vehicles earlier this winter.
General Motors said it had an 87-day inventory of unsold vehicles as of Wednesday, and Ford said its inventory was down to 80 days. The Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G. had just a 58-day supply, its lowest since July 1999.
The auto industry considers a 60-day supply to be ideal, so as to offer a range of colors and options at each dealership. Foreign automakers had manageable inventories even before February.
"We're taking a hard look at putting some production back in," said Jamie Jameson, the vice president for marketing and sales at Chrysler, which has been particularly aggressive in shuttering factories for a week or two at a time and furloughing the workers. The company is proceeding with long-term white-collar and blue-collar layoffs, however.
Ford announced today that it hoped to keep its factories running throughout the second quarter, after shuttering most of them for a week or two at a time earlier this year. Ford's output in the second quarter will be down only 5 percent from last year, because few if any factories will run on overtime, said George Pipas, a Ford market analyst.
G.M. was more cautious, setting a production schedule for the second quarter that calls for making 17 percent fewer automobiles than during the second quarter of last year, when many factories were operating with maximum overtime.
The company has already begun notifying workers at some factories that assembly lines will be slowed and that hundreds of workers will be furloughed, although they will continue to draw most of their pay, under the terms of their union contract.
Chrysler and foreign automakers did not release production schedules today. Auto production schedules affect the entire economy because the industry accounts directly for about 4 percent of the nation's economic output, and accounts directly or indirectly for a quarter of the output of Michigan, Ohio and Indiana.
Some auto industry officials were nonetheless cautious today about how much longer the good times could last, given consumers' increasing gloominess. The major automakers stayed with their estimates that sales for all of this year would be 16 million to 16.5 million cars and light trucks. Since the annual sales rate in January reached 17.1 million vehicles, this means that the manufacturers expect slower sales later in the year.
Ford used to expect a weak first half of this year followed by a stronger second half. Now, the company anticipates a somewhat longer slowdown enduring at least into the third quarter, said Emily Kolinski, a Ford economist.
Paul Ballew, G.M.'s executive director for market analysis, noted that March and April were more important for auto sales than January and February, and would provide a better test of the industry's strength.
Foreign automakers continued to gain market share last month at the expense of the manufacturers based in the Detroit area. Sales at G.M. declined 9.5 percent from a year earlier, while Chrysler's dropped 10.5 percent and Ford's were down 11.2 percent.
G.M.'s market share was 31.2 percent, several points higher than in recent months and matching its share a year ago, when the company was offering incentives that were much more generous, Mr. Stoddard said.
Japanese automakers fared even better. Honda's sales jumped 9.4 percent and Toyota's climbed 1 percent, while Mitsubishi's were down 2.8 percent and Nissan's sales were down 6.1 percent.
European automakers had uneven results, with BMW's sales rising 19 percent while Volkswagen's dipped 10.4 percent and the Mercedes unit of DaimlerChrysler had a 2 percent increase.
Ford named Jan Klug, 41, as its vice president for global marketing today. He is replacing James Schroer, who resigned last week to join Chrysler.
Ms. Klug has been overseeing Ford's sport utility vehicle promotions, including its successful "No Boundaries" campaign, which has been matched recently by a similar Toyota campaign.

HEADLINE: The Mind-Set of a Slowdown; 
Thriving or Hurting, U.S. Manufacturers Brace for the Worst

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Herbert V. Kohler Jr., chairman of the Kohler Company, was caught by surprise when the economic slowdown hit last fall. In the past, sales of the company's bathroom and kitchen fixtures invariably began to fall six months before the economy did, giving him plenty of warning. "They are my leading indicator," Mr. Kohler said. But this time, toilets, sinks and bathtubs kept on selling as briskly as ever, and they still are.
 No sector, despite Kohler's experience, is feeling the pain of the weakening economy more than manufacturing. Robert Barnett, an executive vice president at Motorola, calls what is happening a "spiraling recession." That is certainly Motorola's experience in cellular phones and semiconductors. Some other manufacturers are similarly hard hit, particularly in computers and autos. But across the broad expanse of American industry, the situation is much more diverse. 
 Some companies, like Kohler, have hardly been touched. Others, like the Fluor Corporation, a giant engineering and construction operation, are hurting in America and thriving overseas. Still others, like the Goodman Equipment Corporation, a maker of small locomotives for mining and tunnel building, are shipping their main products in the old volumes, but feeling the slowdown in sales of spare parts, a secondary source of revenue. 
Despite these wide differences among manufacturers, their strategies for the weeks ahead are eerily uniform. Bracing for the worst, most of America's industrial leaders are hunkering down by eliminating overtime, putting a freeze on hiring, scaling back on new investment and shrinking the number of jobs at their companies. Yet in doing so to strengthen their operations for the longer term, they may be helping to make it more likely that in the short run a full-blown recession could indeed arrive.
"When uncertainty spreads, as it is spreading now, you focus on defending your profitability," said Ralph F. Hake, executive vice president and chief financial officer at Fluor. "And that, unfortunately, is self-defeating."
Top executives from more than 100 manufacturing companies gathered in Key Largo, Fla., last weekend for the winter board meeting of the National Association of Manufacturers and concluded that the economic slowdown would endure. In a poll, 53 percent of the 88 executives who responded predicted that economic growth would remain very weak or even nonexistent until year's end, missing the early summer revival that many forecasters still expect. 
Such gloomy sentiments -- useful to the association in persuading the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates again and again -- stand in striking contrast to the more upbeat stories that many manufacturers tell about their current situation. Motorola is more the exception than the rule. With its cell phone business in free fall, it may lose money this quarter, a rare experience. Lucent, Gateway and DaimlerChrysler are similarly in trouble.
But in interviews, executives of a dozen companies making an assortment of products described their experience as more like a tire with a slow leak than a balloon suddenly popped. The slowdown is even seen by some companies as an opportunity to cut costs that should have been eliminated during the boom years.
"In a convoluted way, a downturn provides the opportunity for a cleansing of overcapacity," said Thomas E. Evans, chairman of the Collins & Aikman Corporation, which makes the textile and plastic parts of auto interiors and has closed 3 of its 65 plants. "It creates an acceptable moment to take cost-cutting steps that a lot of managers wanted to do anyway."
That is not a thought shared by Mr. Kohler, whose grandfather founded the Kohler Company a century ago. For him, the slowdown first showed itself not at any of the company's 43 factories, but at the two luxury hotels the company operates in Kohler, Wis., across from the big headquarters plant. "We saw a nervousness in November and December among companies that had scheduled meetings at our hotels for February and March," Mr. Kohler said. "Three or four canceled their reservations."
Kohler, with revenue of $3 billion last year, also makes gasoline motors for garden tractors that homeowners buy. The demand for the motors has fallen by 10 percent since fall. "That smarts," Mr. Kohler said. But sales of plumbing fixtures are still rising, despite the weakness in new-home construction. "People are remodeling their homes more than ever, and that surprises me," Mr. Kohler said.
Resisting the pessimism, he is maintaining capital spending in 2001 at last year's pace of more than $100 million a year. A new factory is going up in Mexico, and plant expansions are under way in the United States, reflecting Mr. Kohler's view that once the economy revives, the extra outlay today will more than pay for itself tomorrow.
Still, in other ways, the Kohler Company is very much in the cost-cutting mainstream. "Overtime disappears naturally; our foremen and supervisors know to pull it back," he said. "And we have slowed hiring."
Capital spending, a source of so much strength for the national economy until last fall, is spotty now. Oil and natural gas companies, for example, are splurging, which gives the Fluor Corporation's revenues a considerable lift through contracts for the pipelines and new refinery capacity that Fluor provides. "Our backlog is beginning to grow; new orders are up about 35 percent in the last two months," Mr. Hake said. "But most of this is overseas." 
At home, for every Kohler in manufacturing that is sustaining its investment plans, other companies are behaving more like Collins & Aikman, an auto industry supplier that is holding back. A backlog of unsold vehicles has forced automakers to cut production, which means that suppliers like Collins & Aikman must also pull back -- and capital spending is not spared.
"The car companies call me and say they are going to cut in half what they buy from us for two weeks, and then go back to full orders," said Mr. Evans, the chairman. The automakers' goal is to keep the suppliers ready to resume full production when the inventory backlog is worked off and the rebound occurs with the introduction of new models in late summer.
That is the expectation. Until it materializes, Collins & Aikman, with headquarters in Troy, Mich., is maintaining enough capacity to fill orders, but is also gradually trimming -- preparing for a rebound that in Mr. Evans's view will never return production to the booming levels that prevailed until the fall. Jobs are being eliminated, including most recently 500 middle-level administrative jobs.
And capital spending has been deferred, as Mr. Evans puts it. New equipment is essential to improve quality and efficiency. But instead of spending $150 million over six months, the original plan, Collins & Aikman is deferring $20 million, including $4 million for computers. "Deferral is not canceling," Mr. Evans said. "There is a powerful difference. We are still moving our agenda forward, but capital spending is one of the things you can control. And when you have to cut back, you turn to the things you can control."
At the Goodman Equipment Corporation in Bedford Park, Ill., discounting, on two fronts, is helping the company through these difficult months. Orders are up for the locomotives it makes for mining and tunnel work and normally sells for $75,000 to $425,000, depending on size. But starting late last year, Calvin A. Campbell Jr., Goodman's chairman, found himself agreeing to discounts of 3 to 10 percent.
The company takes in a big chunk of revenue from the sale of spare parts for the hundreds of locomotives now in the field. "People are saying," Mr. Campbell said, " 'Why should we buy the spare parts and put it on our shelf? You keep it on your shelf.' "
Still, there is a safety valve. Over the years, Goodman has outsourced almost everything except the actual locomotive assembly. Lately, the outsourcing has produced an unanticipated dividend. "The suppliers have been calling on us much more aggressively," Mr. Campbell said. "We can give a 10 percent discount on the locomotives we sell because we can get discounts on what is coming in from our suppliers."
If Goodman Equipment is getting relief from its suppliers, the huge Manitowoc Company, with headquarters in Manitowoc, Wis., is creating its own relief. It has sped up production in response to the reluctance of its customers to be more generous in their ordering. Manitowoc's product line includes construction cranes, some of them giant contraptions mounted on crawlers that can lift a thousand tons -- roughly 50 elephants -- 400 feet.
The $6 million price tag means that buyers finance purchases, not only of the biggest cranes but also of the smallest version, selling for $500,000. They are not happy about the cost of doing that at today's interest rates, even allowing for the Federal Reserve's rate cuts starting in January, says Terry D. Growcock, chief executive at Manitowoc. So the orders are being placed at the last minute, only after a contract has been signed for a construction job instead of six months in advance in anticipation of the contract.
"We are still selling roughly 200 cranes a year," Mr. Growcock said. "But with much less of an order backlog, we have to build the cranes in 50 to 60 days instead of the 120 that prevailed a couple of years ago. It forces you to work much more closely with your suppliers."
Like many executives in manufacturing, Ronald P. Sandmeyer Jr., chief executive of the family-owned Sandmeyer Steel Company in Philadelphia, is braced for the worst. So when orders dropped off last month for Sandmeyer's stainless steel plate, overtime for the 150 employees quickly disappeared.
The company is still getting about 100 requests a month for price quotes, "but our customers are not pulling the trigger at the same rate," Mr. Sandmeyer said.
Instead of the usual 35 orders, the company got 29 in the last month, and for smaller amounts than usual. But February is always a weak month, and Mr. Sandmeyer worries about overreacting -- hunkering down too much.
"It is too soon to know what is happening to us," he said, "but certainly it is a concern when I hear what I am hearing. I don't know if we are talking ourselves into a recession."

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Creates Unit to Spot Early Signs of Foreign Crises 

BYLINE:  By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 1 

 BODY:
As they followed the economic crisis in Turkey with concern, leaders of the International Monetary Fund said today that they were creating a unit to anticipate and head off financial crises in countries to which the fund makes loans.
 The unit, to be known as the International Capital Markets Department, will consolidate the gathering and analysis of information that are now spread among other I.M.F. departments, said Horst Kohler, the fund's managing director. 
 Mr. Kohler asserted that today's announcement was neither precipitated nor hastened by the situation in Turkey. The country was hit last week by a second bout of financial turmoil, despite a multibillion-dollar I.M.F. assistance package intended to stabilize markets. He said his decision to create the department followed a recommendation from a panel formed in October to analyze the fund's operations. The panel was headed by John Lipsky, chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. 
"I see this department as a vital part of the ongoing efforts to strengthen the international financial architecture, and in particular to strengthen the fund's role in crisis prevention," Mr. Kohler said in a statement. "With this move, the fund is sending a clear signal that it is serious about its commitment to being a center of excellence for work on financial markets issues."
Elaborating in a question-and-answer session, Mr. Kohler said the new unit "will enhance the fund's early-warning capabilities." A director for the new unit will be appointed as soon as the right person can be found, he said.
The fund, which has 183 member countries, exists to promote international monetary cooperation and stability and to provide financial assistance to countries that need it. It has been criticized for being slow to anticipate problems in Mexico, Russia and other nations, and thus investing effort and money unwisely.
Mr. Kohler and the fund's second-ranking executive, Stanley Fischer, agreed today that some of that criticism has been justified. 
"Not every crisis is unforeseen," Mr. Fischer said. He acknowledged that the fund should have better anticipated the monetary crisis that struck Mexico in 1994, for instance.
But Mr. Fischer said the situation in Turkey "was hardly to be anticipated by anyone's analysis."
A dispute between Turkey's president and prime minister flared up last week. It disrupted the Istanbul stock market, scared away foreign investors and sent the Turkish currency into a free fall. The big drop in the currency is being felt across the country in many ways. World Business, Section W. Turkey is a North Atlantic Treaty Organization partner and permits its bases to be used by American planes that patrol Iraq. President Bush has expressed his concern about the situation there.
The fund lent $7.5 billion to Turkey in December after a flight by foreign investors threatened a national economic program aimed at reining in inflation and government spending. Mr. Kohler said today that it would be up to Turkey to "demonstrate by action" that the fund's support has been justified.
The new department head will face difficult choices. If he tries to operate quietly and things go wrong in a particular region, he may be criticized for not focusing enough attention on a simmering problem. 
But if he elects to be more open about what he sees going wrong, he may risk causing widespread alarm, driving away investors, and thus aggravating the very situation the monetary fund is supposed to alleviate.

HEADLINE: Struggling City Preps For National Close-Up 

BYLINE:  By JOHN W. FOUNTAIN 

DATELINE: GARY, Ind., March 1 

 BODY:
There is something in the air these days, and it is not just the thick white smoke billowing from the few remaining smokestacks in this long-neglected and perpetually struggling industrial city.
 It is a rare sense of excitement, hope and promise for a city that has had enough bad publicity to last a lifetime. Gary is about to gain the national spotlight with what many would consider the unlikeliest of events: the Miss USA beauty pageant. 
 As one larger-than-life poster high on the side of the abandoned downtown Sheraton hotel boasts, "Gary goes worldwide March 2 on CBS." 
The show goes on Friday night. It is the culmination of months of preparation that has gift-wrapped this city in more glamour than anyone here can remember. And who knows? It just might help turn things around.
Mayor Scott L. King and many others here have high hopes that being the pageant's host city for three years will boost the economy and residents' morale.
Gary bid $1.2 million to play host to the pageant, which is co-owned by CBS and Donald J. Trump, who just happens to own a casino here. Mr. Trump's is one of two casinos in Gary, and they bring in an estimated $25 million in annual tax revenues, city officials said.
While no one expects a cure-all, many here say that prime-time exposure can only help to change perceptions about their city and attract not only businesses to central Gary but also spenders from suburban northwest Indiana and tourists.
That any city would pin its hopes on six hours of TV spread over three years, and on a program that last year ranked 39th in weekly Nielsen ratings (just behind "Ladies Man" on CBS), may say a lot about the dazzling allure of the entertainment business.
But it also says a lot about Gary. Dreamers have had little to cling to in a city crippled -- a lifetime ago, it seems -- by the demise of the steel industry, rampant poverty and a staggering crime rate. While Gary is no longer the nation's murder capital, the process of rebuilding has been agonizingly slow.
And that is why the stage has been set, the trimmings painstakingly completed.
Golden banners on downtown street lights flutter in the wind. Abandoned buildings have been adorned with painted windows. The streets have been swept. And the Genesis Convention Center in the heart of downtown, where the pageant will be held, sparkles.
Friday's broadcast, with William Shatner as host, will include nine minutes of spots promoting Gary. Some, shot last summer, highlight the dunes and beaches along Lake Michigan. Others show the contestants milling about the more photogenic places in town. And already some residents here say the show-business sparkle has begun to rub off in their town.
"It's a good thing," said Lucy Bravo one afternoon this week, standing in her family's downtown restaurant, Los Tacos Bravo's, on Broadway Avenue in the shadow of the convention center. "Gary is like dead, there's nothing here. So with the Miss USA pageant, it's a whole different atmosphere."
"Gary is a nice place," Mrs. Bravo continued, the scent of tortillas filling the air. She said she hoped people outside Gary would begin to "look for the good side because the city has its ups and downs." She was standing behind bulletproof glass, near a picture of the reigning Miss USA, Lynnette Cole, and a sign showing a gun and the words "I don't dial 911." 
While reshaping the city's image will not be easy, nearly everyone here believes it is necessary. A predominantly black city of about 111,000, with a white mayor, Gary bills itself as a city on the mend.
Mayor King, in his second four-year term, said the pageant "has the ability to build local pride in the city and the psychology of the public in a positive way. If you don't have that, nothing else you do is going to work."
With the acquisition of the Steelheads, an International Basketball League team that since December has played at the renovated 6,000-seat convention center, Mr. King said there already has been a trickling in of people who live on the fringes of the city. The city is also laying plans to build a stadium to host a minor-league baseball team as well as other projects over the next several years as it seeks to rebuild downtown and attract private investors.
"I am seeing some fruit," Mr. King said. "Deals still have to be closed, but at least deals are being discussed. Two or three years ago, Gary wasn't even considered." 
Meanwhile, many here like Anthony Mayo, 40, a garage attendant, are gearing up for the pageant.
"For me it's worth it to bring people in and say, 'Hey, you know what, we're people like everybody else,' " said Mr. Mayo, collecting the $3 fee from motorists.
"This is not Chicago. This is not New York. We don't have a tall building. But we have people who are willing to work together to pull it off."
Late this week, crews of workers could still be spotted adding final touches. Not far from downtown, in a neighborhood of boarded-up houses, vacant lots and blight, a famous house still stands.
It is an unassuming red and white frame house with a partial brick front and no special note about its former occupants, the Jackson Five, who wrote a song about this house at 2300 Jackson Street. The current occupant, a mustachioed elderly man, speaking cautiously from behind a black security door, assured a visitor that Michael Jackson and the Jackson family were long gone and likely were not looking back.
But downtown, at the abandoned Palace Theater spruced up with the painted facades, the letters being put up by workers announced, "Jackson Five Tonight."
"I'm just trying to create a media event," said Chris Toepfer, one of the workers, patching up buildings for the city. "This sign was so ugly that they originally wanted us to take it down. We're making the theater look so nice that people will actually show up and think we're selling tickets."
As the men worked, the sign caught the eyes of a passing motorist, who rolled down her car window and excitedly asked, "Are the Jackson Five coming?"
The answer was no. But just down the street, there was Miss USA. No kidding.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Above, contestants rehearsing for the Miss USA Pageant, which will be broadcast tonight from Gary, Ind. The city paid $1.2 million to play host to the pageant for three years. (Photographs by Todd Buchanan for The New York Times)
