INDONESIA: MILITARY STEPS IN
Indonesia's military, which has stayed away from politics since the fall of Suharto in 1998, warned President Abdurrahman Wahid's enemies not to try to unseat him while he is away on an overseas trip. The army chief of staff, Gen. Endriartono Sutarto, left, told The Jakarta Post it was up to the people to decide whether Mr. Wahid should stay. There have been growing calls for Mr. Wahid to step aside. Calvin Sims (NYT)

TAIWAN: WRITER BARRED
The government has barred a Japanese writer from entering Taiwan to confront his critics after a dispute over his comic book, which depicted Taiwan women volunteering to enter Japanese military brothels in World World II. The writer, Kobayashi Yoshinori, quoted a leading Taiwan industrialist as saying that in order to improve their social status, the women willingly submitted to Japanese soldiers. Mark Landler (NYT)

THE AMERICAS

ARGENTINA: ECONOMY MINISTER RESIGNS
Jose Luis Machinea submitted his resignation as minister to President Fernando de la Rua. No reason was given for his resignation, but he has been under pressure to leave office because of an enduring recession that has pushed unemployment over 15 percent. Clifford Krauss (NYT)

PERU, JAPAN: 'NO' ON FUJIMORI
Tokyo will not extradite former President Alberto K. Fujimori, whom Peruvian authorities have charged with criminal abuse of power, the Justice Ministry said. The minister, Masahiko Komura, said that because Mr. Fujimori has Japanese citizenship, Japan would not hand him over if asked to do so, the ministry said. Peru's attorney general has charged Mr. Fujimori with abandonment of office and dereliction of duty but has not yet demanded extradition. (AP)

MIDDLE EAST

IRAN: PRAISE FOR WEST
Iran praised the United States and Britain for crackdowns on its principal armed opposition group, the Iraq-based People's Mujahedeen, the state news agency reported. The F.B.I. said on Wednesday that it had arrested seven people in Los Angeles believed to be members of the Mujahedeen, which the State Department classifies as a terrorist group. On the same day, Britain banned 21 groups, including the Mujahadeen. (Agence France-Presse)

AFRICA

ZIMBABWE: EASING STANCE ON JUDGE
Backing away from their threats, government officials agreed to allow the Supreme Court's chief justice, Anthony Gubbay, to remain in his position until the end of June, his lawyer said. Officials had threatened to force Mr. Gubbay out on Thursday, instead of in June as previously agreed. Mr. Gubbay agreed to quit in June -- 10 months before his scheduled retirement -- because officials said they could not guarantee his safety from government-backed militants who have threatened judges for ordering black squatters to end occupation of white-owned farms. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)

BURUNDI: PEACE TALKS
After nearly a week of intense fighting, the government and the two main rebel factions will begin their first talks next week, to be held in South Africa. A chief negotiator said the two groups, including the National Liberation Forces, which have been battling in a suburb of Bujumbura, the capital, since last Saturday, have not been among the 19 parties working toward a peace pact for two and a half years. Ian Fisher (NYT)

UGANDA: VOTE PUT OFF
Uganda has postponed by five days its presidential elections, in which President Yoweri Museveni is facing his first real challenge after 15 years in power. Election officials said the delay, to March 12, was because of incomplete voter registration and voting cards. Ian Fisher (NYT)

EUROPE

GERMANY: RIGHTIST VIOLENCE
Far-right violence surged by nearly 60 percent last year compared with 1999, Interior Minister Otto Schily said in a statement. The number of cases of violence against foreigners rose 57.4 percent, with anti-Semitic attacks climbing by 68.7 percent. The rise was caused in part by more detailed reporting, officials said. Victor Homola (NYT)

AUSTRIA: HAIDER DENOUNCED
Jorg Haider, the driving force behind the extreme-right Freedom Party, faced new accusations of anti-Semitism. Mr. Haider, who has spoken favorably about some Nazi policies, was attacked over comments he made at an Ash Wednesday rally about Ariel Muzicant, left, leader of Austria's Jewish community. In a wordplay on a well-known soap powder, Mr. Haider said, "I don't understand how someone called Ariel can have such dirty hands." (Agence France-Presse)

FRANCE: EX-SS OFFICER SENTENCED
A former SS officer who was a right-hand man to Adolf Eichmann was tried in absentia and sentenced to life in prison for crimes against humanity. The officer, Alois Brunner -- who if still alive is believed to be in Syria -- was accused of sending hundreds of Jewish children to Auschwitz. "Usually it is very difficult to ask for a life sentence," the prosecutor said. "But in this case there is nothing but unalloyed joy." Suzanne Daley (NYT)

HEADLINE: Salvadorans Illegally in U.S. Are Given Protected Status 

BYLINE:  By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2 

 BODY:
President Bush agreed today to allow as many as 150,000 Salvadorans to remain in the United States for up to 18 months to help El Salvador recover from a series of devastating earthquakes earlier this year. Most of the Salvadorans are in this country without legal visas or work permits.
 President Francisco Flores of El Salvador had requested that the administration grant "temporary protected status" to thousands of his countrymen living illegally here, saying that money they earn in the United States and send to relatives back home would be as valuable to rebuilding efforts as increased American aid. 
 In a meeting with Mr. Flores at the White House today, Mr. Bush granted the request. 
"This will allow them to continue to work here and to remit some of their wages back home to support El Salvador's recovery efforts," Mr. Bush said after the meeting.
Mr. Bush also pledged a two-year package of reconstruction aid, $52 million this fiscal year plus the same or more next year, quieting critics who had complained that Washington had so far provided only $16 million in relief, about half of what Spain has given. 
"This is immensely important for us because it will allow Salvadoran families here in the United States to send their help to Salvadoran families in the devastated areas in our country," Mr. Flores told reporters outside the White House.
Temporary protected status would shield undocumented Salvadorans from being detained or deported for the next 18 months. It also would allow them to work legally. The 1.8 million Salvadorans living in this country send home more than $1.5 billion a year.
Today's action broadens a decision earlier this year by the Immigration and Naturalization Service to halt the deportation of 1,100 Salvadorans here since the first quake, Jan. 13. 
Two major earthquakes have caused nearly $3 billion in damage, an amount that is growing as aftershocks continue. The quakes have left about one in four Salvadorans homeless, Mr. Flores said.
Immigrant rights groups hailed Mr. Bush's decision as a compassionate humanitarian gesture. And in the wake of his visit to Mexico last month, those groups pronounced today's action a signal that Mr. Bush was making good on the pro-immigrant stands he articulated in his presidential campaign. 
"This is really the first opportunity the president has had to demonstrate that he was serious when he talked in Latino communities in the campaign about treating immigrants from other countries fairly and respectfully," said Cecilia Munoz, deputy vice president of the National Council of La Raza, an immigrant rights organization. 
Mr. Flores echoed the sentiments, saying today's agreements underscored Mr. Bush's commitment to a closer relationship between the United States and Latin America.
"He has given us concrete evidence that he is not only putting out his words, but his will, so that this will be a reality," Mr. Flores said.
Salvadorans are eligible to register for the program announced today if they have been in the United States since Feb. 13, the date of this year's second major earthquake, which killed nearly 300 people. 
Applicants are required to provide their names and addresses, be fingerprinted and pay a $50 fee. To apply for work authorization and receive a legal Social Security card costs an additional $100. 
Congress voted to create the temporary-protected status program in 1990, largely to grant temporary refuge to 200,000 Salvadorans who fled their country's civil war. Mr. Bush's father, President George Bush, extended their status in 1992. President Bill Clinton renewed the program a year later, but the temporary status expired in December 1994. 
In addition to El Salvador, residents from nine other countries are allowed to stay in this country because of dangers in their homelands from conflict or environmental disaster: Angola, Burundi, Honduras, Liberia, Montserrat, Nicaragua, Sierra Leone, Somalia and Sudan. 
Salvadoran immigrants from Los Angeles to Washington praised the administration's decision.
Cristino Diaz, 39, a chef at a downtown Washington cafe who lives with his wife and 16-year-old son in Silver Spring, Md., said he and his family sent about $1,500 a month to cousins, aunts and uncles and other family members in El Salvador.
Mr. Diaz said he talked regularly to his family there, who relate tales of misery.
"There is no food," he said. "There is no work. The people are afraid to buy anything because they fear they could lose it in another disaster."
"The only source of income is the dollars" sent home by Salvadorans living in the United States, Mr. Diaz said.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Urges Caution on Spending and Tax Cuts 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 2 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, urged Congress today to be cautious in parceling out tax cuts and spending increases, warning that the projected federal budget surplus should not be considered money in the bank.
 While restating his support for a substantial tax cut and acknowledging the likelihood that huge surpluses will come flooding into the government over the next decade, Mr. Greenspan noted that economists still could not fully explain the surge in tax receipts in recent years or the degree to which a falling stock market might darken the outlook. 
 "What if, for example, the forces driving the surge in tax revenues in recent years begin to dissipate or reverse in ways that we do not now foresee?" Mr. Greenspan said. "Indeed, we still do not have a full understanding of the exceptional strength in individual income tax receipts during the latter years of the 1990's." 
In an appearance before the House Budget Committee, Mr. Greenspan stuck closely to comments he made in January to the Senate Budget Committee in which he blessed a big tax cut. He said that without a tax cut the surplus might be so big that it would force the government to begin buying stocks and bonds on Wall Street in as little as five years, a development he said would be harmful to the free enterprise system.
But he sidestepped efforts by Republicans to elicit a specific endorsement from him of President Bush's proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut. And he declined to say how much of the $3.4 trillion national debt he thought was redeemable in the next 10 years, an issue of heated debate between the parties in the last few days.
He again raised the idea of tying any tax cut to steady progress in reducing the debt, suggesting that the tax cuts could be phased in to take effect as the debt fell to certain levels. Some members of both parties have supported such an approach as a compromise that might help Mr. Bush win approval for his tax cut, but the White House and the Republican leadership in Congress have rejected the idea.
Mr. Greenspan's appearance came as Congress prepared to begin writing its own budget plan for next year, amid growing divisions among Republicans about whether the increase in general government spending can be held to the 4 percent proposed this week by Mr. Bush.
After the release of Mr. Bush's budget on Wednesday, some prominent Republicans, including Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, suggested that a 4 percent increase was unrealistically low. 
Mr. Bush's budget would provide increased spending for education, the military and medical research, but would require cutbacks in most of the biggest cabinet departments to keep the spending increase to the White House's 4 percent target.
Frustrated that spending might increase faster than Mr. Bush has proposed, conservative Republicans said they would battle to hold the line, even if it meant a showdown between the House and the Senate over the budget. Mr. Bush said he, too, would work to hold the spending increase to what he proposed.
"That's caused some consternation, because in Washington the definition of a cut is that you haven't increased the budget as much as anticipated," Mr. Bush said in a speech to the National Conference of State Legislatures.
Mr. Greenspan's support for a tax cut and his warnings about runaway spending have given Republicans a lift as they seek to push Mr. Bush's plan. But Democrats have seized on the Fed chairman's admonitions not to spend the surplus too soon to suggest that the president's tax plan needs to be scaled back.
Mr. Greenspan was also questioned about whether the Fed had brought on the economic slowdown by raising interest rates too much in 1999 and the first half of last year.
No, Mr. Greenspan said, the Fed had responded appropriately. He also said that inflation remained well contained, and that he had been deliberately ambiguous in an appearance before another House committee this week about whether the Fed might cut interest rates before its next scheduled meeting on March 20.

HEADLINE: Robin Hoods of Cyberspace 

BYLINE:  By Steven Johnson; Steven Johnson is the co-founder of Feedmag.com and the author of "Interface Culture." His next book, "Emergence," will be published in September.

 BODY:
 THE HACKER ETHIC
And the Spirit of the Information Age.
By Pekka Himanen.
232 pp. New York: Random House. $24.95.
 It can sometimes seem as if the number of people who have speculated on the social implications of Linux, the free computer operating system collectively engineered by thousands of programmers worldwide, exceeds the number of people who have actually used Linux itself. Ever since the open-source software movement entered into the public consciousness in the late 90's, we've been awash in prophesies about the end of the Windows era and the birth of a less proprietary digital age. Together, the emergence of open-source software and the related Napster music file sharing system constitute the most significant technological development since the arrival of the World Wide Web.
Up to now, most ruminations on the impact of open-source software have limited their view to the computer desktop itself: does the stability of the Linux platform prove that open software development models are intrinsically more stable than the proprietary ones used by Microsoft? Is there an economic model that can support the development of free software? 
These are important questions, but they don't do justice to the most remarkable fact about the open-source movement: at the very epicenter of New Economy capitalism, something that looks a great deal like a wired version of communism has prospered beyond anyone's wildest imagination. While private companies are free to sell "flavors" of Linux, and to sell technical support, no one owns Linux proper. It belongs to the people. If the Web served as a launching pad for the Xtreme capitalism heralded in magazines like Fast Company and Wired, the launching pad itself was partly built by freely contributed collective labor. 
Itself something of a collaborative project, "The Hacker Ethic: And the Spirit of the Information Age" begins with the premise that the programmers behind the open-source movement (called "hackers" throughout the book) represent a "spiritual challenge to our time." As Pekka Himanen writes in his preface, "the hacker ethic is a new work ethic that challenges the attitude toward work that has held us in its thrall for so long, the Protestant work ethic, as explicated in Max Weber's classic 'The Protestant Ethic and the Spirit of Capitalism.' " 
"The Hacker Ethic" begins with a breezy prologue from the legendary programmer behind the Linux revolution, Linus Torvalds, centered on what he calls "Linus's Law." (His theory: people are motivated by "survival," "social life" and "entertainment.") Himanen, a philosopher of technology who teaches at the University of Helsinki and at the University of California, Berkeley, then presents a longer essay -- the bulk of the book, really -- on the core attributes of the hacker ethic, contrasting them with Weber's work and that of his modern disciples. The techno-sociologist Manuel Castells arrives in the closing pages to deliver a somewhat freeze-dried rendition of his grand theory on the difference between today's "network society" and the industrial systems of yore. 
Because Torvalds's contributions are so slender, and because Castells has presented his ideas elsewhere, "The Hacker Ethic" needs to be judged primarily on the substance of Himanen's argument: that the values associated with the open-source movement present a significant challenge to the Protestant ethic. While Himanen's text relies on almost no primary research in terms of interviewing programmers, his survey of the core components of the hacker ethic (which he calls the nethic) is as comprehensive and instructive as any to date. Unlike the dutiful labor of Weber's Protestant ethic, the nethic embraces flexible hours, creativity and a passion for one's work. The nethic also disdains monetary reward for one's achievements, preferring what the open-sourcers call Egoboo -- the respect of one's peers. While Himanen can present a strained image of hacker sainthood, he makes a persuasive case that the nethic stands in direct opposition to the Weberian tradition. 
But that opposition raises two questions. First, is the Protestant work ethic still a useful category in modern industrialized societies? Weber's theory had little room for today's frenzied leisure-time consumption. (Sunday was a day of rest -- not the day for PlayStation 2 and Old Navy.) We may be programming our TiVo's with time-management skills that would have made the efficiency expert Frederick Taylor proud, but surely there's a difference between using those techniques to tape episodes of "Temptation Island" and using them for crop rotation. The dominant culture may still be clinging to older, Weberian notions of labor-as-duty, but it certainly spends a great deal of energy persuading us to kick back and live a little on the weekend. Himanen avoids dealing with the prominence of today's consumer society by wishing it away with the old "false consciousness" dismissals: "Only when work uses up all energy and people are too tired to enjoy the pursuit of their passions are they ready to be reduced to the passively receptive state suited for television." In other words, that feeling you have of actually enjoying "Seinfeld" reruns -- that's just an illusion. 
But even if you accept Himanen's most optimistic scenario -- a band of impassioned hackers challenging the oppressive establishment -- the question remains: What does it mean for the rest of us? Can the playful, work-for-art's-sake nethic be transferred to the analog world? For anyone who is excited about the promise of the open-source revolution, that may well be the most provocative question of all, and Himanen has meager answers for it. "The hacker open model," he writes, "could be transformed into a social model -- call it the open-resource model -- in which someone announces: I have an idea, I can contribute this much to it, please join me! . . . For example, I could announce on the Net that I would be willing, once in a while, to help some elderly person take care of things. I can announce that kids can come and play at our house after school." 
This is a nice idea, but hardly a radical break from, say, a real-world bulletin board at a community center. Himanen has a powerful grasp on that strangely intoxicating contradiction that is open-source, but when it comes to potential extensions of that model, he falls short. You can't help being let down to find that a mainstream adoption of the hacker ethic might only make it easier to find a baby sitter for the kids.

HEADLINE: Colorblind in the Right Eye 

BYLINE:  By Scott L. Malcomson; Scott L. Malcomson's latest book is "One Drop of Blood: The American Misadventure of Race."

 BODY:
 GUESS WHO'S COMING
TO DINNER NOW?
Multicultural Conservatism
in America.
By Angela D. Dillard.
245 pp. New York:
New York University Press. $26.95.
 One does not associate scholars with perfect timing, news-wise, but Angela D. Dillard's "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner Now?" could not be more of the moment. A rainbow arcs above a Republican White House. The desperate mummery of the Philadelphia convention has issued in something more honorable: a looks-like-America cabinet. George W. Bush said that the varied social identities of his early appointments were meant to send a message, namely "that people who work hard and make the right decisions in life can achieve anything they want in America." In other words, the importance of the dark skins and female bodies of those early appointments was that they showed how unimportant dark skins and female bodies are in America. The blackness of Colin Powell is important in that it shows the unimportance of blackness. To judge from Angela D. Dillard's book, this is the essence of multicultural conservatism.
"Given the extent to which the conservative tradition in America was shaped by racialist and outright racist doctrines," Dillard notes, "by heterosexual-patriarchal notions of gender and family and by xenophobic influences, the existence of African-American, Latino, women and homosexual conservatives is that much more fascinating." As her language indicates, Dillard, who teaches history and politics at the Gallatin School at New York University, writes within the style current among younger, left-liberal humanities scholars -- a timorous style that often sacrifices verve to caution, advancing gingerly toward rather legalistic formulations about human reality. Her choice of the word "fascinating" is also telling. Dillard makes it clear that she disagrees with conservatism, but she tries, successfully, to suspend judgment in presenting conservative arguments.
"Guess Who's Coming to Dinner Now?" is more valuable for its information than for its arguments. Dillard economically traces the roles of racial activism, feminism and gay liberation as foils and inspirations for neoconservatism, the New Right, the Moral Majority and the Christian Coalition. She meanwhile keeps an eye on the relations between these fired-up groups and the Republican Party, which they have sought to make their mainstream vehicle. Against this backdrop, Dillard analyzes the famous (Clarence Thomas, Linda Chavez), the obscure (Elizabeth Wright's black conservative newsletter, Issues and Views) and the in-between (the memoirs of the gay conservative Marvin Liebman).
Her main inquiries concern blacks and gays, the groups that represent the greatest threat to conservative colorblindness and family values. Blacks, in the conservative view Dillard presents, are the definitive race, and so the greatest obstacle to colorblindness and race-free individualism. Homosexuals, similarly, are the definitive nonheterosexuals -- yes, there is a circularity at work here -- and so the chief obstacle to a pleasing stability of male and female social roles. As Dillard persuasively shows, antigay feeling (and a related antifeminism) has been the cement, along common-enemy lines, for a cross-racial conservatism. And a certain distancing from blacks has helped to unite nonblack conservative groups. Blacks have not, like gays, quite served as a common enemy. But placing one's group at a distance from blacks, especially the black urban poor, has provided a common bond.
Dillard also takes some quiet glee in pointing out that the special legitimacy of prominent conservatives who are not straight white men derives from the "identities" they supposedly don't want or consider trivial. Clarence Thomas is black, Linda Chavez is female and at least nominally Hispanic, Andrew Sullivan is gay. Their opinions on issues relating to the groups with which they are identified gain credibility for autobiographical reasons. Dillard devotes one of her most absorbing chapters to conservative autiobiography.
I wish she had pushed at this point a little harder, because it hints at a neglected aspect of American history. Every one of the groups Dillard discusses has a long tradition of conservative separatism. African-Americans have sought various forms of protective isolation, informed by cultural conservatism, since the Revolution. The separate black church, though a complex and frequently riven institution, can be considered conservative, as can many of the Hispanic, Chinese, Korean and other "ethnic" churches. There have been many moments in the history of feminism when a separate, distinct female nature and heritage were considered worth conserving. And was that a gay ghetto we just passed, or a gay paradise? Leaving aside the question of straight white men, conservative identity politics is not an oxymoron or a subject for light irony. It is a longstanding fact of American life. And I would note in passing that multiculturalism, in the form of cultural determinism, has become fashionable in American foreign-affairs circles as well, following the early leads of Samuel Huntington, Francis Fukuyama and Robert Kaplan, among others. Here again, multiculturalism is not a new idea nor can it be considered left or liberal. 
There are glimmers of these American conservative traditions in "Guess Who's Coming to Dinner Now?" when, for instance, Dillard notes the debates in the 1930's among Mexican-Americans over whether to continue culturally separate and conservative institutions or to integrate. She also mentions the seeming paradox of black conservatives being against school integration. If anything, black conservatives, in Dillard's broad sampling, have at least as low an opinion of white people as their more leftward peers. The much-demonized "civil rights establishment" is daily accused, as the current ugly phrase has it, of crying Selma. But Dillard's conservatives go on about the federal government's "plantation" and the welfare "slave trade" and civil-rights-establishment "overseers." It is not so much that these black conservatives adore white conservatives as that they have expanded the scope of their rage to include white liberals. George Schuyler, the pre-eminent midcentury black conservative intellectual, described whites' belief in their superiority as "unalterable." This was, in a way worth pondering, a conservative statement.
I suspect Dillard neglects the deep roots of nonwhite, nonheterosexual and nonmale conservatisms in part because she fears that too much historical texture might give them legitimacy. Another reason may be that Dillard avoids considering white conservatism as such -- that is, how white conservatives have understood themselves in racial terms as opposed to how they have understood others in racial terms. To have added material specifically on white Americans might have made it easier to put nonwhite conservatism in context.
Beyond that, the emphasis of conservatism after the 60's was on changing rather than on preserving the status quo. It has often been remarked that conservatism over the past three decades has embraced free-market capitalism, a force that is about the worst enemy cultural conservatism can have (and against which generations of Southern white conservatives struggled). Less frequently noted is that evangelicalism, which Dillard identifies as, "arguably, the mainstream religion," is also not conservative in any preservationist sense; on the contrary, it wants to rock your soul. One of the few genuinely American traditions guarded by contemporary conservatives is to prevent the overreaching of the state -- which is, of course, a liberal idea, perhaps the liberal idea.
As for cultural inclusion, there is no conservative tradition to defend. There are traditions of cultural diversity. Arguments for slavery and segregation and expulsion of Native Americans and against woman suffrage all contended, in various ways, for the honoring, or at least acceptance, of cultural differences. But there is no conservative tradition of inclusion, and so, funnily enough, the Bush cabinet appears to demonstrate that it is the conservative party that doesn't have a past, has indeed broken with the past. While I wish that she had spent more time examining the true histories of American conservatism, Angela D. Dillard has contributed greatly to that work. It is a particularly necessary effort now, because while the Republican Party may think it has broken with the past, I expect the American past is not done yet with the Republican Party, or with any of us.

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Nonfiction 

BYLINE:  By David Gartner 

 BODY:
 THE RACE TO THE BOTTOM
Why a Worldwide Worker Surplus and Uncontrolled Free Trade Are Sinking American Living Standards.
By Alan Tonelson.
Westview, $25.
 Alan Tonelson opens on the streets of Seattle, where protesters startled the nation and provoked a national debate about globalization. Tonelson sides with the protesters in arguing that globalization has "plunged the great majority of U.S. workers into a great worldwide race to the bottom." Despite the booming American economy, he writes, in the past three decades real hourly wages have fallen for a majority of American workers and declined by 31 percent for those without a high school diploma. Tonelson, a research fellow at the United States Business and Industry Council, challenges many economists who contend that technological change is more to blame than trade. As corporations relocate factories to the developing world, he argues, competition with low-wage workers weakens the bargaining power of American workers, not only in low-wage manufacturing but increasingly in high-tech industries as well. Tonelson makes a strong case that the effect of outsourcing on American workers has generally been understated. Less persuasive is his proposed solution. Offering an essentially nationalist vision, Tonelson calls for the United States to dictate the terms of trade and to slow imports from the developing world rather than cooperate in global rule making. He also proposes that trade be linked to international labor and environmental standards that can help American workers by improving global working conditions. Although "The Race to the Bottom" fails to examine any positive aspects of globalization, it is provocative and should lead to further debate about how we should engage the global economy. David Gartner

HEADLINE: Please Take Our Children Away 

BYLINE:  By Mary Rogan; Mary Rogan is a writer who lives in Toronto.

 BODY:
Late last fall, in a remote village in the north of Labrador, native leaders took the extraordinary step of asking the government to take their children away. "The safety of these children is the paramount issue," explained Paul Rich, Innu tribal chief, in a statement to the provincial government requesting the removal of nearly two dozen of the village's children. "The ongoing situation is drastic, and we need to take drastic measures," the plea continued. "We insist that these children be taken into care immediately."
 The children, residents of the village of Sheshatshiu, where 1,200 of the 2,000 members of Labrador's Innu Nation live, are addicted to sniffing gasoline. On most days before Rich's plea, they would stagger along the desolate gravel roads, beginning at dusk, sniffing gas from garbage bags and making their way to a camp deep in the woods outside of town. There, in groups as large as 40 or 50, they'd sniff gas until dawn. As the light broke through the trees, they'd shuffle through subzero temperatures toward home or the detox center in town, where they'd sleep off the effects of the gas. Some would vomit or pass out, and according to local health workers, several had become brain-damaged from the gas. In the past year, one 11-year-old boy died after setting himself on fire, and half a dozen others were severely burned after accidentally going up in flames. 
 The Innu trace their problems with poverty and substance abuse to government relocations that forced them to give up their nomadic way of life. They also attribute their current state to the chronic physical and sexual abuse their children suffered when they were forced to attend Christian residential schools from the 1950's through the 1970's. Today, more than half the 300 children in Sheshatshiu between the ages of 5 and 14 have sniffed gasoline, and at least 20 percent are regular users. It is a community where half of the adults are addicted to alcohol, 42 percent have thought actively about killing themselves and 28 percent have attempted suicide. 
In Davis Inlet, the other Innu community in Labrador, more than 200 miles north of Sheshatshiu, the statistics are even grimmer. Ninety of the 154 Innu children there are chronic gas sniffers, and children as young as 6 have sniffed gas at least once. The London-based human rights group Survival International calls the Innu, whose suicide rate is 13 times as high as that of the rest of Canada, "the most suicide-ridden people in the world."
The provincial government of Newfoundland, which governs Labrador, responded swiftly to Rich's request. Three days after the plea, on Nov. 20, government social workers were flown in to Sheshatshiu to assess the gas-addicted kids. With help from Innu community workers, social workers went door to door talking to parents about the plan to take their children from them and assuring them they would be taken to a place where they would be cared for. "Most of the parents understood what was happening and agreed with our decision," explained Paul Rich. "There were a few who didn't. But there was nothing else we could do. If the parents can't take care of these kids, we can't leave them in the cold to sniff and die." On Nov. 21, anxious parents huddled in the dark outside the town's alcohol-treatment center, waiting for a bus that would take 21 of the most seriously addicted children to a military base in Goose Bay, 25 miles down the road. Inside, the children were distracted with treats of soda and chips and the promise of pizza once they got to Goose Bay. Peter Penashue, the president of the Innu Nation, was there, talking with parents and telling them that everything was going to be O.K. "I looked at the kids and thought, We've come a long way in 50 years to fall this far," he would tell me later. "The sadness overwhelmed me." 
When the bus arrived around 7 p.m., the children were taken out one at a time so that they wouldn't run off. As it pulled away, they smiled and waved out the windows like Fresh Air Fund kids leaving the city for a summer in the Catskills. 
In Goose Bay, they were held in a barracks where half a dozen social workers cared for them. But beyond helping the children detoxify, the government has made it clear it has no long-term solution for them if they return to their ravaged community. Marilyn McCormack, the provincial director for Child, Youth and Family Services, says that in her 23 years as a social worker, the plight of the children of Sheshatshiu is among the worst she has ever seen. 
At first, the children were agitated and nauseated coming off the gas, and social workers could do little beyond providing the basics for them: food, clothing, lots of juice to satisfy the intense thirst that was a symptom of their detoxing. When they began to talk, what they said was hair-raising. They described beatings and sexual abuse at the hands of their relatives. They talked about wondering each day whether they would get dinner at night, about seeing their parents get drunk and beat each other, about witnessing suicides and friends setting themselves on fire. They spoke in monotones, and it's this deadness that McCormack found especially horrifying. "My children couldn't survive what these children have survived," she said. "I don't know if I could survive. And yet they have so little expectation that anything will change." 
Of the 21 children taken from Sheshatshiu in late November, 19 are still in the care of the government, and they are expected to be moved into foster homes or alternate living arrangements. Two of them have returned to Sheshatshiu.
In Davis Inlet, the transfer of gas-addicted children to the authorities has been considerably more difficult. Unlike Paul Rich in Sheshatshiu, Simeon Tshakapesh, the chief in Davis Inlet, has insisted on negotiating with the government before handing over the children. Tshakapesh has been accused by individuals in the government and in the Innu community of holding the children hostage to larger Innu demands -- requesting more money for Innu social services and demanding that treatment programs be run by Innu counselors who will emphasize native culture. One government official who insisted on anonymity said that the Innu in Davis Inlet also requested a guarantee that if doctors discovered the children had been sexually abused, no charges would be brought against the parents.
The degradation of the lives in Davis Inlet is impossible to exaggerate. There are about 100 houses there that are little more than shacks, their doors torn from the hinges and windows smashed. Several snowmobiles, from which children often steal gas, appear to have been set on fire, and outside of every house are mountains of garbage that have been tossed out of windows. The Royal Canadian Mounted Police office, at the foot of the village, is home to three officers, who, because of the stress of being here, work two-week rotations and then fly out for two weeks. 
The R.C.M.P. officers told me I wouldn't have to go far to find children sniffing gas. They're easy to spot, one of them said, because they don't put their arms in the sleeves of their coats. They hug the bags close to their chests and draw the fumes up through the collars of their jackets. The officers also said that sniffing gas is not illegal in Davis Inlet, so they are not allowed to take the bags away from the children. "All we can do is put them out when they set themselves on fire," one officer added.
Outside, about 200 yards from the police office, the road was full of armless zombies. Their sleeves swung loosely at their sides, and their chins were tucked tight to their chests. No one looked to be more than 10 years old. I expected they would run away from a stranger, but they approached me eagerly. When I asked the smallest boy if he was sniffing gas, he laughed and said, "Yeah." The air was saturated with the smell of gasoline, and the children shuffled along in large groups and in lonely pairs. When they spotted the photographer who was traveling with me, they laughed and pushed one another aside to get into the frame, shrieking: "Take my picture, I sniff gas. Take my picture, I sniff gas."
In mid-December, the federal government reached an agreement with the Innu of Davis Inlet. In return for the construction of a detox center in Labrador and a continued commitment to restoring Innu culture, social workers could fly in before the end of the month to assess the situation, and the government could take the gas-addicted children to a facility in St. John's, Newfoundland, at the beginning of the new year. 
On Jan. 9, 16 of the community's most seriously gas-addicted children, ranging in age from 10 to 18, were flown to St. John's. 
To date, 40 children have been removed from the town and put into treatment. Of the addicted children still in Davis Inlet, it's unclear what, if anything, will be done for them. At the time I write this, the temperature has dipped to minus 50 degrees Fahrenheit, and there are five feet of snow on the ground. The police officers are taking turns patrolling all day and night, trying to keep the gas-sniffing children from freezing to death.

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE; 
He Captured The Soul Of Silence

BYLINE:  By DEBORAH SOLOMON; Deborah Solomon is the author of "Utopia Parkway: The Life and Work of Joseph Cornell" and a forthcoming biography of Norman Rockwell.

 BODY:
SOMETIMES the new sensation in the art world can be an old master. Just look at Johannes Vermeer, whose pictures of tranquil housewives have recently come into vogue. In 1995, in one of the most belated tributes in art history, Vermeer was given his first museum retrospective, which was seen in Washington and The Hague. In its wake, acts of homage keep proliferating; they include at least three novels and an opera from Amsterdam at Lincoln Center last summer ("Writing to Vermeer") in which the artist's comely wife belted out songs about art, love and the toxic effects of wet varnish. 
 And now we have "Vermeer and the Delft School," which opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday. You might not think of 17th-century Delft as the site of a radical art scene, but it did have Vermeer, a painter of such overwhelming genius that just being his neighbor was enough to get an artist into the show at the Met. It will round up 15 of Vermeer's paintings -- almost half of his impressively small output -- plus another 70 pictures by 29 of his great and not-so-great contemporaries. 
 What is it about Vermeer's pictures that allows them to speak so forcefully to the current moment? Perhaps it's a matter of noise, or its absence. At a time when we're inundated with a steady clatter of information, Vermeer offers refuge, rooms filled with the kind of intense silence that exists only in museums -- oops, make that monasteries.
Most of Vermeer's paintings are scenes of domestic life, and you can easily see him as a protofeminist. His women appear in rooms where they might read a letter, play a lute or sew a piece of white lace. Unlike earlier art icons -- the Mona Lisa, for instance, with her flirty smile and follow-you-anywhere gaze -- Vermeer's women are caught up in their own thoughts; they're self-sufficient and complete unto themselves. They can fairly be described as the first modern women in art because they're the first women to savor the pleasure of solitude.
That breakthrough could have happened only in 17th-century Holland, a secure, commerce-obsessed era when artists were no longer obliged to turn out scenes of saints and martyrs for local churches. Instead they painted genre scenes -- scenes of everyday life -- for a newly ascendant middle class. Suddenly, bony biblical personalities were out and chubby revelers at taverns were in, though Vermeer obviously had spiritual inclinations. His paintings import the emotional inwardness of early religious art into a mercantile age, while anticipating the modern taste that prefers introspection to action. 
Consider the Metropolitan Museum's "Young Woman With a Water Jug," that daydreamy picture from the 1660's. It shows a room where a woman stands in her royal-blue dress, gazing absently toward a window. Although she's holding a silver pitcher, her distracted expression suggests a suspension of her womanly duties. One imagines that she is taking a respite from a busy household, from bawling children and mounds of laundry. The space around her is a kind of clear fog -- deep, dense, enveloping -- and seems like an extension of her inner life. 
Vermeer's mass appeal is probably as large as van Gogh's, that other Dutchman with spiritual yearnings. For many of us, van Gogh's pictures were the ones that we fell in love with when we first started visiting museums. His high-strung, confessional tone has always appealed to adolescents, particularly those who are firmly convinced that they are the only isolated and poetic individual in their 11th-grade class. Vermeer's pictures, by contrast, are the emblematic pictures of our adulthood, when insanity no longer strikes us as desirable, and we crave quiet. No one captured silence more compellingly than Vermeer, with the exception, perhaps, of Giorgio Morandi, he of the humble gray bottles. 
Not that you can ever say definitively what's happening in Vermeer's paintings. "Girl With a Pearl Earring," which is in The Hague and did not travel to the Met exhibit, shows a girl in a blue turban glancing over her left shoulder, as if someone has just called her name. As she turns her face out of the shadows, the light catches the delicate luster of one of her white pearl earrings. Like other Vermeer female subjects, it is impossible to know who she is, where she is and what's going on. His paintings are narratives with missing plots, which is probably one reason that writers keep trying to sketch in the details. 
Among them is Tracy Chevalier, whose best-selling novel, "Girl With a Pearl Earring," invents an identity for the model in the painting of the same title. Here we meet Griet, a tilemaker's daughter from Delft who works as a live-in maid for the Vermeer family. Naturally, she falls madly in love with Vermeer, and her dusting and sweeping become suffused with desire. Yet she and Vermeer never consummate their relationship. He is presented as a sober, taciturn genius who thinks about nothing except Art, and the tone is one of muffled eroticism as Griet passionately grinds his pigments and tidies up around his easel.
"I don't think Vermeer was someone who would have hit on his models," said Ms. Chevalier, an American living in London. "There's a respect for women in his work that suggests he wouldn't have been lecherous."
It was inevitable. These postfeminist times demand a man as seemingly decent as Vermeer to fill the role of the artist-hero. Compared to Picasso, the archetypal modern artist who used his lovers as models and muses before discarding them like so many paint rags, Vermeer offers the illusion of integrity. His popularity may reflect a longing for a new type of artist: the gentleman artist, who keeps his hands to himself, or rather uses them exclusively to paint. 
In his own time, Vermeer was far less beloved than he is today. His life story, in which the gaps and omissions far outnumber the known facts, reads like a tale about a family man who was short on luck. Born in 1632, Vermeer never left his native Delft, a bustling town known mainly for its breweries, munitions plants and blue-and-white porcelain. He and his wife, Catharina Bolnes, had a typically large Dutch family, 10 children in all, and he did some art dealing on the side to make ends meet. Unlike his contemporary Rembrandt, an art star known throughout the Netherlands who relied on his many studio assistants to churn out portraits of the Dutch elite, Vermeer wasn't known outside of Delft. 
He died when he was 43, in serious debt, and his name was soon forgotten. He languished in obscurity for nearly 200 years, in part because his tiny output of just a few dozen pictures was not easily seen by arts patrons. In the days before museums, photography and the ready reproduction of images, artists who wanted their work to be widely known literally had to create enough work to fill the right walls; they gained exposure as their pictures appeared and reappeared in private collections and at auction.
Vermeer was finally rediscovered in the 1860's, though the reasons were not purely aesthetic. Theodore Thore, a French art critic and political radical, brought him international renown as a fellow leftie whose homey paintings seemed to ignore aristocrats and ennoble the daily life of the common man.
When did viewers finally wake up to the aesthetic perfection of Vermeer's pictures? Certainly by 1913, when Proust brought out "Remembrance of Things Past." The novel includes a scene in which Swann, a cultivated flaneur, is beseeched by his mistress, Odette, to meet her every week for tea. He wants out, and Vermeer is his alibi. ("He had pleaded pressure of work, an essay -- which, in reality, he had abandoned years ago -- on Vermeer of Delft.") Odette protests that she has never heard of Vermeer and asks whether he is still alive. The comment is intended to mark her as a ditz.
Vermeer has meant different things to different generations. While 19th-century intellectuals saw him as a defender of democratic ideals, 20th-century intellectuals saw him as a father of abstract painting. For much of the last century, formalist critics considered it taboo to discuss Vermeer's subject matter. They praised his pictures for their geometry of design and viewed him chiefly as a forerunner of Mondrian, who distilled Vermeer's orderly rooms into the Grid, that fabled rectilinear trademark of modernism. 
But such a classic formalist approach, which ignores the subject matter of a painting, now seems arrogant and incomplete. Vermeer wouldn't have the huge following that he does if, instead of women, he had painted bowls of fruit or highly refined flower pictures, as so many Dutch artists of his era did. His work has enormous appeal to the untrained eye, which isn't just a Philistine reaction. For all his superb technical facility -- the fine motor control that allowed him to cut facets of light and engrave reflections -- the response he inspires is essentially visceral: His radiant housewives move us because they're secularized madonnas, the Virgin Mary in a string of pearls, ensconced in a parlor with a checkerboard floor.
Vermeer has traditionally been described as the artist who took realism to its greatest heights. As everyone knows, he was interested in optics and experimented with a camera obscura, an apparatus that may account for both the blurred edges and photographic sharpness of his images. Even so, he had an idealizing imagination, and real life never looked quite like one of his domestic scenes. Real women are not as serene as the ones he painted, and real rooms are not nearly so calming (nor so dust-free). 
These days, the trend in art history is to downplay an artist's creative will in favor of social and political forces, and the Met show is no exception. It will ask us to consider a new Vermeer -- Vermeer the local guy, a colleague of Pieter de Hooch, Carel Fabritius, Emanuel de Witte and some two dozen other denizens of Delft. The show, according to a Met press release, will cast Vermeer in a fresh light by emphasizing the role played by "the sophisticated patrons of Delft" in a very 1990's effort to trace stylistic developments to economic factors.
Context is always enlightening, and it will be interesting to see whether the Met show succeeds in reinventing Vermeer as a product of his time. Yet to do so would be to flatten his genius, and I suspect we will continue to see him in more personal and ahistorical terms. To me, he's the painter who honored the sovereignty of women by giving them their own space -- pictorial space, that is. His paintings are beautiful to the eye because they bring us life as glimpsed through his eyes, eyes that found infinite pleasure in the sight of a room where a woman stands silently by a window.

HEADLINE: THEATER; 
A Troupe That Sought An Asian-American Role

BYLINE:  By DON SHEWEY 

 BODY:
THE Joseph Papp Public Theater's production of "Dogeaters" may be the most prominent showcase of Filipino talent in New York since Lea Salonga was cast in the title role of "Miss Saigon." But the community of actors appearing in Jessica Hagedorn's play didn't spring up overnight. It has been cultivated in large part by the Ma-Yi Theater Company, the 12-year-old Off Off Broadway group specifically devoted to developing plays about the Filipino-American experience.
 Founded in 1989 by six former students at the University of the Philippines, Ma-Yi has dedicated the current season to two plays by the widely admired 33-year-old playwright Han Ong, who in 1997 was the youngest artist (and the first Filipino-American) to receive a MacArthur Foundation "genius" grant. 
 The season opened in September with "Middle Finger," Mr. Ong's adaptation of Frank Wedekind's "Spring Awakening." A tough-minded portrait of the emotional and sexual torments facing two Filipino-American boys in a Roman Catholic school, the play was directed by Loy Arcenas, who is best known as an award-winning set designer. 
The cast included several gifted actors currently appearing in "Dogeaters" -- Ching Valdes-Aran, Mia Katigbak and Jojo Gonzalez -- as well as a number of fine younger actors, including Ramon de Ocampo, Orlando Pabotoy and Michi Barall (who is not Filipino but half-Japanese). In May, Mr. Arcenas will direct Ms. Valdes-Aran in Mr. Ong's new play, "The Watcher," a noir esque excursion into pre-Disney Times Square. The coalescence of so much seasoned talent in one place has made Ma-Yi one of New York's emerging theaters to watch. 
Ma-Yi takes its name from the pre-colonial name for the Southeast Asian islands that the Spanish named the Philippines. The company has its origins in the political turmoil that swept the country in the final years of the Marcos dictatorship. "We developed a theater company called Godabil that used vaudeville expressionism as a way of doing street protests," said Ralph B. Pena, who was one of the founders of Ma-Yi and has served as artistic director since 1994. "We got to perform in huge rallies for a million people, until the military started noticing our work." Mr. Pena said he was called to the office of Army intelligence and questioned; three weeks later, at the urging of his parents, he left the country. 
After finishing school at the University of California at Los Angeles, Mr. Pena landed in New York. By chance he reunited with some Godabil colleagues at a gay bar in Greenwich Village, and commiserated with them about the difficulties of finding work in the theater as an Asian-American actor. "I'd been working as an actor in New York and the regional theaters, mostly in American plays," he said over breakfast at Time Cafe in the Village before a "Dogeaters" rehearsal. "Or, I'd be the token nonwhite in Shakespeare or Chekhov, if the director felt adventurous. I got cast as Chinese, and I played a Korean. You never get to play your own ethnicity. Filipinos especially feel that. That got tiring."
At the time, Tisa Chang's Pan Asian Repertory, which itself had evolved from Ellen Stewart's embrace of international theater at La Mama E.T.C., offered the only major casting opportunities. So Mr. Pena and his Filipino friends decided to start their own company.
"At first, we asked writers we knew from the Philippines to send us material, and we translated it," Mr. Pena said. "But we quickly figured out that it didn't have the same resonance for people living here and that we needed to focus on Filipino-American writers if we could. There were only a handful of them. In the beginning, it was strictly looking at the immigrant experience of Filipino- Americans. Now, as with a lot of Asian-Americans, the second wave of writers aren't so focused on that particular story. If you look at Diana Son's 'Stop Kiss,' there are no Asian markers in that play. We're looking for plays that have more to say than 'I came here, and I got lost.' "
Like many idealistic young companies, Ma-Yi had its stumbles. After producing its first show for $1,500 in the auditorium of Local 1199, the union for medical workers on West 43rd Street in Manhattan, Ma-Yi rented the Astor Place Theater, opposite the Public Theater, for the next show and spent $30,000, which nearly capsized the company. 
Jorge Ortoll, a Columbia University business major and real estate manager, came on board in 1992 as executive director to provide economic stability. What really got the company on its feet was bringing in Mr. Arcenas to direct Mr. Pena's play "Flipzoids" in 1996. Born in the Philippines and trained in London, Mr. Arcenas had become one of the busiest and most respected set designers Off Broadway, so when he launched his directing career at Ma-Yi, he made sure that colleagues at the Public Theater, the Manhattan Theater Club, New York Theater Workshop and other theaters came to see his work.
"He created a buzz around the company among theater insiders," Mr. Pena said, and this industry stature led to grants that helped the company sustain itself.
Mr. Arcenas said: "Theater is about acting. The reason I started working with Ma-Yi was that when we were doing 'Flipzoids' we had a difficult time casting the boy. From that time on, I decided that I would pay specific attention to Asian-American actors and see what it's like to give them a chance to blossom.
"When we did 'Middle Finger' last year, the pool of interesting young actors had already widened by a big margin. It's comforting to know, but also disheartening because they're really given very few chances to take big roles. You don't become Hamlet because you're given the role. You have to build your stamina. You have to go through a lot of performances until you can be secure in such a lead role. People have to exercise the muscles."
Ms. Valdes-Aran is the kind of performer Mr. Arcenas is referring to. She has become one of the hardest-working actors in New York. In the last year alone, she has performed on Broadway in "The Wild Party," in Central Park in "Julius Caesar" and in the National Asian-American Theater Company's production of "The House of Bernarda Alba," as well as "Middle Finger" and "Dog eaters."
But it has been a long slow climb to this peak of employment. When she moved to New York from the Philippines in 1967, she worked as a dancer until 1980 and then tried to make her way as an actress. She was cast in David Henry Hwang's "Sound and Beauty" at the Public Theater in 1983, but roles for Asian women were few and far between. She gained experience by working (mostly for free) in colorblind productions staged by downtown directors like John Vaccaro, John Jesurun and David Greenspan. With the advent of Ma-Yi and its sister group, the National Asian-American Theater Company, she was able to undertake leading roles and show what she could do. She won an Obie Award for her performance in "Flipzoids." 
In 1989 Mia Katigbak was also a frustrated, underemployed actress. With Richard Eng, she founded the National Asian-American Theater Company to give Asian-American actors opportunities "to do the repertory we're not allowed to -- European and American classics done straight," she said. "When we're cast out of tokenism, or we do it in a Chinese accent or Japanese accent, that perpetuates stereotypes."
The company has earned critical praise for its productions of plays as disparate as "Long Day's Journey Into Night," "You Can't Take It With You" and William Finn's "Falsettoland."
A commitment to breaking cultural misconceptions and planting the seeds of cross-cultural understanding is what makes the National Asian-American Theater Company and Ma-Yi sister troupes. "We hold joint auditions sometimes and consult each other," Mr. Pena said.
"Ten years ago," he continued, "I could not cast a six-character Filipino-American play with all Filipinos. I like to think we had some small part in developing the talent pool, because it has grown. And we have a core audience of people who have stayed with us as we slowly got riskier with the work. Every time, people say, 'I can't believe you did that.' I hope they keep saying it."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
Villagelike Complex to Replace 320-Acre Farm

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THOUGH a 320-acre former dairy farm along Route 31 in Washington Township in Warren County has been eyed for residential development since the mid 1980's, not a single house has been built. But new owners, working with township officials, have carved part of the site into an 18-hole golf course and now plan to build a villagelike complex of 120 homes and 100,000 square feet of commercial space. 
 The first phase of building construction will be 96 detached and 24 attached houses, which will rise adjacent to the 250-acre golf course, Hawk Pointe, which opened last June. The residences are for active adults age 55 and older and offer social and recreational facilities and maintenance services like lawn mowing or snow clearance. 
 The $40 million housing component, the Reserve at Hawk Pointe, will be on 30 acres of the wooded site, which looks out at Point Mountain and is near Interstate 78. Pinnacle Communities of Millburn will develop the homes with the developer of the golf course, an investment partnership led by Richard Cotton of Franklin Township. Construction is expected to start this summer. 
Both groups will develop the commercial portion once two-thirds of the homes are built. The plan is for the retail stores and professional offices to be linked to the housing by walking paths.
The residential project is among the first active adult housing developments in the northern half of New Jersey. Such projects had previously been concentrated in Ocean and Monmouth Counties. It reflects a way to allow development with minimal adverse impact on the quality of life of existing residents, officials from the township and building team said. 
During the mid-80's, a developer proposed building 2,600 units on the site and sued the township under the state's Mount Laurel doctrines when his plan was rejected. (Under the doctrines every New Jersey municipality must zone some land for residences for low-income people. If not, they are vulnerable to lawsuits by builders seeking to build high-density projects.)
By the end of that decade a settlement was reached, reducing the number of homes to 350 and requiring the developer to contribute money to the township's affordable housing plan. But by then the developer had gone bankrupt and the site was taken back by the lender. 
In 1996 after a sale of the site to another housing developer fell through, the bank sold it for $1.25 million to the partnership led by Mr. Cotton, who owns a farm in neighboring Franklin and is involved in preservation efforts in the area. He said that after he had been unable to secure public money to preserve the Washington farm, he began working with the township, which by then had met its Mount Laurel obligation, "to develop the site in an economically, environmentally and socially" responsible manner. After a year of negotiations the township rezoned the site for the current project. 
"We would rather see the farm, but the golf course is better than more houses," said Michael A. Kovacs, a member of the township council and a former mayor. "This is the best compromise." The township also "negotiated for active-adult housing" because it will not have an impact on schools; and it also had considerable "input into the design of the project," Mr. Kovacs said, adding that the traditional-style houses will blend with the area.
INDICATIVE of the growing antisprawl sentiment in the state in recent years Washington, like other towns, has put in place more restrictive zoning. It has increased the size of residential lots in certain areas to four or five acres from two "to preserve the township's rural atmosphere," Mr. Kovacs said. It has also acquired 1,526 acres for open space and is working to preserve 300 more. 
Development in western New Jersey, as in other rural areas, is expected to become more constrained because the state is buying one million acres over the next decade. And through various initiatives, it is encouraging growth in urban areas, where utilities, roads and mass transit are in place. 
Mary Boorman, director of sales and marketing at Pinnacle, said her company became involved with the Washington Township project because the zoning was in place and "there are not many opportunities available to build an active-adult community on a golf course." 
With selling prices expected to range from just under $300,000 to just under $400,000, the homes at the Reserve at Hawk Pointe, each with 2,200 to 3,000 square feet, are considered big and expensive by market standards. The project is also one of the first high-priced adult communities in a part of the state known for its affordability.
William E. Becker, a housing consultant in Teaneck who focuses on active adult communities, said there are 5,500 adult housing units under way or planned in the state. The average unit costs $200,000, he said.
Among the most expensive are the 120 attached homes at the Four Seasons at Chester, which the K. Hovnanian Companies of Red Bank, the state's largest developer, is building on 60 acres off Old Chester-Gladstone Road in Chester Township in Morris County. In the year since sales began, 76 of the 2,100 to 2,900 square foot homes have been sold at prices of $389,950 to $456,950, Michael Villane, vice president of sales and marketing at Hovnanian, said most buyers are adding some $80,000 in upgrades to the houses. In general, he said, the buyers are scaling down from larger and more expensive homes in the area. 
Jeffrey Otteau, president of the Otteau Appraisal Group in East Brunswick, said there is a demand for bigger and more costly active adult houses and "the demographics are certainly in place to support it." 
STATE figures show that baby boomers -- people born between 1946 and 1964 -- make up 2.8 million of the New Jersey's 8.1 million population, about 35 percent. This year the first wave of boomers will turn 55. 
There are other factors stoking the active adult market and by extension the luxury end of it, developers and housing professionals said. Among them are that today people over age 55 have more money and prefer to retire closer to where they once lived or where their children live.
They are also able to sell their homes at a profit, John G. Udell, president of Weichert New Homes and Land in Morris Plains, said, adding that "they will continue to do well unless there is some economic catastrophe." 
Still, Mr. Otteau and Mr. Becker said the challenge for the Reserve at Hawk Pointe is not its concept, but its rural location. The question, both said, is whether it will support the project's high prices.
Though the median price of existing homes in Washington is $185,000, according to township figures, new single-family houses are selling in the $200,000 to $300,000 range. And just across the border in Franklin Township, Toll Brothers Inc. of Huntingdon Valley, Pa., among the state's larger developers, is building 80 homes with 3,000 to 4,000 square feet and set on at least one acre lots, priced from $387,000 to $454,000. Since sales began at late in 1999, 37 homes have been sold and prices have been raised $70,000 to the current level, said Wayne Patterson, a senior vice president at Toll.
He said while the prices may seem high for the area, they are $100,000 less than those for similar homes in closer-in Hunterdon County. 
That is also expected to be the case at the Reserve at Hawk Pointe, Ms. Boorman said, adding "we are creating a community and in turn value." 
A new home of equal size on a golf course in closer-in affluent communities in Somerset County would cost at least $200,000 more, if there was land available to build it, she said, stressing the lack of available alternatives in north Jersey. 
The market, she added, will be couples in Somerset, Morris and Hunterdon counties who are scaling down from homes worth $400,000 to $500,000 or more, but who do not want to compromise on size and open space or to migrate to south Jersey. She noted there are more than 100,000 people age 65 or older with median yearly income above $70,000 living in those three counties.
At the Reserve at Hawk Pointe the single-family detached homes will sit on relatively small lots of 7,000 to 9,000 square feet, with the larger ones backing up to the golf course or woodlands. Lots directly on the course carry a $50,000 premium. The attached houses will be in eight buildings, each with three units. 
All the one- and two-story residences will have two-car garages and front porches and the master bedroom will be on the first floor in most models. They will be clad in a combination of shingle, brick and stone. 
In addition to the golf course, planned amenities include a clubhouse and outdoor pool. Monthly maintenance fees, though not yet set, are expected to be almost $200 a month, Ms. Boorman said, adding that she expected to start preconstruction sales this spring and to take three years to complete the homes.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Westbury; 
A Tone of Small Lots, Trees and Diversity

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
AS the national economy has wobbled, the real estate market in the conveniently located, moderately priced cosmopolitan village of Westbury in central Nassau County has remained strong.
 "The economy may have slowed down, but we didn't feel it," said Eric W. Jackson, the branch manager at Century 21 Laffey Associates in Westbury. "In January things just took off and really started moving. It's a very good market, for sellers at least." 
 In a village offering good rail and road connections and convenient shopping, the housing stock ranges from pre-World War I dwellings in the old downtown area that sell for more than $200,000 to Post-World War II Capes built by William Levitt in the years before he built Levittown to more recent colonials in the Wheatley Villa section, where prices may go above $500,000. 
There are two condominiums: the 126-unit Westbury Terrace and the 62-unit Maple Arms, where a two-bedroom unit recently sold for $190,000. At the Post House, which consists of 12 two-story buildings with a total of 145 co-op units, two-bedroom units cost about $60,000. Two-family houses that sell for more than $300,000 are in the Breezy Hill section, near Old Country Road.
But a small-lot, single-family home on a tidily kept, tree-lined residential street best defines the village, which is distinct from surrounding unincorporated areas also called Westbury and not to be confused with the neighboring Gold Coast village of Old Westbury, with its large lots, estates and median house prices of more than $1 million. 
Nancy Ann Jarvis, a broker at Daniel Gale Associates in East Hills, said a recently listed 71-year-old colonial in the west village -- generally defined as the part of the village west of Post Avenue -- was listed at $289,000 but drew interest from six potential buyers, who bid the price above $300,000.
It was the kind of house, Ms. Jarvis said, that seemed to hold the greatest attraction for current buyers. "The older houses are very much in vogue right now," she said. "People want the high ceilings, the fireplace." 
But it is also convenience that sells here, Ms. Jarvis and other real estate professionals said. "People are particularly attracted by the easy commute to the city," said Tom Seidl, an associate broker at Century 21 Prevete in Plainview.
The Long Island Rail Road carries commuters from the Westbury station to Manhattan in comfortably less than an hour. Northern State Parkway, a major east-to-west thoroughfare, cuts through the village. Jericho Turnpike (Route 25) and Old Country Road bracket it on the north and south.
Shops and services line Post Avenue, the village's spinal cord and main commercial street, which is close enough for many residents to reach on foot. Roosevelt Field, a regional shopping mall, is a five-minute drive away, and South Shore beaches are within easy range.
"Locationwise, it's terrific," said Barbara E. M. Krampitz, who moved to the village from Queens 30 years ago. "I can walk downtown for basic services, the railroad is right there, and people take very good care of their homes. It's a very pretty community."
Mrs. Krampitz is the director of the Westbury Children's Library, where programs for children up to 12 years old include story readings on the first Wednesday of each month. The library, with 18,000 volumes, is celebrating its 75th anniversary. The village's adult library, the Westbury Memorial Public Library, is next door.
THE village, which is in the town of North Hempstead, tends the roads and handles garbage collection. Nassau County provides policing. A village recreation center offers after-school programs for children. An adjacent village park, though small, has a playground and benches. The village also runs weekday programs for senior citizens at a community center on Post Avenue.
The village and surrounding areas, including neighboring New Cassel, has a greater degree of ethnic and economic diversity that many other areas of Nassau.
"Westbury is a very international community," said Ghazi Y. Khankan, the director of interfaith affairs and communications for the Islamic Center of Long Island, which is in the village. "It's a tolerant community. We have all races, many ethnicities, and many languages are spoken in the area." 
The Islamic center, which draws members from the estimated 70,000 Muslims residing in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, is the site of the only house of worship on Long Island built from the ground up as a mosque. It opened in 1991.
There are about 100 students in kindergarten through grade 8 at the center's Crescent School, where instruction is offered in Islamic history and Arabic as well as in traditional subjects. Fees on a sliding scale range from $300 to $450 a month.
Most of the village is in the 4,000-student Westbury Union Free School District, which also includes New Cassel. About 69 percent of the Westbury High School graduating class of 2000 went on to higher education, a low percentage for a public school in Nassau County. The most recent College Board scores averaged 437 on the verbal test and 440 in math, both considerably below state and national averages.
The district has an early childhood center for half-day pre-K and kindergarten classes, a separate school for grades 1 and 2, two elementary schools for grades 3 to 5, and a middle school for grades 6 through 8. The state named the Powell's Lane Elementary School for grades 3 to 5 a school of excellence this year. 
Last spring voters turned down a school budget that would have raised taxes by about 12 percent, an increase attributed in part to the fact that enrollment has gone up by 5 percent annually for the last several years. As a result of the defeat, the district is operating under an austerity budget for the current school year.
Dr. Joan Colvin, an assistant superintendent, said Westbury had been implementing the Comer educational reform model in all grades since 1998. The program, based on the work of Dr. James P. Comer, a psychiatrist at the Yale Child Study Center in New Haven, encourages active parent involvement in schools and builds programs around children's needs, Dr. Colvin said.
The district offers advanced placement courses in a number of subjects. A special music program encourages students to take up stringed instruments in elementary grades and culminates with high school students performing in a special spring concert with the Brooklyn Philharmonic.
A small western section of the village is in the Carle Place school district, where 96 percent of the graduates in the class of 2000 went on to higher education. Most recent averages for the College Board tests were 515 in verbal and 558 in math, both above state and national averages. The enrollment is 1,525. There are two schools for kindergarten to grade 2, an elementary school for grades 3 to 6, a middle school for grades 7 and 8 and a high school. Buyers pay a premium for village houses within the district. 
The Westbury Friends School, a culturally diverse Quaker elementary school on a 17-acre village campus, has an enrollment of 175 students ages 3 through 12 in programs ranging from a three-mornings-a-week nursery school for $4,049 to full-day classes in grades 1 through 6 for $8,454. The school has a computer center, art studio, gymnasium and new playground facilities. Class size is limited to 16 or less. The school, whose mission is to "create in each child a sense of self-worth and a respect for the worth of others," is open to all.
St. Bridget's School, a Roman Catholic school with 520 students, offers a program for 2-year-olds and their mothers, a nursery for 3-year-olds, a half-day prekindergarten program for 4-year-olds, and full-day classes for kindergarten through grade 8. The school declined to discuss tuition.
With the exception of a standout Little League field and a small park near Jericho Turnpike, the village has little open space. But a major outdoor area, Nassau County's Eisenhower Park, is just south of the village boundary.
In addition, the 150-acre Old Westbury Gardens is just to the north in the neighboring village of Old Westbury. It is open to the public from late April through October. Visitors there may go inside the Westbury House, the turn-of-the century Charles II style mansion of the financier and philanthropist John S. Phipps, and walk in a surrounding formal English garden. 
The Westbury Music Fair, also just beyond the village boundary in an unincorporated area of Westbury, offers a year-round schedule of music and entertainment. The March schedule includes concerts by Johnny Mathis; Andy Cooney, an Irish singer; and O-Town, a pop group. 
The area that includes the village was once part of the Hempstead Plains. Two English Quakers, Edmund Titus and Henry Willis, were the first European settlers in the 1650's, and Westbury, named after Willis's hometown in England in the county of Wiltshire, soon became a Quaker stronghold and meeting place.
It remained agricultural until the late 19th century, when the seriously rich arrived and built mansions in what is now Old Westbury and in other parts of Nassau that became known collectively as the Gold Coast. Commerce sprang up along Post Avenue to serve the estates, and gardeners and other estate workers moved in. The village incorporated in 1932 and exploded with new houses and residents in the 1950's.
In years that followed, the village and surrounding areas became known for ethnic and racial diversity. "It's always been a multiracial community, and that has always been one of the things I like about it," said Mrs. Krampitz, the children's library director.

Gretchen Haynes, the assistant clerk for the Westbury Meeting, said events would include a Sunday school pageant, historic presentations and the introduction of a Web site with historic documents and photographs commemorating the Quakers' long history in Westbury and other parts of Long Island. The original Westbury meetinghouse stood until 1801, when it was replaced by a larger building destroyed by fire in 1901. Mrs. Haynes said the current meetinghouse is on the same site as the earlier buildings. She said Quakers from Manhasset, Bethpage, Matinecock and Jericho gathered for meeting in Westbury beginning in 1671 and by the time of the American Revolution were the fourth-largest religious affiliation on Long Island. "Of course we're not fourth largest now," she said, adding that church membership had been growing. Names of Quaker families that once attended meetings in Westbury, including Post, Hicks, Willis and Albertson, survive in the names of roads and nearby communities.
