HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Connecticut; 
First Steps on Proposed Major Project in Norwalk

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
BEGINNING at the Maritime Aquarium in South Norwalk and running north along the Norwalk River, a linear park nearing completion overlooks an idyllic scene of swans mingling with Canada geese, seagulls and ducks as they bob for fish or waddle onto the wet shore.
 Reclaimed from 17 acres of rubble-strewn mud flats, scraggly uplands and the city dump, Heritage Park represents the first step in developing Riverwalk, a $350 million office complex that eventually is to include retail and residential elements. Riverwalk will cover 42 acres within Norwalk's Reed-Putnam urban renewal area of 70 acres bounded by Interstate 95, West Avenue, Washington Street and the river. 
 The project is within walking distance of the South Norwalk Metro-North station and directly off Exits 14 and 15 of Interstate 95. It is described by Joseph McGee, a vice president of the Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association in Stamford, a business organization for the part of Fairfield County that includes Norwalk, as just what the association advocates. "Growth eastward of Stamford," he said, "particularly in train station areas, takes the pressure off the highways." 
James Fagan, senior managing director of suburban real estate at the Stamford office of CB Richard Ellis, a real estate services company, calls Riverwalk "one of the best located projects in the county -- the best way to tap into the working population coming mostly from the north and east." His company will be the leasing agent for more than one million square feet of offices in the proposed complex. "There is a pent-up demand for office space of 100,000 to 300,000 square feet," he said.
Envisioned by the city in 1984 but sidelined by the recession, the scheme has the preliminary agreement of lawyers for the City of Norwalk and two developers: Fred F. French and the Spinnaker Companies, both of Stamford. Ahead lies a long succession of property acquisitions and applications to city boards and commissions and to city and state bonding authorities. Approval must also be obtained from the Norwalk Redevelopment Agency, which has oversight on everything within Reed-Putnam, named after two neighborhood streets. 
Gov. John G. Rowland has included in his budget a grant of $10 million a year over the next two years for infrastructure improvements to be made before construction can begin, including widening West Avenue by two lanes from Crescent Street to Garner Street and widening access and exit ramps at Exits 14 and 15 of Interstate 95. If approved by the Legislature, the first $10 million will become available this summer. 
The park, a work in progress for four years, will officially open in June at a cost of about $6.75 million in city, state and federal money. It contains a network of paved and rustic paths lined with trees, stylish street lights and an occasional information kiosk. A handsome fence encloses the lawns, and one riverside path ending at a large fishing pier will eventually be extended to downtown Norwalk, half a mile away. Encircling a hill over the capped landfill are ribbons of crushed clamshells soon to become borders for plantings of wildflowers. An amphitheater overlooking the river is planned, along with an ice-skating pond.
Timon Malloy, president of Fred F. French Investing L.L.C., has had an association with Reed-Putnam since the mid-80's. "We lived in Westport," he said, "and we were looking for new investment opportunities in the area." His late father, Edwin Malloy, president of the venerable Fred F. French real estate company in Manhattan, saw bad times coming and had liquidated French's portfolio of two million square feet of offices in New York and Georgia. 
"We started discussions with the city in 1986 but discontinued them until three years ago," Mr. Malloy said, "when we started talking again." Confident that current real estate fundamentals are sound, he said: "This is a long-term project. The deal will allow us to move forward now and for the next up cycle -- if there's a downturn."
With four acres acquired, he needs nine additional acres to make up three parcels on which he could build up to 1.15 million square feet of offices in four or five buildings with two levels of underground parking. Preliminary offers have been made to some of the almost two dozen homeowners and small businesses whose properties must be bought or taken by eminent domain, though no such acquisitions will actually be made until all approvals are in place. 
Compared with office rents of $40 to $45 a square foot a year in downtown Stamford, "we expect rents would be around $37.50," Mr. Fagan said, "including a first year charge of $1.50 a foot for taxes, insurance, janitorial services and heating that will increase in subsequent years." 
Al Mirin, a vice president at CB Richard Ellis, said, "French won't build prior to having a tenant." 
The conversion of a former 19th century lock factory opposite the aquarium is under way by Spinnaker. When completed, it will contain 100,000 square feet of offices and about 4,000 square feet of restaurant and retail space on the ground floor. The first tenants are expected to move in this spring as work continues on the building. The original interior brick walls and massive wood beams have been retained, and tenants will have two landscaped inner courtyards.
In partnership with Summit Development and Greenfield Partners of Westport, Spinnaker is also authorized to build 200 market-rate apartments overlooking the river, an unspecified amount of additional office space and shops and a full-service 200-room hotel on vacant land, according to Clay Fowler, president of Spinnaker. No details have been announced yet about this phase of the project. The partnership, called Maritime Place L.L.C., will invest about $100 million, while Fred F. French is to spend $250 million for environmental cleanup of its sites, demolition of existing buildings, relocation of displaced residents and businesses, land acquisition and construction costs. 
A five-story city-owned garage for about 720 cars to be built on North Water Street is intended to alleviate parking problems in the area, accommodating the aquarium and some office tenants. Jack Miller, Norwalk's chief financial officer, said an estimated cost of $11.5 million was authorized for the garage in the city's capital budget last year.
If all of the projects now under construction or planned in Norwalk come to fruition, the city could add close to two million square feet of new offices within the decade to the more than five million square feet it has now, filling what industry brokers generally estimate as pent-up demand for two million square feet of offices countywide. Some real estate professionals think some of the offices planned for Norwalk will be delayed or scaled back, although the city's vacancy rate for first class offices is currently 6 percent, a very low figure.
New construction in Norwalk includes a 255,000-square-foot building at Merritt 7 Corporate Park on Route 7, scheduled to open in the summer of 2002. The complex of 1.2 million square feet in five buildings was begun in 1978.
Sometime next month, after site plan modifications are approved, Building and Land Technologies, a development company based in Wilton, expects to start work on a 350,000-square-foot office building adjacent to Merritt 7, to be completed in the fall of 2002. "When we get some tenants for that building, we will start on a second 300,000-square-foot building on the same seven and a half acre parcel," said Carl Kuehner III, president of the development company. 
He recently completed Merritt on the River, a conversion of a 235,000-square-foot former Caldor's store on Glover Avenue into offices. "We build on spec with the help of lenders who are willing to spec with us," he said, noting that Merritt on the River is 95 percent leased. 
JUST north of Norwalk on Route 7 in Wilton, David Fiore, a senior vice president of the Davis Companies of Boston and Wilton, expects approval this month for Wilton Corporate Park on 30 acres. Two existing buildings are to be renovated and two new buildings are to be constructed for a total of 476,000 square feet of offices.
And at 20 Westport Road in Wilton, the Dreyfus Company's 335,000-square-foot building is 95 percent leased well before its scheduled opening in July. The tenants already signed up include News America Marketing Inc., a subsidiary of the News Corporation, with 110,000 square feet, and the Louis Dreyfus Corporation with 113,000. 
Meanwhile, two Stamford office buildings of almost 600,000 square feet each, proposed by the Dreyfus Company and Hines Interests and approved by the city three and four years ago, remain unbuilt. Dean J. Shapiro, executive director of Insignia/ESG in Stamford, said: "The issue is there's no single tenant out there that could fill the critical mass of 50 percent of the square footage to guarantee financing."
Mr. Fiore and many real estate professionals believe it will be years before ground is broken for Riverwalk's first building or for Blackrock, a similar $250 million office, housing and retail project with a new Metro-North train station in the town of Fairfield. "What's proposed and what's built are two different things," said Mr. Fiore. 
Edward Deak, professor of economics at Fairfield University, discounts such pessimism, saying: "We're looking at a vibrant marketplace in Connecticut, with unemployment down to 2 percent. All this space coming on line with no tenants tends to be a bit of a concern, but my prediction is that in January of 2002, everyone will be saying how surprisingly good things are."

HEADLINE: Deficit Hits Waterbury and Residents Try to Cope 

BYLINE:  By FRED MUSANTE

 BODY:
NO one should be faulted for leaving the tax collector's office in a funk, but in Waterbury, which recently levied special taxes to meet its municipal payroll, where the mill rate is poised to rise and residents have been hit with higher sewer fees, that is especially true.
 "I have heard complaints for years," said Christy Schade, a resident who had just left the tax collector's office on the first floor of Waterbury's city hall after paying her taxes one morning last month. "The taxes are outrageous." 
 Ms. Schade complained that residents of Waterbury pay higher taxes on their cars than taxpayers in other towns do, and that when the city was hit by a snowstorm in early February, no plows ever came down her street, stranding her at home. 
This has been a winter of discontent for residents in Waterbury, for whom those perennially favorite grievances, high taxes and questionable moves by city government, suddenly have reached Shakespearean proportions.
Since mid-November, each week seems to bring more, and worse, bad news. Although decades in the making, the city's financial crisis seems to have caught a majority of residents by surprise, leaving them stunned as deficits soared to a quarter of the total budget.
Next week, the State Legislature is expected to consider a state takeover of the city, including the establishment of a financial review board that would be similar to the ones imposed on Bridgeport in the 1980's and West Haven and Jewett City in the 1990's. It is a measure of Waterbury residents' anxiety that they are optimistic about the financial review board.
"We all have the same view that something has to be done," said Ms. Schade, reflecting the view of her fellow residents. "I am trying to get out of the city," she added. When her lease is up, she said she's moving to nearby Naugatuck or Watertown.
"You wouldn't print what I'd have to say," said another woman, who walked by declining further comment.
Waterbury has been limping along financially from month to month since November, when it was revealed that it had severe budget problems. Budget deficit estimates rose from $30 million to $40 million, to $50 million, and lately to $62 million, about a quarter of the city's $257 million budget.
To meet the city's December payroll, Mayor Philip A. Giordano borrowed nearly $20 million and levied a special 5.8-mill supplemental property and vehicle tax. The state also advanced Waterbury nearly $10 million in state education funding, which provided extra help.
According to a state government calculation, for the city to meet its budget obligations next year its mill rate would have to rise from the current rate of 74 mills to 111 mills, unless costs are cut somewhere. Stephen Markowski, a spokesman for Mr. Giordano, said a much lower tax increase was more likely, though the eventual amount depends on unknown factors including the size of union contract concessions, the powers a state oversight board might have to impose cost-cutting, and a revaluation of taxable property that is under way.
"We're looking at some mill rate increase, but it won't be 111 mills," Mr. Markowski said.
Mr. Giordano put the blame on previous mayors, who he said underfunded the city employees' pension fund for at least a decade and signed union contracts with what Mr. Giordano said were overly generous fringe benefits packages.
Then there are an imminent property assessment revaluation and a sewer fee that has more than doubled after a new sewer treatment plant opened last year. By state law, a revaluation was supposed to have been done in 1990, but the city was granted waivers by the state for eight consecutive years. Mayor Giordano has hired a company to perform one, but the prospect of a revaluation on top of a tax increase has just heightened the emotions of taxpayers.
City tax collection rates have historically been too low, but here again its bad luck held. A Florida company was hired to pursue delinquent tax collection liens, but the company itself went broke, tying up Waterbury's delinquent tax collections in federal bankruptcy court.
In the best of times, snowstorms are troublesome for Waterbury's narrow, hill streets, but the unexpectedly heavy storm on Feb. 5, which brought a foot and a half of snow, was especially tough. Although many residents, like Ms. Schade, thought the city's financial problems were to blame, Mr. Markowski, who also serves as the city's director of emergency management, said the storm's unusual fury, depositing up to four inches of snow per hour, was at fault. The financial problems did not affect snow plowing in that storm, he said.
In conversations with Waterbury residents about the city's fiscal difficulties, time and again their complaints were about the revaluation and the sewer fee, which has risen to an average of about $360 a quarter for a family of four.
Because they arrived in a bunch along with the fiscal problems, they seem to have had a combined psychological effect.
At Jimmy's Charcoal Kitchen, a luncheonette across the street from city hall, Dave Ryan, a postal worker, was at the counter picking up some coffees for himself and his co-workers when the subject of the supplemental property tax came up. The tax on his house and cars cost him $450 just a month after Christmas, he said.
"I have kids who have glasses and braces," Mr. Ryan said.
Like Ms. Schade, he would like to move out of Waterbury, but he can't. He bought his house in the northern Bucks Hill neighborhood 10 years ago for $110,000, but now he said he thinks he could only get about $80,000 because of the fiscal crisis. He said he wouldn't even break even.
Another customer, John Thursfield, moved to Naugatuck in December after he and his siblings sold their parents' house. Mr. Thursfield had lived in Waterbury for all of his 45 years, but said high taxes drove him away. The sewer bill was the last straw.
"We didn't want to live in Waterbury any more," he said, adding that he knows many other people who put their homes on the market.
Some people said landlords had also increased rents to help them recover their tax increases. At the West Main Barber Shop, Jimmy Crespo, who was getting his hair cut by Gino Rodriguez, said his landlord had raised his rent from $350 to $450 a month.
"I knew a couple of people who wanted to buy a house here," Mr. Rodriguez said. "Now they don't." 
Philip Nargi opened a restaurant, Circa Bistro, on Bank Street three weeks ago in one of the dozen commercial buildings he owns downtown. The supplemental tax cost him $13,000, he said, and combined with the sewer fee, the revaluation, and an impending tax increase for next year it all seemed too much to him.
"It's not good that we get hit with all of this all at once," Mr. Nargi said. "Where do they think all this money's going to come from? We're not in a high-income bracket here.
"I don't mind paying, but I don't think we should have a bomb dropped on us all at one time," he added.
Mr. Giordano said, however, that things are not as bad as they seem. The city's mill rate, tax increases, and rent increases should be put in perspective because Waterbury is one of the state's most affordable cities, he said. Its home prices and apartment rents are much lower than in other cities, and tax bills are based on 1979 property assessments and the bills average only $1,700 a year for a one-family house, he said.
"We were ranked No. 2 in the last Connecticut Magazine survey for the best bang for your buck in real estate," he said.
Many in the city are optimistic about its economic development prospects, which don't appear to have been affected by the municipal fiscal problems.
"There's almost a disconnect between what's happening and the business sector, which is doing quite good," said Bernard Lynch, president of the Greater Waterbury Chamber of Commerce. A new information technology zone, 40 blocks with access to fiber optic communication cables, is attracting high-tech businesses, he said.
Waterbury's two state senators, Stephen R. Somma, a Republican like the mayor, and Joan V. Hartley, a Democrat, both share the view of the mayor, the Chamber of Commerce, and many residents that the imposition by the state of a financial review board would be a positive step. It worked for other municipalities and it should work for Waterbury, too.
People expect to pay their fair share, but they expect accountability from city government, Ms. Hartley said. They hope to get that accountability through a state oversight board. Mr. Somma cautioned against rushing to blame either Mr. Giordano or the city unions for the problem.
"Everyone needs to be part of the solution," he said. "I think many people believe this in an opportunity to effect real change."

HEADLINE: Mohegans Deal a New Hand: A Fishery 

BYLINE:  By JOE WOJTAS

 BODY:
THE members of the Mohegan Indians tribe hope they will soon be recognized as much for their oysters and fish fillets as they are for their slot machines and blackjack tables.
 While public attention has been focused on the successful Mohegan Sun casino in Uncasville, the tribe is quietly entering the aquaculture business. 
 The Mohegans will soon purchase a lobster pound in Stonington with plans to raise oysters and clams. They will also raise tilapia, a fish raised extensively overseas, on up to a dozen farms in southeastern Connecticut.
The Mohegans also plan to build a processing plant to provide Mohegan Brand Seafood Products to upscale restaurants, many of them in the New York City area, as well as to supermarkets and to the casino's restaurants. 
The diversification from gambling into fish farming is not that much of a stretch for the Mohegans, whose ancestors survived by eating fish and clams from Long Island Sound and the Thames River.
"Shellfish and finfish have always been a part of out history," said David Fowler, a tribe member who is also a tribal planner. "In modern times we wanted to get some of that back so aquaculture seemed like a good way to go."
This is not the tribe's only current effort to diversify. The Mohegans recently obtained permission from the state to sell telephone service.
Leo Chupaska, the Mohegan chief financial officer, said the Tribal Council was constantly reviewing proposals for new business ventures.
"Gambling is the economic engine that gets us the bucks but we want to do different things," he said.
Mr. Fowler added that "diversity has always been part of our plan." 
"I know a lot of tribes say that but it's usually just hollow words," he said. "We've always wanted to pursue different ventures and evaluate different ideas."
Soon after the tribe opened its casino in 1996, Mr. Fowler said it began to consider establishing an aquaculture program. Other projects took priority, he said, and the aquaculture effort was put on the back burner.
"We got to the point, though, where we saw that the aquaculture industry was about to take off and that this would be viable," Mr. Fowler said.
Meanwhile, the tribe began leasing shellfish beds in Fishers Island Sound and Stonington Harbor over the last several years and now controls 1,300 acres of ocean.
"At one point we realized it was beyond us to take this project any further so we had to bring in an expert," Mr. Fowler said.
Twenty months ago, after an extensive search, the tribe hired Paul Maugle as director of aquaculture.
Mr. Maugle, a fish nutritionist, has spent more than 25 years working on aquaculture projects in 15 countries. The job was a homecoming for Mr. Maugle, who grew up in Norwich with members of the Mohegan tribe.
With the aquaculture industry growing at a rate of 15 to 20 percent a year, Mr. Maugle said this was a good time to go into business.
"We're also in marketing heaven," he said. "We're in one of the wealthiest corridors in the country, halfway between Boston and New York, and we don't have to sell people on this. They're already familiar with seafood." 
Connecticut oysters already have the reputation of being some of the best while tilapia is becoming increasingly popular, especially in upscale restaurants. Because they are local, the Mohegans will be able to provide fresher shellfish and tilapia to restaurants than their competition. Most of the tilapia used in the United States is imported from countries such as Taiwan, Ecuador and Costa Rica.
The tribe plans to start slowly, gradually increasing the size of its operation over several years. Mr. Chupaska said the Tribal Council understands that it will take several years before the $10 million project is in the black, but after that, he said, "We expect to do quite well." 
Mr. Maugle said: "This is a long-term investment, not a short-term one. It's nice to have an opportunity like this. Not many businesses would be willing to wait four years to make money." 
The Mohegans plan to convert the former Garbo Lobster Company property for the shellfish operations. They plan to start with eight million oysters and eventually build to a point of producing 20 million oysters. (The amount of clams to be produced each year is still undetermined.) While many of the oysters and clams will be sold to restaurants, the tribe will also sell prepackaged products such as "shooters," oysters in a shot glass with seafood sauce, which is then consumed with vodka.
J. Evan Ward, a University of Connecticut scientist and the former president of the National Shellfisheries Association, said the Mohegans were "using tried and true methods" to raise shellfish.
"This is certainly not experimental," Mr. Ward said. "They've done their research. Oysters are already extensively grown in Long Island Sound so it's good bet."
Mr. Ward said that the shellfish grounds the tribe will use have a good tidal flushing, plenty of food and are not subject to toxic substances or disease. He said the riskiest part of the plan is raising the seedlings in a hatchery.
Stonington officials have welcomed the Mohegans, saying their presence will bolster the Town Dock, home to the state's last commercial fishing fleet. Some commercial fishermen in Stonington say the prospect of a steady paycheck, good benefits and being home with their families each night is appealing and that they may contact the tribe about a job.
Some residents had feared that the new owners of the lobster company property would not use the site for a maritime-related activity.
"I'm glad to see it being used again in connection with the ocean," said Arthur Medeiros, president of the Southern New England Fishermen and Lobstermen's Association. "I wish them all the luck in the world with it."
The tribe will begin a pilot project to raise tilapia in about 18 months. The Mohegans plan to slowly increase the production of tilapia to a point where the objective is to have facilities on 12 farms in six years. The tribe also sees the tilapia project as a way to help some local farmers stay in business.
Eventually, the Mohegans plan to produce 3.6 millions pounds of tilapia each year. Fish farms in the United States currently produce 19 million pounds of fish annually, but that figure increases as the demand rises.
The Mohegans will provide the feed, technical support and training for the farmers, who will raise the fish in their barns, pay for labor and utilities and then sell the fish to the tribe. The Mohegans will process the fish and ship it to customers.
Although most of the fish will be sold as fresh fillets, some will be sold in prepackaged oven-ready meals, smoked, or as a mousse. 
Kevin Fitzsimmons, a University of Arizona scientist and an officer of the American Tilapia Association, said the Mohegans would have to identify niche markets and not try to compete with established producers in the large fish markets.
"Then they have a really good chance of being successful," he said.
Mr. Fitzsimmons said the Mohegans had the advantage of being close to large markets.
"They'll have to deliver the product really fresh to the back door of the restaurants," he said. "They can process the fish in the morning, deliver it in the afternoon and it can be on the table at night. That's the way they'll have to compete."

Glover for The New York Times); Raising shellfish seedlings in a hatchery may be one of the riskiest parts of the aquaculture operation for the Mohegans. Above, oyster seedlings. (Mohegan Tribe)

HEADLINE: Hospital Plan Accepted for Review 

BYLINE:  By COREY KILGANNON

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS 

 BODY:
FACED with the possibility of paying millions of dollars in damages to New York Presbyterian Hospital for delaying its development project, the City of White Plains has agreed to review a hospital plan to develop part of its land just east of the city's downtown shopping district.
 On Feb. 22, the Common Council, after being advised by its lawyers to cooperate with the hospital, voted 5 to 2 to have its agencies review a hospital plan to build two medical research buildings. The plan was rejected by the Council in July, along with a much larger proposal that included a residential-commercial component and parkland for the city. 
 New York Presbyterian has been making proposals for this site since 1983, but the city and community groups have long opposed a rezoning for commercial use. 
In November 1999, the hospital, after two years of extensive community outreach, unveiled its $300 million Millennium Preservation Master Plan. Nicknamed Plan A, it included new medical laboratory space, as well as 480 units of housing, 405,000 square feet of retail space and a hotel-conference center.
As part of the rezoning plan, the hospital offered to give the city 61 acres of undeveloped land for use as a park. Mayor Joseph M. Delfino hailed Plan A for the roughly $10 million in sales tax revenue it could generate for the city. He envisioned a "central park" for White Plains that would include eight ball fields and be three times larger than the city's next biggest park.
But some residents and most council members argued that the commercial project was inappropriate for the site and would siphon shoppers from the city's ailing downtown. Concerned Citizens for Open Space, a community group opposed to the hospital's plans, demanded at least 100 acres of hospital property for parkland.
Sensing opposition to Plan A, the hospital created a backup Plan B, which used only 19 of the 214 acres and needed no zoning change. This $200 million alternative included two 192,000-square-foot office and medical research buildings near Bryant Avenue. The plan included no park, and its nonprofit status provided the city little tax revenue.
The hospital needed the Common Council only to amend its special permit for the medical use of the land, a routine application.
On July 10, Mayor Delfino and Councilman Robert E. Greer voted to approve Plan A, but they were outvoted by the five other council members. After the Council also rejected Plan B, the hospital filed suit in State Supreme Court challenging the city's refusal.
This month, city lawyers concluded that they would probably lose the suit, which would cost White Plains millions of dollars in damages. They advised the city to settle by agreeing to review Plan B, a process begun with the Feb. 22 vote. Only two council members, William M. King and Rita Z. Malmud, the council president, voted against Plan B.
The mayor blamed council members for rejecting Plan A in July, and thereby losing out on parkland and sales and property tax revenue. Timothy Sheehan, a former member of the county planning board, also scolded the Council: "When 60 acres of land were offered to you, you yawned and spurned it. You had big chips on your shoulder. Now they will take those fields that could have been ours and cover them with buildings, brick by brick and floor by floor."
But in an interview last week, Ms. Malmud insisted that Plan A "came with a poison pill," the large commercial component. And she vowed to keep fighting Plan B, fearing a hidden agenda by the hospital, like the possible blending of commercial and medical uses. The hospital's plans are too vague for the city to determine whether they are appropriate, she said.
At the Feb. 22 meeting, Barbara Benjamin, a White Plains resident, said that an enlarged medical complex would turn Interstate 287 "into a Long Island Expressway parking lot."
But Constance P. Hildesley, the hospital's vice president for real estate, said that additional traffic to the site would not create congestion, and that plans included adding about 500 parking spaces in two garages. She called Plan B a prestigious, world-class medical center that would give an economic boost to White Plains and draw residential and commercial tenants to the area.
The hospital had gone to considerable expense and spent 18 months attending community meetings in an effort to create an acceptable plan, she said. But faced with too much resistance from the city, the hospital decided to pursue Plan B.
For Mayor Delfino, 68, a Republican, the demise of Plan A was especially disappointing. He is up for re-election in November, with Ms. Malmud as his likely Democratic challenger. As of last summer, he had envisioned that Plan A, along with the retail-multiplex project on the former Macy's site downtown, would revive White Plains and benefit him politically. While he has accomplished several other major development projects and lowered the office vacancy rate in White Plains, the two projects were cornerstones in his Phase 2 revitalization plan. A central park would have been his legacy, but now both plans have sputtered.
At the Feb. 22 meeting, he insisted that the city would continue to negotiate with the hospital for parkland. But he was not optimistic, and he spoke wistfully of the scrapped park.
"Every time I drove down Bryant Avenue," he said, "I could see children playing."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME; 
Rent Rules: Changes And Debates

BYLINE:  By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
WHEN the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal adopted amendments to state and city rent regulations last December, officials said that the amendments were intended to update the regulations to make them conform to changes in the law, judicial decisions and the division's policies and practices.
 And while most of the changes do just that, tenant advocates say that on some amendments that are potentially unfavorable to tenants the housing division may have overstepped its authority. Some of those amendments are likely to be challenged in court, but the division says it is confident the changes will withstand the challenges. 
 In one change, the subletting of an apartment has been added to the factors that can be considered when a landlord alleges that a tenant is not using an apartment as a primary residence. 
Another expands the list of individuals considered immediate family members of an owner who wants to reclaim an apartment for owner occupancy, and a third allows an owner of an apartment that has been deregulated because the legal rent exceeds $2,000 to rent the apartment for less without losing the benefits of deregulation.
(Three other disputed issues were covered in this space last week. They included changes in the way base rents are calculated when an overcharge complaint is filed; elimination of the prohibition against landlords getting more than one vacancy allowance during the one-year period between Rent Guidelines Board rent increases; and a prohibition against tenants charging roommates more than a proportionate share of the rent.)
David Ng, a Manhattan landlord-tenant lawyer, said he is troubled by the provision that adds subletting to the list of factors that determine whether an apartment is a primary residence.
"Listing subletting as a factor to prove that a tenant is not living in an apartment flies in the face of other provisions in the law that specifically permit subletting under appropriate circumstances," Mr. Ng said.
Historically, Mr. Ng said, the regulations provided that addresses on a tenant's driver's license, motor vehicle registration, voting records and tax returns could all be used as evidence that a tenant was not using an apartment as a primary residence. Other factors include whether the tenant paid city income tax and whether she lived in the apartment at least 183 days a year.
Now, he said, adding subletting to the list may result in discouraging sublets entirely.
"If a tenant asks me, 'Can I sublet my apartment without fear that the landlord will use it against me in a primary residence case?,' my answer is going to have to be: 'No. Not anymore,' " Mr. Ng said.
Marcia Hirsch, general counsel for the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, said that subletting was listed because under certain circumstances it is a legitimate factor to consider.
"Some people use subletting as a way to hold onto their apartment for as long as they can even though they may have no intention of ever returning," Ms. Hirsch said, adding that one condition for legally subletting an apartment is an intention to return after the subtenancy. 
"Just because you do everything by the book when you sublet an apartment doesn't necessarily mean you intend to return to it," she said. 
Ms. Hirsch said she is confident that the subletting amendment -- and scores of other changes adopted by the division -- will withstand judicial scrutiny. 
Mary Ann Hallenborg, a lawyer in Nyack, N.Y., who is also publisher and managing editor of the Landlord-Tenant Practice Reporter, a trade publication for landlord-tenant lawyers, said that another amendment expands the definition of a property owner's immediate family members for purposes of taking back an apartment for owner occupancy.
"The law now allows a broader class of family members," Ms. Hallenborg said, explaining that sons-in-law, daughters-in-law, fathers-in-law and mothers-in-law have been added to the list of immediate family members an owner can place in an apartment after a rent-stabilized tenant's lease expires. (Ms. Hallenborg said that only property owners who own their buildings personally -- as opposed to those who own them through a business entity -- are entitled to take back an apartment for owner occupancy.) Other landlord family members on the list include spouses, children, stepchildren, parents, stepparents, siblings, grandparents and grandchildren.
She said that another amendment -- one that reflects a change in the law made in 1997 -- excludes a tenant's nephews, nieces, uncles and aunts from the list of individuals entitled to succeed the tenant in a rent-regulated apartment. That list includes every relative on the landlord's list, plus nontraditional family members who are entitled to succession rights under certain circumstances.
Another change, Ms. Hallenborg said, allows a landlord to impose surcharges when the tenant is allowed to install appliances like washers, dryers and dishwashers. The amounts of the surcharges are to be set by the agency at a later date, she said, adding that the surcharges do not become part of the legal regulated rent and the appliance does not become a required service.
Colleen F. McGuire, a Manhattan tenant lawyer, said that another change in the regulations has to do with what is known as high-rent luxury decontrol. For the last eight years, as a result of changes in the 1993 rent laws, once the legal rent that can be charged for a vacant apartment exceeds $2,000, the apartment is considered deregulated. 
There has been some discussion, however, over whether the $2,000 decontrol trigger applied automatically when the maximum allowable rent exceeded that figure, or only when the maximum allowable rent exceeded that amount and a new tenant rented the apartment for more than $2,000.
That dispute has been settled in favor of landlords, Ms. McGuire said, by a provision in the new regulations that a vacant apartment is considered decontrolled when the maximum allowable rent exceeds $2,000, whether or not the apartment is actually rented for that amount.
The amendment means that a tenant who rents an apartment for less $2,000 a month could be renting a deregulated apartment.
Ms. McGuire said that tenants who pay less than $2,000 for an apartment that a landlord says is deregulated because it can legally be rented for more might want to ask the landlord, before the lease expires, to document the computations used to arrive at the $2,000 threshold. If the landlord refuses, she said, the tenant might want to consider taking the landlord to court.
"The courts have allowed the first tenant who rents a deregulated apartment to challenge the computations that allowed the deregulation," Ms. McGuire said. "And it doesn't matter whether the tenant is paying over $2,000 or not."

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 3160 words

HEADLINE: Encore, Encore 

BYLINE:  By DEBRA GALANT

 BODY:
AT the core of it all -- the hype, the acclaim, the protests, the T-shirts, the billboards, the premieres -- is a sallow, sad-looking writer with dark circles under his eyes and a hangdog expression. And at the core of that writer is an Italian boy from New Jersey who was never good enough for his mother.
 Tony Soprano may be mobster as soccer dad. Indeed, James Gandolfini, who won an Emmy Award for his portrayal of Tony on the HBO series, recently bought an estate in Somerset. But David Chase -- a k a DeCesare, the creator of "The Sopranos" -- is just one more insecure writer. 
 "We had written ourselves into a corner," Mr. Chase, a product of North Caldwell by way of Clifton, said last month, explaining how he had pretty much used up his concept of a suburban mobster with a monster mother by the end of the first season. 
Apparently he turned the corner.
The third season of the widely acclaimed series begins tonight amid a storm of publicity and an almost equal flood of protest from the Italian-American antidefamation movement.
Yes, New Jersey's biggest cultural export -- about six million viewers are expected to tune in -- is a lightning rod for controversy. And nowhere do emotions run stronger than here on the show's turf.
On the one hand there are the fans -- O.K., a bit daft -- who treat "The Sopranos" like the home team. These are the people who will show up today at a pre-premiere baked ziti party at Mae's Pub in Clifton organized by "Soprano Sue" of Sopranoland.com. Part of the sport is hearing Tony ask Junior to hand over Bloomfield, or to spot on television a parking lot or bridge you pass every day. If Tony Soprano is a star, then those who live in Essex or Union or Hudson Counties are close enough to gather some of the magic fairy dust.
Then there are the others, for whom the geographic closeness to television's favorite mob family has the opposite effect. These are the Italian-Americans who are tired of hearing the "F word," who have spent all their lives cringing at the notion that neighbors think that just because they are Italian, they have mob connections. For them, the local scenery just adds insult to injury. These are the people who will show up today at St. Thomas Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, where Emanuele Alfano of Unico National, a service organization for Americans of Italian descent, will present the Mille Grazie Award to the Essex County Executive, James W. Treffinger, who last December banned filming in the South Mountain Reservation, a sprawling public park with lots of places to dispose of a body in a ravine or under dead leaves.
Oddly enough, Mr. Chase hinted at this controversy several times in the first season. In one episode, Tony's daughter asks if he's in the Mafia.
"There's no such thing," the mobster huffs. "That's a stereotype. And it's offensive."
He could have been writing the script for Mr. Alfano, who lately has been gaining some momentum in his campaign to use the blockbuster HBO series as an object lesson in the way Italian-Americans are portrayed in the media. But it is a skirmish in which the show does not have to pack a 9 millimeter to win.
Last month, for instance, no less than the Museum of Modern Art in New York screened the first two seasons' episodes and invited Ken Auletta of The New Yorker magazine to interview Mr. Chase. Billboards of "The Sopranos" extended family on a Jersey-Shore-like boardwalk have sprouted up at the entrances to the Lincoln and Holland Tunnels.
An around-the-clock market in "Sopranos" tchotchkes grinds away on eBay. And star-studded premiere parties were planned in New York and at the Pleasantdale Chateau in West Orange, where the crew could pay back all those who tolerated the trucks and the cables and the lights and the other inconveniences of the filming there.
All this has accompanied a last-minute frenzy by the "Sopranos" crew to finish filming the final episode of third season -- with attendant "Sopranos" sightings and autograph opportunities from Caldwell to Kearny. HBO, which has kept a Mob-like grip on the show's publicity, has meted out coveted interviews with Mr. Chase like drops of holy water.
As the cameras keep rolling, Dr. Alfano, a retired chiropractor, runs his campaign from an office in Bloomfield, where a statue of Venus de Milo offers a different statement on Italian culture. He contends the entertainment industry offers stereotypes of Italian-Americans as violent or uncouth -- either toting guns or shoveling down pasta -- in a way it would not dare to portray other ethnic groups.
"People look at that and say, yes, that's what Italians are," Dr. Alfano said.
Although Dr. Alfano says he does not know anyone in the mob, he says he has heard even they find the show offensive.
"They were upset by how they were being portrayed," he said. "A mob person would never have tolerated foul language at the table from the kids. And a mother trying to kill her son? Never in a million years!"
But as much as Dr. Alfano excoriates "The Sopranos" for perpetuating negative stereotypes, the show from hell is also the gift that keeps on giving. After all, along with e-mail messages, it is the best thing that ever happened to his media sensitivity campaign. Just two weeks ago, the show's latest advertising campaign gave Dr. Alfano a new opportunity to protest; he sent a letter to the general counsel of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey complaining about the "Sopranos" posters on PATH trains.
"A friend of mine said, 'It should go on for 18 years,' " Dr. Alfano admitted with a smile. "He said, 'Manny, we never got this much coverage.' "
THERE are many "Sopranos" fans, but none more devoted than a 40-year-old Clifton woman who calls herself Soprano Sue.
Soprano Sue, a k a Sue Sadik, was a geography major at William Paterson University, and she runs a courier service in Jersey City, both of which she credits for her talent in recognizing the Jersey locations on the show. "Locations are my thing," Ms. Sadik said. "That's what my degree's in. I drive all day. Then it became a game, picking out where everything was."
Not only can Soprano Sue identify all 22 locations in the show's opening credits, she has also made herself its No. 1 self-appointed paparazzo. She regularly uploads digital images of "Sopranos" shoots to a special page of her fan site, "Sopranoland.com"
The first time she stumbled across the site of Satriale's Pork Store, the Kearny location where Tony and his gang discuss strategy, it was like a revelation.
"I came over a hill and I look and, oh my God, I found it, I found it!" Ms. Sadik recalled recently. "It made my whole night." She considers the North Caldwell residence used as Tony's house on the show "hallowed ground" and refuses to give out the address because she doesn't want others to invade the privacy of its owner.
Soprano Sue has a coterie of fellow fans and other sources (including a well-informed auto body mechanic and a woman who lives in an apartment across from Satriale's) who keep one another current on the status of filming. One of her biggest coups was finding the substitute location used after Mr. Treffinger forbade filming in South Mountain Reservation.
"The crew members were betting whether I'd find them," she said. She did, in Harriman State Park in Orange County, N.Y.
Ms. Sadik keeps a wall of photographs from her "Sopranos" shoots -- including one with her and Mr. Gandolfini -- but her prized possession is the picture taken with her and Mr. Chase.
"Nobody has a hobby like mine," she said. "I want to get buried on the cemetery on Newark Avenue -- Jersey City Cemetery on Newark Avenue," she said, referring to the cemetery where the "Sopranos" filmed the funeral of the character Livia Soprano, played by the Nancy Marchand.
"I belong in there and everybody knows it."
When Mr. Treffinger denied "The Sopranos" a permit to film in the reservation, nobody was more surprised than Mark Kamine, the show's location manager. "We'd used Essex County property in the past," he recalled recently. "As long as safety procedures are in place, it's a rubber stamp."
Although initially the county cited a deer hunt as the reason for turning down the permit, Mr. Treffinger soon went on record saying that future permits would not be given for a show that demeaned an ethnic minority.
"This idea that because of the content of the show that it might be turned down, it never occurred to us," Mr. Kamine said.
Not that it stopped the "Sopranos" crew for long. Immediately, there were offers from private citizens and municipalities to film in other wooded areas, Mr. Kamine said. One offer came from the mayor of Oakland, who offered a local campground. But Mr. Kamine decided on Harriman State Park instead, largely because of a superior plot of pine trees. For its trouble, Harriman got a $10,000 donation from the show, Mr. Kamine said, and he estimated that the crew probably spent another $20,000 to $50,000 during its four days there.
It is hard to say exactly how much revenue "The Sopranos" -- a cottage industry in New Jersey -- brings the state. "It's millions of dollars," said Steven Gorelick, associate director of the New Jersey Motion Picture and Television Commission, whose job is to attract the film industry to the state. "It's an annuity for us."
Although New Jersey has been successful lately in attracting many big names in entertainment -- the directors Steven Soderbergh and Ang Lee both shot here on the same day last month -- "The Sopranos" is considered the jewel in New Jersey's show business crown.
It is not just cash, but the series' growing star power and its introduction of scores of New Jersey scenes into the popular culture. "It's become a national obsession," Mr. Gorelick said. "I'm convinced that it's raised the consciousness among filmmakers."
Michael Aaron Rockland, chairman of the American Studies Department at Rutgers University, who is a frequent writer on pop culture, sees the TV show as a sort of culture ambassador for the state.
"The 'Sopranos,' I think, have been part of the Jersey Renaissance," Professor Rockland said. "Wherever I travel, when people mention the 'Sopranos,' they mention it as if, 'Wow, you're from New Jersey. Look at you.' "
So just what is "The Sopranos," which many consider to be the best television series ever -- New Jersey's chief cultural export or ethnic embarrassment?
At the film commission, there is no question.
"You can't attract the film industry and then tell the film industry that they can only make certain kinds of movies here," Mr. Gorelick said. "Our position is we don't act as a board of censorship. We are strictly an agency of economic development."
But for politicians, who work both sides of the political street, the question is murkier, and they are not leaping at the opportunity to go on the record about it. Mr. Treffinger declined to be interviewed, but did speak through his director of policy and planning, Joanna Noonan.
"He says this is not a First Amendment issue because filming on county property is not a right," Ms. Noonan relayed.
The state's acting governor, Donald DiFrancesco, also turned down an opportunity to be interviewed about the "Sopranos." He did say through spokeswoman, Jayne O'Conner, that he had never seen the show.
"Based on what he's heard and read, his preference would be that it would be more accurate about its portrayal of New Jersey and not perpetuate some of the stereotypes about New Jersey and the Italians," Ms. O'Conner said.
Nervousness about "The Sopranos" extends to other institutions as well. William Paterson University in Wayne revoked a permit to shoot a scene there last year about the same time a professor was to deliver a lecture on Italian stereotypes in the media. And Seton Hall University in South Orange was reportedly embarrassed last month when a clip from "The Sopranos" was played during a basketball game at the Continental Airlines Arena.
UNICO National, the group most vocally opposed to "The Sopranos," is a donor to Seton Hall's Italian studies program, and its first vice president, John Alati, a Seton Hall alumnus, was at the game.
Another group walking a tightrope over the "Sopranos" is the Anti-Defamation League of the B'nai B'rith. Although the group is sympathic to the Italian-American group's outrage, it is being careful about getting into a gang war over a television show.
" 'The Sopranos' feeds into stereotyping," said Charles Goldstein, director of the league's New Jersey chapter. "A false negative stereotype, which can feed into bigotry."
But Mr. Goldstein added: "It is not a focus of the A.D.L. to object to entertainment. We live in a market economy. This is what the market will bear, and it's not illegal. People have to have freedom of choice."
IT WAS 36 degrees and raining, a chilling combination that made being outside for longer than a few minutes an exercise in misery. But that did not stop the locals in Belleville from standing vigil on the hill in front of Belleville Middle School, where they watched "The Sopranos" being filmed at the Cozzarelli Funeral Home across the street.
Since the filming was going on inside, all anybody could see were some police officers guarding the front of the funeral parlor, and production vans lining the street. But there were some minor thrills when the actors occasionally emerged. Debbie Sangemino and Sharon Capezio, both 46, were thrilled when they got a kiss from Michael Imperioli, who plays Christopher Moltisanti. Despite the weather, they stood on the hill for most of the day, and for their trouble also got to see Mr. Gandolfini, Edie Falco (Carmela Soprano) and Tony Sirico (Paulie Walnuts).
Mrs. Sangemino found out about the shoot a few days earlier when her daughter, who attends the middle school, came home with news that a school dance planned for that Friday night had been canceled because of the filming.
"I think it's wonderful that they came to the town of Belleville," said Mrs. Capezio, who was wearing a black "Sopranos" T-shirt. Neither woman was offended in the least by the show's depiction of Italian-American gangsters. "It's television," Mrs. Sangemino said. "It's fun. If you don't have to face it in your backyard every day, it's entertainment."
Paul Santos, a 32-year-old autograph collector from Scotch Plains, also showed up for the Cozzarelli shoot -- along with 2-year-old Paul Jr., who rode in a stroller outfitted with a rain shield. It was old hat for Mr. Santos, a police officer in Elizabeth, who had been to 20 or 30 different shoots. "This weather is nothing," he said, shrugging off the icy drizzle. Mr. Santos was in a good mood because he had finally scored an autograph from Edie Falco, the last major cast member whose signature he needed to complete his collection.
Peter Caternicchio, of Elizabeth, a 30-year-old phone company employee and aspiring actor, also showed up in the hope of being discovered -- just as he had last summer at "The Sopranos" open casting call in Harrison, which drew 14,000 wannabes.
Notes about the shoot were also passed back and forth on New Jersey Online's "Sopranos" chat board. In the etiquette of on-line "Sopranos" devotees, fans warned each other if they had a "spoiler" -- that is, information about the show's content that could "spoil" a surprise. According to the spoilers (don't read on, if you care), the funeral being shot was for Meadow's college boyfriend. An August shoot at the same funeral home was supposedly for Livia Soprano's funeral. Of course, that was not much of a spoiler, since Nancy Marchand died over the summer.
Mr. Treffinger may have deemed "The Sopranos" politically incorrect, but that will not stop Essex County prosecutors from tuning in to the newest adventures of Tony and Carmela tonight.
"There's a lot of people in our office that watch it," said Bob Laurino, the prosecutor in charge of Essex County's sex crimes unit. "I know a lot of people who got HBO to watch it."
One of six million people expected to watch tonight will undoubtedly be Mr. Laurino, who said he had a "love-hate" relationship with the show. Sure, Mr. Laurino, who grew up in an Italian-American home in Short Hills, knows that it offends many people. And as a prosecutor, he acknowledged that "anything that glamorizes organized crime is unfortunate." Still, he added, "it's pretty compelling viewing."
In addition to the Monday-morning water cooler conversation at the prosecutor's office, one of the people Mr. Laurino discusses the show with is his sister, Maria Laurino, who wrote the memoir "Were You Always an Italian?" (W. W. Norton, $23.95). Ms. Laurino, who admits being a "Sopranos" fan, said she admired the show for its subtle handling of issues of ethnicity in suburbia, and for its accurate use of dialect. Lately, she has become impatient with the protests against "The Sopranos."
"I think it's silly," she said. "If you don't like the way Italian-American culture is presented, come up with your own."
Another Italian-American who is an unrepentant "Sopranos" fan is David Bonanno, editor of The American Poetry Review, who grew up in Caldwell and now lives in Philadelphia.
"I think the show is so well written that it's not a stretch to talk about it as being Shakespearean," said Mr. Bonanno, who planned to celebrate the new season with a party. Mr. Bonanno, who has a prized "Sopranos" baseball cap, says the show allows him some vicarious thrills he does not normally get as a poetry editor. "It's pretend tough guys in North Jersey," he said. "It's like cowboys and Indians."
Mr. Chase made almost the same point last month at the Museum of Modern Art. Although the inspiration for the series was his own problematic relationship with his mother, Mr. Chase decided that setting that conflict against a mob story was inherently more interesting.
"They didn't do stories about chicken farmers," he said. "They focused on gun slingers."
It has become a truism that the Mafia story has become the latest incarnation of the western. Everybody immediately understands the format, so the creativity comes with each new spin.
But some Italian-Americans are quick to point out that the western is now considered politically incorrect too.
"It's doing the same thing to Italian-Americans that the western did to Native Americans," said Maria Mazziotti Gillan, executive director of the Poetry Center at Passaic County Community College in Paterson.
Yet, despite her intellectual opposition to the show, Ms. Gillan finds herself sucked in.
"Unfortunately," she said, "it's very well written. It's fast-paced. It's almost like a Greek tragedy."
But the taciturn Mr. Chase may find the compliments about his writing as reassuring as a peck on the cheek from Livia Soprano. After all, he heard the same thing for years -- from television executives when they turned down his scripts.
"They would always say, 'This is really great writing,' Mr. Chase told the audience at the Museum of Modern Arta. "And you'd know it's over."

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 11; Column 2; Real Estate Desk; Pg. 1

HEADLINE: Exiles Find There's Life After Manhattan 

BYLINE:  By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
THEY are expatriates and exiles from Manhattan -- some native to the 13-mile sliver between the rivers, others who brought their dreams of career and exhilaration from the other boroughs, the suburbs or even more tranquil environs.
 With a confidence founded on the certainty of a loving if close-quartered family of seven in the South Bronx, George Cabrera knew from the age of 13 that, despite near-nightly gunfire on his block, he would someday join the ranks of the "go-getters, the lawyers and traders" in Manhattan. And for 10 years, he thoroughly enjoyed his bachelor pad, a $1,600-a-month one-bedroom apartment on 34th Street at First Avenue. 
 Courtney Clark came from a cottage in the woods on her parents' farm outside Lynchburg, Va. -- where, to her, the animals were "permanent lawn ornaments" -- her eyes wide for that job in public relations. "I decided I'd go for it in The City," she said, emphasizing the article. 
Now they, like numbers of other onetime Manhattanites, leave the island each night for apartments in less dear districts of the other boroughs, private houses in suburbanlike swaths of the city, or communities on other shores that offer gloriously detached views of the jagged skyline they left behind. 
The exiles have been forced from Manhattan by market pressures: by purchase prices that, despite the nation's economic jitters, have barely abated in the borough; by commonplace rents of, say, $1,500 or more for a studio. And, according to tenant advocates, by the weakening of rent regulations that, they say, used to mitigate those market pressures, but now encourage owners to push longstanding tenants out.
Mr. Cabrera, an equity trader, now lives in Jacob's Ferry, a town house development on the New Jersey side of the Hudson, where he looks back at Manhattan from the terrace outside his bedroom, contemplating how he won't get stuck in the tunnel when he climbs aboard the ferry for his 15-minute morning commute.
Ms. Clark, who used to rent a room in Harlem for $650 a month, grew weary of looking at downtown Manhattan apartments that were "like closets, with the shower in the kitchen."
"I was willing to pay up to $1,300, preferably a one-bedroom," she said, "but I wasn't going to live in a hole, just because I could afford it."
Ms. Clark now lives in a two-bedroom apartment in a private home in Astoria, Queens. And when her best friend comes to town in May, they will share the $1,600-a-month rent.
To be sure, the refugees miss living within the pulse-quickening pace of Manhattan, the vertical views, the bright lights, the museums and theaters, the barhopping, the panoply of choices in the Yellow Pages, the 24-hour deli down the block, the friends they left behind. Many use the word "wrenching" to describe the parting.
Just as surely, they appreciate the calm of their new communities, the "main street feel," as one of them said; the neighbors who offer more than a nod in the hallway. One said the folks next door actually helped carry in the couch. Many appreciate the ethnic flavors of their blocks: Greek-Italian in Astoria; Hispanic-Hasidic in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.
They like not being so cramped, the extra bedroom for the same price, lots of closets. They very much value not having to fork over three months' rent up front, sometimes equal to the down payment on an outer-borough co-op.
And certainly they are less lured by the siren sounds of the city.
BARBARA KLAR, who once lived in earshot of the traffic clog to the Holland Tunnel, has heard and seen it all. Hers is a fairly comprehensive casebook on the difficulties of the Manhattan market.
Ms. Klar, a jewelry designer, is owner of Clear Metals on Thompson Street in SoHo. In previous rental incarnations, she used to reside and metalsmith in one location -- not always according to code.
"I opened my first store in 1984 on Seventh Street in the East Village," Ms. Klar said, "a little shop, 500 square feet -- tiny, tiny, like a boat with a sleeping berth." Ms. Klar, now 47, lived and worked there, "even though that wasn't allowed." The five-year lease started at $500, with $50 increases annually.
But in 1988, the building was sold, and Ms. Klar signed another five-year lease with the new owner, starting at $650 and rising to $950. "The next lease, however, started at $950, jumped to $1,500 the second year, then $1,750," Ms. Klar said. The top rent was $2,400.
"When I signed, I said to him: 'I don't know if I'm going to stay, because business is down. If I want to, will you let me out of the lease?' And he said yes."
Soon after, Ms. Klar continued: "He began to boot the old rent-control people out of the building, and began renovating. He renovated above me, directly. I had leaks, the ceiling fell in."
So began a legal battle in which Ms. Klar claimed constructive eviction -- a legal term for landlord actions that interfere with a tenant's use of the property -- and the landlord claimed she broke the lease. Ms. Klar lost.
In 1991, Ms. Klar opened the store on Thompson Street. By then, she was subletting a friend's loft on the Bowery for $450 a month, with no lease.
Some friends not always being so friendly, she said: "Every time we turned around, the rent went up. By the time it hit $1,800, the end of six years, she doubled that, and I decided to look elsewhere" -- across the East River.
By then, with the upscaling of downtown Manhattan, SoHo artists were moving into Williamsburg. "Manhattanites think Brooklyn is so far away," Ms. Klar said. "I couldn't believe how close it is." She started looking at rentals.
"I found an incredible live-work situation, a huge open space," on Graham Avenue in Williamsburg, she said. "The owner wanted $5,000 a month, and three months' security, but no lease. That's $15,000, not counting $10,000 to renovate. I decided, that's a down payment on a house."
And then there it was: an L-shaped, linoleum-lined medical office with an antique X-ray machine in front and a two-bedroom apartment in the back on South Fourth Street in Williamsburg. The price: $250,000.
"It's interesting I ended up doing my work in a doctor's office because I like to think it's healing, giving people pleasure," she said. "And we healed the building, too, because now it's beautiful."
It was scary leaving Manhattan, Ms. Klar said, "the 24-hour accessibility for anything." What she misses most are the rooftops. "You know, hanging out on the roof on a hot summer night, the beautiful urban landscape, just sitting and looking at the sky."
Still, it was a "love-hate relationship," Ms. Klar conceded. "At my loft on the Bowery, traffic backed up from the Williamsburg Bridge to the tunnel; twice a day, two hours each time, horns were blaring, people screaming."
The manic Manhattan market has provoked screams in recent years. But tenant representatives say more than demand has caused the squeeze.
"It's really market pressure and the fact that the public policies and laws that historically mitigated those market forces have, in recent years, been substantially weakened," said Andrew Scherer, acting executive director of Legal Services for New York City, which represents poor people in civil cases, and author of "Residential Landlord-Tenant Law in New York" (West Group, 2001).
Mr. Scherer specifically pointed to a process commonly called luxury decontrol, which was enacted by the state under the Rent Regulation Reform Act of 1993 and continued in the 1997 rent law.
"Landlords routinely now, if there is a vacancy, can make apartment improvements that in many cases enable them to increase rents above $2,000 a month," Mr. Scherer said. "That exempts the unit from rent regulation." 
If the landlord renovates a vacant apartment -- perhaps remodeling the kitchen and bathroom and replacing the appliances -- one-fortieth of the cost of those improvements can be included in the monthly rent. If that one-fortieth increase -- combined with a "vacancy allowance" that is typically 20 percent -- takes the rent over $2,000 a month, the apartment is permanently decontrolled and the landlord can charge a new tenant whatever the market will bear. "This is happening very commonly, at this point," Mr. Scherer said.
At the same time, eviction procedures in Housing Court have been "ratcheted up considerably," Mr. Scherer said.
Morton Cohen, senior staff attorney at Harlem Legal Services, concurred with that assessment. "There are legitimate nonpayment cases," he said, "and there are those landlords who are just taking a shot that the tenant won't find a lawyer or will default, and maybe they will be able to get the apartment."
SO the squeeze is hardly limited to the more affluent areas of Manhattan. "There's tremendous pressure up here," Mr. Cohen said. "They want to get the rents on a par with mid-Manhattan." 
And that phenomenon holds true, Mr. Scherer added, "even though it may be shifting a little just in the last few months because of the real estate market softening a bit."
There was nothing mushy about the market 14 months ago when Jason and Annie Kantor, both 32 -- he a biotech stock analyst, she a textile designer -- began looking for more space after their daughter, Emma, now 2, began walking.
The one-bedroom in the high-rise at 36th Street and Lexington Avenue was just too cramped.
The Kantors are both from more spacious locales in California. "It was a unique experience for us, living on the 23rd floor with a big-city view of Midtown, the Chrysler Building," Mr. Kantor said.
Mrs. Kantor said they were not used to elevators. "It's ironic," she said, "because now our daughter doesn't know otherwise. She's uncomfortable on uneven ground. What could be worse for Californians than to take your daughter to the beach and she screams and retracts her feet? She won't even step on the sand."
The Kantors had been subletting the co-op apartment for $2,300 a month, with a jump to $2,600 in the offing. "It was a white-glove doorman building; odd for us, always somebody there to help with the bags," Mr. Kantor said. "But we weren't filled with any feelings of undue importance."
Mainly because the apartment was, for them, tiny. "Emma took over one of the precious corners, meaning in a one-bedroom you don't have that many corners," Mrs. Kantor said. "I sacrificed my knitting machine for the crib, and the computer station. We downsized from a whole computer table to a laptop."
And so the search began. "We started looking at both renting or buying in our neighborhood, Murray Hill, first," Mr. Kantor said. It soon became clear that full two-bedrooms would be out of their reach. "We saw convertible one-bedrooms -- those apartments with a dining alcove you can convert to a baby's room -- but they were close to $3,000, and not very nice."
Then Mr. Kantor's parents came to town. "We went to visit Brooklyn Heights for sightseeing purposes," he said, "and we fell in love with it. The old architecture -- it reminded me a lot of the Back Bay in Boston," where he had gone to college.
Resetting their sights, within a price range of $350,000 to $400,000, the couple looked at nine apartments in Brooklyn Heights. They placed an offer on a two-bedroom on Pineapple Street, but were turned down.
"We found this place right after, and we liked it better, so we weren't disappointed," Mr. Kantor said of the two-bedroom co-op on Hicks Street for which they offered the asking price, "the high end of our range."
Next came the New York City equivalent of the Chinese water torture -- the approval process. "The co-op was surprisingly thorough," Mr. Kantor said. "We needed something on the order of four or five letters of recommendation each, both personal and professional; obviously, all the financial details and finally an interview."
Even little Emma would be perused. "They asked us to bring everybody," Ms. Kantor said. "And she was on her best behavior, she charmed them. There was a big sigh of relief when we made it through without breaking anything or screaming."
Though they miss the instant access to the museums of Manhattan, the theaters and the all-night deli down the block, the Kantors are enchanted by their new neighborhood. "We love the feel of Montague Street; it's like a little town," Mr. Kantor said. He also pointed out, "The commute for me is terrific, 'cause I work on Wall Street -- 15 minutes and one subway stop away."
Mrs. Kantor called Brooklyn Heights "neighborhoody" and "kid-centric." And there's "a beautiful little park right here on the Promenade," she said, where -- while Emma whoops it up on the see-saw and the slide -- her parents can take in the cathedral-like arches of the Brooklyn Bridge.
THE view was less appealing for Mr. Cabrera -- the South Bronx native now living across the Hudson -- when he was growing up. "Drugs being peddled on the corner, gunshots under the window every night," he said.
But his father, a six-day-a-week cab driver, and his mother, a seamstress, held it together. "It may have only been two bedrooms, and there were a few of us -- my mom and dad, two sisters, a younger brother, myself and Grandma," Mr. Cabrera said. "But you know what? Honest to God, I don't remember ever being hungry; I don't remember being disappointed for Christmas."
"I knew my life was going to be more than Walton Avenue," he said.
After graduating from Wesleyan University in Connecticut in 1989, Mr. Cabrera landed his stock trader's job and moved into the Rivergate on First Avenue. "I really did enjoy it," he said, "but when all was said and done, I had nothing to show for it."
Mr. Cabrera started considering buying, knowing that "for the same price for what I was going to get in Manhattan, besides 700 square feet of warm bedroom, I could have the place I have now in Jacob's Ferry." The development is in West New York, N.J., "which, I guess, is funny in itself," he said.
The town house, where Mr. Cabrera lives with his fiancee, Nora Montoya, is 1,300 square feet, has two bedrooms, a living room, a dining room, a rec room, a terrace and a garage -- for which he paid, in 1998, $285,000. The gated community also has two pools.
Ms. Montoya, 27, formerly an aspiring actress who says she now applies feng shui principles to people's living and work spaces, moved from Manhattan to the couple's New Jersey home a year ago. "I was bartending to support myself during acting, and I hated the vampire lifestyle, getting home at 4 or 5 in the morning," she said.
For Ms. Montoya, the greatest benefit of the move was just slowing down -- "not being so consumed with, 'Oh, I have to be here to do this, to do that.' Just taking a walk by the river, it's so grounding. You don't hear those city sounds -- the sirens, the drunk students at 3 a.m. In the city, what's natural becomes foreign."
The laugh is on Mr. Cabrera. "When I was a kid," he said, "I couldn't stop making jokes about people from New Jersey. Joe Piscopo, on 'Saturday Night Live,' used to do a skit with this high, goofy voice: 'Hi, I'm from Joisey!' He was a real doofus. I used to do the voice. Now I am that guy."

HEADLINE: EDUCATION; 
A New Law Library, A Growing Problem

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: NEWARK 

 BODY:
The library at the Rutgers University Center for Law and Justice is a 56,236-square-foot citadel of hushed legal scholarship. 
 Opened to students, faculty members, the legal community and the rest of the public last January, the library has 488,100 books on fixed and space-saving rolling stacks, four computer labs providing access to anything not printed on paper, 8 study rooms, 12 seminar rooms, an alumni research room, a renowned criminal justice collection and moot courtrooms. 
 The library is situated within the 220,000-square-foot law and justice center, a gleaming postmodern building with a clock tower and vaulting rotunda, which also provides space for Rutgers law and criminal justice schools, and anchors a quadlike pedestrian mall that lends the Newark campus a collegiate feel.
"I study here every night," said 22-year-old Lauren Baime of Hoboken, a first-year law student. "I think it's really nice. As for the library's content, I can find anything I need for class." 
But if you think you have been improperly turned down for a job and you weave through the stacks to find Clark, Boardman, Callaghan's Employment Discrimination Coordinator, an updatable loose-leaf index in search of recent decisions that could support your discrimination suit, you might end up feeling overruled.
"Canceled 1995: Not Current," is the hand-scrawled message inside the coordinator's gray vinyl binder.
Cancellations of loose-leaf services, duplicate law journal subscriptions and various printed resources as well as a hold on some types of book acquisitions are the result of budget constraints on the library that, in view of the grand new building, seem incongruous at best. At worst, says the library director, stagnant financing for the past seven years now threatens to cut into the library's traditional mission to serve not only as a resource for the law school but also for lawyers, alumni, litigants arguing their own cases and those doing legal research.
"So we've had to do some very careful honing of what we receive," said the library's director, Prof. Carol Roehrenbeck. "We certainly get the critical important items, but a lot of the fringe items are no longer available, or they're available in an online format or you must use a database."
But, Professor Roehrenbeck was quick to add, "You also have to look at it in terms of what is the mission of the university, and we traditionally have been oriented to serving the community, and some of those online subscriptions are limited to enrolled students."
"We're lean and mean at the moment," she said. "But we can't get too much leaner."
While Rutgers spent $49 million in tax and tuition on the law and justice center, the law library's $627,236 operating budget for the current academic year -- not including salaries -- is actually $20,000 less than what it was in 1994-95.
Moreover, Ms. Roehrenbeck said she was told not to expect an increase for 2001-2002. With inflation averaging around 10 percent a year for printed materials, she said the library's real purchasing power has just about been cut in half since 1994-95.
"It's just obvious that if a budget is cut in half there are going to be constraints," said Prof. Charlie Harvey Woods, a librarian. "I don't know what the priorities are, I just know what trickles down."
Yet for his part, Andrew J. Rothman, the law school's assistant dean for faculty and students, said he had never received a complaint about the library from students since it opened a year ago. In addition, Professor Rothman said colleagues had traveled from all over northern New Jersey to use the library, attesting to its ample resources.
"I have had no complaints whatsoever about the library," Mr. Rothman said.
Students and faculty members are unlikely to suffer much moreinconvenience from cuts in printed material -- the library no longer receives multiple copies of the Harvard Law Review, for example it has subscriptions to Lexus and West Law, the premier legal databases.
But as Professor Roehrenbeck pointed out, the public typically does not .... And while she conceded that most printed materials not on hand can be obtained by inter-library loan, she said the process is inconvenient to borrowers and a demand on librarians' time. 
The cutbacks are especially significant, libarians say, since the Rutgers complexes in Newark and Camden are the premier law libraries available to the public in the state.
Moreover, the issue of financing is set against a backdrop of a debate in recent years over the university's spending priorities, particularly concerning whether too much emphasis has been placed on athletics. For instance, the annual salary for the women's head basketball coach, C. Vivian Stringer, is $400,000 -- or nearly two-thirds of the law library budget.
Of course, many Scarlet Knights fans contend that winning teams are more likely to attract lucrative television contracts and alumni donations than bulging library stacks.
The library's stagnant financing also seems inconsistent with the facility's increased use. For example, Professor Roehrenbeck said that a recent visual survey found that 850 to 950 people use the library every day, or three times the number of users before the library moved from its former location in the historic Firemen's Fund Building several blocks away.
Paul Grassi of Paterson, who was in the library last week researching conflict-of-interest cases to defend himself against code enforcement charges involving contracting work, said the service and availability of material could not have been better.
"If I come here and ask them for something, they're very helpful," Grassi said. "This library is not failing me."
