HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
From Cash toStocks and Back, Based on the Calendar

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I MUST confess that I was skeptical two decades ago, when I started monitoring a stock market timing model that looked too good to be true. According to that model, beating the market was as simple as being invested in stocks on the days when the market has historically gone up the most and remaining in cash at all other times.
 But apparently I am wrong. That model -- the Seasonality Trading System from the Institute for Econometric Research of Deerfield Beach, Fla. -- has outperformed every other timing model monitored by The Hulbert Financial Digest over two decades. 
 The model calls for investors to be invested in stocks only on distinct occasions each year -- around the turns of each month, as well as just before and after exchange holidays. On average, that would be a total of about 90 market trading days a year. The model is relatively low-risk, because it is safely invested in cash much of the time. In fact, its returns are about half as volatile as the stock market as a whole.
Despite its conservative bent, the model has produced long-term returns that are every bit as good as those of the market itself. An investor who used the model -- switching between hypothetical shares of the Wilshire 5000 index and 90-day Treasury bills -- would have made 16.1 percent, annualized, from the beginning of 1982 through January 2001. That compares to 16.0 percent for simply buying and holding the Wilshire 5000 stocks over this nearly 20-year period.
That record is impressive. Conservative investors would have been able to sidestep much of the market's risk without also having to forfeit profits. Aggressive investors would also have benefited from this timing model: by investing twice as much money as they would have otherwise, for example, they would have doubled the market's return while incurring no greater risk.
But no one should choose a strategy on the basis of its track record alone. That is because past success, without some plausible explanation, may be a result of luck alone. 
Fortunately, in this case, there is an explanation. According to research conducted by Prof. Donald B. Keim of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, there are distinct calendar patterns to how stocks trade relative to their bid-asked spreads. It turns out that at various points during the year -- at the end of December, for example, or just before exchange holidays -- stocks typically trade near their bid prices. But immediately after those periods, they trade closer to their asked prices. To the extent of its bid-asked spread, then, the average stock rises during such periods.
Professor Keim's findings imply that there is no way to exploit these seasonal patterns by investing directly in individual stocks, because the bid-asked spreads would eliminate the potential gains. But that is not the case when you buy stocks indirectly, through no-load mutual funds and exchange-traded funds, whose net asset values are calculated on the basis of their component stocks' last trades. By investing in them during these seasonal periods, you can, in effect, buy stocks at or near their bid prices and sell them near their asked prices.
And you thought only market-makers could do that!
Why should there be seasonal patterns for how stocks trade relative to their spreads? Many different explanations have been suggested. One is that retirement plan contributions typically hit the market at the beginning of each month. Another factor is tax-loss selling that reaches a crescendo at year-end. A third is short-term traders' propensity, just before exchange holidays, to cover, or buy back, the stocks they are short.
There is a downside to investing according to seasonal patterns: it means frequent switching into and out of the market. Over the last two decades, in fact, the Seasonality Trading System has recommended an average of 16 such round trips a year. So do not even consider following the strategy in a taxable account or with any investment that involves high transaction costs.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Conservative Winner"Despite being invested in cash almost two-thirds of the time, the Seasonality Trading System, an investment model from the Institute for Econometric Research, has kept pace with the overall stock market since the early 1980's. HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
Nike inIndonesia, Through a Different Lens

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AROUND our house, there were two big stories in the footwear business recently: Critics of Nike again walked all over the company because of conditions in Indonesian factories. And my son got new sneakers for $7.
 Is there a connection between the two events? You bet. They both involve third-world workers desperate to better themselves. The difference is that, by buying the $7 sneakers, we actually did some good. 
 The latest flak directed at Nike, much beset by critics of its practices in third-world factories, comes in a report from the nonprofit Global Alliance for Workers and Communities, of which a penitent Nike is a founding member. The alliance said it uncovered a string of problems in a survey of 4,450 workers at nine Indonesian factories. 
What were those problems? Well, to start, nearly 8 percent of workers reported receiving unwanted sexual comments and nearly 2.5 percent said they had received unwanted sexual touching on the job.
These numbers are astounding -- astoundingly low. Last year, a Wall Street Journal/NBC poll found that 31 percent of American women had experienced workplace harassment. In the American military, according to a government survey for 1995, the figure was 55 percent. (It is possible, of course, that because of cultural differences or fear of retaliation, some Indonesian women interviewed by Global Alliance did not disclose possible harassment.)
Another finding in the Global Alliance survey was that 55 percent of the Nike contract workers in Indonesia were happy with company medical clinics, while 45 percent were unhappy. Yet few American factories have company health clinics, and 42 million Americans lack health insurance. 
The report also found that 30 percent of the Indonesian workers had been victims of verbal abuse, like swearing or yelling. Yet the report found that 73 percent of the workers were satisfied with work relationships with their direct supervisors, and 68 percent with factory management.
Some workers also complained that while overtime was voluntary, they felt pressure to take it. This at least differs from my past experience in the American newspaper industry, where overtime at smaller publications was often compulsory and sometimes uncompensated despite labor laws. The only widespread complaint, raised by 90 percent of the Indonesian workers surveyed, was that it was hard to get sick time off. Otherwise, the Indonesian factories appear to be models of their kind, providing incomes that are above minimum wage to workers who would be poorer in their absence.
Still, Maria Eitel, a Nike vice president and senior adviser for corporate responsibility, said the report's findings were disturbing. She said a remediation plan had begun to address the problems. 
Evidently, Nike has had to embrace the accusations of its accusers instead of boasting that, by contracting with factories employing more than a half-million workers in 55 countries, the company is running one of the world's most extensive international development programs. By hiring many women (83 percent of the workers in the Indonesian factories) Nike is giving them the economic power to help raise their often-lowly social status. 
The critics may score extra benefits for some workers, but by hectoring Nike, they weaken its brand and raise its cost of doing business. Well-meaning customers, upset by stories of sweatshops and happy to save money, may skip the Nikes and buy off brands. Of course, these knock-offs were probably made under worse conditions. 
Imagine for a minute that there were no big-name companies manufacturing in third-world countries. Everyone would buy the kind of no-name sneakers that we just did -- made in Guatemala under God-knows-what circumstances -- and there would be no one to try to embarrass except me, which will never work. Like most people, I want cheap sneakers. And I know that the Guatemalans need the money; otherwise, they wouldn't take these jobs. 
If companies like Nike are the devil that we know, the off-brand devil that we don't is probably worse. The day may come when Americans display their concern for third-world workers by making sure their Nike "swoosh" is showing. Then the logo won't be just ubiquitous; it will also be P.C.

HEADLINE: BRIEFING: ECONOMY; 
UNEMPLOYMENT RATE

BYLINE:  By George James

 BODY:
 While the nation's unemployment rate continues to climb, New Jersey's continues to fall. The state's jobless rate in January fell 0.2 percentage points to 3.6 percent, its lowest monthly rate since March 1970, according to figures released last week by the New Jersey Department of Labor. 
The figures, however, did not reflect recent corporate layoffs, such as those by Lucent Technologies, based in Murray Hill, which is letting go 10,000 workers -- 1,500 of them in New Jersey. Nonetheless, in a week when the economic news nationally was mostly bad, labor analysts were cheered by the fact the state's unemployment rate for the 13th consecutive month had fallen below the national rate, which was 4.2 percent in January. George James

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 
In Crowded Areas, a Parking Lot Can Look Like Paradise

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE

 BODY:
The real estate boom may have leveled off, but it has eaten up vacant lots used for parking, and their loss may be felt for years. At the same time, some residents say lots once viewed as eyesores provide relief in a crowded city.
 During the economic upswing, scores of parking lots from TriBeCa to Harlem were snatched by developers seeking to build residential and commercial buildings. 
 "As a result of their rising value and demand, as well as the availability of financing, sites that were not viable for development became viable," said Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
In SoHo, 10 of 17 remaining parking lots are being developed for new buildings, said Sean Sweeney, director of the SoHo Alliance, a community group.
New zoning rules adopted by the city have also encouraged more development. In the flower district along the Avenue of the Americas, which was rezoned in 1995 to allow for residential use, nearly 34,000 square feet of parking lot space have disappeared and an additional 59,000 square feet are being negotiated.
But in neighborhoods with little open air, some residents say they prefer parked cars to new buildings.
"Parking lots aren't seen as an eyesore anymore, but a relief," Mr. Sweeney said. "They provide sunlight and breathing room. We would rather see ugly hydraulic lifts for stacked cars than see a new building."
For car owners, this trend means higher prices and fewer vacancies. Nearly 900 parking lots are licensed by the city, but that number is expected to decline as developers complete real estate deals. And waiting lists of up to two years for an indoor spot are becoming more common, said Elliot Brownstein, president of Mutual Parking, which operates 60 garages in Manhattan. 
Mr. Rose of the Planning Commission said his department might revise 1982 rules aimed at reducing traffic by limiting the number of parking spaces.
"We are consciously in the process of changing the regulations to allow more off-street parking," he said. DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: INVESTING; 
How to Hedge Bets, Two by Two

BYLINE:  By JOANNE LEGOMSKY 

 BODY:
IT'S time to bring in the stock pickers.
 With grand strategies and firm convictions becoming casualties of the stalled, often rocky stock market, some people on Wall Street are reviving a strategy intended to capitalize on such difficult conditions. The approach, called pair trading, is essentially an exercise in extreme stock-picking that seeks to make an investor indifferent to the which way the overall market goes -- or whether it moves at all. 
 A pair trade means buying a stock that is thought to be undervalued while selling short an equal dollar amount of a similar or related stock, typically of a competitor, that appears overvalued. 
The short position, which is a wager that the stock price will decline, reduces risk by protecting against a market downturn. Offsetting it with the stock that is owned -- the long side of the equation -- makes an investor neutral to the market, and, depending on the picks, more or less impervious to the vicissitudes of a particular industry. What's left are bets on individual stocks. 
If the stock picks are squarely on the mark, an investor can make money on both the long and short sides, and the direction of the the overall market does not matter.
"It's actually an all-weather strategy, but it makes more sense in a sideways market," said Christopher J. Wolfe, equity strategist for private clients at J. P. Morgan Chase. "It works well with companies with similar products or end markets whose stocks are closely correlated, but where there is a valuation disparity." 
But the strategy can be used in gyrating markets, too.
"Pair trades also are a way to play volatility," Mr. Wolfe said. That is because any development that strengthens the competitive position of one of the companies versus the other, like a new product, will have a greater impact on the respective stock prices in a volatile market.
"The correlations become less stable," he said.
If you are unswervingly bullish or bearish, of course, you probably would be better off simply owning stocks or shorting them, without any hedge. "You don't hear much about pair trades in bull or bear markets," said Clark B. Winter Jr., chief investment strategist for Citigroup's private banking division.
But Mr. Winter said he thought the current investment climate made this strategy attractive for the bank's clients. He said Citigroup looked for hedge fund managers "with the ability to identify pair trades as part of their ongoing strategy."
Catherine Jackson, director of research at LJH Global Investments, a firm in Naples, Fla., that helps institutions and wealthy individuals assemble hedge fund portfolios, said pair trading was gaining appeal with managers investing in Europe.
"Everybody's using the strategy now," Ms. Jackson said. "What else can you do in a trendless market?" 
To sell a stock short, an investor sells borrowed shares and hopes that the price drops so he can eventually return them at lower cost, pocketing the difference. If it rises, the investor loses money, a theoretically unlimited amount. 
So should an investor buy, say, General Motors and sell short Ford Motor, which has a higher price-to-earnings ratio? Experts suggest caution in pair trading.
Like any form of active management, it has risks, because the investor is still picking stocks rather than relying on a broader, indexed approach that will provide average market returns. In fact, pair trades can increase risk, as well as reduce it. If you select the wrong stocks, you can lose money on both sides of the transaction. 
"It requires intensive research," said John Moon, manager of $1 billion in emerging-markets hedge funds at Oak Tree Capital. "You need to identify price anomalies plus make a call on the fundamentals." 
In his view, pair trades work best in volatile industries, like technology and telecommunications, because there is more opportunity to take advantage of stock price divergences. 
Mr. Moon is now shorting the stocks of several American manufacturers that work on contracts, because of high valuations and vulnerability to a prolonged economic slump, though he would not disclose any company names. He is long the shares of certain Asian companies in the same industry, like Elec & Eltek, which he considers more reasonably valued and likely to rise more when the sector improves. 
Robert Jain, head of global portfolio and program trading at Credit Suisse First Boston, regularly uses pair trades on behalf of the firm's clients. He said he thought the strategy's appeal was growing. "People are realizing that they can't rely on the market's continuing to go up," he said. 
But Mr. Jain usually recommends that clients buy a stock and short a related exchange-traded fund, a mutual-fund-like product that trades like a stock. Or, they may buy the E.T.F. and short the stock. "Buying one stock and shorting another doesn't reduce your risk that much," he said. "You're still assuming a lot of company-specific risk."
He is now recommending a pair trade that involves buying either the El Paso Corporation or Anadarko Petroleum, energy companies that carry the firm's top rating, and selling short either the iShares Dow Jones U.S. Energy Sector Index fund or the Energy Select Sector SPDR, a basket of energy stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange that has similar investment characteristics but is more actively traded. 
Mr. Jain also recommends buying either of two health care stocks, Johnson & Johnson or Pharmacia, and shorting the iShares Dow Jones U.S. Healthcare Sector Index fund. 
Using exchange-traded funds has an advantage beyond greater diversification. Unlike stocks, they are not subject to the downtick rule, which prohibits shorting a stock at a lower price than the preceding sale to prevent negative sentiment from snowballing.
"If you're trying to put on a trade of two stocks, there's a risk that you can execute one side and not another, because of the short-sale rule," Mr. Jain said. 
AT J. P. Morgan Chase, Mr. Wolfe is recommending several stock-for-stock pair trades to the firm's private clients. 
He advises investors to buy shares of Pfizer, the pharmaceutical company, and short the shares of its rival, Merck. He said that despite comparable valuations, Pfizer had fewer major drugs about to lose patent protection.
He continues to like a trade pairing a long position in Sun Microsystems with a short position in EMC. The companies have similar markets in data storage, Mr. Wolfe said, but he added that EMC was more vulnerable to weakness in this sector because of its still-high price-to-earnings multiple.
But Mr. Wolfe added this caution about pair trading: "This is a trading strategy, not an investing strategy," he said. "You should view it as a side bet."

HEADLINE: At a Horse Show, Entitlement Is in the Air 

BYLINE:  By GUY TREBAY 

DATELINE: WELLINGTON, Fla. 

 BODY:
NO sooner had the plane hit the tarmac at West Palm Beach than a passenger fired up his cell phone and started giving instructions to his groom. "If you go downstairs and look behind the door in my bedroom, my sticks are hanging on the door," the man said, in the adenoidal drawl one imagines as the speaking voice of characters in William Hamilton cartoons. 
 The sticks he was referring to were polo mallets. His knee pads, as fellow Delta Air Lines passengers soon learned, were in the closet by the stairs, along with his breeches and his boots. The man's helmet was in the hall closet in a monogrammed blue bag. 
 "It'll be terrific if you can just meet me at the club, just terrific, and that way I'll be able to get in an extra chukker," said the man, referring to the seven-minute periods that are polo's version of innings. Then he added, not remotely sotto voce: "Oh, and I've got a $100,000 check you can deposit for me on your way home." 
It is like that in Palm Beach County, where -- although the median per capita income is near the United States average -- there are houses the size of suburban banks, luxury cars built on the scale of public conveyances and, in general, a human-to-Gulfstream V jet ratio more impressive than any place outside Qatar. The economic downturn that has many middle-class people resetting their retirement dates seems to have made few inroads in these parts. One place where this can be observed most plainly is at the Palm Beach Polo Equestrian Club in this town 14 miles inland from the ocean.
It's here that polo teams fielded by the super-rich spend the winter at play. Here, too, is the site of an annual winter equestrian festival that represents not only the top-level equestrians in the country, but what may be the greatest seasonal migration of that tiny herd substantially in charge of controlling America's wealth. 
What began a little more than a decade ago as a place for snowbirds to campaign their sport horses during the bitter East Coast winters has now become the premier event on the American show jumping circuit. Beginning in January, the emerald lawns of the Palm Beach Polo Equestrian Club are transformed into the Cosequin Winter Equestrian Festival, a vast, luxurious tent camp accommodating a 10-week occupation by what Gore Vidal once characterized as America's stealth rulers, and Lewis Lapham has more delicately termed "the equestrian class."
Some of their names are the boldface kind: Kelly Klein, Patty Davis Raynes, Sloan Lindemann Barnett, Alison Firestone, Georgina Bloomberg, Cornelia Guest. Many are not. Equally, there are those here who are obscure outside the radius of a show ring and, inside one, virtual gods. They include the former Olympians Joe Fargis and Conrad Homfeld, the current Olympic team member Laura Kraut and national circuit champions like Margie Goldstein Engle. 
All of them convene each winter on what once was farmland abutting the Everglades. Here, in a suburb of equestrian-themed estates is set a multi-ring showgrounds, a stadium-size Grand Prix arena, and row upon row of green-striped tents erected to stable horseflesh valued conservatively in the scores of millions. Accompanying the approximately 6,500 animals that arrived this particular winter was an army of the wealthy: new money, dot-com money, Wall Street money and a significant number of people whose raw fortunes have been passed through the purifying filter of time. 
It is probably these types whom Warren E. Buffett, the Omaha investor, was referring to when he recently urged Congress not to repeal the estate tax. Without the tax, Mr. Buffett warned, "you pass down the ability to command the resources of the nation based on heredity rather than merit." Sportsmen are not the only ones to understand the importance of bloodlines to success. It's apparent to anyone visiting the Cosequin Winter Equestrian Festival just what Mr. Buffett means.
"The horse business is the biggest business in America," C. Z. Guest, the socialite and garden writer, observed last weekend, as she made her way to her family's private box overlooking the Grand Prix arena at the showgrounds. And it may be surprising to learn that more than seven million Americans are involved with horses, either as owners, service providers, employees or volunteers. A survey conducted by the Barents Group of Washington, D.C., concluded that the total impact of the industry on the United States' economy was $112.1 billion. A separate study by a private group tidily collapsed this finding to a more useful comparison of haves and have nots: "The ratio of horse owners whose annual income exceeds $100,000 to nonhorse owners who earn more than $100,000 per year: 4 to 1."
Wearing beige silk shorts and a white cotton cap stitched with the logo of the Myopia Hunt Club, Mrs. Guest leaned over a rail and waved toward a training arena where riders were conducting their mounts over four-foot "schooling" fences. "There's an awful lot of money floating around these days," she said. "These are $1 million and $2 million horses. Show jumping has gotten more expensive than horse racing, and I know because I've done both." Adjusting her visor, Mrs. Guest added, "Anyone who thinks there's a depression should come here."
Anyone who thinks there's a depression would probably be too spooked even to enter the showgrounds, where the aura of wealth is so palpable the whole place resembles the gentrified scenarios conjured in Ralph Lauren ads. It is not just a matter of obviously expensive horseflesh (horses at Wellington cost on average $50,000, although at the higher levels the threshold rises to $250,000 and above). Neither is it the $300 German riding breeches or $750 bespoke Der-Dau boots or $4,500 Hermes flat saddles or $1,400 alligator-banded Charles Pinnell chaps.
It is not the fact that, as one rider put it, "You can't even be standing here with one horse for under $10,000 a week." It is not that some owners ship their horses to Florida in private jets; or that others, like the Atlanta insurance heiress Mary B. Schwab, arrive with as many as 15 mounts. It is not even the fact that bicolor Rolex Oyster Perpetual watches seem to be the timepiece of choice -- for 12-year-olds. 
Rather, it is the palpable air of remove, an atmosphere of entitlement so casually assumed that it makes the effetely languid models in those Ralph Lauren ads seem like jokes or cartoons. Once you have turned off Polo Club Road and onto the showgrounds, you would be hard-pressed to believe that a world exists of bank overdrafts, credit card debt or mortgage shortfalls, never mind that only 30 miles down the road, people are actually setting cane field fires and then waiting for wild rabbits to flee the flames in order to club them for food. 
Wellington is not the place for those realities. It is, instead, where you will find the originals for all the bogus patricians central not only to Mr. Lauren's vision, but to that of so many designers, including Michael Kors. In fact, Mr. Kors's fall 2001 collection was entirely built around an equestrian theme, the models sent out in clothes inspired not so much by the clothes riders wear as garments for their mounts. Empire waist dresses were belted with the same type of surcingle belts used on horse "coolers." Coats were made in blanket wool. And why not copy horses when -- at Wellington, at least -- they're typically turned out as expensively and with as much chic as a Park Avenue socialite. 
"The horses have a dozen different blankets and sheets and rain blankets and turnout blankets," said Mark Badgley, half of the evening-wear design team of Badgley Mischka, who commutes each weekend to Wellington to ride one of his three hunters. "Everything is done in the barn's colors," he said. "And then the tack trunks have to match."
The stable blocks, too, are arranged in theme colors, with homey displays out front, each decorated with monogrammed felt banners. There are mounting blocks and saddle racks, hunting prints, antique jockey hitching posts, old wicker and cast iron chairs. "There's so much that goes along with the riding," Mr. Badgley said. Many of the big stables plant miniature gardens outside their tents for the season: dwarf palms, begonias, camellias arrayed in lush miniature lawns. "We were going to do a garden; we always have," explained Cornelia Guest, who long ago jettisoned her 1970's Deb of the Decade tag to pursue a career on the show jumping circuit. "But there's the drought," she added, referring to Florida's worst dry season in 100 years.
Ms. Guest has six horses at Wellington, which she rides in amateur owner jumper classes on courses with motocross turns, spooky angles and fences considerably taller than, say, Gary Coleman. "Cornelia has no fear, she'll jump a school bus," said Mr. Badgley. "She's also a prime example of someone who does this really seriously full time."
She is not alone in that. "Sure, it's a circus and a zoo, and with so many horses and riders and such a high level of money it's unreal," said Katie Monahan Prudent, a United States Equestrian Team and World Cup veteran. No one complains, Ms. Prudent added, because, "for every person who's down here, there's 600 people waiting behind them for a spot." 
For the athletes, added George Morris, the chef d'equipe of the U.S.E.T.'s show jumping team, "Wellington has become the toughest and the best" horse show in the country, even supplanting such traditional fixtures of the winter circuit as the National Horse Show in New York. "The indoor circuit has lost its luster because of this," said Mr. Morris, who has trained generations of riders at his New Jersey-based Hunterdon Farm. "Even the top, top, top riders from Europe, when they come here, don't just come along and win," said Mr. Morris. "The best course builders are here, the best riders, the best horses."
People say that show jumping "is elitist," Ms. Guest said. People would be correct. Yet, she added, "the sport is coming away from that image." Perhaps it is. "That show jumping is an expensive sport is not a misconception for a layman to have," said Mary B. Schwab, whose string of thoroughbreds and crossbreds are managed and ridden by Mr. Fargis, the Olympic medalist. Surveying the eight rings in which riders of all ages were trotting and cantering on a staggering array of immaculate horseflesh, Ms. Schwab added: "It's not entirely just pros and people who ride seven days a week who come down here. There are actually riders here who do other things. They have a life. They work at jobs." 
The accuracy of her statement must be taken on faith.

HEADLINE: Gone.com 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
DURING the week, while other people are at work, Christa Sidman, a 32-year-old casualty of dot-com fallout, answers the phone in her apartment on East 22nd Street.
 "I was laid off the week after Thanksgiving," she said during one recent call. "I still haven't found a job." Could she meet sometime to talk about it? "I am flexibility itself," she answered. 
 So, the next day, sitting in a sunny coffee shop, Ms. Sidman drained a cup and recalled her life in a far grander place, the white granite and brick 22-story building in Lower Manhattan where she used to work. 
Two Scottish brothers, George and William Audsley, completed the structure in 1898 in an eclectic style that the architects called Hellenic Renaissance. During its life the building, 11 Broadway, has sheltered banks, law firms, insurers, utilities, engineering outfits, maritime ventures and financial concerns. This is the story of the spectacular rise and fall of some of its most recent residents: more than 60 Internet and high-tech companies, and the people, like Ms. Sidman, who worked for them. 
Ms. Sidman's stay at 11 Broadway was just three and a half months. She worked in a dazzling office on the 17th floor for a dot-com called Stockback. The company projected its name on the entrance wall in white light and, every other week, its executives would don chef's hats and serve the employees a buffet of sausage and eggs. Her job, as a copywriter, was to explain the exhilaration of shopping online and getting a rebate, either in cash or in stock. She still remembers her best line, written for a campaign aimed at fraternities and sororities: "There's a time when another bake sale isn't going to do the trick." 
"You could sit and brainstorm whole new worlds into being," said Ms. Sidman, an Ohio native with a literature degree from Earlham College in Richmond, Ind. "They paid me more than I've ever been paid before to do what I love. They said they valued writers. I believed them. I still believe they meant what they said."
Ms. Sidman remembers gazing out the wide windows of 11 Broadway, watching the orange sunlight shining off the East River and the Statue of Liberty. She also remembers the Wednesday after Thanksgiving, the day she was fired, when she zipped over to the company meeting early to claim one of the cozy, deep leather couches. Soon, one of the owners stood up.
"Well," he said, "you know how the market's doing."
If your name began with A-L you had to get in one line, M-Z in another. The executives handed out envelopes containing a sheet of paper with a conference room and a time written in script. Workers showed up at their appointed time and, by day's end, 37 workers would have jobs and 29 would not.
Ms. Sidman's meeting was at 9:30 a.m. She would not be coming back. She barely heard the phrases: "nothing to do with performance," "appease our investors." They gave her a week of severance pay. She sat with a friend, the only other copywriter, and watched people file in and out of the conference rooms, then start to pack or to cry. At 11:30, her friend lost her job. They shared a cab uptown. 
"Don't tell me after three and a half months I have to look for another job," she remembers thinking that day. "Don't tell me. It was so fun to work here."
Although New York's economy is healthy, Ms. Sidman is clearly not alone among the young and the wretched in the Internet world these days. Still, as dry statistics pour into papers about dot-com layoffs -- more than 5,000 in the city in the last six months -- it is difficult to realize that the dot-com decline happens in real places. And one of those places is 11 Broadway.
The building -- on a walk north from the Battery, it's the second one on the west side of the street -- has witnessed other disasters. The White Star Line, owner of the Titanic, had its headquarters there, and when the ship sank in 1912 crowds of men in black hats thronged the entrances, shouting for news of their loved ones. In the mid-80's, the disgraced stock speculator Ivan F. Boesky had 9,500 square feet of office space overlooking the harbor.
Something always seemed off about the building, which is a designated landmark and is officially known as 5-11 Broadway. It was built on slanted ground and even had an oddball floor that was four and a half feet high from floor to ceiling, like the one in the film "Being John Malkovich." 
But money has no memory. In the mid-90's, with its cheap rents and funky, historic character, 11 Broadway seemed like a good place to start a business.

The Virtual Wagon Trains Begin to Arrive
Anthony Spina, a former newspaper truck driver, was the first Internet entrepreneur to arrive. It was May 1995, and he had recently started an Internet service provider, Thorn Communications. A real estate agent showed him 11 Broadway, whose owner, then and now, is a group called Bowling Green Associates.
The plywood walls in the elevator and the cheap pink wallpaper on the marble columns did not make the place look attractive. Nor was it brimming with tenants. "It was 10 percent full, if you count those who weren't paying rent," said Robert Shenker, the landlord's lawyer. But for $12 a square foot plus electric, Mr. Spina moved in.
"All of downtown was kind of a ghost town," said Mr. Spina, 42. "There was no incentive but good cheap space."
Mr. Spina quickly started exploring 11 Broadway, and he found incredible things. The building was like a streambed, with each floor, like a layer of sedimentary rock, trapping a different era. There were the old vaults of the steamship captains in the basement; an abandoned, dusty set of bookshelves, circa 1910; a newspaper lodged in a wall that announced the Russians had launched their first moon rocket, and a mysterious out-of-order shower on the top floor, which has a huge window built into the wall that would make the shower's users feel as if they were floating in air. 
Soon, Mr. Spina had neighbors. Another company, Web Factory, moved onto the third floor and started giving parties on the 16th, where fine harbor views made these pioneers feel as if they owned the world. They had art shows there, and disc jockeys. They roped off some areas so guests wouldn't fall through the holes in the floor.
"It was the wild, wild West," said Kim Hill, who was a partner at Web Factory, now defunct. He is now a vice president at Click Radio, an online radio station. "There was a sense of cash in the air."
More dot-coms arrived, claiming more and more of the building. Many came to 11 Broadway under the Plug 'n' Go program run by the Downtown Alliance, the local business improvement district. The deal: if landlords held down rents to around $15 a square foot, the BID marketed their properties free.
The dot-coms had esprit. They knocked off early on Fridays and played massive games of Quake, the popular computer game, at the eighth-floor offices of a company called Random Walk Computing. 
"There were just six nerds playing then; including me, seven nerds," said Edmund Bogen, who runs Bogen PR, a public relations company that worked with dot-coms and held informal bagel breakfasts for the dot-com workers. "Soon it went to 50 nerds."
Paul Guzyk, who ran an Internet service provider called Infohouse, started an e-mail list at 11 Broadway. Someone else set up a video camera feeding into a Macintosh in an empty office and called it LibertyCam. All day it gazed at the Statue of Liberty, like a cyberimmigrant perpetually arriving to live the American dream.
"The feeling was much newer then," Mr. Bogen said.

Halcyon Days Of Bagels and Foosball
By early last year, 11 Broadway had soared from 10 percent occupancy to 98 percent, and rents had shot up from $15 to $40 a square foot. The dot-coms had come marching in: Moving.com, Stockback, NetGrocer.com, Commissioner.com. WealthHound.com, an investing site calling itself the "portal to prosperity," took prestige space on the top floors.
Some grew fast. In spring 1997, Mail.com, which sets up e-mail systems for businesses, moved 20 people into a corner of the sixth floor. After going public in June 1999, the company spread to the whole sixth floor, then part of the ninth, then most of the second and parts of the third and fourth. By then it had almost 300 employees. Other companies arrived with such haste that the landlords didn't have enough time to add them to the floor directories. The startups glued and taped their names up instead.
"We used to laugh," said Michael Gersh, one of four fraternity brothers from Carnegie-Mellon University who ran a sports fantasy Web site called Commissioner.com. "Every third one would be like Cyberintertechnology Inc." 
Then there were the million-dollar redesigns. Tempest Software, an online security firm, converted the 16th floor into a minimalist space station, with clean lines, 17-foot ceilings and chrome spotlights. The cubicles were fashioned from a special white surface that could be written on, making the whole office a literal drawing board. 
Fun was embraced. "We got a Foosball table and at one point in time, it was myself, the vice president of engineering, the vice president of professional services and the president, playing a game of Foosball," said Roland Cozzolino, a Tempest executive. "I looked around and said, 'You realize how much money is being spent on us playing Foosball right now?' " 
For a time, it didn't matter. In December 1999, Paul Guzyk sold Infohouse for $3 million in cash and stock. That same month, Mr. Gersh and his fraternity brothers sold their company for $31 million. The night of the sale, they rented a skybox at ESPN Zone to see a football game and in their glee and civic gratitude sent some Dom Perignon to Mayor Giuliani, who was sitting nearby.
Matt Fortnow, one of the fraternity brothers, bought a bumblebee-colored Harley-Davidson for $21,000. All four had to work at Commissioner.com for a year after the sale, but since then Mr. Fortnow hasn't worked. He wrote a screenplay about a baseball team during the Depression, applied to be a Big Brother, is installing a new kitchen in his one-bedroom co-op on the Upper East Side and goes out almost every night.
When asked if he would ever need to work again, Mr. Fortnow said, "No."
Perhaps nothing captures those halcyon times better than the day in June 1999 that Mail.com went public.
When the Nasdaq exchange opened, Lon Otremba, the chief operating officer, and other executives were there. They cheered as the price soared from its opening at $8. Back at the office, with the stock still rising, the employees had a catered lunch and their shouting was heard buildingwide. Then they stormed out the bronze doors of 11 Broadway, charged up to the bull sculpture in Bowling Green and rubbed its nose for luck. They snapped pictures of themselves, to remember the day forever.
Company executives had urged everyone to remember that going public was a beginning, not an ending, but the excitement was great. And for a while, justified: by December 1999, six months after Mail.com went public, the stock hit $29 and the young founders were worth $26 million.

The Year the Heroes Fell to Earth
From April to December of last year, the dream dimmed.
Mail.com, the best-known publicly traded company there, felt it first. Overnight, the office became like some bizarre day-trading hell, where nervous employees checked the stock price every five minutes.
"When the stock price went down 20 percent in three days we knew something was happening," Mr. Otremba said. "It felt awful. The week before you were a hero."
The decline hit Internet service providers like Infohouse, then owned by Network Plus, which saw a couple of clients fail to pay bills. It hit Internet publicity firms like Bogen PR and Breakfast Network Productions, another Bogen venture, which laid off six people in November. It hit dot-com consultants like Hudson Williams, which laid off two people this January and widened its clientele to include traditional businesses.
"It hurt," Mr. Bogen said. "It hurt really, really badly. It was a massive crash."
Overnight, the reversal transformed futuristic offices of promise into dark caverns of empty desks. People grimly joked about stealing a part of the bull's anatomy to stave off disaster. Eventually, in one way or another, everyone was affected.
Belts were tightened. Workers switched from car services to yellow cabs and stopped the office massages. There were fewer coolers full of free soda, fewer spreads of food at fewer parties.
"We all hoped we were going to be rich and we'd never have to work again," said Dana Zerlin, who still works at Hudson Williams. "Now a lot of people are going to corporate companies."
The stock of Mail.com fell below 75 cents. It now trades in the $1 range. The company also cut its staff, slashing 15 percent on Oct. 30, making it a very creepy Halloween Eve. 
Dan Duffany was one of those Halloween casualties, getting one month's notice and three months of severance pay, he said.
"I've been discovering the joys of daytime TV and Pokemon," Mr. Duffany said. He finally landed a job two weeks ago with a Yonkers company that makes stage sets. 
"I put the brakes on all my spending immediately," Mr. Duffany said. "Going out to dinner frequently stopped. The DVD's stopped. I stopped shopping at Balducci's and went back to the Food Emporium." During the December holidays, he added, "I was not as generous as I'd like to have been. I felt ashamed at first. I like to treat my nieces and nephews well, and I was like, 'Gee, I really have to cheap out this year.' "
Mr. Otremba himself left Mail.com in November to head another dot-com. But, he remembers, "The stress level rose at home" as the troubles persisted. 
"My wife was looking at the financial pages," he said. "I couldn't sell any shares. Most paper wealth was just that."
"I'm proud of the work I did," Mr. Otremba said. "It's somewhat bittersweet. I'm still a sizable stockholder, so I'm cheering them from the stands."

Web Sites of Yore: You Can't Go Home Again
What about Christa Sidman? 
On most mornings, she wakes up, eats a blueberry muffin, works on her resume and searches for a job in a market glutted with dot-com people. Sometimes she just can't deal with it and strolls through the East Village and window-shops. At times, she nostalgically logs onto the Stockback site. 
She can't afford to shoot pool at Fat Cat Billiards in the West Village anymore, but she does pull out old Duran Duran and Fleetwood Mac records from high school, and listens to them with her cat, Uma.
"Not having a job is not like a vacation," Ms. Sidman said. "You don't feel free. You're either actively looking, or you feel like you should look. One thing I did not do is cancel my Club Med vacation in March. It's costing a thousand bucks."
When she talks about that trip to Mexico, with dance lessons and horseback riding on the beach, her spirits seem to lift.
At 11 Broadway life goes on, but far less ebulliently. Holly Lehr, a spokeswoman for Mail.com, said it plans to move to New Jersey. And in mid-February, the venture announced it would drop its dot-com label and change its name to EasyLink Services. 
Dot-coms are going mainstream in other ways. Mike Atwood, the new chief executive of Tempest Software, arrived at its offices the other day carrying a resume that includes a stint at Electronic Data Systems, the company founded by Ross Perot that now employs 125,000.
"You have to bring in people of influence and power," said Mr. Cozzolino, the Tempest executive. "It becomes more like a regular day-to-day company." 
Matt Fortnow rode his Harley away from 11 Broadway for the last time on New Year's Eve. His frat brothers stayed on, but soon they will move to Fort Lauderdale, Fla., to the headquarters of SportsLine.com, the new owner of Commissioner.com.
As old companies leave, new ones arrive, with 11 Broadway still essentially full, Mr. Shenker said. Loquesea, a Web site based in Caracas, Venezuela, is now building an office with mosaic tiles and dark-stained cherry wood on the 18th and 19th floors.
On a recent afternoon, Mr. Guzyk returned to 11 Broadway from the West Side offices of Network Plus, the new owner of Infohouse. He took the elevator to the 11th floor and unlocked the tiny room where Infohouse began. A single blue data cabinet sat in the once busy room, coldly whooshing. Wires lay strewn across the floor.
"At one point in time our entire operation was in this room," Mr. Guzyk said, waving his arm over the rubble, which the company will soon abandon altogether. "We had seven people in here and our equipment. It looked like this when we got here and we cleaned it up. Now it looks like this again."
If 11 Broadway had a voice, it would be that of Prashant, the 24-year-old with mocking eyes who runs the lobby newsstand, where, he says, business has slowed.
"Every day companies come and companies go," he said on a recent afternoon. "What do I care? I never ask them about their business. They tell me that it's their last day, that they have to find a job. What do I care? What's going to happen if I do?"
In case you lost track of time, it all took less than six years.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CLINTON; 
The $4 Movie Goes the Way of the 5 cents Phone Call

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE

 BODY:
Cineplex Odeon Encore Worldwide, long known to moviegoers as the $3 theater on West 50th Street, closed its doors two weeks ago, just as ticket prices citywide reached a record high.
 Since 1994 the theater, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, had booked second-run films as well as first-run releases that had already played elsewhere. Its final schedule included movies like "Charlie's Angels," which was released in November and can still be seen at about 70 theaters around the nation. 
 The low prices drew crowds from across the city. After holding prices steady at $3 for several years, the theater recently raised admission to $4. But that amount was still far less than the city's average ticket, which cost $8.50 last summer.
"I'm devastated," said Maura Keaney, who lives in Flatbush, Brooklyn, and works as an aide to City Councilwoman Christine Quinn.
"I'm from Florida, where there are still dollar theaters everywhere," Ms. Keane said. "I thought $4 was still a rip-off, but now I'm quite upset." 
Officials at Loews Cineplex Entertainment, which ran the theater, said the closing had stemmed from the company's recent filing for bankruptcy as part of a deal to be acquired by an investment group.
"The economics just don't work at that price point," said Mindy Tucker, a Loews spokeswoman. "It had suffered from competition from newer theaters like the AMC Empire Theater nearby."
But a week after closing what was one of the city's cheapest theaters, Loews announced that it was raising prices at its 13 remaining theaters in Manhattan, to $10 from $9.50. The change, which became effective last Friday, made New York the only city with a double-digit movie stub. Loews also raised prices at its theaters in the other boroughs.
The markup elicited nostalgia from some. 
"I'm old enough to remember 50-cent tickets," said John Fisher, who lives in Clinton. "Prices today are obscene." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: BUSINESS; 
The Deeper Dangers of Corporate Bankruptcy

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
OMINOUS increases in commercial debts, defaults and delinquencies are signaling that a new wave of bankruptcies is approaching. But many vulnerable companies may be less prepared to withstand the pain than those at risk during the last wave, a decade ago.
 Back then, the overwhelming challenge faced by corporate America was the debt itself: companies were making money, but not enough to pay creditors. Fixing corporate balance sheets by rescheduling loan payments and converting debt to equity went a long way toward solving problems. 
 Those solutions alone will not work this time, say bankruptcy and debt restructuring experts. While many struggling companies are carrying too much debt, the more difficult problems are their weak, often unprofitable businesses. 
Many companies today have assets that are hard to value and sell. They lack revenue to finance even rescheduled debt payments because their business plans assumed market demand that does not exist. As a result, bankruptcy lawyers must delve deeply into poorly planned businesses to decide whether they are even worth saving.
"In today's economy, more often than not, the company that is in distressed condition has operational problems," said Harvey Miller, a partner at Weil, Gotshal & Manges,in New York, a large law firm with a well-established bankruptcy practice. As a result, he said, eliminating debt alone "may not be sufficient to effect a reorganization."
That is a big difference from the main cause of corporate bankruptcies 10 years ago. Edward I. Altman, a finance professor at New York University's Stern School of Business who did a study for Salomon Smith Barney on corporate debt, said that from 1989 to 1991, more than half of defaults were "due to ill-fated, leveraged restructurings."
To determine whether a company in distress now can be saved, bankruptcy specialists must learn about its strategy, target market and manufacturing or production. If a company is not generating significant profits and has no imminent prospects of doing so, creditors do not want to reschedule loan payments or swap debt for equity, Mr. Miller said. Such a situation could arise, he said, if a company poured money into infrastructure, like cables or satellites, that would not generate profits for years.
If a company has overestimated demand, then "given the credit market as shaky as it is, it's difficult to get new debt to fund operations and it's as difficult, if not more difficult, to refinance the existing debt," said Dominic DiNapoli, managing partner of business recovery services at PricewaterhouseCoopers in New York.
IF refinancing is not an option, Mr. DiNapoli said, lawyers and financial advisers to the company and its creditors must quickly identify those business lines or assets that can generate enough revenue to sustain the company and pay its debts. 
Iridium Communications is an example of the problem's intractability. Iridium had planned to sell a worldwide satellite telephone service. To do so, it had to launch satellites into orbit, at huge cost. Then it had to persuade people to buy bulky, one-pound handsets to use the service.
Getting money to build and launch the satellites was, in retrospect, too easy. Finding customers was the problem. 
That left the company short on revenue and landed it in bankruptcy court, where finding a solution has proved difficult. Swapping debt for equity would not repair the balance sheet in the absence of a viable business -- why would anyone want the equity of a company with no revenue? Selling the assets required a buyer that saw value in a set of satellites serving overweight handsets. That bankruptcy appears headed for litigation to sort out who did what to whom, and who should pay. Creditors like Chase Manhattan Bank, Alliance Capital and Conseco, which once were happy to finance the satellites, are bitter.
The mistake of financing too much growth based on hope of future market demand is not confined to telecommunications and other technology companies. Several movie theater chains, including Loews Cineplex, Carmike and United Artists, have sought bankruptcy protection because they built too many new theaters financed with debt, and too few customers bought tickets.
"How did the industry believe that it could support an expansion to 37,000 screens, at a time when attendance per screen was going down?" Mr. Miller asked. 
Of course, as several lawyers pointed out, people will keep going to the movies. So the theater chains' prospects for survival are better than those of technology companies that, like Iridium, used borrowed money to bet on a product that would not generate profits for years at best.
And given good management, a company's operations can be streamlined and debts eventually paid. Even some bankrupt telecommunications companies may recover, said Bill Repko, managing director of the restructuring group at J. P. Morgan. 
Before a bankrupt company can be saved from its own mistakes, financial advisers and creditors must obtain reliable information on exactly what is generating revenue, said Al Koch, managing principal at Jay Alix & Associates, a Southfield, Mich., firm that helps distressed companies reorganize.
Equally important, he added, is finding the money-losing operations. "If I'm a retailer, do I have unprofitable stores that need to be closed?" he asked. 
The search for good information is often complicated at troubled companies because departing employees take their knowledge of the business along with them. That helps to explain why many dot-com companies that have failed over the last year have not filed for bankruptcy, lawyers say: once employees leave, there is not much in the way of assets to sell to pay creditors.
THE next step in the salvage process is determining where the more successful business lines will be most highly valued, said Corinne Ball, a Weil, Gotshal partner who represents bondholders in the Iridium bankruptcy.
"Who or what has an interest in what major part of this business surviving?" she asked. If the owners are intent on saving the business, the focus should be on helping them jettison unproductive assets. If an outside buyer is solicited, then the focus should be on having that buyer pay the highest price, she said.
The expected difficulties from a new wave of corporate bankruptcies are not completely new. They are similar to what happened in the 1970's, Mr. Miller said, when real estate investment trusts bought tracts of land, only to see their value plummet. The difficulty for bankruptcy specialists was figuring out how or whether the trusts could repay creditors when the trusts had no prospect of earning income anytime soon.
The lessons of the 70's, Mr. Repko said, are simple, if not inspiring: "The fixes will take longer, they will be more difficult, and it will be a lot more challenging to maximize the recoveries."

HEADLINE: CITY LORE; 
Learning to Love the World Trade Center

BYLINE:  By TARA BAHRAMPOUR

 BODY:
MAYBE it happened in 1974, when a Frenchman strung up a tightrope and balanced his way from one tower to the other. Maybe it was in 1977, when a man they called the human fly scaled the South Tower as hundreds of New Yorkers looked on in amazement. Or it could have been in 1975, when an unemployed construction worker parachuted from the North Tower in an attempt to draw attention to the world's poor (some office workers in the building called to report a suicide; others waved).
 But Robert Fitch, author of "The Assassination of New York" (Verso Books), has his own theory about what made New Yorkers learn to love the World Trade Center, which 10 days ago was leased to a commercial real estate firm based in Paramus, N.J., for $3.25 billion -- the largest such deal ever. 
 "King Kong was probably the watershed moment," he said, referring to the 1976 remake of the movie in which the gorilla, desperately in love with Jessica Lange, scales one of the towers. "If King Kong could love it, who are we to disagree?"
We don't. Today the World Trade Center is the city's most often-sent postcard image, it appears in countless advertisements and its familiar silhouette once formed the logo of WPIX television, underscoring the indelible mark it has made on the Manhattan skyline and the city's psyche.
It wasn't always that way. When construction began in 1966, the Twin Towers were part of a less-than-popular urban renewal plan that sought to transform shabby Lower Manhattan into a sleek business district. The 110-story towers would form a hub for international trade, and, planners hoped, would help recapture Lower Manhattan's lost title as the city's main business center. 
The project added 12 million square feet of office space, and its excavation soil formed Battery Park City. But its construction destroyed 16 acres of existing neighborhoods, and many jobs were lost. 
Besides, people thought it was ugly. "Architectural historians and art critics were mostly unimpressed," said Angus Kress Gillespie, professor of American studies at Rutgers and author of "Twin Towers" (Rutgers University Press). "They called it banal, boring, unimaginative." 
A telling sign of the times was the fact that the towers' offices were designed without light switches. Lights would simply be left on overnight. "At that time it was a rational decision," said Mr. Gillespie, noting that energy conservation was not then a priority. "But just as the building was completed, there was this big energy crisis. Everything just seemed to go wrong."
Even birds hated the World Trade Center.
"The buildings interfered with flight patterns," Mr. Gillespie said. "Birds were bumping into the buildings and dropping dead on the plaza."
But over the years Manhattanites got used to the double-cigarette silhouette hanging from the lip of their island. 
And although the World Trade Center, unlike the Brooklyn Bridge or the Empire State Building, has not inspired droves of artists, a few have warmed to its gleaming aluminum charms. The artist and architect Allan Wexler recalled going out daily at dusk to photograph the new towers. He saw them as "not just an icon but a barometer that kind of marks the changing weather and lighting conditions." As for their metaphysical qualities, "I always saw it as a sort of Tower of Babel or Jacob's Ladder," he said, "an attempt to penetrate through the cloud layer and attempt enlightenment."
Mr. Wexler was so taken that he planned several projects around the towers. One, never carried out, involved pulling down the shades of specific windows at night to allow the lighted windows to depict different images. 
"I was interested in the idea of binary surfaces," he said. The towers would be blank canvases upon which the forms of other buildings, like the Empire State Building or Notre Dame, could be etched. He described it as "a cataloguing of various images that the World Trade Center could then turn itself into," allowing the New York skyline to change nightly.
Eventually Mr. Wexler produced his own renditions of the project, as well as a photomontage in which he added a third, identical tower to the skyline.
Meanwhile, public sympathy got a boost from the daredevil acts at the towers. It helped that the city, after arresting each stuntman, played its public relations cards right. The tightrope walker was sentenced to perform a high-wire act for children in Central Park. As for the climber, George Willig, "It took hours for him to climb up," said Mr. Gillespie, adding that the feat was tracked by live television cameras. "He gets to the top, he's arrested."
To deflect negative publicity about the arresting of a folk hero, the city fined Mr. Willig one penny for each of the 110 floors he climbed. "So George Willig gives the mayor $1.10," Mr. Gillespie said, "they shake hands, and what could have been a P.R. disaster becomes the World Trade Center's first turnaround."
Another turnaround involved the views. While one tower housed an expensive restaurant, Windows on the World, the other offered an observation deck that was deliberately inexpensive. "Rank-and-file New Yorkers came to embrace the building," Mr. Gillespie said. "It's really won the hearts and minds of New Yorkers."
And of the world at large. "If you're treating it as poetry," Mr. Gillespie said, "it stands for capitalism, for free trade, for private enterprise, and, by extension, for the American dream." 
Even illegal immigrants have joined the chorus. According to the Immigration and Naturalization Service, stowaways on freighters in New York Harbor have been found carrying only a crumpled postcard of the World Trade Center. And the 1993 bombing only seemed to bolster the towers' sense of permanence, as a truckload of explosives failed to topple them. 
Technically, its title as tallest building on earth still stands, sort of. "It's not the tallest building in the world, and yet it is," said Valerie Lewis, a spokeswoman for the Alliance for Downtown New York. If you count the trade center's 316-foot antennas, she explained, it tops even the 1,483-foot Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. 
To many, the recent real estate transaction confirmed the World Trade Center's status as an indispensable city landmark.
"It was quite a change, quite an embrace," Mr. Gillespie said. "What was once kicked around by everybody is now the most precious real estate in Manhattan."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS; 
Building on Ideas for Urban Conservation

BYLINE:  By LINDA BAKER 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore. 

 BODY:
WHEN construction crews finish converting a 105-year-old brick warehouse into an office-shopping complex here this summer, visitors will have the chance to shop for fleece outdoor wear made from recycled plastic while sipping organic coffee. Parents will be able to inquire about investing for their children's education in environmentally responsible mutual funds. 
 Small-business owners will have the opportunity to apply for loans at a bank that encourages conservation. And the building's office workers will be able to open their windows -- with frames built from certified sustainable lumber and reclaimed scrap wood. 
 "How do you turn a building into an experience of the conservation economy?" said Diane Dulken, director of the building, the Jean Vollum Natural Capital Center (named for an environmental philanthropist who helped to finance the renovation). "We're trying to provide an experience of the great new ideas that we want to become standard in the future, and that we're experimenting with right now." 
As policy makers search for solutions to the West Coast power crisis, the Natural Capital Center, near downtown, has become something of a model for the creation of buildings that conserve energy and are otherwise ecologically friendly.
The building, which was not damaged in the earthquake that hit the Pacific Northwest last week, is owned by Ecotrust, a nonprofit organization based in Portland that promotes compatibility of economic development and environmental protection. Ecotrust had spent more than $1 million on earthquake-protection measures required by the city code, according to Bettina von Hagen, director of the Natural Capital Center Fund. 
The renovation of the warehouse, once a United States Steel depot, is considered a prominent example of a national trend toward imaginative workplace architecture, as well as toward more environmentally sound buildings. It includes wide-open spaces that are supposed to encourage interaction, even to the point of eliminating some barriers between tenants. 
Ecotrust faces some challenges in making the building a success, however. For the rental space, it is charging $18 to $23 a square foot, which is considered quite high by Portland standards. So only well-financed tenants can afford leases. Partly for that reason, Ecotrust has been having trouble filling all the space. Visions of a farmer's market in the building's vast "green marketplace" atrium, for example, are now considered unrealistic. 
And while the building recycles rooftop rainwater, uses power-saving lights and has more parking spaces for bicycles than for cars, Ecotrust is not calling it an island of natural purity. The building relies on the same basic electricity and sewage services as its neighbors.
SPENCER BEEBE, Ecotrust's president and founder, acknowledged the financial challenges in an interview, saying he was concerned about repaying millions in loans. "This could eat us alive," he said.
Nonetheless, 80 percent of the 70,000 square feet of space has been rented by a combination of business and nonprofit tenants that share a commitment to environmental restoration.
Mr. Beebe, a longtime conservation activist who has worked for the Nature Conservancy and Conservation International, perhaps never envisioned himself as a landlord. He said Ecotrust was inspired to try the renovation by Jane Jacobs, an Ecotrust founding board member, whose book, "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," is enjoying a revival as a manual for innovative office design. 
The center is "a cluster of organizations which are necessarily different and diverse but are sufficiently clustered around critical themes," Mr. Beebe said. It is, he added, "a place where we hope people discover spontaneous connections and relationships with other people, other tenants, other customers, other stories."
The building is the first urban revitalization project undertaken by Ecotrust, which gained prominence several years ago by creating a fund to invest in environmentally minded businesses. It also helped to found ShoreBank Pacific, a bank that promotes environmental conservation and economic development in the Pacific Northwest. The bank is a partnership of Ecotrust and the Shorebank Corporation, a Chicago community development bank that emphasizes socially responsible investing.
Ecotrust bought the building two years ago with the help of a $2.5 million gift from Ms. Vollum, whose husband was the founder of the Tektronix Corporation, which makes high-technology products. Additional financing comes from $3.5 million in grants and $5 million in foundation and conventional loans. When the center is fully occupied, the organization hopes to generate $250,000 annually for Ecotrust programs.
THE rental rates are high partly because the building is in one of Portland's hottest real estate markets, an industrial neighborhood near the Willamette River. Patagonia, the outdoor-clothing retailer, will be the anchor tenant, occupying 8,000 square feet on the ground floor. 
At a groundbreaking ceremony last year, Michael Crooke, the chief executive of Patagonia, called the Natural Capital Center a venue for "the business partnerships of the future."
Other tenants include Progressive Investment Management, creator of Portfolio 21, a mutual fund that invests in environmentally sustainable enterprises, and ShoreBank Pacific. Carsten Henningsen, who founded Progressive Investment in 1982, said he decided to move to the Natural Capital Center rather than renovate its existing home, a Victorian-era mansion. 
Nonprofit tenants include the Certified Forest Products Council, which promotes land management that sustains forests; the Wild Salmon Center, an international organization working to protect salmon; and Ecotrust itself. A ground-floor retail area is intended to house a combination grocery store-restaurant, which will sell foods like free-range Oregon beef and oysters harvested from replenished seabeds.
The building will also house a 2,500-square-foot conference center for public lectures and workshops.
With its high-profile restoration of the warehouse, Ecotrust is beginning to have an impact on Portland's development policies and practices. Bob Naito, the main contractor for the Natural Capital Center, plans to incorporate some of the building's features in his next project, a new office building that is also in Portland's River District. 
Inspired by meetings with Ecotrust and a visit to the Natural Capital Center, the Portland City Council last month adopted legislation that requires an expedited permit process for construction projects that show concern for the environment.
"This is a huge step forward," Ms. Dulken said. "Rather than just taking into account what city-owned and managed projects can look like, this is taking it to the private sector and saying, 'What can the city do to get green building right?' "
The design of the Natural Capital Center includes an "eco roof," accessible to the public, and a filtering system that will recycle all of the building's rainwater, eliminating runoff into the Willamette River. About 97 percent of the construction debris has been reclaimed for other uses. The Portland Streetcar, a downtown mass transit system scheduled to open this summer, will have a stop in front of the building.
Inside, the architecture features skylights, wide hallways, ample public spaces and a noticeable lack of walls. Visual openness in office design, intended to promote collaboration and new ideas, is a trend among businesses and nonprofit organizations alike.
"Designing with nature as metaphor is potentially powerful and backed by some scientific data," said Judith Heerwagen, a Seattle-based psychologist and consultant. Case studies of office workers demonstrate that ecological design promotes communication and interaction and reduces stress, she said.
Ms. Heerwagen said the psychological and social effects of habitat design were not always positive. "There is evidence that noise generation due to openness is a serious problem," she said. Because of lighting problems, she added, rehabilitating an urban warehouse is also much more difficult than building a new company headquarters "out in a bucolic landscape." 
"But that's the message," she said. The Natural Capital Center shows the "congruence between the values of the work and values of the building."
For Mr. Beebe, the Natural Capital Center is a bet on the office building of the future.
"We're always searching and asking ourselves whether we're making any difference," he said. "Although we have a high tolerance for ambiguity and unpredictability, we keep asking ourselves what we are really accomplishing."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Jean Vollum Natural Capital Center is being built in a renovated warehouse, above right, in Portland, Ore. Construction workers, above and right, placed the first layer of an "eco roof" atop the structure. (Photographs by Michael Wilhelm for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Utility Deregulation: Square Peg, Round Hole?

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
IN the forensic pursuit of what caused California's power failure, the Bush administration, the energy industry and many analysts have granted immunity to deregulation.
 Robert Shapiro, a managing director of Enron, the giant electricity marketer, says the California mess should in no way affect deregulation in other states, "because California didn't really deregulate." Spencer Abraham, the new energy secretary, said Californians simply goofed, setting up a "dysfunctional" system. It is the way California deregulated, not deregulation itself, that should take the blame, they say. 
 Yet some economists argue that California's troubles should inform the debate about whether -- not just how -- to deregulate. Among them is Alfred E. Kahn, the Cornell University economist who helped oversee the creation of free markets in the rail, trucking and airline industries.
"I am worried about the uniqueness of electricity markets," Mr. Kahn said. He is still studying whether the design flaws in California's market explain the whole problem. But he is sounding a note of skepticism.
"I've always been uncertain about eliminating vertical integration," he said, referring to the old ways of allowing a single, heavily regulated power company to produce, transmit and distribute electricity. "It may be one industry in which it works reasonably well."
Mr. Kahn's comments might sound a little heretical. When this former Carter administration official was pushing deregulation, it was still a novel and politically risky concept. Today, getting government out of most businesses is part of the Washington economic canon.
Moreover, few people believe that California, the first state to overhaul its electricity sector from top to bottom, has proved a good laboratory. To satisfy interest groups, the markets were designed in an awkward way, which soured some deregulation experts on California before the first electron went on the auction block.
Among the quirks: The state required utilities to buy nearly all their power on daily spot markets, rather than arranging long-term contracts that might have allowed them to hedge risk. Consumer prices were also fixed, making it impossible for utilities to pass on higher wholesale costs.
Paul L. Joskow, an expert on electricity markets at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and a former student of Mr. Kahn's, remains hopeful that the kinks can be ironed out.
In New England and the the Middle Atlantic states, as well in as Britain, Chile and Argentina, all places that have restructured electricity markets, regulators have had to adjust market rules to correct flaws. They have found ways to check the tendency of power sellers to exploit infant markets and charge high prices, Mr. Joskow said.
Regulators have also had to establish new markets that, through price signals, encourage power companies to build enough generating capacity so that they have reserves for peak hours. During peak hours, shortages and price spikes can substantially raise average prices.
"If they can do it in Britain, Chile and Argentina, then I think we can do it here," Mr. Joskow said.
Still, he warns that proper regulation requires tough political choices. Allowing high prices to pass through to consumers is one. Making sure Nimbyism does not prevent the construction of power plants is another.
"The political system must rise to the task," Mr. Joskow said, or the "old way might be the best we can do."
Mr. Kahn knows a bit about the old way. In the mid-1970's, he headed the New York Public Service Commission, which oversaw electricity and other regulated industries. The drawbacks were legendary. Local utilities had an endemic tendency to overestimate demand to justify new power plants, for which consumers paid through steady rate increases. Nearly everyone assumed that competition would slash prices.
But though free markets do a better job managing rail, phone and airline prices, they have yet to match regulators' ability to juggle the complexities of electricity, Mr. Kahn said.
Regulators tended to apply heavy political pressure on utilities to keep prices as low as possible and profit margins steady but thin. The vertical integration of electricity monopolies may have also had advantages, Mr. Kahn said. Engineers coordinated power plants and transmission lines in ideal ways. Planners who saw the need for new plants helped find a place for them to be built. "The players all depended on one another," he said.
California has probably not derailed deregulation efforts. But it has made people wonder anew whether market forces work for kilowatts as they do for widgets.
