HEADLINE: The World: A Sorry Mess; 
Taking the Measure of Suffering

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH dispatched a special envoy, a Navy admiral, to Japan last week to make another in an extraordinary string of apologies for the sinking of a fishing school boat off Hawaii by an American submarine early last month. And yet feelings on both sides of the Pacific remain as ruffled by the fuss over making amends as over the accident itself. 
 From the Americans, the first regrets may have come from a high level, but those directly responsible remained silent. After it was clear the Japanese were infuriated, there were phone calls to Japan by President Bush, visits with family members by Ambassador Thomas S. Foley and many other gestures. Rarely has Washington apologized at so many levels for an accident involving the armed forces. 
 But relatives of the nine people still missing from the accident and Japan's government and media complain bitterly that the Americans have shown bad form, and possibly bad faith, in explaining the accident and atoning for the loss of life. Some called for the captain of the submarine, Cmdr. Scott D. Waddle, to apologize even after he sent a letter to Japan's national television network, an effort some called insufficient, insincere and indirect. He finally had his apology accepted -- by showing up at the Japanese consulate in Honolulu with letters for the victims' families, and bowing and weeping before a ranking Japanese official. 
The nations' painful pas de deux is easily seen as a cautionary illustration of how cultural misunderstandings can separate even allies as close as the United States and Japan. The accident's aftermath may be unnecessarily painful simply because, from subtle gradations of bowing to the elaborate calendar of shrine visits and offerings that Japanese use to expiate guilt, apologizing is woven into Japan's politics and psyche in a way that remains foreign to America. 
But the incident, examined more closely, reveals a range of Japanese, not American, problems, from deepening post-cold war malaise and smoldering resentments of American success to the country's own hypocrisy in coming to terms with its Asian neighbors.
Richard Cohen, a columnist for The Washington Post, touched this nerve when he wrote that Japan's attitude smacked of "epic hypocrisy" because of Japan's much belated, and for its neighbors still dubious, apologies for the atrocities committed by the Imperial Army in Asia during World War II. 
By coincidence, the column appeared on Thursday, while the Japanese government was under attack by both China and South Korea for plans to approve new textbooks that describe the war not as a vicious imperial conquest, but instead, in a chilling revival of Japan's wartime propaganda, as a benevolent effort to create a "Greater East Asian War of the Co-Prosperity Sphere." Also last week, a lawsuit was brought against two Japanese conglomerates in a Los Angeles court seeking damages for Koreans forced into wartime slave labor.
But the column drew an indignant reply from Japan's ambassador to Washington, Shunji Yanai, who said that Mr. Cohen was not "entitled" to speak about Japan's past.
Recrimination over apologies has been a constant feature of relations between Japan and its East Asian neighbors for decades. The display of raw feelings between Japan and the United States has been much rarer. But now, latent Japanese resentment toward the United States in many areas have come to the fore. Most notably, Okinawa's governor acted on his region's increasing anger over the huge American military presence -- fueled by a history of crimes committed by troops -- and demanded that Tokyo negotiate a reduction.
Some Americans, resentful of Japan's complaints about the apology, see manipulation. "They are trying to build up leverage for something, politically and psychologically, for negotiations with the United States," said Ivan P. Hall, author of "Cartels of the Mind" (Norton, 1997), an exploration of Japanese protectionism. "It may be on trade issues, it may be on the bases, it may be on something else. They are abusing a tragedy." 
IN a similarly ominous vein, some Japanese say the accident was planned. "There were suggestions in some magazines that this was somehow deliberate," said Yoshikuni Igarashi, a historian at Vanderbilt University and the author of "Bodies of Memory" (Princeton University Press, 2000), an examination of World War II on Japanese culture. "It is difficult to know what to make of this except that the accident is not just about the nine lives that were lost. It has become symbolic of the relationship between the two countries." 
Patrick Smith, an analyst of Japanese affairs, said: "There is a restlessness under the surface of the relationship. The accident was a very regrettable thing, but it didn't put the restlessness there. It was the eruption that let it come through the surface. You see it in the things that people are looking for from the U.S., and most importantly, they are looking for justice. 
"Justice comes from equality in the relationship. And that is the rub here." 
In the first days after the accident, Japanese anger was directed mostly at the country's prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, who brushed off news of the sinking and continued playing golf, saying later: "Why is this an issue of emergency management? It is an accident, isn't it? I think I exercised my leadership." 
But Mr. Mori, whose popularity has sunk into the single digits, is merely the least impressive of a string of failed prime ministers. Most have simply worked to forestall change while Japan's problems accumulated, from repeated recession and shrinking population to rampant bankruptcies and exploding public debt. Many Japanese people feel their country is doomed to decline.
"The American government gave the best possible response," said Makoto Iokibe, a historian at Kobe University specializing in relations between the United States and Japanese. "But when one's psyche is injured, you can only give attention to one side of a problem."

HEADLINE: Iraqis Who Look Back in Anguish 

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: SAFWAN, Iraq, Feb. 28 

 BODY:
Most days, Hamza Jabbar comes to this silent, deserted border crossing to sit, and remember. From where he rests, on a concrete plinth bearing a benign portrait of Saddam Hussein, he can see across a rusting barrier to abandoned customs sheds and down a heavily potholed road that leads to Kuwait.
 For Mr. Jabbar, the hours spent alone here, hands resting on a walking stick, are filled with unquenchable regret. Down the road, 85 miles away, lies Kuwait City, where for 37 years he was one of thousands of Iraqis with solid salaried jobs -- in Mr. Jabbar's case as a $750-a-month storeman in Kuwait's Education Ministry. He had a home and a lifestyle that were better than anything he could have hoped for in Iraq. 
 That life is gone now, along with the pension that Mr. Jabbar, who is 67, hoped would sustain his retirement. On Aug. 2, 1990, Iraq invaded Kuwait; on Feb. 27, 1991, the Iraqi occupation force fled headlong, pursued by the military might of a 33-nation alliance. Afterward, all Iraqi citizens were ordered out by Kuwait's restored rulers. 
Under the United Nations economic sanctions adopted after Iraq's invasion, and reinforced after the war, Iraq was cut off from all normal commerce with surrounding states. Here at the Safwan border post, where thousands of cars and trucks once crossed daily, vehicles from the United Nations force that monitors a nine-mile-wide demilitarized zone straddling the border have been the only traffic for 10 years.
Where Mr. Jabbar sits, there is little but stillness, and a solitude that gives him the time to juggle his painful memories and sometimes, he admitted, to weep.
Asked what solace he found in his vigils, the old storeman, squinting from beneath his Arab headdress in the noonday sun, pondered for some time, then spoke finally, in a quavering voice. "I come here when I am upset," he said. "I had a good life there, in Kuwait, for many, many years, then one day I looked up" -- he raised his arms skyward -- "and suddenly, everything was gone -- my job, my house, my pension, even my son. I lost everything, only because I was an Iraqi."
His 21-year-old son, Ahmed, he said, was shot dead by Kuwaitis amid the wave of recriminations that accompanied the Iraqi withdrawal as he tried to retrieve the family car and drive it home. At the time, thousands of Iraqis were trying to escape with cars they had looted.
In the United States, and other countries, the victory over the Iraqis 10 years ago is remembered, mainly, as a moment of decency restored, and six months of brutality and pillage by Iraqi troops ended.
But the war is viewed through quite another prism in Iraq, and not only in the proud pronouncements that have accompanied Iraq's official commemorations of what Saddam Hussein called "the mother of all battles," and the veiled hints, from senior Iraqi officials, that if they had the chance they might try to take Kuwait again.
The Baghdad government has used the occasion to weave the Kuwait invasion ever more firmly into the hagiography, pronouncing the day of the Iraqi attack "a joyous moment in the history of the Arab peoples' struggle" and pledging, in the "immortal memory" of the estimated 20,000 to 50,000 Iraqi troops who died, that Iraq will never forsake the "road taken" in 1990. Officials in Mr. Hussein's inner circle have indicated that they have nothing to regret.
And then there are the bitter reminiscences of ordinary Iraqis. For the war itself, they paid heavily -- as soldiers who suffered injuries and sicknesses attributed to allied bombing, and relatives of people killed in the fighting or when American or allied bombs went astray.
Beyond all this, there are the privations endured by all but the most privileged of the 23 million Iraqis. Surveys by the United Nations, and estimates by Iraqi economists, have put the shrinkage in Iraq's economy under the impact of the war and sanctions at anything between 20 and 50 percent; inflation in the 1990's devalued the local currency, the dinar, by more than 5,000 percent. 
As they guide foreign journalists around the country, monitoring every conversation and every photograph, and stepping in abruptly to halt anything they deem potentially injurious, Information Ministry officials lay heavy emphasis on the human suffering. In a country that has never officially conceded defeat, the concern to lay the blame for this suffering on the United States prompts these officials, sometimes, to lead what amount to guided tours of Iraqi troops' humiliation.
One such place is Jabal Sanam, a rocky hill a few miles southwest of Safwan, where, Iraq says, American aircraft attacked a unit of the Iraqi Army's Soviet-built T-62 tanks on the night of Feb. 26 to 27, 1991.
From what is visible now, the American planes struck every tank with such force that they remain, a decade later, where they were hit, their rusting hulks resting deep in gullies, their turrets blown 150 feet or more away, and the burned-out seats for their four-man crews covered with what appear to be human ashes.
A mile north of Safwan, by a highway interchange, is the spot where American and Iraqi generals met in an American tent to sign a cease-fire agreement. But Jabal Sanam is more central to a new Iraqi thrust against the United States.
The Iraqi contention, vigorously contested by the Pentagon, is that the use of depleted uranium warheads on tank-busting missiles, and other bombs and rockets, led to thousands of cases of leukemia, lymphoma and other cancers. Similar charges have been made by groups representing gulf war veterans in the United States and Europe, but officially commissioned British and American studies have reported no evidence that the incidence of cancer is higher than in the general population.
At Jabal Sanam, Iraqi officials behave with self-conscious unease, as though to press home the allegations about depleted uranium. Empty oil barrels painted in the United Nations colors of blue and white carry hand-painted warnings in English, "Bomblet Area," denoting that cluster bombs were used in the American attack, and not cleared. One bomblet was visible only feet from the road leading up the hill to a blasted tank.
While two Westerners walked cautiously over the tanks to inspect and photograph them, the officials lingered nearby smoking, occasionally calling out to drive home their point about high levels of radiation allegedly detected here. 
"It is not good to stay here too long," said one. "Radiation here is very high. Many people in Safwan have blood cancer from this place."
Getting closer to the truth of the allegations is difficult, even after visiting supposed victims in Safwan and Basra, the oil city 35 miles north of Safwan that underwent heavy American air attacks. Visits to two sufferers -- a 9-year-old boy in Safwan with a mass of suppurating scars on his face that doctors said remain undiagnosed and a 28-year-old war infantry veteran who developed lymphoma in 1996 -- produced wrenching personal stories, but little to link the cases to the war.
Perhaps most striking, considering the ceaseless government polemics against the United States, few ordinary Iraqis seem inclined to engage in political recriminations over the causes of the war, or over the heavy American bombing.
Few of those interviewed had anything harsh to say about the American decision to reverse the Kuwait invasion, and only a handful, mostly former officers or officials, seemed ready to depict the conflict as an occasion of glory for Iraq.
Umran Abid Ali, the lymphoma victim, who met visitors in a Basra house shared with 13 relatives, described how he survived an air attack on a retreating column on the night of Feb. 26 by jumping off the tank when he heard approaching aircraft. "When I saw that all the vehicles in the column had been destroyed, I was afraid," he said, describing the fireball that consumed tanks, trucks and cars. "I heard some soldiers who were trapped in their vehicles crying out for help, and then everything went quiet."
For years, Iraq described the battering of retreating columns as war crimes, but Mr. Ali talked as though the attack was to be expected in war. Like many other veterans, he focused his indignation on the economic sanctions; all 14 members of his family, he said, live off one salary, that of his brother Ahmed, who said he makes about $8 a month as a trader in Basra's bazaars.
After a tour of the gulf region this week, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell said he would recommend that Washington revamp the sanctions -- for which support has frayed among Arab nations and even European allies -- to reinforce elements intended to hinder an Iraqi arms buildup, while easing suffering.
General Powell said Arab allies reported that the sanctions have had the effect of strengthening Saddam Hussein. This observation is supported by United Nations reports and complaints by some intrepid Iraqis, who contend that the government has diverted some of the $10 billion of food and medicines bought with carefully monitored oil revenues to regime loyalists, fostering an artificial crisis among the less fortunate.
Disabled veterans get a pension, equivalent to about $4 a month, enough for three cartons of eggs. But others, including Mr. Ali, said they had received no government money at all. Baghdad and Basra are filled with veterans on sidewalks selling off pitiful remains of their households -- old plumbing parts, ancient steam irons, old vinyl records.
Perhaps because his cancer is advanced, perhaps out of weariness at the parade of reporters brought to see him, Mr. Ali responded to a question about what he would say to Saddam Hussein with a directness that was startling, considering the common habit of lauding the Iraqi ruler whenever his name comes up. "If I met His Excellency, I would tell him, 'Please, bring us good doctors and medicines and food,' " he said. "I wouldn't tell him, 'Make war on America, they did bad things to Iraq' -- no, no. I would only say, bring us the best doctors, bring us the best medicines, and bring us food."

Before the gulf war, he held a good job there, but lost everything, including his son. HEADLINE: AUTO RACING; 
The Crossing of Faith and Big-Time Sport

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
The current beatification of Dale Earnhardt as a man's man who sacrificed himself to shepherd his flock to the finish line, a hero who in death evoked both John Wayne and Jesus, has presented America with its biggest jolt of sports and evangelical Christianity since Billy Sunday left the Chicago outfield a century ago to become a superstar preacher. But it should not be a surprise.
 "In many ways, evangelical Christianity and big-time sport are similar," says Prof. William J. Baker, an expert on both. "Both are win-loss mentalities. In evangelical Christianity you are either saved or lost. You've gone to Heaven or you've gone to hell. You win or you lose, and that's what sport is all about." 
 Stock car racing, born on the red clay of the Bible belt, may be the major sport that institutionally most encourages religious practice. Physical danger lurks in the corners, as does instant economic disaster. The uneasy mixes of man and machine, individual heroics and teamwork, ego and corporate sponsors, endless travel and young families, create a roiling sea of stress.
Talking to the chaplain is far more acceptable in this culture than talking to a psychotherapist. And don't forget the need for forgiveness -- bumping a rival out of your way as well as cheating on technical specifications are common practices, only recently frowned on.
The sport's most celebrated active star, Jeff Gordon, says: "There is a fine line in our sport between trying to do the right thing and trying to do the competitive thing that puts you over the top to win. We've had a lot of conversations in our Bible studies about that. God wants us to do all of what we know in our abilities to win the race, but we all know in the back of our minds what wins a race in a way that you'll feel proud and what wins a race in a way that you're not very proud of."
Gordon, Darrell Waltrip, Dale Jarrett and Joe Gibbs have been stalwarts in Motor Racing Outreach, a 13-year-old program whose circuit-riding preachers provide scheduled trackside services as well as grief counseling. Two M.R.O. clergymen, Max Helton, a founder of the group, and Dale Beaver, reached national television audiences last month at the memorial service for Earnhardt. Along with ministering to NascarNation, M.R.O.'s goal has been to reach that national audience.
"God is using people in these higher-profile positions, whether they are the drivers of these race cars or the men that make it happen," Beaver said. "God is using them to remind people, 'I'm still here, I'm not silent and I still care about you.' "
Gordon said: "I think I've been put on a platform to show other people what God has done for me in my life. I think God wants all of us to spread that word and be able to influence others, so they can live a better life."
The above quotations are all five months old, gathered with the producer Lou Charlip for a PBS show, "Religion & Ethics Newsweekly." Despite their willingness to discuss their religiosity when asked, stock car drivers tend to be less publicly ostentatious in their expressions of faith than many baseball and football players.
They are certainly more restrained than Sunday, who admitted to having prayed for a divine push while chasing fly balls. But as did Sunday, the drivers bring the grit and sweat of the arena to the pulpit, a 19th-century ideal of muscular Christianity. In his time, Sunday's fans credited him with restoring the masculine aura of Christ and of rescuing religion from women and effete clergymen.
But it wasn't until the 1970's, with the rise of groups like the Fellowship of Christian Athletes and the Baseball Chapel, that evangelical Christianity once again became a strong presence in big-time sports. (Coincidentally or not, this was at a time when the world's most famous athlete, Muhammad Ali, had abandoned Christianity for Islam.) In some locker rooms, the splits between blacks and whites, and between boozers and dopers were overshadowed by the schism between so-called God Squaders and the Unsaved. Ballplayers who felt oppressed by the born-agains questioned their commitment to winning and snickered when they were arrested on vice charges.
Outside stock car racing, this is still a hot issue. The flip side of joyously thanking Jesus on television for a touchdown is muttering, "It was God's will" when a kick sails wide and the game is lost. Is religion, like drugs and performance-
enhancement therapy, yet another way for athletes to find an edge? And what about Carolina Panther Reggie White, the so-called minister of defense, an ordained clergyman who has never been officially censored by the National Football League for offensive remarks about gays?
As president of the Texas Rangers, George W. Bush encouraged what was the epicenter of right-thinking locker-room religion. When Joe Gibbs was the Washington Redskins' spectacularly successful coach, he says he "never not hired somebody, kept somebody on a football team -- I've never even asked that question -- but if you ask me personally are we better performers for knowing we have a personal relationship with Christ, I think I am."
Now a spectacularly successful Winston Cup team owner, Gibbs told me last September before a race in Richmond: "I think God makes everything about everything. Does he have a hand in everything? I think he has a hand in the outcome."
Stock car racers tend to be wary of sharing faith with the more expressive baseball and football players, many of whom, the racers say, are praying to "trinket Gods, false Gods," to bring them better luck. Professor Baker, who grew up in northern Georgia, was the "passing preacher" as a quarterback at Furman and now teaches history at the University of Maine, detects racism in this -- stock car racing is overwhelmingly white.
But Baker, author of the forthcoming "Playing With God," a study of religion and sport, is convinced of the logic and the sincerity of the response to Earnhardt's death.
"When good old boys say Dale's in a better place now, they mean it," Baker said last week. "You go to Heaven because you believe in Jesus, not by your good works. You can live your life like a dog, but be saved at the end. And that's like sport, too. You can win on the last lap."

The Series So Far
 This is the seventh article in a series following auto racing, its safety, its sense of family and its popularity. Previous articles were about the sport's appeal to a crossover audience, the search for the sport's Tiger Woods, a veteran driver's view and how the sport's insiders deal with death on the track.

HEADLINE: Gipper Meets 'Survivor' As G.E.'s Image Hardens; 
PCB Battle Tests a Venerable Tradition

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
One of the more upbeat theories of postmodern capitalism is that nice companies will eventually finish first. In a market of instant information, where perception and image are increasingly linked to stock prices, investors will reward the environmentally green and the socially conscious because such companies have fewer potential liabilities, or so the thinking goes.
 But the nice-guy theory is getting a major test in upstate New York, where General Electric is waging a vehement, line-in-the-sand battle against dredging the Hudson River to remove the PCB's that its factories leaked or dumped into the water in the decades after World War II. 
 Environmentalists, economists and stock market experts say that as the company has poured tens of millions of dollars into a campaign of television infomercials, billboards and lobbying over the last year, an argument about the future of the river has increasingly mutated into an argument about G.E. itself. The messenger has become the message. Whether the federal Environmental Protection Agency's proposed $460 million dredging plan to remove the river's pollution at G.E.'s expense is the right scientific answer has become a battle instead over which side to trust. 
And that in turn presents a whole series of questions, not only for the local residents who are being bombarded with sound-bites about E.P.A. high-handedness and river hydrology, but for the legions of investors who for years on end have worshiped the company and its chief executive, John F. Welch Jr. Last month, G.E. was declared the most admired corporation in the world for the fourth year in a row by Fortune magazine.
Is there a point at which G.E.'s Hudson strategy backfires and becomes an environmental liability? Is G.E.'s dismissive tone about the federal government a mark of arrogance, as critics suggest, or the righteousness of a just cause in the face of a dictatorial federal bureaucracy, as company officials claim? 
Perhaps most crucially, what does the campaign say about its intended audience? What, in the end, do Americans really admire -- the stand-up citizen who admits responsibility and takes a poke in the eye, or the win-at-any-cost competitor? Do people want the most decent person in the Australian outback to win a million dollars, or the most cunning?
Some experts on corporate behavior and the environment say the most revealing thing about the Hudson-G.E. fight is that it could occur at all.
"It's a testament to how much times have changed that a company can even float a campaign like this," said Andrew J. Hoffman, a professor of management at Boston University who has studied the frontier of business and the environment. In the early days of environmental regulation, Professor Hoffman said, corporate public relations efforts mostly focused on damage control -- like Exxon's strategy after the Valdez oil spill or Union Carbide's after the chemical disaster in Bhopal, India.
A proactive campaign like G.E.'s, charging that the environmental regulators are simply wrong, incompetent or politically motivated, shows not only how much more complex environmental issues have become, he said, but also how much the power bases have shifted. Fewer people believe the government has all the answers, and corporations have charged in to fill the gap.
General Electric used polychlorinated biphenyls for nearly three decades at two factories in the towns of Hudson Falls and Fort Edward. An estimated 1.3 million pounds of PCB's, oily chemicals that were later linked to cancer in humans and various problems in wildlife, leaked or were discharged into the river. Most of it is gone, E.P.A. officials say -- absorbed into the tissues of fish, animals and people, or washed out to sea. The government's plan, announced in December, would try to recover about 100,000 pounds of PCB's from the most polluted hot spots along a 40-mile stretch north of Albany. 
The company's counterattack to dredging -- on which it has spent by some estimates $60 million or more over the last year in the Albany media market alone -- is stark and stylistically striking. The G.E. spokesmen are invariably tieless and looking relaxed, often before an inviting river backdrop. Everyone looks windblown and outdoorsy -- at home in the natural world. 
Film clips of E.P.A. officials, by contrast, especially the former administrator, Carol M. Browner, show her standing awkwardly at a lectern, with the clear suggestion that she is a woman of the indoors -- or worse, a Washington insider. Harsh, metallic background music that sounds like something from the movie "Hannibal" surges up whenever a clip is shown of an E.P.A. dredging site. Even city buses in Albany now carry anti-dredging billboards. 
General Electric's vice president for corporate communications, Beth Comstock, said that G.E.'s strategy was simply to educate. The company's scientific inquiries have shown the E.P.A.'s dredging plan to be ill conceived and potentially disastrous for the Hudson's ecosystem and the local economy, Ms. Comstock said, and G.E. has an obligation to make sure residents are informed of that. Under the E.P.A.'s rules, the government must consider local opinion in the area of any proposed environmental remediation -- a comment period that in the Hudson case runs through mid-April.
The fight is not about saving the company half a billion dollars, Ms. Comstock said. "The easiest thing in the world would be for G.E. to write a check, but that's not what this is about; it's about finding the right answer for the river. People admire G.E. because we're willing to fight for what we believe in."
Stock market analysts say that for now G.E. seems to be suffering not at all for its defiance.
"Those appreciative of G.E. tend to be appreciative of Jack Welch's hard-charging style," said James N. Kelleher, a senior analyst at Argus Research in New York. "G.E.'s aggressive brand of capitalism and unwillingness to kowtow to environmentalists may not be winning them any enemies in the investment community, and may be winning them some adherents."
But there are also some subtle indications that what had been a kind of fire wall within G.E.'s image -- investors cheering on one side, environmentalists booing on the other -- may be eroding a little. Last year, a resolution put to the company's shareholders by a coalition of religious groups asking G.E. to give a full report of how much it was spending on media and lobbying drew more than 8 percent of all votes cast. That was nearly three times the number needed to keep the resolution alive for presentation a second year. And in February, a column in Fortune magazine -- in the same issue crowning the company as most admired -- forcefully called on G.E. to "just do it," and announce a cleanup of the river.
Sociologists and other researchers who study corporate behavior say that G.E. has long been a mirror for American society, because so much of its culture has been bound up in the presentation and cultivation of its own image. In the 1950's, for example, when Ronald Reagan became G.E.'s front man and "General Electric Theater" was the company's national television platform, G.E. was paternal and competent, an unflappable commander just back from the war, said Peter D. Kinder, the president of Kinder, Lydenberg, Domini & Company, a Boston-based firm that does social research for institutional investors. But beginning in the 1980's and 1990's, he added, a different ethos emerged in America, and at General Electric.
"Now they're tough in all the areas it's fashionable to be tough in," Mr. Kinder said. And while he stressed that G.E. failed most of his tests to qualify as a socially responsible investment, he confessed to a certain admiration for its "They're brilliant," he said.
Some experts on science and economics say that part of the backdrop of G.E.'s fight is that environmentalism itself has changed. The anti-establishment, anti-business youth culture groups that put together the first Earth Day in 1970 have in many cases become powerful and well-financed environmental lobbying organizations. Many corporations, meanwhile, have seen that environmentalism can be good for business, and have actively marketed themselves as ecologically correct pillars of hardheaded real world expertise.
Instead of passively embracing the values of environmentalism, some business researchers say, companies are redefining what it means to be green at all. In the same way that many once-radical environmentalists of the street were tamed, so too were anti-environmentalists of the boardroom.
What has not changed, at least at the E.P.A., is the idea that rational science will carry the day. The agency's mission on the Hudson, a spokeswoman said, is not to manipulate public opinion, or use emotion on the river's behalf, but rather to put forward the best evidence available and trust in the intelligence of the public.
"We are not out there to sell this like a can of soup," said Ann C. Rychlenski, a spokeswoman for the agency.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS; 
Why Is He on Top? He's a Tyson, for One

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: SPRINGDALE, Ark. 

 BODY:
JOHN H. TYSON may be this state's latest comeback kid.
 Just over a decade ago, while he was addicted to drugs and alcohol, he was named to the board of Tyson Foods, the giant poultry company that his grandfather founded in 1935. He was also a lobbyist for Tyson, calling upon some of the most powerful politicians in the land, though for three years, he said, he had a "nonexistent" relationship with his father, Donald J. Tyson, who was then the company's chairman and chief executive. 
 Then, in the mid-1990's, when he was president of Tyson's beef and pork division, John Tyson became caught up in a political scandal; it culminated four years ago, when he was named an unindicted co-conspirator in a special prosecutor's case against the former agriculture secretary, Mike Espy, who was accused, but ultimately acquitted, of illegally accepting gifts and favors from Tyson and other big corporations.
Despite that unusual resume, John Tyson is now the chairman and chief executive of Tyson Foods, the nation's biggest chicken processor. He is also the force behind Tyson's decision early this year to acquire IBP, the world's largest beef processor, for about $3.2 billion, in a merger that would make Tyson the nation's No. 1 processor of beef and chicken and the second-biggest processor of pork. 
That Mr. Tyson got to the top, despite abusing drugs and sometimes acting cavalierly on the job, illustrates just how much power the Tyson family retains in what is, after all, a public company. Family members own less than a majority of the outstanding shares, yet they control 90 percent of its votes. 
Some big investors have criticized the company because of that dual-class stock structure and because its board is made up largely of insiders. But few have publicly opposed the appointment of Mr. Tyson, 47, who says he stopped abusing drugs and alcohol in 1990.
And Don Tyson said he had no doubts about his son, who became chief executive last April. "Within the past years, he's stepped forward and proven himself a serious business person," Mr. Tyson said in a statement. "I am really proud of what he's done since assuming the role of chairman in 1998. The way our company has operated in the face of very difficult circumstances in our industry is a testament to John and his entire management team."
But as John Tyson takes over, the company is facing some of its stiffest challenges in decades, from slumping chicken prices and eroding profit growth to recurring questions about his company's labor and environmental practices.
There is also growing skepticism about whether it can successfully merge its operations with those of IBP, and even uncertainty about whether it can complete the deal. For one thing, the merger is being delayed by the Securities and Exchange Commission, which is looking into accounting irregularities at a unit of IBP.
But perhaps the biggest challenge facing Mr. Tyson -- whom employees at the headquarters here still call Johnny -- will be to convince investors and skeptics that he can run what would be the nation's biggest meat company, a $23 billion enterprise.
For his part, Mr. Tyson appears to be moving fast to put his stamp on a company that is shifting course after more than two decades of spectacular growth. In less than a year, he has restructured the company's operations, reshuffled top management and then, in one bold move, snatched IBP from the clutches of Smithfield Foods, the nation's biggest pork producer and processor, after a fierce bidding war.
Mr. Tyson is confidently, even aggressively, pursuing his own course, though his father, Don Tyson, 70, is still involved with the company's big decisions. If the son succeeds, Tyson will be processing nearly one-quarter of all meat sold in the United States and will become the nation's third-largest packaged-food company, behind Philip Morris's Kraft Foods division and Conagra.
In an interview in his office, which his father adorned with chicken and egg motifs, Mr. Tyson spoke candidly about his drug and alcohol abuse and his seemingly unlikely comeback. But he scoffed at the suggestion that he was not qualified for the top job. "If I wasn't qualified, I wouldn't have this job," he snapped.
Chief among those qualifications, of course, was being the only son of Don Tyson, the flamboyant and politically powerful head of Tyson Foods from 1967 to 1995. John Tyson says that was not his only virtue.
He was an excellent student at Springdale High School, where he was on the student council and participated in basketball, golf, gymnastics and track, he said. Though he attended three colleges as an undergraduate -- the University of Arkansas in Fayetteville, the University of Southern California in Los Angeles and Southern Methodist University in Dallas -- his grades were solid.
It was in college that he began to drift. He lost faith in God and began to drink heavily and to experiment with drugs, he said. "I didn't stay on the path," he said, referring to his Presbyterian and Methodist upbringing. "I was wandering around."
Still, in 1975, he graduated from S.M.U. with a business degree, then spent a year at the University of Arkansas law school before dropping out. He later said he had decided that lawyers were paid to give opinions while he wanted to make decisions.

Law School to Hog Farm
He would get that chance at Tyson Foods. In the 1970's, the company was blossoming into a chicken giant, acquiring big competitors and perfecting an efficient factory-like farm system that now processes close to two billion chickens a year.
Shortly after law school, he recalled, he traveled to New York with his father to meet a man who was selling a hog operation to Tyson. It was one of the company's earliest efforts to diversify. He was sent to North Carolina to manage one of Tyson's small hog operations.
In the late 1970's and early 80's, he worked in a variety of jobs at Tyson, but as late as 1989, few people expected him to succeed his father as chairman and chief executive.
Marvin Schwartz, who was writing a book about Tyson Foods at the time, said John Tyson was not a serious contender for the top jobs. When he asked about interviewing John Tyson for his book, he said, Don Tyson's answer was: Don't bother.
And when Mr. Schwartz proposed having father and son pose in front of a portrait of John W. Tyson, the company's founder, for the book's cover photograph, Don Tyson again discouraged the idea. "I asked Don, and he didn't think there was any use in that," Mr. Schwartz recalled. Don Tyson posed alone.
The reasoning, one Tyson executive said, was simple: John Tyson, at the time, was thoroughly messed up. From 1984, when he joined Tyson's board, to 1990, he was addicted to cocaine and alcohol. His friends knew it, his family knew it and, apparently, so did the company.
"I can tell you the only reason I was on the payroll is because I was the son of the boss," John Tyson testified at a 1998 court trial that grew out of the Espy case. "Any other corporation, I would have been thrown to the wolves."
For the better part of six years, he was lost. "Everything was foggy," particularly his work at Tyson, he said, and he became "a renegade." That included wearing a ponytail that he liked to flop over his shoulder, just to get attention.
He got married around that time, but his friends say that his behavior was erratic and that he occasionally appeared depressed. In social gatherings, he often showed clear signs of being under the influence.
"There were times when it was extremely noticeable," said Woody Bassett, a lawyer who has known John Tyson since childhood. "If he didn't handle this, I'm not sure he'd be here today."
Even Wall Street analysts noticed the problems in the 1980's, when Mr. Tyson appeared at conferences or social functions with other company executives. "He showed up boozed at one of the meetings," said an analyst who asked not to be identified. "He had lost a lot of weight."
Friends say Mr. Tyson's drug and alcohol problems ended shortly after a trip they took with him to Dallas, where they visited Butch Davis, a childhood friend who was an assistant coach of the Dallas Cowboys.
During that weekend, Mr. Tyson seemed depressed, they say. At the end of the trip, Mr. Tyson returned home and sought treatment. He said he received "private help" and also went to Alcoholics Anonymous and Narcotics Anonymous -- a decade later, he still attends meetings regularly -- and undertook the A.A. 12-step program.
He said he had his last drink in November 1990. "I count my birth date as December 1, 1990," he once said. "Since then, I've been headed in the right direction."

Recovery and Rise to Power
Mr. Tyson also tried to rehabilitate his professional life. He says his relationship with his father improved, and so did his career prospects. In 1990, he was a vice chairman at the company, but with very few responsibilities. Within three years, he rose to president of the beef and pork division -- just as the small unit began to lose sales. He later headed the international division just before it faltered with the collapse of the Russian economy in 1998.
Wall Street analysts say he failed to distinguish himself in either position. But they also say he received some of the toughest assignments.
"One could argue he's never been given the best hand to play," said John McMillin, an analyst at Prudential Securities. "But I don't think he did much with the cards he had."
Then came the political scandal. In 1994, a special prosecutor began investigating Mr. Espy, who resigned amid suspicions that he had accepted gifts, lodging and other favors worth thousands of dollars from people and companies he was supposed to be regulating. Tyson Foods topped the gratuity list.
Tyson Foods pleaded guilty to making illegal gifts and agreed to pay $6 million in 1997 for illegally funneling $12,000 worth of gifts to Mr. Espy in 1993 and 1994, when the agriculture department was mulling costly safety labeling regulations.
John Tyson figured in nearly all the transactions. He met privately with Mr. Espy, accompanied him to a Dallas Cowboys football game, and helped Mr. Espy's girlfriend, Patricia Dempsey, obtain a $1,200 scholarship from the Tyson Foundation. Tyson Foods also paid $2,556 for Mr. Espy and Ms. Dempsey to travel to Arkansas for a 1994 weekend gala to celebrate the birthdays of John Tyson and Don Tyson's girlfriend, who were both turning 40.
In exchange for their cooperation, Don and John Tyson were granted immunity from prosecution. Still, they were named as unindicted co-conspirators in a case that eventually led to prison sentences for Tyson's communications director, Archibald R. Schaffer 3rd, and its Washington lobbyist, Jack L. Williams. (Both men were pardoned in January by President Clinton.)
A jury acquitted Mr. Espy of all charges in December 1998.
John Tyson says the Espy case was just part of a political witch hunt that had more to do with President Clinton than with Tyson Foods.
The company said that all it gave Mr. Espy was an "act of common hospitality." 
Mr. Tyson said, "We became a political football, and when you're a football it doesn't matter which side you're on, they're going to kick you." 
The scandal clearly did not impede Mr. Tyson's rise to power. Don Tyson, who had taken over after his own father was killed in a 1967 car accident, stepped down as chief executive in 1995, when he turned 65.
First, Leland Tollett, a longtime Tyson executive, was named chairman and chief executive. In 1998, when Wayne Britt took over as chief executive, John Tyson became chairman, replacing his father, who became senior chairman. Last year, when Mr. Britt resigned for personal reasons, John Tyson added the title of chief executive. The company would not say if other candidates were considered, but John Tyson was the highest-ranking family member in the company. (His two younger sisters once worked there.)
In the 1980's, Randal Tyson, Don's half brother, had been groomed for a major role at the company, but he died in 1986, at 34, after choking on food. Family friends say he and John Tyson, who were only a year apart, were close; a few days before the death, the two had talked at length about how they would some day run Tyson. Don's death made John, despite his troubles, the most likely heir to the throne.
"Let's be real -- it's a fairly controlled operation," said Clark Irwin, a senior vice president who heads Tyson's food service division, and a childhood friend of John Tyson. "And without Randal here, you figure it had to fall into John's hands at some point."

Running Things His Way
Just outside his oak-paneled oval office, Mr. Tyson is showing off his art collection -- prints by Willem de Kooning, Lichtenstein and Warhol -- and a table made from stainless steel parts rescued from a processing plant. Among the works that predate his tenure are bronzed cowboys and a giant mounted marlin.
He has a sense of the history at Tyson. Down the hall is a replica of the office his grandfather occupied at the time of his death, a memorial with the clock stopped at the hour he died: 12:30 p.m.
Mr. Tyson wants to leave his mark, he says, and he is bringing his own style. Like his father, he has a puckish grin; he is gregarious and adventurous, perhaps to a fault, his friends say. He also has the capacity to shock and play the bad boy, they add, as he seemed to do in his court testimony in the Espy case.
According to his court testimony, Mr. Tyson said he used to charter company planes for football games and that his father liked to have company-sponsored parties for the sole purpose of getting his friends drunk. He also said Tyson's board was "nonactive" and served at the pleasure of the chairman and the management team.
That comment drew criticism from the California Public Employees' Retirement System, the nation's largest pension fund, which had been pressing Tyson Foods to abolish its dual-class stock structure and put more outsiders on its board.
Tyson officials dismiss the criticism, saying the dual-class stock creates stability in the company. They also say Mr. Tyson's testimony may have been taken out of context.
Mr. Tyson's friends say that he has calmed down, now that he has gone through a spiritual awakening. (He often attends Bible classes.) He and his wife of 11 years were divorced in 1998, but he is a dedicated father with joint custody of his two children, ages 8 and 10, the friends say. He arranges his travel schedule so that he is home every other week, when he has custody.
Following his father, who was considered a visionary and a risk taker, John Tyson has already rolled his own dice, on IBP. He says the merger will make Tyson "the Procter & Gamble of the meat case."
The question for investors, of course, is not whether John Tyson can make deals, but whether he can make them work. Does he have the skills to manage a company that is about to more than double its size and abandon its "focus on feathers" in offering beef and pork as well as chicken?
The company's earlier attempt to diversify, by acquiring smaller beef, pork and seafood units, failed miserably, partly because of its inexperience in those businesses and the units' small size. By 1999, Tyson had sold them all.
Mr. Tyson faces other challenges, too. First is completing the deal for IBP, which is cooperating with an S.E.C. inquiry into possible accounting irregularities at DFG, a Chicago company that IBP bought in 1998.
Because of the inquiry, IBP has restated its earnings for the past two years and taken a charge against earnings of $162 million. Tyson executives could pressure the company to alter the terms of the agreement because of the findings -- or they might just walk away.

No Plans to 'Chickenize'
Tyson, meanwhile, is laying the groundwork for the merger. Mr. Tyson is trying to allay the fears of ranchers about the rapid consolidation of the food and agriculture industry. Some wince at the idea of one company dominating the meat industry and possibly altering the dynamics of the beef industry.
Tom Bias, director of governmental relations at the National Farmers Union, said some ranchers feared that big processors would force smaller rivals out of business, by lowering prices, and then seize control of the market.
"That could leave just Conagra, Tyson and Smithfield," Mr. Bias said. "Tyson has contract farming, which turns farmers into tractor drivers and manure shovelers. Tyson has a long history of doing this in the poultry industry."
To assuage fears, Mr. Tyson has promised that the company will not "chickenize" the beef industry by trying to control the entire process from raising and slaughtering the animals to marketing the beef. "Our expertise is on marketing and convenience items and taking them to the next level," he said. "We want to spend our money on marketing."
Yet Mr. Tyson has also shown that he will stake out his positions with a tart tongue when necessary. Environmentalists accuse Tyson and other big processors of operating giant factory farm operations that foul rivers, streams and other water supplies. But he complains that activists are unfairly criticizing his company. And on regulatory issues, he says, the rules are a moving target, and the pace of regulatory change is costly and confusing to companies.
"We don't want to spend our money, and 12 months later things have changed," he said, as if speaking to regulators. "Don't make us guess where you're going."
He also uses the bully pulpit on labor issues. Tyson and other big meat processors are all struggling with high turnover rates, labor shortages and allegations that they hire and unfairly treat illegal workers.
Mr. Tyson acknowledges that there are labor problems. He says Tyson is moving to automate its processing facilities, to cut costs and to improve safety. As for accusations of unfair labor practices, he says Tyson treats its workers well, and he disputes government findings that indicate many poultry companies are violating the Fair Labor and Standards Act by not paying workers properly.
The biggest challenge faced by Tyson is whether it can truly transform itself from a giant chicken operation into a diversified meat company, one that can deliver fatter profits.
After two decades of double-digit growth in profits, shares of Tyson peaked in late 1998, and then dropped sharply over the next two years on a weakening profit outlook. Since Mr. Tyson took over last April, the stock has recouped some of those loses, closing on Friday at $12.60, but remains down about 50 percent from the 1998 high. Although Tyson's profits fell last year to $151 million, on slowing sales of $7.1 billion, analysts are hopeful about the IBP prospects.

A More Polished Approach
Mr. Tyson, of course, says the IBP deal was something the company had to do. Tyson had missed the opportunity to add IBP in 1981, when it was acquired by Occidental Petroleum. And, with retailers and food service companies consolidating, Tyson felt pressure to bulk up.
"Right now, the top five retailers have 48 percent of the business," Mr. Tyson said of the grocery store market. "They expect a vendor to be able to service them to meet a basket of goods. Now, we're big, and we have the three primary proteins."
His confident words may be indicative. After his unusual rise to power, Mr. Tyson has grabbed the company's reins, perhaps too tightly at first, Wall Street analysts say. In public, he seemed too ebullient, too flippant in his talks with investors and others, they say.
But his presentation last week at a conference in New York seemed more mature and polished, they said. Though, as a young boy, he had insisted that he did not want to run Tyson Foods, that might have been posturing, friends say.
"I think for a while Johnny was searching around, trying to find his niche," said Mr. Bassett, his childhood friend. "But I would say he's always wanted to do what he's doing right now."

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about John H. Tyson, the chairman and chief executive of Tyson Foods, misstated the month that former President Bill Clinton pardoned Archibald R. Schaffer III, the company's former communications director. It was December 2000, not January 2001. 
Because of an an editing error, the article omitted a word in a quotation from Donald J. Tyson, the company's senior chairman and John H. Tyson's father. He said of his son's rise to power: "Within the past 10 years, he's stepped forward and proven himself as a serious business person;" he did not say "Within the past years."

HEADLINE: The World: Capitalist Tools; 
Cutting a Rightward Path

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
AS President Bush sent his budget blueprint to Capitol Hill last week, he offered an exquisitely calibrated view of government that seemed just slightly to the right of President Clinton's "third way": "Government should be active, but limited, engaged, but not overbearing." Just the right size for a public that consistently shows mistrust of "government" but strong support for individual government programs. A careful middle ground.
 Then why are so many conservatives so happy -- and liberals so despairing? Because, both sides believe, Mr. Bush's neo-Clintonian formulations mask a major shift in the vision of government and a new stage in a philosophic debate that has raged across two generations. Mr. Bush's proposed $1.6 trillion tax cut, combined with his leaner budget and his proposals to remake Social Security and Medicare, could begin to turn the battleship of the federal government in a direction conservative Republicans have wanted for a long time. 
 It would, they believe, revive and retrofit the Reagan revolution -- by putting new spending constraints on the federal government with the tax cut; by ceding more responsibilities to state and local governments and religious institutions; and by transforming two great monuments of the New Deal and the Great Society, with partial privatizing of Social Security and Medicare. 
"I personally love this president," said Paul M. Weyrich, a longtime conservative activist. Grover G. Norquist, head of Americans for Tax Reform, a conservative group, said Mr. Bush's tax cut, the biggest since 1981, would limit government in important, lasting ways. "If you don't take that money off the table, they will spend it in Washington," he said. "Everybody understands that's the fight. The left understands it."
The old stereotypes of free-spending, big-government Democrats and tax-cutting, government-off-our backs Republicans were oversimplified, particularly in the Clinton era, when Democrats embraced the cause of fiscal responsibility and balanced budgets -- thanks, in part, to some powerful pushing from a Republican Congress. It is true, though, that Congressional Republicans are hardly immune to the joys of spending money. Meanwhile, last week Mr. Bush sounded at times as if he were channeling Hubert H. Humphrey. Proudly pointing to his new spending initiatives in education and medical research, he declared, "A budget's impact is counted in dollars, but measured in lives."
Yet, even now, when so much of politics seems a centrist muddle, there are enduring differences between the parties on the role the federal government should play on a range of domestic issues.
Consider health care: Democratic voters are still far more likely than Republicans to believe the federal government should do something major to cover the uninsured and to add a prescription drug benefit to the Medicare program, according to a new study by researchers at Harvard and the Kaiser Family Foundation. On Capitol Hill, Democrats tend to lead the charge to protect traditional Medicare. Republicans tend to want to inject more competition, consumer choice and market forces into what they insist is a creaky bureaucracy. 
Such divisions have dominated the politics of the past 10 years, with each side overreaching at times -- Mr. Clinton's bid to reorganize the private health insurance industry in 1993 and 1994, for example, and Speaker Newt Gingrich's bid to pare Medicare in 1995. Both engendered a backlash in the next election.
Mr. Bush and his advisers clearly learned from this; as many analysts noted last week, he neither calls for hard choices nor uses tough language in his speeches. A group of voters assembled by Democratic pollsters to watch the speech "had no sense at all that he was posing a philosophical choice about the role of government," said one pollster, Geoffrey Garin. "What people interpreted Bush as saying was that the surplus was so large that they can have it all," he said, "and, in fact, it was a point that made some people nervous."
BUT there is a real choice posed by the Bush tax cut and the reconfigurations it will require in the rest of the budget. Democrats and their allies assert there simply isn't enough money to pay for Mr. Bush's tax proposals, protect the Medicare surplus, add a meaningful prescription drug benefit for Medicare and finance the rest of his initiatives, even with the slowdown he proposes in other government spending.
Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the director of the Office of Management and Budget, obviously disagrees, insisting: "There is not 'more than enough room' for the president's relief plan. There is vastly more than enough room." But Democrats argue that the "reserve" fund at the heart of this have-it-all argument is "oversubscribed," meaning the government will ultimately face hard choices, including returning to deficits or deep cuts in spending.
Until now, voters took a fairly tempered view of a tax cut. A survey by the Pew Research Center for the People and the Press, conducted between Feb. 14 and Feb. 19, found that when voters are offered a list of possible uses for the money, the idea of tapping the budget surplus for a major tax cut is only slightly more popular than a year ago. Thirty-seven percent said the surplus should shore up Medicare and Social Security, compared with 19 percent who preferred a tax cut. A Washington Post-ABC Poll, released just before Mr. Bush's speech, found a similar result.
Support for a tax cut is higher when voters are not asked to rank priorities. For example, a CNN/ USA Today Poll asked, "Do you favor or oppose the federal income tax cuts President Bush has proposed?" Sixty-eight percent said they favored them before the speech; 79 percent favored them after. Still, Stanley B. Greenberg, who polled for Vice President Al Gore's campaign, cited the earlier trend, asserting: "There's something that's holding people back. I think they still think it's not quite the right thing to do." Democrats clearly intend to appeal to those doubts, while Republicans argue the tax cut is a win-win proposition. 
In fact, liberals argue that the question of priorities is fundamental. Robert Greenstein, head of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a liberal research group, rattled off a list of problems last week -- long-term care for the elderly, the 43 million Americans who lack health insurance, lack of drug coverage for the elderly, the long-term financing problems of Social Security and Medicare -- and argued the surplus was a once-in-a-generation opportunity to address them.
"There's a half-dozen problems we could make real progress on, and this budget says that's not the route we want to go," he said.
But John F. Cogan, a senior fellow at Stanford's Hoover Institution, who worked in the Reagan administration and now advises Mr. Bush on economic and budget matters, sees government expansionism as a risk, not an opportunity. "These surpluses are a great opportunity for the country, but they also present a danger," he said. "The danger is they will be used to expand the size and scope of government."
Not even many Democrats make a strong case for big new government spending initiatives now. On an issue like the uninsured, Theda Skocpol, a professor of government and sociology at Harvard, said: "Ten years ago we were saying, 'Gee, we'd like to do it if we could afford it.' We don't even mention that anymore. I don't think that's Bush and the Republicans alone. The whole discourse has shifted."
CONSERVATIVES argue that, indeed, the country has changed. "What would have been considered 10 or 20 years ago radical conservative positions -- consumer choice in Medicare and education, Social Security that's defined contribution rather than defined benefits ---- are now consensus positions of the center-right coalition, and 70 percent of the public is reasonably comfortable with them," said Mr. Norquist.
"Bush understands that the country is to the right of where his father thought it was," he added. Even so, there is still criticism in some conservative quarters that Mr. Bush's tax cut is not big enough.
Yet Democrats are not completely in despair, remembering how formidable Mr. Clinton looked in 1993, when he urged Congress to pass universal health insurance. They say Mr. Bush is only beginning a process that will require him to spell out the details and trade-offs of his plan, and thus test its true appeal. The lessons of the last 10 years suggest that voters, with all their conflicting views about government, will eventually listen closely.

SECTION: Section C; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 5

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Access charges are tumbling in Vietnam, where the Internet is seen as a gateway to other business.

BYLINE:  By Matt Richtel 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam 

 BODY:
HANG BE STREET flirts with chaos, as dozens of moped riders dodge and weave among bicyclists and pedestrians. 
 But inside a half-dozen businesses on the block, matters could not be more in lock step. The impetus is the Internet, which has caused the outbreak of a price war, providing a textbook case of capitalism. 
 Recent months have seen a boom in the number of Internet cafes, not just on Hang Be but in several districts of the city as well. In turn, access prices have dropped so rapidly that cafe owners have taken to writing over outdated prices or even printing them on disposable signs. 
It is a price war that conjures a bit of mystery because it now costs but pennies an hour to be online here, far less than the price of access in the United States. 
Dang Duc Thuc said the matter was as plain as a plate of white rice. "The more cafes, the cheaper the price," said Mr. Thuc, who owns a chain of AtoZ Queen Cafes, which are among the two dozen or more businesses now loudly advertising Internet access in Hanoi. 
The cafes, hostels and tour offices that offer Net access are interspersed on tourist streets with stores selling counterfeit compact discs, trinkets or inexpensive meals. Employees of the Internet shops beckon passers-by with promises of "fastest Internet" or "cheap Internet" like madams cajoling cowboys into an Old West brothel.
Mr. Thuc said his cafes had two advantages: they were the oldest in Vietnam and offered the fastest connection. But other cafe owners made clear that these are widely shared distinctions, and each claimed to have brought the Internet to Hanoi in 1997. 
There is one matter on which all agree: the cost of access. They say it started at about 800 dong a minute, or about $3 an hour. It quickly declined to 700 and then started falling faster than the Nasdaq. In the last year, it has slid to 300 dong from 500, and more recently to 200 or 150 a minute, depending on the establishment. 
It turns out that such a price war was not unique to Hanoi in this part of the world. Travelers in the region say access prices dropped in the tourist area of Katmandu, Nepal, over the two weeks they went on a trek. 
Joe Cummings, an author for Lonely Planet guidebooks in Southeast Asia, said Internet access charges were dropping across the region. In particular, he said, rates have dropped some in Laos and steeply in Thailand, where a cutthroat price war has driven costs to a few pennies an hour to log on. Mr. Cummings was at a loss to explain the phenomenon. "I don't know how they're making money," he said. 
Back at the AtoZ cafes, the same question was put to Mr. Thuc: If computers cost $500, can you make money charging less than $1 an hour? "Maybe not," said Mr. Thuc, who turned out to be a man of few words, or at least few words of English. 
He did, though, manage to convey that the Internet nevertheless has a value to the cafes, tourism shops and hotels that offer it. The reason, he explained, is that the entrepreneurs use the Internet to attract customers and then sell them other services, like tour packages, hotel rooms or a cup of coffee and a fried egg.
Matei Mihalca, the Internet analyst at Merrill Lynch in Hong Kong, filled in an additional piece of the puzzle. Mr. Mihalca said Internet entrepreneurs hoped to make money by buying one connection to the Internet and then splitting it among a handful of computers. This method, he said, keeps costs down. But, he added, that still doesn't make it easy to make money, given how low the prices have dropped. 
Then again, the price reflects the overall cost of living here. A sumptuous feast of chicken in garlic sauce, rice and beer costs $2, tops. A night in a charming, French-influenced hotel costs $20.
But local incomes are commensurate, which means many Vietnamese have neither the money -- nor the training -- to venture into cyberspace themselves. Vu Van Phuong, 28, who taxis people around the city on his Honda 50 Deluxe moped for about $1.50 a day, said he had heard of the Internet but did not know what it was and found the idea of spending 200 dong a minute amusingly extravagant. 
His attitude may help explain the low prices charged by people like Ng Thang Hang. "Most Vietnamese think the Internet is useless," said Ms. Hang, the manager of the Trekking Cafe, outside of which Mr. Phuong had parked his bike. A sign outside the Trekking Cafe advertises a 10 percent discount on Internet access (ordinarily 200 dong a minute), but Ms. Hang said there was another advantage to logging on at Trekking: "In my shop, the speed is the fastest."
The sharing of one Internet connection among many users has a side effect: during busy times, access can be painfully slow. Such pain registered glaringly on the face of Verity Sessions, a 34-year-old British woman who was waiting to download e-mail at the AtoZ cafe on Hang Be Street. 
"I've been waiting like eight or nine minutes for the page to come up," Ms. Sessions complained. Then again, Ms. Sessions said she couldn't complain about the price. Nor does she shop around, looking to save a few dong. "I'll go anywhere where the price is close" to the going rate, she said. 
If recent history continues to serve as a guide, she'll be able to do just that: go anywhere. The prices appear to be continuing to drop, lock step, among the growing number of cafes. At this rate, it's only a matter of time before the Internet is ubiquitous -- and cheaper than spending an afternoon eating a plate of garlic chicken and drinking a beer.

HEADLINE: 'Seinfeld' Star Planning Pilot With NBC 

BYLINE:  By BILL CARTER 

 BODY:
 In an unusual deal based on an unusual format for a TV series, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, one of the stars of the NBC comedy hit "Seinfeld," will make a pilot for a new comedy for NBC that, if made, could spur changes in the traditional economics of a television series and the scheduling of the network prime-time season. 
 The proposed series, still untitled, would produce only 15 episodes a season, rather than the 22 to 25 that other network series develop, making it more difficult for the series to attain the number of episodes needed to sell it in the lucrative syndication market.
The show's creative innovation is to present one continuous real-time scene, 22 consecutive minutes, of a slice in the main character's day, interrupted only by commercials. Ms. Louis-Dreyfus described her character as "a mildly successful singer in Los Angeles who performs in cabaret clubs or else sings jingles for grocery stores."
NBC has embraced the idea because, like other networks, it is looking for shows that reach out to viewers by altering standard storytelling formats. Very few new comedies have succeeded on the networks in recent years, and network research has pointed to increasing fatigue -- especially among young adult viewers -- with the familiar format of a family or other group in a living-room set dominated by a sofa. 
Instead, comedies have turned to surrealism, as in Fox's "Malcolm in the Middle"; totally improvised dialogue, as in HBO's "Curb Your Enthusiasm"; and stories told in overlapping flashbacks, as in Fox's "Grounded for Life."
Indeed, NBC's willingness to sign on for what amounts to a shortened series order shows the particular influence of HBO, which has developed a schedule that calls for the regular rotation of series in the same time slot, 13 to 15 episodes at a stretch.
Initially, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus sought even more radical changes in her show, including running each episode for 22 straight minutes with no commercial interruption, underscoring the real-time approach. NBC declined that notion, arguing that the network had to keep some of its usual business structures intact.
Ms. Louis-Dreyfus, who has been much in demand at several networks, insisted on limiting the number of episodes she will make each season as a concession to the real priority in her life. "I also want to be a mom," she said in a telephone interview. She and her husband, Brad Hall, a writer who created the new series, have two boys, ages 3 and 8.
Jeff Zucker, the president of NBC Entertainment, who made the deal with Ms. Louis-Dreyfus and Mr. Hall, acknowledged that the notion of doing only 15 episodes of a series disrupts the traditional structure of television series. "But the traditional system keeps so many good things from happening, we have to figure out a new economic model," Mr. Zucker said.
Both Mr. Zucker and Tom Werner, of the Carser-Werner-Mandabach Company which will produce the series, cited the success of one television series, HBO's "The Sopranos," as a goal for this show -- and others -- to shoot for.
"HBO does it," Mr. Zucker said. "They are able to go from 'Sopranos' straight into 'Sex and the City' to keep their schedule going." He said reports that Ms. Louis-Dreyfus would go back to a standard 22-episode season if her show succeeds were erroneous. "She's a family person," he said. "We have to work with her schedule."
Mr. Werner called "The Sopranos," which films only 13 episodes a season "event programming," adding, "Maybe we can do that with Julia's series: make it an event."
He acknowledged that shows usually need to make more episodes every season because they only really make money when they have accumulated about 100 episodes and can be sold into syndication. But Mr. Werner said: "If you do something terrific, the economics tend to work themselves out. It's a lot better to have 15 wonderful things than 22 not-so-wonderful things."
Most shows are produced at a deficit, which is why they need syndication money to become profitable. To counter that, shows with fewer episodes would need to receive higher network license fees to make a profit. If a show becomes a hit, it can ask for higher license fees. NBC did not disclose its financial arrangements for Ms. Louis-Dreyfus's show, and they probably will not be set until the network decides to commit to the series.
If the show were to succeed, it would present other problems: Mr. Zucker would be forced to find some new way to schedule it. "But that's O.K.," he said. "I think we're in a whole new era of television anyway, and we have to go in new directions."
Ms. Louis-Dreyfus, who is once and forever Elaine thanks to the reruns of "Seinfeld" -- television's biggest hit of the 1990's -- was besieged with offers for her own series from the moment the show went off the air. She pulled back, she said, partly to take care of her children, but also because she recognized what going back to television comedy would mean.
"It's extremely daunting," she said, referring to the high bar of great expectations set by "Seinfeld."
The challenge became even tougher this season when Michael Richards, who had played Kramer on "Seinfeld," brought a new series to NBC that flamed out after a strong start. Mr. Zucker said, "I'm not scared off by what happened with Michael Richards. This is a different project."
For starters, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus's show will not go on the air at all if NBC does not like the pilot, a decision that limits its financial risk. Mr. Richards's show was guaranteed a spot on the air and 13 episodes, which cost NBC heavily when the show failed quickly. If NBC does not order her series, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus will get what is known as a penalty payment -- a less costly commitment.
The show is also likely go on the air in the middle of the next television season, probably after NBC's broadcast of the Winter Olympics from Salt Lake City, offering it the best opportunity for promotion. If the series is successful, it might come back the following January after NBC uses a different comedy in the fall. That way NBC could limit the number of repeats it has to show during a season.
Ms. Louis-Dreyfus noted that she has spent her entire television career on NBC, having earlier been a cast member on "Saturday Night Live." "I sense a new enthusiasm at NBC with Jeff there," she said. "It feels right and comfortable to be going back."
Ms. Louis-Dreyfus said that after a period of enjoying simply being a mother, she started looking for a vehicle to return to work. "What I like to do is entertain," she said. All she has done since leaving "Seinfeld" is one musical movie on ABC, "Geppetto," and a guest appearance on "Curb Your Enthusiasm," which was created by the chief "Seinfeld" writer, Larry David.
"I loved working with Larry. It was a very pleasant reminder of how much I like to act," Ms. Louis-Dreyfus said. As for singing on "Geppetto," it certainly helped lead to the premise for the new series. "I do love to sing, it's joyful for me. And I have been trained. It's not like I just took voice lessons last week."
For a time she considered offers to join a Broadway musical in New York, but again she felt that would take her too far away from her young boys. After she started talking to some writers about a possible series last year, her husband Mr. Hall, without her knowledge, sat down and wrote a pilot script with her in mind. "The neat thing about it is that it's really like intimate observations of someone's life," Mr. Hall said.
The couple presented the script to several networks, not knowing what to expect. "It's not a straight-down-the-middle comedy," Ms. Louis-Dreyfus said. "There's a small cast of regulars. But it's not going to be us on a couch talking about biological clocks ticking down."
As for the short unhappy series experience for Mr. Richards, Ms. Louis-Dreyfus said that was no reason to resist going back to television. "There has to be life after 'Seinfeld,' " she said.
