HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: The Markets; 
No Earnings, Debatable Prospects: A New I.P.O. With a 90's Feel

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
Get ready for the return of the Internet concept stock. On Thursday, Loudcloud Inc. is expected to offer shares to the public in what seems like a throwback to the dot-com glory days.
 The Silicon Valley company has a constellation of star power rallying behind its chairman, Marc Andreessen, who co-founded Netscape Communications. 
 This time out Mr. Andreessen aims to build and automate corporate Internet systems. His company's software would replace the armies of consultants who maintain these systems, threatening turf occupied by I.B.M. and Electronic Data Systems, as well as Web hosting companies like Exodus Communications. 
Loudcloud has attracted a few big name customers like Ford and Nike, but its technology is still in a gestational phase. So is the company's financial outlook. It is barely a year-and-a-half old and has 575 employees. It has no earnings and no immediate prospect for earnings. With revenues of just $6.6 million, it had losses of $107.6 million from its start in September 1999 through the end of October, with $51 million of that stock option charges. The company says it has signed contracts for $120 million over the next two years.
Its chief obstacle, though, is timing. The market for initial public offerings of technology companies has crashed this year. The public markets have been heaping scorn on technology companies with weak earnings, let alone those that are asking for a multiyear grace period before any profits materialize.
What Loudcloud does have is star power, and plenty of it. In fact, it will be one of the most closely watched public offerings in success-starved Silicon Valley, and on Wall Street. Perhaps it is a sign of how desperate the market has become that Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter have teamed up as co-lead underwriters, a rare pairing roughly equivalent to Shaquille O'Neal and Kobe Bryant agreeing to share a basketball.
Loudcloud's investors include the venture capital giant Benchmark Capital and Michael Ovitz, the Hollywood agent. But the real draw is Mr. Andreessen, the 29-year-old technology whiz who is one of a handful of Valley personalities who inspires awe among programmers and technologists, in much the same way as Linus Torvalds, the creator of the Linux operating system. 
"It's the Marc Andreessen, 'can lightning strike twice' scenario," said David Menlow, president of IPOfinancial.com, a New Jersey firm that tracks public offerings. 
Robert C. Stimson, a Merrill Lynch computer services analyst, said he was impressed with Loudcloud's technology, but Mr. Andreessen is the real draw. "A lot of cars are slowing down to take a look at what he's trying to do," he said. "'I buy into his vision," he said, "but it will take us a few years to reach the promise of that vision."
George J. Gilbert, co-manager of the $950 million Northern Technology fund, was more skeptical.
"It's not profitable, and it isn't going to be for a long while," he said. "From an analytical viewpoint, there are no real ways to even guesstimate what kind of profitability this company could have."
Mr. Andreessen has faced long odds before. He was principal creator of the world's first Web browser, Mosaic, and went on to co-found Netscape Communications with Jim Clark. It was Netscape, for those who don't know the story, that sparked the late 90's trend of concept companies going public and garnering huge valuations before they had earned a dollar. 
These are rough times for any public offerings, but especially anything technology related. Last year, there were 236 technology related I.P.O.'s, according to Renaissance Capital, a Greenwich, Conn., firm that tracks and invests in I.P.O.'s. This year, there has been only one new technology offering of note. It is Riverstone Networks, a Santa Clara, Calif., networking company, whose stock was offered at $12 a share on Feb. 15 and closed yesterday at $10.56, down 12 percent.
Many of the stars of 1999 have gone out of business or seen their prices plummet by well over 50 percent. 
"It's a zero," said Andrew J. Kessler of the market for technology offerings. Mr. Kessler runs the $300 million Velocity Capital, a technology hedge fund based in Silicon Valley. 
The soft market has forced Loudcloud to lower its asking price. Initially, it planned to offer 10 million shares at $9 to $11 for about 16 percent of the company. That was later amended to 20 million shares at $8 to $10 for about 30 percent of the company. If it priced in the middle of its range, Loudcloud would have an implied market value of $600 million.
Some money managers wonder if the company will be able to fetch even $8 a share. Melanie Hase, an analyst at Renaissance Capital, says probably, though she calls it a "test for the I.P.O. market."
More than 2 million shareholders of two giant mutual funds managed by Capital Research and Management, one of the nation's largest mutual fund management firms, should pay attention. Capital owns a stake that will be equivalent to 3.6 percent of the company, once it goes public, according to Loudcloud's registration statement. 
The holdings are spread among the $36 billion Growth Fund of America, one of the nation's 10 largest mutual funds, which has 3.6 million shares, and the $10 billion New Economy fund, which has 1.2 million shares of Loudcloud.
Mr. Gilbert, of Northern, said Loudcloud reminded him of Webvan, a struggling online grocer that his fund invested in. These are not fond memories. Webvan fell 97 percent in 2000.
"I bought the story," Mr. Gilbert said. "Fortunately, I realized very soon after that I'd been drinking Kool-Aid."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS; 
Times Company Forecasts Slower Growth in Ad Revenue

 BODY:
The New York Times Company said yesterday that the economic slowdown was likely to mean advertising revenue for its newspapers would grow this year by only 1 to 3 percent. That would compare with growth of 11.3 percent in 2000. 
 But the company said it still planned to meet its goal of achieving 10 to 15 percent earnings growth this year through circulation price increases and cost reductions. 
 Within the last six weeks, the Times Company has announced a price increase that has already taken effect for home delivery of the daily issues of its flagship newspaper, The New York Times, and newsstand price increases of Sunday editions of The Times that will take effect on March 25.
The increases, coupled with a circulation price increase last fall at The Boston Globe, which is owned by the Times Company, will produce $30 million to $32 million in additional operating income in 2001, the Times Company said in a news release.
For the current quarter, the company said that diluted earnings per share, excluding special items, were expected to be 35 cents to 38 cents for the first quarter, compared with 47 cents for the first quarter last year. That would be an earnings decline of 19 to 25 percent, compared with last year's first quarter, when earnings grew more than 38 percent.
The announcement by the Times Company followed a cautionary statement two weeks ago from another big newspaper company, Knight Ridder, which forecast a "modest" decline in first quarter earnings. 
The Times Company's newspaper price increases come as Dow Jones & Company plans to raise the cover price of The Wall Street Journal to $1 from 75 cents in April. Yesterday, The Los Angeles Times raised its daily newsstand cover price to 50 cents, from 25 cents, in Southern California.
"This is going to be the worst first quarter the newspaper industry has faced in nearly a decade," said Peter P. Appert, an analyst for Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown. "The macroeconomic variables correlate with trends in ad spending, consumer confidence, existing home sales, auto sales, personal income growth. All of these variables are trending negative."
Catherine Mathis, a Times Company spokeswoman, said yesterday: "The economic environment has clearly softened, and as a result of that we don't think ad revenue growth will be as robust as we did in December. Because it won't be, we have to take steps to achieve our commitment to shareholders of 10 to 15 percent growth. A lot of it is going to come from reducing our costs."
She said that expenses in the company's newspaper division would grow by no more than 2 percent this year. 
In its recent statement, Knight Ridder had said classified advertising was particularly weak. But Ms. Mathis said the Times Company's advertising revenues had been soft "across the board."
Two analysts, Douglas M. Arthur of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Lauren Rich Fine of Merrill Lynch, both said that the industry's sharp advertising downturn in December had seemed to ease slightly in January. 
But their view of the subsequent period diverged. Mr. Arthur said the fall-off resumed or even worsened in February. Ms. Fine was less pessimistic about February, saying, "I don't think things are deteriorating at that rapid a pace."
The stock of the Times Company closed at $43 a share yesterday, down $2.50, or about 5.5 percent. The Standard & Poor's index of newspaper company stocks closed down about 2.6 percent for the day.

HEADLINE: Northeast Says Merger With Con Edison Has Collapsed 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Northeast Utilities, New England's largest energy delivery company, said last night that its planned merger with New York's Consolidated Edison had collapsed, ending the companies' effort to create the largest utility company in the Northeast.
 The development came after the attorney general in Connecticut sought to block the merger on the grounds that it would cost customers more and harm the environment. 
 Despite Northeast Utilities' claims that the merger had collapsed, Con Edison insisted yesterday that the agreement between the two utilities "remains in effect."
The companies entered the merger agreement, which calls on Con Ed to acquire Northeast for $7.5 billion, in October 1999, and shareholders of both companies approved it several months later. At the time, the companies said that by joining together they would be in a better position to provide cheaper power to their customers and to compete more effectively at a time of growing competition amid increasing deregulation. 
With a total of 6.5 million electric and natural-gas customers from Pennsylvania to New Hampshire, the merged company would have been one of the largest utilities in the country.
But not everyone thought the planned union was the blessing described by its advocates. One of the fiercest opponents, Attorney General Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut, has been waging a lawsuit in Connecticut Superior Court to block the deal, arguing that it would be bad for energy customers, the economy and the environment in his state because Con Ed has an "abysmal record of high rates, poor quality service and environmental disrespect."
In saying last night that the merger deal was dead, Northeast Utilities said that Con Ed had told it earlier in the day that "it was not willing to close the parties' pending merger on the previously agreed upon terms." As a result, Northeast said in its statement, it had "notified Con Edison that it was treating its refusal to proceed" on the previously agreed terms "as a repudiation and breach of the merger agreement."
Michael G. Morris, the chairman and president of Northeast, said his company was "treating the agreement as effectively terminated."
Northeast did not say what issues had caused the merger deal to founder, but its statement suggested that Con Ed might have developed reservations about Northeast's financial condition that prompted a request for changes in the agreement.
In any case, Northeast said it would file a lawsuit "to obtain the benefits of the transaction as negotiated for Northeast Utilities' shareholders."
Mary Jo Keating, Northeast's vice president for corporate communications, said she could not comment on what Northeast would argue were the lost benefits to its shareholders or how much the lost benefits would amount to.
In its statement, Con Edison said there were questions regarding Northeast's financial prospects.
As an example of its concerns, the utility cited the question of whether an unregulated Northeast subsidiary, Select Energy, could satisfy its supply obligations under the merger agreement. Select Energy sells power and other energy services, and Con Ed said Select's failure to meet its obligations would "pose a significant risk" in Northeast's unregulated businesses.
The Con Edison statement did not say what kind of changes it wanted in the merger agreement, and a spokesman for the utility, Michael Clendenin, declined to provide the information.
Late last year, it appeared that the merger agreement was in peril for another reason: Connecticut's department of public utility control approved it with conditions that Con Ed said at the time "so significantly changes the economic effects and risks of the merger that it calls into serious question whether the transaction will be completed."
The conditions included a 3 percent cut in the distribution rates that customers in Connecticut are charged, and acceptance by the combined company of a $60 million loss in costs stemming from the deregulation process.
But last night, Mr. Clendenin said that the state department had modified the conditions to some degree, and he suggested that Con Ed's financial concerns had become the main roadblock.

HEADLINE: Index of Service Industry Rebounds Slightly 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
A measure largely representing the service sector steadied in February, a new survey showed yesterday. 
 The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its nonmanufacturing business index rose to 51.7 from January's 50.1, which was the lowest since the report's inception in July 1997. A reading above 50 means activity is expanding, while below 50 indicates contraction. 
 The nonmanufacturing survey is a companion report to a survey of factory purchasing managers and mainly reflects service industries.
The increase, together with the first rise in a year in the manufacturing index, "reinforces the notion that January was a low" for the economy, said Steven Wieting, an economist with Salomon Smith Barney in New York.
Still, "the idea of a recovery is very tentative at this point," he said.
For the nonmanufacturing report, the association gathers statistics from more than 370 purchasing executives in more than 62 industries, including utilities, law firms, hospitals, construction companies, government, retailers and electronic commerce.
The degree of economic weakness in January was also seen in a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
The Chicago Fed's new index was - 0.55 in January versus - 0.79 in December. The bank, which developed the index, released it for the first time yesterday. The reading was the lowest since a reading of - 1.13 in January 1996, based on previously published data gathered by the Chicago Fed.
The Chicago Fed national index draws on 85 indicators that gauge production and income, employment and hours, consumer spending, housing starts and sales, manufacturing and inventories. It is based on the work of James Stock of Harvard and Mark Watson of Princeton, which was published in 1999 in The Journal of Monetary Economics.
"The negative January reading should be interpreted as continuing evidence of national economic growth below trend," the report said. "The January index does not currently point to an economy in recession."
A separate survey showed that businesses announced plans to cut 101,731 jobs last month, 28 percent below the 142,208 cuts announced in January. The number of announced cuts in January was the highest since the outplacement firm of Challenger, Gray & Christmas started the survey eight years ago.
Even with a decline, it was the first time the number of job cuts surpassed 100,000 for three consecutive months.

North Korea Concessions Were Wider Than Thought
The Clinton administration's negotiations with North Korea late last year apparently made more progress than thought, though the decision not to pursue them to conclusion is still hotly debated. HEADLINE: Losses in Online Ventures Cut Pearson's Profit 17% 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, March 5 

 BODY:
Heedless of the poor marks investors now give companies that keep pouring money into money-losing Internet ventures, Pearson P.L.C., the British media and educational publishing company, said today that it had stepped up such spending fivefold last year, lopping 17 percent off its pretax profit for 2000 in the process.
 With media holdings ranging from The Financial Times and The Economist to Penguin Books and a huge educational publishing arm, Pearson had been one of the biggest beneficiaries of the online boom. 
 Pearson's shares rose to a high of $:23.01 ($33.82) a year ago as investors bet that it would convert its dominant positions in publishing and education into a lucrative online currency. 
Now, like most other companies that have spent heavily on Internet ventures that have yet to make money, Pearson is facing investors who are impatient for profits at a time when an economic slowdown threatens to undermine growth in its offline businesses.
"Pearson had been viewed as a one-way bet," said Paul Richards, an analyst with WestLB Panmure. "But people are now realizing you can't have double-digit growth indefinitely."
For the year, Pearson earned $:333 million ($489.5 million) in pretax profit, including $:196 million ($288 million) spent on Internet ventures. That compares with $:402 million ($591 million) in pretax profit the year earlier.
Mr. Richards said he was more cautious of the company's prospects for 2001 given that growth in advertising revenue and school budgets are likely to slow, along with the United States economy, from which Pearson derived 60 percent of its profit and 64 percent of its revenue last year.
Shares of Pearson fell 4.1 percent, or 64 pence, to $:14.97 in trading today in London.
Over the last three years, under its chief executive, Marjorie Scardino, Pearson has undergone a major overhaul, jettisoning noncore assets and using the money to make acquisitions. Now analysts say that Mrs. Scardino must integrate the new businesses and grow the company in a more challenging economic environment.
Already signs of a slowdown are visible. 
Luke Swanson, a Pearson spokesman, said advertising sales for the first two months of the year are up 8 percent, compared with a 34 percent increase for the comparable period last year.
Mr. Swanson said that only 10 percent of Pearson's sales came from advertising, while about half the company's revenue was generated from educational publishing, an area that Pearson expected to contract less rapidly.
For instance, Mr. Swanson suggested that the number of standardized tests that American children take each year would increase sharply under President Bush's education proposals, pointing to a model developed under Mr. Bush's tenure as governor in Texas. Any such increase would be a boon to National Computer Systems, one of the country's largest standardized testing companies, which Pearson acquired last year.
For the moment, that potential is somewhat veiled by Pearson's willingness to funnel money into Internet ventures like the online version of The Financial Times, which lost $:113 million ($166 million) last year, or triple the prior year's losses. Likewise the Learning Network, an educational portal, lost $:83 million, ($122 million) while only generating $:3 million ($4.4 million) in revenue last year.
Mr. Swanson said that Internet spending in 2001 would decline as revenue for both divisions are projected to rise, with the online publishing arm forecasted to break even in 2002 and the portal to follow suit a year later.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pearson's chief, Marjorie Scardino, right, and finance director, John Makinson, announced earnings yesterday of $489.5 million. (NewsCast)

HEADLINE: Treasury Secretary to Keep Stake in Alcoa 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT and DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill has decided to keep about $100 million in Alcoa stock and options, giving him perhaps the largest single-company holding that a top government official has ever held.
 Mr. O'Neill's decision, which was stated in a letter to a government ethics official in January and reiterated in a television interview on Sunday, stands in contrast to moves by other government officials in recent years who diversified their investments upon taking office. 
 Just yesterday, Vice President Dick Cheney said he would donate to charity the profits from his remaining stock options in Halliburton, the oil-services giant. 
Mr. Cheney was the chief executive of Halliburton until last year, and Mr. O'Neill was chairman or chief executive of Alcoa, the large aluminum maker, from 1987 until late last year.
Mr. O'Neill has said he will recuse himself from all Treasury Department decisions concerning Alcoa. Appearing Sunday on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Mr. O'Neill said he had received clearance from government ethics experts to hold onto the shares.
But some government and corporate analysts said that Mr. O'Neill's decision raised a host of potential problems. Alcoa, with $22.9 billion in revenue last year, sells its products around the world and is affected by many trade regulations. It also has many clients in regulated industries like aerospace and railroads.
"It's an inherent conflict of interest," said Judith Fischer, publisher of Executive Compensation Reports, a newsletter. "It's also a distraction."
Charles Lewis, the executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a nonpartisan research group in Washington, added, "Everyone at Treasury and everyone in the Bush administration will know 'Mr. Alcoa' is the treasury secretary. That does raise some issues."
Mr. O'Neill's decision differs both from Mr. Cheney's and those of some recent cabinet secretaries. In 1993, when Robert Rubin joined the Clinton administration as an economic adviser, he said he was severing his financial ties with Goldman, Sachs & Company, the investment bank at which he had been co-chairman, and establishing a blind trust. Mr. Rubin became treasury secretary in 1995.
In 1989, James A. Baker III, the new secretary of state under President George Bush, sold millions of dollars worth of stock in Chemical Bank and other companies after being criticized for holding them. Economists at the time said that Mr. Baker would shape policy regarding international debt, which in turn would affect Chemical Bank's stock.
But Mr. Baker had held the stock when he was treasury secretary in the mid-1980's. Like Mr. O'Neill, he said he would recuse himself from decisions affecting the company when he took office.
In 1989, though, Mr. Baker told the adviser managing his investments to sell the stock. "While I believe this decision goes well beyond what is required or has been recommended," Mr. Baker said in a statement then, "I think it is the correct decision for someone committed to meeting the highest ethical standards."
During last year's presidential campaign, Mr. Cheney said he would sell all his Halliburton stock if he and George W. Bush were elected.
In August, Mr. Cheney made $20.6 million by selling his shares and exercising all eligible stock options. Yesterday, a lawyer for Mr. Cheney said the remaining options -- those that cannot yet be turned into stock or that currently have no value -- would be donated to the University of Wyoming; Capital Partners for Education, which provides financial aid for low-income students attending private high schools in Washington; and the George Washington University Medical Faculty Associates, which will establish a cardiac institute bearing Mr. Cheney's name.
Mr. O'Neill owned about 2.4 million shares of Alcoa stock, worth about $80 million, at the end of 2000, according to the company's most recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He also held 3.8 million stock options.
Stock options, which give their holder the right to buy stock at a fixed price regardless of the shares' current value, have become the most lucrative form of executive pay in the last decade. Mr. O'Neill, for example, made $53 million last year converting Alcoa options into stock. 
On "Meet the Press," he said he had never sold any Alcoa stock. That suggests he still owns the shares he bought last year with his options.
At the end of last year, his 3.8 million remaining options were worth about $11 million, the company said. Their value could rise sharply if Alcoa's stock rises in the coming years. Already, company shares are worth about $4.60 more than they were on Dec. 31, meaning Mr. O'Neill's options could be worth more than twice what they were at the end of last year.
Mr. Cheney still holds 433,333 options to buy Halliburton stock, and he and his wife, Lynne, also received options from four other corporations on whose boards one of them had served: EDS, Procter & Gamble, Anadarko Petroleum and Lockheed Martin, according to Terrence O'Donnell, a lawyer for Mr. Cheney.
During the campaign, Mr. Cheney said he was "fully prepared to forfeit any options that had not vested by the time I assume office."
That sounded like he intended to have Halliburton cancel the unvested options. But actually, according to his legal advisers, Mr. Cheney forfeited any personal stake in those options by arranging for any eventual profits to be given to the three charities he designated.
"We went back and reviewed all of the statements he made during the campaign," said Mr. O'Donnell last night. "We believe that this meets his commitments fully."
On Jan. 18, Mr. Cheney and his wife signed an irrevocable agreement giving an independent administrator the power to decide when to exercise the options, and directs the administrator to donate the after-tax proceeds to the charities.
The University of Wyoming and the George Washington University medical group will each receive 40 percent of the proceeds from the Cheneys' remaining options. Capital Partners for Education will get the remaining 20 percent. The gift arrangement is intended to be "100-percent tax-neutral," Mr. O'Donnell said, with taxes the Cheneys owe on any profits offsetting the charitable deduction they can claim.
Spokesmen for Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans said that they would soon release information on their financial holdings.

HEADLINE: Bush to Name Fed Governor For 2nd Term 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5 

 BODY:
The White House said today that President Bush would nominate Roger W. Ferguson Jr., the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, to another term on the central bank's governing board.
 The appointment was the first by Mr. Bush to the Fed. It followed public and private efforts on Mr. Ferguson's behalf by Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman. 
 Mr. Ferguson was first appointed to the Fed by President Clinton in 1997. He became vice chairman of the board two years later. His job had been in limbo since last year, when Senator Phil Gramm, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, blocked Mr. Clinton's reappointment of Mr. Ferguson as a Fed governor. Senator Gramm said the next president should have a chance to place his own nominee on the Fed.
In a statement, Mr. Ferguson said he was "delighted" by the news. Mr. Greenspan said in a statement that he welcomed Mr. Bush's decision.
"Roger Ferguson has been a distinguished and respected member of the Federal Reserve Board, exercising sound judgment and benefiting our work on a wide range of domestic and international policy matters," Mr. Greenspan said.
Mr. Gramm's spokeswoman, Christi Harlan, said he would have no comment.
The White House also announced today that Mr. Bush would nominate Kenneth W. Dam, a law professor at the University of Chicago who was deputy secretary of state in the Reagan administration, to be deputy treasury secretary.
Mr. Dam, whose appointment was expected, also worked at the Office of Management and Budget and on the White House economic policy staff during the Nixon administration. He was also a senior executive at I.B.M. from 1985 to 1992, and a director of Alcoa, whose longtime chairman, Paul H. O'Neill, is now the Treasury secretary.
Mr. Dam has written extensively about foreign policy, trade, finance and tax policy. He will become a member of a Treasury team that will also include John B. Taylor, an economist from Stanford University who has been nominated by Mr. Bush as undersecretary for international affairs, and Peter R. Fisher, an executive vice president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who is expected to be named undersecretary for domestic finance soon.
Mr. Bush's decision to reappoint Mr. Ferguson to the Fed leaves two open seats on the Fed's seven-member board. In addition, the terms of two more seats, those held by Laurence H. Meyer and Edward W. Kelley Jr., will expire during Mr. Bush's term in office.
Mr. Greenspan's current term as chairman, his fourth, will expire in 2004, when he will be 78.
As a result, Mr. Bush has a chance to put a strong imprint on the Fed.
The president technically nominated Mr. Ferguson to fill a board seat that runs for another 13 years.
Although Mr. Ferguson's previous term on the board expired last year, Fed rules permitted him to continue to serve until he was reappointed or someone else was nominated for the job.
The vice chairman's post is filled from among board members. Mr. Ferguson's four-year term in that position expires in 2003.
On monetary policy, Mr. Ferguson's views are close to those of Mr. Greenspan.
Like Mr. Greenspan, he has become increasingly convinced that heavy investments in technology have made American businesses more productive than they were a decade ago, giving the economy more room to expand without generating inflation.
Mr. Ferguson has also been heavily involved in banking regulation. The Fed has taken a somewhat more restrictive view than Congressional Republicans of how much freedom large financial services companies should have to take advantage of the blurring lines between traditional commercial banking and investment banking.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roger Ferguson has been asked to serve another 13 years as a Federal Reserve governor. His four-year term as vice chairman expires in 2003. (Bloomberg News)(pg. C4)

HEADLINE: How Politics Sank Accord on Missiles With North Korea 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 5 

 BODY:
Wendy R. Sherman brought along an extra suitcase of cold-weather gear even when she joined Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright for a December trip through Africa. 
 As the Clinton administration's senior policy coordinator on North Korea, Ms. Sherman was prepared to fly to Pyongyang on a moment's notice. Her task there would be to clear away the final barriers to an accord that would neutralize the North Korean missile threat, which has been a central justification for the hotly debated American national missile defense project. Had she succeeded, the framework of an agreement would have been signed by President Clinton and Kim Jong Il, the North Korean leader, in Pyongyang, the North's capital. 
 But Ms. Sherman never made the trip. 
In a decision that is still hotly debated by national security experts, the Clinton administration put North Korea diplomacy aside while the Republican and Democratic presidential contenders wrestled over the vote count in Florida, a decision that Clinton aides have sought to justify on the premise that the president could not travel abroad during a potential constitutional crisis.
By the time the dust settled in Florida, and confronting a lukewarm response from the victorious Republicans, Mr. Clinton's team reluctantly decided that it had run out of time.
"Although there were still critical details to be worked out, it appeared that an agreement was within reach," Ms. Sherman said in an interview this week, reflecting the dominant view in the Clinton team.
The episode remains vitally relevant because the North Korean missile threat has been the driving force behind the debate in Washington over missile defenses, and because President Bush has yet to declare whether he plans to carry through or modify the Clinton strategy. 
The Bush team has been generally skeptical about North Korea, and it is not clear how much they will use diplomacy to try to head off missile threats, instead of relying primarily on their plans for missile defense. 
The South Korean president, Kim Dae Jung, who will meet with Mr. Bush on Wednesday, is expected to press the new administration to engage with Pyongyang. And while the negotiations are still shrouded in secrecy, they apparently made more progress than generally thought.
According to current and former government experts, Kim Jong Il promised in confidential talks not to produce, test or deploy missiles with a range of more than 300 miles. That offer would prevent North Korea from fielding missiles that could strike the United States. 
North Korea, the experts said, also offered to halt the sale of missiles, missile components, technology and training. The pledge would ban systems that North Korea had already contracted to provide to aspiring third world powers.
And North Korea dropped its demand that it be paid cash for giving up its long-range missile programs.
Several important issues remained unresolved, including how to verify the agreements; whether North Korea was willing to destroy missiles it had already produced, and the value of the nonmonetary aid North Korea should receive in lieu of cash.
"We got further than we thought was possible on the missile issue," one government specialist said. "But there is still more work to do on the details before we know if we will have something substantial."
When it comes to ballistic missiles, North Korea has been a major source of concern for Washington. North Korea shocked American defense experts when it tried to put a satellite into orbit in August 1998 on a Taepo Dong-1 missile. 
The attempt failed when the solid-fuel third stage exploded. And the Taepo Dong-1 lacked the ability to reach American territory with a nuclear payload. 
But experts were worried that with time, North Korea would field a more capable successor, the Taepo Dong-2, which could threaten the United States. North Korea is also one of the major sellers of missile technology around the world. The Iranian and Pakistani missile programs, for instance, are heavily dependent on North Korean technology. 
The Taepo Dong test and a general deterioration in relations between Pyongyang and Washington prompted the Clinton administration to ask former Defense Secretary William J. Perry to conduct a policy review.
Traveling to Pyongyang in May 1999, Mr. Perry told the North Koreans that there were two paths they could follow: cooperation, or a collision course with the United States and its Asian allies.
If North Korea chose cooperation, Mr. Perry advised, it needed to give up its missile program. Specifically, the North Koreans should agree not to sell or deploy missiles that exceeded the guidelines of the Missile Technology Control Regime -- that is, missiles that can carry an 1,100-pound payload more than 180 miles.
Mr. Perry recalled in an interview that he was initially discouraged by what he heard in Pyongyang.
But the Korea experts on Mr. Perry's team detected a shift in the North Korean stance, and over the next 18 months, developments appeared to prove them right. 
North Korea declared a moratorium on its long-range missile tests, and in June, Kim Jong Il and Kim Dae Jung met. And as the clock wound down on the Clinton administration in September, it was asked to receive a high-level Korean envoy. 
The envoy was Vice Marshal Cho Myong Rok, the head of the North Korean military, and his visit was taken by most Clinton aides as an indication that Mr. Kim was trying to bring his skeptical generals around. 
"I think Kim poked his head out of the groundhog hole, looked around and decided that his regime is not sustainable unless it is somehow connected with the rest of the world," Samuel R. Berger, Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, said today. 
Marshal Cho also brought an invitation for Mr. Clinton to visit Pyonyang -- and thus underscored a fundamentally different approach to diplomacy. While media-conscious American administrations prefer to carry out painstaking negotiations in advance for a carefully scripted summit meeting, the authoritarian Kim Jong Il believed that agreements should first be resolved at the highest level, leaving details to be worked out later by subordinates.
The invitation also underscored the enormous political value the North Korean government attached to a visit by the American president, seeing a Clinton visit would signify an end to enmity and acceptance by the international community.
Marshal Cho offered the Americans something they wanted as well. He reaffirmed an earlier proposal that Mr. Kim had raised with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia: that North Korea was willing to forgo its long-range missiles if the West would agreed to launch civilian satellites for Pyongyang. 
The Clinton administration decided to send Dr. Albright to Pyongyang to see if there was the basis for a Clinton trip. Her visit narrowed the gap with the North Koreas still further and challenged the Western image of Mr. Kim as an irrational leader. 
Zippered up in a khaki jump suit, Mr. Kim offered several important concessions during six hours of talks. He offered to "forgo" missiles with a range of more than 300 miles. That concession was tied to an American willingness to provide satellite-launching services.
He also indicated that he was willing to halt all missile exports, including missile components, technical advice and brokering services. And North Korea was no longer asking for a $1 billion a year in cash in return, but was prepared to accept $1 billion worth of nonmonetary assistance, like food, coal or other commodities for its stricken economy.
Little progress was made on verification. The North Korean leader insisted that Washington had adequate means to monitor compliance through satellite and other technical means and did not welcome intrusive inspections. 
North Korea's existing stock of missiles was another big issue. Mr. Kim's offer to forgo long-range missiles did not apply to weapons that the North had already produced. 
Defense Secretary William S. Cohen and the Joint Chiefs of Staff wanted the North Koreans to destroy their missile stocks, which were a threat to Japan and to American troops in South Korea. Still, the mood at the Pyongyang meetings was good. Mr. Kim invited Dr. Albright to a huge Communist-style celebration by his party in which workers held colored placards in the shape of the Taepo-Dong missile. The North Korean leader turned to Dr. Albright and said this was the first satellite launching and would be the last.
To iron out the remaining differences and set the stage for a summit meeting, the Clinton administration organized expert-level talks in the Malaysian capital, Kuala Lumpur.
But without Mr. Kim, the North's experts had no authority to negotiate. When the Americans tried to clarify Pyongyang's position, the North Koreans complained that their move was an insult.
To keep the negotiations moving, the American team gave the North Koreans two documents: a draft framework agreement that could be made public and signed at a summit meeting, and a confidential letter outlining each side's obligations.
Those obligations went beyond the proposals Mr. Kim had made in Pyongyang. The Americans wanted to ban the production, testing and deployment of all missiles with a range of more than 180 miles that could carry a 1,000-pound payload -- the same standard that Mr. Perry had cited in his 1999 talks. 
The Americans also wanted verification provisions, including a declaration by the North Koreans of the numbers and types of missiles in their arsenal. And the Americans pressed the North Koreans for a commitment to destroy their existing stocks, although some officials would have settled for a promise to negotiate this in the future.
The Americans did not quantify how much assistance they were willing to provide North Korea, though they reportedly considered providing several hundred million dollars a years worth of food aid.
Before the administration could consider a Clinton trip, it was clear there would have to be another session in which the North's negotiators could consult with the one man who could make decisions: Kim Jong Il.
So plans were made to send Ms. Sherman and a team of Pentagon, National Security Council and State Department officials to Pyongyang. Ms. Sherman would be authorized to give the North Koreans a date for a Clinton summit meeting if they made more concessions on missiles. 
In an ideal world, officials said, Ms. Sherman would have gone to Pyongyang in November, and if the North Koreans made the needed concessions, she could have arranged a Clinton visit. He would then have signed a broadly written accord, while verification and other technical issues were tackled later.
But the election wrangle intruded. Mr. Berger was reluctant to send an envoy with the election in doubt. He said the administration did not deem it wise for the president to leave the country at the time of a potential "constitutional crisis."
As the weeks dragged on, Dr. Albright and Ms. Sherman kept an anxious eye on Florida. At one point, they were monitoring the Florida events from Mauritius, wondering if the Korea operation would proceed. 
After the election was decided in mid-December, Ms. Sherman and the White House Asia expert, Jack Pritchard, briefed Colin L. Powell and Condoleezza Rice. The Bush team made it clear that it would not undercut Mr. Clinton, but not would it endorse a deal, former Clinton aides said. That attitudewas one factor that led the Clinton team not to send Ms. Sherman, according to a former ranking Clinton official. The concern was that the new administration would not support or even complete a deal hammered out then. 
Finally, the Clinton administration announced on Dec. 29 that there was no longer enough time for its talks. 
Critics inside and outside the government say Mr. Clinton made a mistake by not sending Ms. Sherman ahead. The White House, they say, could have consulted with the Bush team before the election was decided, but refrained for fear of lending legitimacy to Mr. Bush's claims to the White House. 
"They did not run out of time; they ran out of courage," said Leon V. Sigal, the author of a book on Korean diplomacy.
Dr. Albright insists that the administration did the best it could. But even she has some regrets.
"Of the various places in the world where there is a chance to change the dynamic, this was it," she said last week. "Do I regret that we did not go forward? I personally do. I wish we could have."

HEADLINE: Australia Set to Auction Mobile Phone Licenses 

BYLINE:  By BECKY GAYLORD

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia, March 6 

 BODY:
The auction for third-generation mobile phone licenses in Australia, scheduled to begin on March 15, is progressing more smoothly than recent sales in some other countries. The timetable is on track, and a range of companies, both domestic and multinational, recently paid deposits to participate.
 But as with some other recent sales, the revenues are expected to be disappointing. Analysts say that the government is unlikely to get the 2.6 billion Australian dollars ($1.4 billion) that it is counting on from spectrum sales to help generate an election-year budget surplus because of the softening in the telecommunications market and because consolidation in the domestic industry may reduce demand. 
 Most of the proceeds from the spectrum sales were to have come from this auction of third-generation, or 3G, wireless licenses, which are expected to allow carriers to offer advanced Internet services on mobile phones and other hand-held devices. But many analysts are saying it may bring in only about 1.2 billion dollars ($636 million), a price just above the lowest amount the government said it would accept.
Seven companies plan to bid for the 15-year licenses, which will run from October 2002.
Telstra, Australia's No. 1 telecommunications company, is among the bidders for up to four licenses that cover the nation. The second- and third-largest, Cable and Wireless Optus and Vodafone Pacific, both units of British companies, are also involved, as well as AAPT Spectrum, part of the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand; Hutchison Telecommunications Australia, majority-owned by Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong; and 3G Investments (Australia), a subsidiary of Qualcomm, the digital wireless communications company based in San Diego.
CKW Wireless, a unit of the American wireless technology group ArrayComm, is eligible to bid for a regional license.
Global pressures, including volatile telecommunications stock prices, rising corporate debt levels and weak demand for the licenses, have prompted some countries to delay their third-generation spectrum sales. Singapore, Brazil and Switzerland recently postponed their auctions; France, too, has had delays. Last year, auctions in Italy, Austria and the Netherlands brought in far less than had been expected.
The Australian government has resisted calls to delay its auction. Among the concerns was how the expected sale of Cable and Wireless Optus would affect it. Because the Vodafone Group and Telecom New Zealand plan to bid for Optus, the outcome of that "vastly changes the whole situation" for the third-generation auction, said Paul Budde, who runs a telecommunications research and consulting firm in Sydney.
Prime Minister John Howard's determination to push ahead with the sale can be traced, in part, to the federal election that will be called later this year. His conservative coalition government has predicted a federal budget surplus of 4.3 billion dollars ($2.3 billion) for the year ending June 30, an amount that relies significantly on the government's anticipated proceeds from this auction.
Last year, when the government first estimated that the spectrum sales would fetch 2.6 billion dollars, the projection seemed modest. But the Australian telecommunications industry has weakened considerably since then, part of a global downturn.
Moreover, the actual budget surplus is already likely to be lower than earlier estimates because economic growth and employment have slowed. The surplus forecast was further trimmed last week by 1.5 billion dollars ($795 million) when Mr. Howard cut a fuel tax to appease voters.

HEADLINE: New Worries Of Slowdown Spur Canada To Cut Rates 

BYLINE:  By TIMOTHY PRITCHARD

DATELINE: TORONTO, March 6 

 BODY:
Worried that the United States economy is losing steam more rapidly than expected and that its appetite for goods from Canada will flag, the Canadian central bank reduced short-term interest rates by half a percentage point today to try to stimulate domestic demand.
 The Bank of Canada reduced the benchmark bank rate to 5.25 percent from 5.75 percent, which effectively lowered the rate it charges on overnight loans to Canadian banks to 5 percent. Leading Canadian banks quickly responded with matching reductions in their prime lending rates, to 6.75 percent, effective on Wednesday. 
 In a statement announcing the reduction, the Bank of Canada said today that "the slowdown in the U.S. economy in the first half of 2001 could be more pronounced than expected," and in Canada, "recent information suggests that the positive underlying momentum in the economy was somewhat less strong than had previously been estimated." 
Analysts saw deeper worries beneath the measured language of the announcement.
"The Bank of Canada is clearly much more concerned about the economic outlook than they are letting on," said Sherry Cooper, chief economist at Nesbitt Burns Inc., a brokerage house in Toronto. The half-point cut "is a moderate surprise, especially given the bank's bullish rhetoric on the economy."
David A. Dodge, the new governor of the central bank, gave a speech two weeks ago on Canada's economic prospects that was taken by many analysts as signaling a quarter-point rate cut today, rather than the half-point cut the bank announced. 
Other government officials, notably the finance minister, Paul Martin, have been saying that Canada would be largely insulated from a slowdown in the United States because its economy had become more diversified in recent years. 
But Canada still depends on the United States for 80 percent of its merchandise trade, and some important domestic indicators here have been weakening. 
Gross domestic product grew 2.6 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with 4.5 percent in the third. Manufacturing output fell by 0.7 percent in December, and new job creation collapsed, although the unemployment rate rose only slightly, to 6.9 percent.
Economists, who had generally forecast growth of 3 percent or greater in 2001, have been lowering their estimates to the 2 percent range despite a personal tax cut at the start of the year that was meant to stimulate demand. 
Still, many economists agreed with the central bank's view that business activity would rebound on both sides of the border in the second half as the stimulus of lower interest rates took hold. 
Before last fall, the Bank of Canada generally set its rates by quickly matching whatever moves were made by the Federal Reserve Board in the United States. Now it sets dates in advance for announcements like today's about whether interest rate policy will be changed. 
The next announcement by the bank is scheduled for April 17, although the bank could move sooner, especially if the Fed makes another half-point reduction at its March 20 meeting, as some forecasters expect.

HEADLINE: China Rejects Allegations On Improving Iraqi Weapons 

BYLINE:  By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 6 

 BODY:
After conducting "serious investigations," China has rejected American allegations that Chinese companies helped improve Iraqi air defenses in violation of United Nations sanctions, the foreign minister said today. 
 At a news conference on the second day of China's annual Parliament meeting, Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan also warned the United States of grave consequences if it sold Taiwan advanced weapons systems, an issue that may come to the forefront next month, when the United States is to decide on Taiwan's arms requests. 
 Underscoring China's determination to press Taiwan to rejoin the "motherland" with force if necessary, even if it means some day confronting American might, China also announced that military spending this year would increase 17.7 percent, accelerating its drive for a more powerful and modern military. 
Last month, after American and British warplanes bombed what they said were enhanced Iraqi air defenses, the United States said it had evidence that Chinese companies were selling and installing fiber optic cables and other equipment being used to improve antiaircraft equipment in Iraq. 
Chinese officials initially denied the contentions, but their position then seemed to soften. Now the government has declared its sometimes freewheeling international technology companies to be innocent of any improper aid or sales to Iraq. 
"Relevant agencies in China have carried out some serious investigations," Mr. Tang said. "Chinese enterprises and corporations have not assisted Iraq in building the project of fiber optic cable for air defense." 
In Washington, a spokeswoman for the National Security Council, Mary Ellen Countryman, said: "The Chinese government has reiterated its understanding of China's responsibilities to uphold U.N. Security Council resolutions and to insure that Chinese companies abide by these resolutions. We will continue to work with the Chinese government to address this issue."
Ms. Countryman did not say whether the United States considered the incident closed.
Mr. Tang's wording appeared to leave open a possibility that a Chinese company had worked on nonmilitary telecommunications in Iraq, but he insisted that China had carefully obeyed the sanctions. 
China's top foreign policy official, Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen, will visit Washington on March 18 for the first high-level contacts with the United States since President Bush took office, meetings that both sides see as potentially pivotal. Mr. Tang said today that Chinese-American relations could "continue to move forward," but only if "the American side handles the question of Taiwan well." 
China is waging a diplomatic offensive to head off Taiwan's requests to buy warships equipped with the advanced Aegis radar system, which could be used against Chinese planes and missiles, and upgraded versions of Patriot missiles. 
"The American side should come to a recognition of the serious dangers involved" in providing such weapons, Mr. Tang said. 
"It should rein in its wild horse right on the edge of the precipice," he added, using a Chinese adage. 
Releasing the national budget this morning, Finance Minister Xiang Huaicheng said official military spending for the year would increase 17.7 percent over last year, putting the total at just over $17 billion. But Western experts said true military spending might be two to three times that amount and it is unclear whether part of the announced increase includes a shift of expenditures into the announced budget. 
Seeking to modernize its huge but modestly trained and equipped forces, China has increased its announced military budget by more than 10 percent a year for more than 10 years, and has purchased advanced Russian arms from a separate budget. Still, this year's increase appears to represent an acceleration compared with last year's 12.7 percent.
Mr. Xiang said the increase was mainly to raise military salaries but also reflected "the need to adapt to drastic changes in the military situation of the world and prepare for defense and combat given the conditions of modern technology." The government also provided new funds to offset revenues lost when the military was forced to give up industries.
Even if unreported spending is included, China's military budget remains small compared with that of the United States. 
Mr. Tang also confirmed reports that China and Russia would sign an unusual treaty on "good-neighborly friendship and cooperation" in July, when President Jiang Zemin visits Moscow. 
At the news conference, Mr. Tang spoke in scathing terms about Washington's recent annual report on human rights in various countries including China, calling it hypocritical.

HEADLINE: Productivity Grew by 2.2% In 4th Quarter 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 6 

 BODY:
Productivity grew at a revised 2.2 percent during the fourth quarter, closing out the best year for worker efficiency in almost two decades, the government said today.
 The figure was less than the 2.4 percent pace previously estimated for the final three months of last year, the Labor Department said. Still, productivity -- the measure of how much an employee produces for every hour worked -- was stronger than the 2 percent pace expected by analysts. 
 "If companies adjust production faster because of technology, then productivity will hold up better during this growth slowdown," said Ken Mayland, president of ClearView Economics in Pepper Pike, Ohio.
For all of last year, productivity rose 4.3 percent, the most since a 4.5 percent jump in 1983 and evidence that investment in computers and management systems is helping employees stay efficient even as the economy cools.
The use of software and information technology and computers has helped double productivity gains in the last five years. That has made businesses less likely to raise prices to offset any increase in labor costs and has given Federal Reserve policy makers leeway to reduce interest rates.
Since the beginning of 1996, productivity has increased at an annual rate of about 3 percent compared with about 1.5 percent during the previous two decades. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has expressed optimism that the accelerated pace of productivity growth will continue.
A separate report from the Commerce Department today showed factory orders fell 3.8 percent in January as bookings declined for aircraft. Excluding aircraft and other transportation equipment, orders to factories fell 0.3 percent.
Slower growth has meant a surge in unit labor costs. The measure of wages and other expenses tied to productivity rose at a 4.3 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, compared with a 3.2 percent pace in the previous three months. The increase was the biggest since a 5.5 percent rise in the fourth quarter of 1997. For all of last year, unit labor costs rose 0.7 percent, the smallest increase since 1996, when they grew at a 0.5 percent rate. Labor costs rose 1.8 percent in 1999.
Companies are cutting employee hours to limit the damage the slowing economy is having on their bottom lines. Hours worked fell at a 1.4 percent annual rate in the fourth quarter, previously reported as dropping at a 1.1 pace. That is the biggest decline since a 2.3 percent drop in the first quarter of 1992 and compares with a 0.7 percent rate of decline in the third quarter.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
In Arizona, Signed, Sealed and Deferred

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: TUCSON, March 4 

 BODY:
The feel-good story in the Arizona Diamondbacks' camp is the willingness of 10 veteran players to change their contracts in midstream and defer more of their salaries. The players agreed to the request of Jerry Colangelo, the team's managing partner, to ease the Diamondbacks' growing financial burden.
 "I feel I'm helping this organization out to let Jerry have some working capital and go out and get what he needs to make this a competitive team," Randy Johnson, one of the deferring 10, said. 
 But not everything about the Diamondbacks' deferred plan feels good. Major League Baseball was initially alerted to the Diamondbacks' economic stress last year when it had to guarantee a bank loan for the club, a first for the sport. Now, a baseball official said, Commissioner Bud Selig sees growing concerns as the team struggles to maintain its expensive lifestyle. 
"There are significant concerns there," the official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "They've spent themselves into serious economic problems. What they've done with deferring more money has only postponed the problem."
The Diamondbacks' spending strategy -- they signed four free agents after their first season, committing a total of $118 million -- paid an instant dividend. They won a division championship in their second season, making them the most successful startup baseball team ever.
But they slipped to third place last season, matching a steady decline in season attendance, from 3.6 million to 3 million to 2.9 million, and in season-ticket sales, from 36,000 to 27,000 to 22,000.
Colangelo does not see these financial developments as ominous.
"Not at all," he said. "People refinance their homes. Companies downsize and let people go. In our case, when the season ended last year and we took inventory, I had to weigh the fact that I had committed to make a run with a group of players I put together.
"To keep it together, looking at our cash-flow projection, we needed to get a little more lean in our operations. We were a little fat. Part of what I thought was a viable option was spreading the payouts to the players. It lessens the cash-flow requirements each year."
The Diamondbacks' payroll for the coming season is expected to exceed $80 million, but the team will actually spend nearly $30 million less this year because of all of the deferrals.
The contracts of the 10 players who agreed to additional deferrals originally called for $81.7 million, or 45 percent, to be deferred out of $183.3 million in salaries for the remaining years of the deals.
The additional deferments, Colangelo said, will save the team $18 million in cash payments this year, about $16 million next year and $12 million the following year. The players' deferred money will be paid at 6.5 percent interest.
Players with four-year contracts, Colangelo said, using an example that pertains to four of the 10 players, already had eight-year payouts and now will have two years added.
But will those delayed payments create problems later?
"Not really," Colangelo said, "if that's what you're looking at as part of your overhead. Quite honestly, you have franchises in baseball that have difficulty going year to year. I'm just trying to handle my fiduciary responsibilities with some effectiveness. The balancing act is trying to stay competitive and deal with this package that's not going to go away."
Colangelo has constructed the Diamondbacks to win now. His players are expensive and they are moving along in age. The eight starting players range in age from 31 to 36 and four of the five starting pitchers are between 34 and 37 years old.
Asked if these was a sense that the Diamondbacks had to win this year, before they grow even older, Jay Bell, at 36 the oldest everyday player, said, "Certainly this year or next year."
Bell is one of the 10 players who agreed to defer more money, joining Johnson, Curt Schilling, Todd Stottlemyre, Brian Anderson, Armando Reynoso, Matt Williams, Steve Finley, Luis Gonzalez and Tony Womack. They make up the entire pitching rotation and five-eighths of the starting lineup.
"For me it was real easy," Stottlemyre said of the decision to defer more of his salary. "We're all in this together. We want to win as bad as Jerry does. Jerry wants to win as bad as we do. Maybe we're sacrificing a little bit, but the key ingredient is we all want the same thing. We all want the club to be financially stable and we all want to win. I don't think it's asking a whole lot from a guy who's getting paid millions of dollars to play a baseball game."
Colangelo said he not only encountered no resistance in carrying out his offseason plan, but he even found it to be a positive development.
"I think it has the potential to really bring a group together because everyone's in a trench together," he said. "To the best of my knowledge it's never happened before. I think a lot had to do with relationships you build with players."
That is precisely what the Diamondbacks' creator has done. 
"He was very, very fair with us in a lot of ways," said Bell, the team's first expensive free agent. "Our feeling was whenever it came time for him to do something for us, he did it. He asked us to do something for him, and we did it for him."
Colangelo said that the problems stemmed from the high cost of getting into baseball and operating the team. He estimated that cost at about $350 million, including a $130 million franchise fee and the team's share of the construction of its ballpark, about $115 million. 
The players, who said they were not concerned that they would get their deferred money, said they did not know if the team had serious financial problems.
"I don't sit in with Jerry at the board meetings to know that they have problems," Johnson said.

HEADLINE: Familiar Cast but Less Talk of Florida Voting Reform as Jeb Bush Unveils Plan 

BYLINE:  By DANA CANEDY

DATELINE: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 6 

 BODY:
In his first address to Florida lawmakers since the presidential election thrust the state into the international spotlight, Gov. Jeb Bush outlined his vision for tax relief, investment in education and improving nursing home care, but only briefly touched on the 36-day drama that put his brother in the White House.
 Mr. Bush's State of the State address opened this year's regular session of the Florida Legislature and was delivered before an audience that included many of those whose names and faces became familiar fixtures on television sets nationwide during the election. 
 There was Katherine Harris, the now-famous secretary of state, whose rulings on absentee ballots and late election returns made her the subject of numerous lawsuits and equal doses of criticism and praise. There were John McKay, the Florida Senate president, and Tom Feeney, the speaker of the Florida House, who in December convened a special session of the Legislature to appoint a slate of Bush electors. 
And there were the Florida Supreme Court justices, whose decision to order a manual recount of ballots in contested counties across the state was effectively reversed by the United States Supreme Court, ending former Vice President Al Gore's challenge of the election results.
Florida is facing a tight budget year, but Mr. Bush, nonetheless, outlined a wish list of priorities that called for spending more money for teacher recruitment and retention and improving the quality of nursing homes while also reducing the so-called intangible tax on assets like stocks and bonds.
"Improving public schools, providing quality long-term care, dealing with development, cutting taxes, these are all issues that should be at the forefront of the public agenda," Mr. Bush said.
It hardly seemed like the same State Capitol that was at the center of the election chaos just four months ago. In fact, the governor's speech, which he delivered in about 45 minutes, included only two paragraphs at the end about the election.
"And finally," Mr. Bush told the legislators, "we must make reliable and accurate the very machinery of democracy, the voting process." He urged lawmakers to "dedicate the resources that are needed to modernize our voting systems and move forward with confidence into the next election cycle."
The day before his address, Mr. Bush's study group on election reform presented him with a 78-page report of its findings and recommendations. Mr. Bush said then that replacing outdated voter equipment across the state was a top priority, though he gave no specific recommendations for doing so in his address. 
Democrats said Mr. Bush's speech was surprisingly short on references to election reform, especially given his very public pronouncement the day after the election was settled that he was appointing a bipartisan study group to recommend proposals to update the state's voting system.
"What I'm afraid of is that the governor is not making this a front-burner issue," said Senator Kendrick Meek, a Miami Democrat. "We have to deal with it in this session."
Several Democratic legislators said the Republicans seemed to be softening their oratory about the need for election reform, particularly to spending money to upgrade the system. Mr. Bush's study group has suggested that the state consider investing up to $40 million to lease optical scanning equipment for use in all of Florida's 67 counties.
Senator McKay said that he did not favor spending the money to put the equipment in every precinct but that he and fellow Republicans were still committed to improving the state's election system. "I think we need to work on voter education," Mr. McKay said. And he added: "We will do something. Whether we fix the system depends on how you define the term fix."
Debate about voting equipment, though, was overshadowed by a focus among many in legislators on Mr. Bush's proposed $43.3 billion budget, a 3 percent increase over last year's, and his proposed tax cut on intangible assets. Democrats say the state cannot afford the cut at a time when a slowing economy has resulted in a tight budget and possibly having to cut health services and many programs for single mothers, children and the poor.
But Mr. Bush defended the tax cut in his address, saying it would also help some people on fixed incomes. "I think we all can agree that taxing people on fixed incomes or taxing the capital that grows small businesses is bad public policy," he said.

HEADLINE: Goldman Sachs Drops Plans For New Tower at Plaza Site 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
The Goldman Sachs Group has canceled plans to build an $850 million trading structure on the site of a large public plaza at 55 Water Street, less than a week after presenting the project to city planners.
 Although the Lower Manhattan community board voted against the plan, Goldman Sachs said it decided not to proceed with the complex project strictly for business reasons. 
 The company's withdrawal puts 1.38 million square feet at 55 Water Street back on the market -- more space than in the entire Chrysler Building. It will be vacated in 2003 by J. P. Morgan Chase & Company. 
Michael G. Carey, president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation, said yesterday that he was not overly concerned about the Goldman Sachs decision. "They continue to be committed to Lower Manhattan," he said.
As for 55 Water Street, he added: "We have worried about large users being able to meet their space needs. Now we've got some space."
Other prospective tenants have already spoken up since Goldman Sachs made its decision known on Monday evening, said Edward J. Kulik Jr., the head of real estate for the Retirement Systems of Alabama, which manages the state's pension programs and owns 55 Water Street.
"There's a little bit of a setback, no question," Mr. Kulik said. "But there are a lot of opportunities."
At 3 Hanover Square, a nearby co-op apartment building that would have lost sunlight and river views to the trading structure, the news came as a relief. "Obviously, as a resident of 3 Hanover Square, I am very pleased with Goldman Sachs's change of plans," said Jonathan Greenspan, president of the co-op board. "However, I must admit that I am stunned by the swiftness of the decision and Goldman's sudden nervousness about the economy."
The decision may not have been as 11th-hour as it seems. Goldman Sachs appeared before the City Planning Commission in part to ensure its support early in the process before signing a long-term lease at 55 Water Street. Goldman Sachs occupies eight other towers downtown, including its headquarters, 85 Broad Street.
Mr. Kulik said that Retirement Systems had not abandoned the idea of adding a structure along the lines proposed by Goldman Sachs.
The structure would replace one of the largest privately owned public spaces in New York, with almost an acre of space. It was created by the developers of 55 Water Street in exchange for permission to build a larger tower than zoning rules allowed. But it never proved much of a public benefit. More than 30 feet above street level, it is often deserted, particularly when the escalators are not working. (They were, however, running yesterday.)
Under the Goldman Sachs proposal, the plaza would have been replaced by a 240-foot-high building with at least seven vast trading floors. An existing 15-story office tower on the plaza would have been altered and expanded.
This new building would have been joined to a 53-story tower on the south half of the complex, which also includes part of Vietnam Veterans Plaza.
To make up for the loss of the plaza, Goldman Sachs proposed to buy unused development rights from the low-rise South Street Seaport district.
It also proposed to build a 1,300-foot stretch of East River esplanade, to landscape a spartan public plaza along Water Street and to contribute to the reconstruction of Vietnam Veterans Plaza, which is under way.
"We were confident that given the conversations we were having with the community, we would be able to develop the site in a way that benefited all the parties," said Kathleen Baum, a spokeswoman for Goldman Sachs.
The chairwoman of the local community board, Madelyn Wils, said she had looked forward to negotiating better neighborhood amenities with Goldman Sachs. "We're left with a plaza which is unusable," she said, "and a lack of open space."

HEADLINE: Broadcom Reduces Earnings Forecast 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: IRVINE, Calif., March 6 

 BODY:
The Broadcom Corporation, the No. 1 maker of chips for cable modems, said today that first-quarter profit would be about two-thirds less than analysts' estimates because of a slowing United States economy and a canceled contract.
 Earnings are expected to be 8 cents to 9 cents a share on revenue of $315 million to $325 million, the company said. 
It was expected to earn 25 cents on revenue of $398 million, according to a First Call/Thomson Financial poll of analysts. 
 The company, which is based in Irvine, is the latest maker of telecommunications chips to scale back earnings expectations, blaming the slowing economy. Broadcom said that more customers delayed orders last month and that one of its biggest customers, the 3Com Corporation, canceled a contract. 3Com officials could not be reached to comment.
Broadcom is also one of the biggest makers of chips for digital cable set-top boxes and computer-networking equipment.
Its shares rose 75 cents, to $47.88. They have fallen 80 percent over the last year. The news was released after the close of regular trading.

HEADLINE: Talking to the North Koreans 

BYLINE:  By Wendy R. Sherman; Wendy R. Sherman was special adviser to the president and the secretary of state on North Korea policy in the Clinton administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
President George Bush campaigned on a promise to defend America against missile threats from countries like North Korea. His intention is to build a national missile defense system. But such a system is not only unproven; it would undoubtedly be costly in both dollars and in diplomacy.
 Although there is some logic in trying to construct a missile defense system, there is also logic in seizing every opportunity to reduce or eliminate the missile threats through the less costly means of arms control negotiations. In dealing with North Korea, President Bush has an opportunity to take this latter approach. The question now is whether he will seize it. We may know the answer after President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea meets with President Bush today. 
 Reconciliation and engagement with North Korea have been the centerpiece of President Kim's three years in office. Although some believe that continued international isolation would bring a welcome demise of the dictatorial North Korean regime, its sudden collapse would pose terrible security and economic challenges that South Korea and the world can ill afford. Any international crisis with North Korea, particularly one involving the United States, would be likely to halt efforts, heightened by last year's summit between North and South Korea, to bring the North out of its isolation. Undoubtedly, such a crisis would also doom for the foreseeable future prospects for a final peace agreement between the North and the South.
Because Mr. Kim knows that North Korea's long-range missile threat is uppermost among America's concerns, he will most likely want to know if President Bush will close the deal with North Korea that came tantalizingly close for President Bill Clinton in his final days in office. That agreement, when completed, would both halt North Korea's exports of missiles and related technology and stop further production, deployment and testing of long-range missiles.
The clock ran out on the Clinton administration before it could nail down the final details. For two years, the administration had pursued a practical, step-by-step policy that achieved a moratorium on missile testing by Pyongyang, gained access to an underground area suspected of being a nuclear reactor site and saw the first visit of a high-ranking North Korean military official, Vice Marshal Cho Myong Rok, to the United States.
After a series of negotiations that led to Secretary of State Madeleine Albright's visit to Pyongyang in October 2000, North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, appears ready to make landmark commitments about the missile program. To ensure the survival of his regime, he has to improve the country's disastrous economy by reducing the burden of a vast missile program and opening the doors to trade.
There are many challenges in ending this lingering Cold War conflict, and many would assume that Kim Dae Jung would first want to get North Korea to move back its million-man army from deployment along the North-South border. But he knows that he can counter that with conventional forces. So his priority is to reduce the destabilizing force of weapons of mass destruction, particularly long-range nuclear missiles. The world saw the threat they pose in 1998, when a missile being tested by North Korea flew over Japan and set off an international crisis that could have undone the 1994 nuclear agreement with the United States that halted the North's fissile material production.
President Bush, for his part, does not need to make a false choice between negotiating a missile agreement with North Korea and pursuing his already stated intention to build a national missile defense. It will take time to achieve a missile agreement and test North Korea's compliance with it. It will also take considerable time to develop and test virtually any national missile defense system. So Mr. Bush can move forward on both strategies without foreclosing any options. If negotiations do achieve a real reduction or elimination of the North Korean missile threat, Mr. Bush can then decide if he should change his approach to national missile defense.
Although President Bush has time to consider his approach to negotiations, North Korea, a country of immense pride, will not wait forever. Kim Jong Il is capable of creating a crisis absent a clear signal that negotiations are possible. He is certain to be listening closely to the tone and substance of reports from this week's meeting between Mr. Bush and Kim Dae Jung. President Bush should restart talks with North Korea, and if an agreement is at hand, be ready to meet with Kim Jong Il. 
Some are understandably concerned that a summit with President Bush would only legitimize the North Korean leader. But, if such a meeting verifiably eliminated a major missile threat to the United States and the world, drew North Korea into the international community and began to open a window of freedom for that country's starved and desperate citizens, it would be more than worth the risk. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
